properties.artist_bio: Pascal Paquette produces site- and context-specific works using painting, design, graffiti, street art and photography. His  work has been commissioned, published and exhibited internationally and locally, notably at the Museum of Contemporary Canadian Art (MOCCA), the Art Gallery of Ontario (AGO), Canadian Heritage as well as Art Basel (Switzerland), Art Basel Miami, FIAC (Paris, France), Art Chicago (USA), Art Cologne (Köln, Germany) and Scope (London, UK). The Ontario Arts Council, British Arts Council, European Cultural Fund, Open Society Foundation and Toronto Arts Council have all supported his projects. He currently lives in Toronto, Canada with his wife and three children.

properties.artist_bio:
Sean Martindale is an internationally recognized, award winning interdisciplinary artist and designer based in Toronto, Canada. His interventions activate public spaces to encourage engagement, and often focus on ecological and social issues. His playful works suggest alternate possibilities for existing spaces, infrastructures, and materials found in urban environments. Frequently, he uses salvaged goods in unexpected ways that prompt conversation.

Among other notable projects, he was the lead artist on the Community Rising, the tallest mural in the world from 2013 to 2018 (now the second tallest), the result of a community project in St James Town, Toronto, with local youth, STEPS and the Toronto Muralists. Martindale has been the lead artist for a number of the GTA’s largest mural projects. He continues to work closely with communities and organizations big and small; including partners such as Harbourfront Centre, the Art Gallery of Ontario, and the City of Toronto.

Martindale holds an MFA from the Interdisciplinary Masters of Art, Media and Design program at OCAD University in Toronto, and a BDes in Communication Design from Emily Carr University in Vancouver. He was the Decennial Hancock Lecturer at the University of Toronto’s Hart House, where his presentation was broadcast by TVO for their Big Ideas series. He is a recipient of the prestigious Artist Prize from Toronto Friends of the Visual Arts, numerous grants at municipal, provincial, and federal levels, and a Chalmers Arts Fellowship from the Ontario Arts Council. Martindale was profiled for the first episode of CBC’s Great Minds of Design, and his works have been featured digitally and published in traditional media around the world in multiple languages. His works have been exhibited publicly in many cities across the globe.

Recently, Martindale was Harbourfront Centre’s inaugural Visual Artist-in-Residence, and alongside his collaborator JP King, was also the first Artist-in-Residence with the City of Toronto, Solid Waste Management Services.

-------------

•	While I continue to be interested in traditional mural forms, I am also excited to keep exploring other media/materials in the public realm, spearhead new practices, and explore diverse approaches to community engagement. As well, I am interested in potentially growing other areas of my practice, and taking on more roles in related areas such as project coordination, program development, and consulting.

properties.artist_bio: Through his artistic journey Rob Matejka has embraced art as a medium for positive social intervention and enjoys animating the communities and people he works with - making art accessible to all through; workshops, mentoring, and adding to the growing outdoor public gallery. Rob has been an arts educator and mentor for over 12 years - having worked with organizations across Toronto such as; Lakeshore Arts, Mural Routes, TDSB, The Toronto Public Library, VIBE Arts, and more. Rob enjoys using murals to create spaces we enter and experience physically - while coordinating large scale projects engaging large numbers of community members to beautify communities and build community pride.

properties.artist_bio:
MONICA WICKELER
As a trained visual artist who has worked in the large scale painting industry in Toronto for many years, in outdoor advertising as a mural artist and in the film and television industry as a scenic artist, Monica Wickeler has found a love of community and public art. As well as painting community murals in playgrounds, on wading pools and in pedestrian laneways, she has recently enjoyed working with students to inspire them to approach large scale paintings in their own community and taking ownership and pride in who they are and in their neighborhoods.
ARTISTIC STATEMENT
I have always been inspired by the newest STREET/PUBLIC artist projects around the world. When I start a project my sketches will often be uploaded and worked on digitally to see how my ideas respond to the space it will be painted on I can digitally mock up and idea and can easily share it with the client. Once at the wall producing the work, that amazing feeling of working in the public eye kicks in and the getting feedback from pedestrians is always an inspiration. Recently I have been using a combination of brushwork and aerosol painting techniques and I am thrilled with the vibrancy of color and effects produced. Finding the connection between the visual landscape and the images the community connects with is my biggest goal during my design process.

properties.artist_bio: Mike Parsons is a professional artist living in Toronto. I work exclusively with black and white images sing a combination of comic book illustration, graffiti street art and abstract images. Thematically my artworks explore the interrelationships between man, nature and technology primarily from an urban perspective. The goal of my work is express a positive optimistic warning towards progress and society. My work is playful yet insightful in order to appeal to audiences of all ages. I focus on live painting performances and street art because I believe public artworks have the most impact an offer the best opportunity to initiate dialogue. I worked as a fully licensed street artist from 2005-2009 where I created live murals at various locations across Toronto. Since that time I have become a full time muralist working across Canada and internationally. Notable clients include Hudson’s Bay Co., Scotiabank, Converse, Dr. Martens, Waterloo University, UofT, Thyssenkrupp Canada, A.G.O. StreetARTToronto.

properties.artist_bio:
Dan Bergeron is a public artist who employs a range of styles, themes and materials to activate and explore the meaning of our shared public spaces. The shape, texture and location of a site and its history or current uses dictate the form and content of his projects. Dan’s public installations aim to open a dialog with viewers, promoting engagement through both intimate familiarity and wonder at the unexpected.

Dan has created public art projects for municipalities across Canada (Toronto, Mississauga, Ottawa, Gaspe, Calgary, Richmond), working in both two-dimensional mediums (murals, photo-based wheat pasting) and three dimensional sculpture. He has also been commissioned by the AGO, MOCA Toronto, the ROM and corporate clients Nike, Converse and Vespa.

properties.artist_bio:
Visual Artist

Christiano De Araujo is a self-taught artist who was born in Anápolis, Goiás, Brazil. His earliest memory as a child is the moment when he discovered his love of art. As a toddler, he remembers picking up a crayon that his older sister had left behind. When she found that Christiano had taken it, she grabbed it away from him, but in that short amount of time, he had fallen in love with colours and the ability to create.

His love of art and his talent for the drawing were evident when he was a student in school. His first passion was comics and cartoons and at age 12 he drew his first comic strip.

In his late teens, Christiano began working for Brazil’s highly circulated newspaper, Diário da Manhã, doing editorial cartoons and illustrations. He also continued to work for other local newspapers and magazines. Realizing that he wanted more opportunities than he could have in Brazil, Christiano chose to immigrate to Canada.

His first years in Canada were a struggle. Early on, he landed a job as a Bricklayer, which he did for a number of years. Christiano confronted his weaknesses and discovered his strengths, learned to laugh at his hardships, quickly moving on. He was able to overcome any adversities with a determination to succeed and a desire to make himself a better man. This led to his artwork being published in numerous magazines and newspapers in Toronto.

He also credits his success to a spiritual awakening that he had through meditation and self-hypnosis. It gave him clarity and focus. This experience gave him more confidence and the ability to control his emotions and himself. Christiano devotes much of his life to his art. His endeavours include drawing, oil and acrylic painting, airbrushing, cartooning and sculpting. He is an artist by trade, finds art fun and likes to explore new media and innovated techniques.

Christiano currently resides in Toronto, Canada. He is the founder of Toronto Artists Studio, a studio of visual artists, painters, digital artists and sculptors who design and produce murals and visual communication projects for audiences on a small and grand scale.

At the present moment, this very moment… Christiano is enjoying the wonderful interaction between the mind and the universe. This infinite universe in which we are all one!

properties.artist_bio: Amir Akbari is a Greater Toronto Area (GTA) based Visual Artist, Educator, Community Advocate and Entrepreneur.   In 2002, he enrolled in OCAD University where he would go on to complete a Bachelors of Fine Arts with a focus on Drawing and Painting.  In 2003, Amir led his first community mural art project working with Urban Art Toronto.  The following year, he took on his first role with Street Art (then Graffiti Transformation Project) as the lead artist with Lamp Community Health Centre.  That project would be a launching pad for his eventual artistic and professional career.From 2003 to 2010 Amir continued to work with various community organizations and charities as an artist facilitator, youth works and educator.  He would go onto complete over 30 public murals throughout this time, working with and mentoring hundreds of youth across the GTA.In 2010 Amir founded Behind the Line with the purpose of providing existing support structures within the community with creative and artistic support.  Behind the Line has since worked closely with multiple organizations to enhance their arts programming and creative reach, from curriculum development, programming consultation and arts integration strategies.In the summer of 2019, Amir completed his largest mural production, the Susan Street Mural at 3847 Lawrence Ave. East.  This would be his 6th Street Art Partnership Project with the Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough and his 3rd partnership with Toronto Community Housing.  The large 14 story mural is the crowning achievement of his artistic journey as a community and mural artist.  Focused on creating designs that reflect, represent and inspire the communities that he is working with, this mural is a celebration of the collaborative and uplifting nature of public murals funded by Street Art Toronto.His work is rooted in the belief that self-expression can have a lasting impact on the development and growth of young people and their communities, and that there is a disproportional disadvantage across the board for those that face multiple barriers with accessing the arts.   He hopes to fill this void through innovative arts strategies, collaborative mural projects and local community partnerships.
properties.description: This project celebrates the dynamic and thriving local community and highlights the importance of belonging through various collapsing and reconstructed shapes and images of local landmarks and daily interactions.
properties.organizations: Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough
properties.title: Amir Akbari

properties.artist_bio:
At the tender age of nine, Toronto-based illustrator Adrian Hayles discovered the expressive
nature of the visual arts. With his continued artistic development, illustration became his
deepest passion and talent. His desire to learn and absorb from his surroundings led him on a
personal creative journey. As a graduate of the Graphic Design program at Humber College
with over 10 years of working experience behind him, Adrian has established his place in
Toronto’s modern art community. His style is provocative and inspiring and defies
categorization. Blurring the lines between graffiti and ultra realism, Adrian’s voice and vision is
instantly identifiable. His works include countless portraits and illustrations for various
magazines and collaborations with the City of Toronto to develop murals for vacant community
spaces. In the past Adrian has painted complete buildings and city blocks, designed award
winning video games and animated television shows. He has also successfully developed and
filed a functioning patent for the Stud Horse Foldable Drawing Bench and is the Principal and
Founder of Behind the Front Visual Arts Studio.

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to work with StART because I have a history of working on public and community-engaged mural projects and programs, many of which have been supported and in partnership with StART. I believe in the values of the StART programs and have experienced the dedication of the team to carrying out these values through supporting and partnering.

I am a visual artist passionate about arts engagement and education, collaborative art making, and murals. These practices bridge my background from a Bachelor of Fine Art in Drawing & Painting from OCAD University and a Community Arts Practice Certificate from York University. Since 2011, I have worn many ‘hats’ in the mural, art and community arts field; from artist, arts educator, facilitator, curator, arts administrator and project manager. I have had the opportunity to work and learn from these experiences, building adaptability and flexibility through working in unique situations including libraries, schools, art galleries, community centres, seniors centres, skate parks, abandoned storefronts (you name it!). I have built a strong rapport working with many artists and arts organizations such as Mural Routes, Vibe Arts, Nuit Blanche, Lakeshore Arts, Platform A, Scribble me Silly, Arts Etobicoke and East End Arts. In particular, I have worked closely with Mural Routes since 2011, as Program Coordinator, Facilitator, Curriculum Coordinator, and Program Director, with a focus on mentorship and the Mural Art Learning Institute programs.

My creative processes for involving community and youth in projects within their own neighbourhoods are based in facilitation style that creatively employs storytelling, brainstorming, and playful art techniques like collage to encourage conversations, confidence and to bring many ideas together into action. It gives me great joy to facilitate consultation, design, art making and mural making to bring community members together to reflect and re-imagine their neighbourhood. I love any opportunity to nurture participants’ creative abilities and create a safe space for exploration and connection through visual arts and storytelling. I see art as a tool for exploring themes, beginning conversation, gathering patterns and beginning important dialogue. Mural consultation and participation offers a space where artists and community members alike can share, exchange, grow and work together.
properties.description: This legacy mural depicts the people and activities of the Taste of Lawrence Festival, a celebration of international food, music, and culture.
properties.title: Jennifer Moyer and Tara Dorey

properties.address: Park Lawn Rd & Lake Shore Blvd W
properties.artist_bio:
MONICA WICKELER
As a trained visual artist who has worked in the large scale painting industry in Toronto for many years, in outdoor advertising as a mural artist and in the film and television industry as a scenic artist, Monica Wickeler has found a love of community and public art. As well as painting community murals in playgrounds, on wading pools and in pedestrian laneways, she has recently enjoyed working with students to inspire them to approach large scale paintings in their own community and taking ownership and pride in who they are and in their neighborhoods.
ARTISTIC STATEMENT
I have always been inspired by the newest STREET/PUBLIC artist projects around the world. When I start a project my sketches will often be uploaded and worked on digitally to see how my ideas respond to the space it will be painted on I can digitally mock up and idea and can easily share it with the client. Once at the wall producing the work, that amazing feeling of working in the public eye kicks in and the getting feedback from pedestrians is always an inspiration. Recently I have been using a combination of brushwork and aerosol painting techniques and I am thrilled with the vibrancy of color and effects produced. Finding the connection between the visual landscape and the images the community connects with is my biggest goal during my design process.
properties.description: Monica Wickeler’s work shows full scale fox silhouettes exploring the signal box. By placing these foxes in an urban setting it reminds us that we share this space and makes us think about the co-existence of urban wildlife and people in the city.
properties.title: Monica Wickeler

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to continue working with StART because they support the creation of art that makes our public realm a more beautiful and inviting place. StART has helped me create meaningful work that strengthens communities and enables me to develop my practice of using art as a way to build inclusive communities who celebrate their identity with pride. I would like to develop my leadership skills and am interested in mentorship opportunities where I can learn how to work more effectively with the city to realize large scale initiatives that give more artists and community members opportunities to feel empowered through the process of creating art in the public realm.

I am a Toronto based visual artist, community organizer, muralist, curator, and eternal optimist. My work is motivated by my desire to spread joy, nurture present minded living, cultivate gratitude, and foster new social interactions from a place of love and empathy. Using aerosol and acrylic paint, I work with bright colours and bold patterns to captivate people’s attention and fill them with delight and hope. I am passionate about creating art that both aesthetically and psychologically brightens the streets and work to build a community around positive living.

My belief that public art is a powerful tool for building community drives my practice. In 2017, I founded Womxn Paint, an annual street art jam that has produced 44 murals celebrating the strength and diversity of womxn. I would like to continue this initiative and grow it to include additional programming that supports the professional development of womxn artists and more opportunities for young girls to learn about mural arts. In 2016, I facilitated an intergenerational mural at Baycrest Health Sciences and would like work more with the senior community.

Over the last six years, I have created custom large-scale outdoor artworks for clients including The New Yorker, Tourism Canada, the City of Toronto, the City of Mississauga, the Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany in Toronto, the STEPS Initiative, Arts Etobicoke, East End Arts and private clients.
properties.description: Baraket Kezwar’s smile project is about creating an alternative dialogue within public space. Her goal is to remind people to view the glass as half full. This box promotes positive messaging and art. Smile creates a space for positive conversation and seeks to remind people that life is great! The bright colours and bold patterns are eye catching and immediately uplifting.
properties.title: Baraket Kezwar

properties.address: Queen St W & St Joseph St
properties.artist_bio:
My name is Jeff Blackburn and I am a visual artist based in Toronto. With over a decade of experience producing projects for exhibition and clients, my multi-disciplinary techniques are versatile, but also maintain a recognizable style. Inspired by illustration, graffiti, and comic books, my work is known for its emphasis on line and texture, and its exploration of form using interpretive contour lines. Paintings are constructed by merging pop art aesthetics with contemporary urban art materials and techniques.

My work explores themes that revel in a flippant joie de vivre, yet remain lightly steeped in some measure of memento mori. The combined effect is one of playfully self-assured yet shadowed cheek. My compositions tend to centre on a central figure, giving the piece a definitive focal point from which the viewer can explore. The subjects of my work are chosen for their relevance to the project or location, or simply for their relevance to me. Visual impact in my murals is further accomplished through a vibrant and textured usage of colour. In these paintings, colour is freed from its formal descriptive function and displays energy and motion through a build up of spray and acrylic paint layers.

I want to continue working with StART as I have been creating projects with their team since year one, and I greatly appreciate the opportunities that they’ve funded and helped bring to fruition for both my peers and myself.  I am hoping to grow the scale of my work in the public realm, while simultaneously gaining the key skills necessary in developing the business side of my career. With the backing of StART I have painted 14 traffic signal boxes, participated in roughly 10 StART funded mural jams, assisted American artist Andrew Schoultz in 2012 on one of the first Partnership Program murals, and most recently assisted BirdO on the first Monumental Program wall.
properties.description: Jeff Blackburn’s designs play with the concept of nature encroaching back into urban spaces. His two boxes depict vibrant pink bears. The dynamic colours used by Blackburn bring these signal boxes to life and brighten the streetscape. The bears have a cartoonish, welcoming quality that draws the attention of those passing by.
properties.title: Jeff Blackburn

properties.artist_bio: Colin Turner Bloom has been involved in mural oriented community building projects since 2008 when he was 16. He was first involved in the LOFT painting program out of Christie Ossington Community Center. In 2011 Colin started his own mural company called Annex Creative Services, receiving a Youth Entrepreneurship (Summer Company) award for the business. Since 2011 through the Annex Creative Services Company Colin has produced dozens of pieces of work, predominantly murals, for a variety of private homeowners as well as commercial clients including the Miles Nadal JCC and Queen’s University. Colin also painted four boxes as part of the 2013 and 2014 Outside the Box programs. More recently Colin had a large city theme mural on display at the AGO for a First Thursday event in 2016.
properties.description: Colin Turner-Bloom’s Canadian Shield design creates a stunning juxtaposition between the grey hues of downtown Toronto and explosion of colour present on the box itself. The bright colours used in this design will grab the attention of nearby pedestrians and draw their attention to the more subtle themes of tranquility and nature.
properties.title: Colin Turner Bloom

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.description: Mediah’s designs compliment Toronto’s dynamic nature. They depict both the speed and urban abstraction within the City. The boxes are meant to evoke a sense of curiosity and wonder.
properties.title: Evond Blake (Mediah)

properties.artist_bio: At the age of 14, strolling through urban jungles lit with spring sunlight, on the way back from high school I took a different route to home.Passing by another dull building, I was unexpectedly struck by richly coloured, wild and vibrant ornaments on the wall.Graffiti that fascinated me that day was a sign of love and passion for art and the beginning of my artistic journey.In Following years, getting better at graffiti I got actively involved in mural making.At 24, I entered A.R.A. Toronto and studied classical drawing and painting for 3 years, thereafter I became an apprentice to Vladimir Ribatchok and continued mastering oil painting working in the vein of contemporary realism.As an emerging artist, I work towards gaining more experience in mural making with skills I have learned over the years.
properties.description: Evgeny Cherkassov took inspiration from the ancient exotic wall murals of India. He used warm and vibrant colours which produced the cartoonish and pleasing look of the finished boxes. There’s also an element of mystery in the images.
properties.title: Evgeny Cherkassov

properties.organizations: Bell Box Murals Project / Community Matters Toronto

properties.artist_bio: Christina Mazzulla is a Toronto based multi-disciplinary artist who specializes in spray paint and mixed-media work. She is well known for her mural contributions throughout the city and paintings comprised of intricate cutouts and exploration of combined media. Her artwork is heavily informed by psychedelic imagery, incorporating wildlife, fantasy, landscapes, and electric colour gradients. Christina has been working as a professional artist and showcasing work having graduated from OCADU in 2012, with a Bachelor of Fine Arts. Her passion for street art combined with traditional fine art training has helped her form a unique style, and gain a large following throughout North America. Christina continues her creative pursuits within the gallery scene, while also remaining one of the few active female graffiti artists within Toronto. She has provided many commissioned murals for large businesses and non-profit organizations including American Express, Universal Music, Chevrolet Canada, PangeaSeed Foundation, and The David Suzuki Foundation. She has worked with City of Toronto BIA's and StArt Toronto, along with many privately funded mural projects, with hopes to continue working with other street art initiatives.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals project has transformed utility cabinets into works of art. This piece promotes harmony and 'oneness' through imagery representing the coming together of all elements to create a universal consciousness.
properties.organizations: Bell Box Murals Project / Community Matters Toronto

properties.artist_bio: My name is Katrina Canedo and I am a Toronto-based freelance visual artist and live painter. I typically work with acrylic paint and digital art. However, recently I've been getting more into creating murals for commercials spaces (with spray paint and house paint) and would really love to participate and learn more from StrART projects and how the organization beautifies the city. Generally, my work is influenced by how colours and how they shape a subject can express universal stories or emotions especially applying them on portraits to elaborate on the subject's nuanced story/mood. Since my work is essentially influenced by formless colours and emotions, my process basically involves trying to form or incorporate these colours/shapes into the subject I'm reinterpreting into my style. My overall goal for getting involved with StART is to essentially learn and challenge myself in new ways to express that colourful vision.

properties.artist_bio: Jim Bravo was born in Ecuador, South America in 1973. He is a graduate of The Ontario College of Art and Design University where he majored in Fine Art and studied monumental & public art. Bravo has been active in the street/public art arena since his 2006 graduation, completing several city-funded murals and an array of community engagement art projects.  Through his affiliation with various local arts organizations he has gained vast experience as an arts mentor for at-risk youth initiatives. Bravo is a 4 time award winning painter and muralist and he lives and works in the city of Toronto
properties.description: The bench designs reflect mystical elements and complement the traditions depicted in the sculpted wood totem pole and other public art located in the park.

properties.artist_bio:
Sean Martindale is an internationally recognized, award winning interdisciplinary artist and designer based in Toronto, Canada. His interventions activate public spaces to encourage engagement, and often focus on ecological and social issues. His playful works suggest alternate possibilities for existing spaces, infrastructures, and materials found in urban environments. Frequently, he uses salvaged goods in unexpected ways that prompt conversation.

Among other notable projects, he was the lead artist on the Community Rising, the tallest mural in the world from 2013 to 2018 (now the second tallest), the result of a community project in St James Town, Toronto, with local youth, STEPS and the Toronto Muralists. Martindale has been the lead artist for a number of the GTA’s largest mural projects. He continues to work closely with communities and organizations big and small; including partners such as Harbourfront Centre, the Art Gallery of Ontario, and the City of Toronto.

Martindale holds an MFA from the Interdisciplinary Masters of Art, Media and Design program at OCAD University in Toronto, and a BDes in Communication Design from Emily Carr University in Vancouver. He was the Decennial Hancock Lecturer at the University of Toronto’s Hart House, where his presentation was broadcast by TVO for their Big Ideas series. He is a recipient of the prestigious Artist Prize from Toronto Friends of the Visual Arts, numerous grants at municipal, provincial, and federal levels, and a Chalmers Arts Fellowship from the Ontario Arts Council. Martindale was profiled for the first episode of CBC’s Great Minds of Design, and his works have been featured digitally and published in traditional media around the world in multiple languages. His works have been exhibited publicly in many cities across the globe.

Recently, Martindale was Harbourfront Centre’s inaugural Visual Artist-in-Residence, and alongside his collaborator JP King, was also the first Artist-in-Residence with the City of Toronto, Solid Waste Management Services.

-------------

•	While I continue to be interested in traditional mural forms, I am also excited to keep exploring other media/materials in the public realm, spearhead new practices, and explore diverse approaches to community engagement. As well, I am interested in potentially growing other areas of my practice, and taking on more roles in related areas such as project coordination, program development, and consulting.
properties.description: This mural symbolizes and honours the environmental narrative of the Rexdale community and the Indigenous connection to the land and local area in order to celebrate Rexdale's past and present.
properties.title: Emilia Jajus and Sean Martindale

properties.artist_bio:
I am a Filipnx 26-year-old multidisciplinary Scarborough-based artist. Inspired by indigenous Filipinx art, abstract contemporary art and graffiti, my work is both cathartic and shares the narrative of Filipinx and POC identities facing diaspora and poverty in urban areas, encouraging viewers to tap into their ancestral energies and power.

I love to combine many elements in my work, mediums , styles and tools to create. I feel the more mediums , styles and tools create more infinite forms and and ever lasting growing process.

Through these practices, he has established a signature style of his own called, 'Ancient Graffuturism'.
In this he combines elements of abstract art,Manga,international Architecture, Calligraphy, Graffiti & Ancient Filipino Design Inspired Images & Symbols.
Being a Diaspora, Rowell likes to blend his asian heritage into his work to feel more connected with himself.


I want to work with StART because I Share a common Thread with the organization which is to create and protect communities and businesses. I do this for a living so If I can join forces with the organization we could become more of a powerful positive force and spread love through mural art. I would like to learn from StART anything that comes with mural making, Mural planning, community engagement, outreach. I know a little bit about each element but there will always be more to learn. I am good at working with people. I have colloborated many times in the city and internationally on Murals. I am open to learning and working with new people in StART . I feel there is so much that Artists, StART's Organization have to offer and looking forward to seeing what stART has in store.

properties.artist_bio: Jim Bravo was born in Ecuador, South America in 1973. He is a graduate of The Ontario College of Art and Design University where he majored in Fine Art and studied monumental & public art. Bravo has been active in the street/public art arena since his 2006 graduation, completing several city-funded murals and an array of community engagement art projects.  Through his affiliation with various local arts organizations he has gained vast experience as an arts mentor for at-risk youth initiatives. Bravo is a 4 time award winning painter and muralist and he lives and works in the city of Toronto
properties.description: This 3-walled mural highlights "Weston Then and Now" by depicting the living history of the area, while capturing ongoing changes in the community.
properties.title: Jim Bravo, Niel Yee, Rowena Kizito, and Bryan Bermudez

properties.description: This mural symbolizes the growth, diversity, and future of the Weston/Mount Dennis community by depicting vibrant local imagery such as the nearby Humber River and children.
properties.title: Emanuel Ciobanica

properties.description: This mural depicts a scene at the nearby Grenadier Pond, a familiar local landmark in Toronto's High Park.

properties.artist_bio:
Ted Hamer is a multidisciplinary Artist and educator based in Toronto. His work explores the juxtaposition of nature with human constructs through explorations into challenging humanities anthropocentric views towards ourselves and our environment. He merges historical approaches to realist and modern art to explore the nature vs culture divide through figures that examine various overlapping themes of anthropocenterism using natural and man made elements and materials.
Ted's work has exhibited in the Art Gallery of Ontario, the Steamwhistle Gallery, the RMG, The Station Gallery, Nathan Phillips Square, Bluffs Gallery, the Super Wonder Gallery and his Sculptural Mural Installation is the centerpiece installation of the Aurora Cultural Centre in Aurora Ontario.

In paint I work with Aerosol and acrylic and Latex. In Sculpture I work in clays, fibreglass, resins, bronze and wood and am now experimenting with 3D printed pieces. I would like to work with StART to develop more street art that challenges the urban landscape with art based on nature and animals. My practice is moving more to the 3D side of things and I would like to work with StART to fabricate more street level sculptural pieces as I see the need for that in Toronto.
I have mentored many emerging artists but I feel I could use help in taking my own practice to the next level possibly through mentor ship or guidance from another artist.
I also coordinate creative projects and have worked previously with StART on the Outside the Box Program, with the Bell Box Murals Project and with the Aurora Cultural Centre facilitating workshops, designing and creating artwork and mentoring emerging artists.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals project has transformed utility cabinets into works of art. This piece references the saying "If you love something, set it free; if it comes back, it's yours" by depicting a girl releasing a bird, that symbolizes love.
properties.organizations: Bell Box Murals Project / Community Matters Toronto
properties.title: Ted Hamer

properties.artist_bio: ‘Elicser’ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.
properties.description: This mural draws attention to the multicultural identity of the Alexandra Park community and the plight of individuals in the face of financial challenges through an artistic approach that enlivens the spirits of passersby and resonates with local youth.

properties.address: St Clair Ave W & Caledonia Park Rd

properties.description: This mural represents the local evolving multicultural community through various colours and lines and is intended to be appreciated by people of all walks of life, regardless of age or nationality. It was completed entirely by hand with paint rollers.

properties.description: This mural depicts a time-lapse of Toronto, from the 1940s to early 2000s. It pays homage to the business on the site, Visic Bros, which has been installing heating and A/C units in Toronto for 60 years.

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.description: This mural, THE RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS’, depicts dynamic movement and togetherness and represents the entrance way into the surrounding communities.
properties.title: MEDIAH (Evond Blake)

properties.artist_bio:
My name is Jeff Blackburn and I am a visual artist based in Toronto. With over a decade of experience producing projects for exhibition and clients, my multi-disciplinary techniques are versatile, but also maintain a recognizable style. Inspired by illustration, graffiti, and comic books, my work is known for its emphasis on line and texture, and its exploration of form using interpretive contour lines. Paintings are constructed by merging pop art aesthetics with contemporary urban art materials and techniques.

My work explores themes that revel in a flippant joie de vivre, yet remain lightly steeped in some measure of memento mori. The combined effect is one of playfully self-assured yet shadowed cheek. My compositions tend to centre on a central figure, giving the piece a definitive focal point from which the viewer can explore. The subjects of my work are chosen for their relevance to the project or location, or simply for their relevance to me. Visual impact in my murals is further accomplished through a vibrant and textured usage of colour. In these paintings, colour is freed from its formal descriptive function and displays energy and motion through a build up of spray and acrylic paint layers.

I want to continue working with StART as I have been creating projects with their team since year one, and I greatly appreciate the opportunities that they’ve funded and helped bring to fruition for both my peers and myself.  I am hoping to grow the scale of my work in the public realm, while simultaneously gaining the key skills necessary in developing the business side of my career. With the backing of StART I have painted 14 traffic signal boxes, participated in roughly 10 StART funded mural jams, assisted American artist Andrew Schoultz in 2012 on one of the first Partnership Program murals, and most recently assisted BirdO on the first Monumental Program wall.
properties.title: Jeff Blackburn

properties.artist_bio:
I want to continue co-collaborating with StART to keep growing as an artist in my skill set, practice and portfolio. With StART’s support I want to be mentored in my mural career with any opportunities to connect with seasoned mural/street artists and get on a swing-stage, aerial lift, use a spray gun, while learning to comprehend XL large walls and huge quantities of paint among advanced techniques of execution and project production. I’ve currently reached the stage of painting garages in Toronto and am interested and ready to go larger.

Bio & Artist Statement
Anya Mielniczek is a Toronto based multidisciplinary artist who combines her fine art background with raw material grit in both private and public sectors creating mixed-media installations, mural work and facilitating community art activations.
The artists approach to mediums includes latex, aerosol and up-cycled waste, working with the mechanical application of spray and the energy of hand brushed strokes (infused with powerful female portraits and garbage bits if possible).
A Queen’s University graduate, Anya’s worked with various organizations, municipalities and businesses creating public art within communities around Toronto and internationally. Recent corporate projects include lead production on HideSeek, a 7000sq foot immersive art experience in Toronto and collaborations with BACARDI, QUO Makeup, Moroccanoil, DELL, RBC, 1800GOTJUNK and Chevrolet. Her commitment to her practice especially when aligned with public spaces is to create with purpose by giving nature a voice while defining a conversation with the viewer that may inspire and bring awareness for sustainable change.
properties.description:
The theme behind this design surrounds positive affirmations that we tell
ourselves --phrases that are short, sweet and to the point. In the fast pace of city life
or the flurry of a million thoughts it’s easy to lose oneself. The idea behind  'Feel Good'
is for this box to stand as a little reminder or pick me up (if needs be).
properties.title: Mielniczek

properties.address: St Clair Ave W & Caledonia Rd
properties.title: Dawson

properties.artist_bio:
At the tender age of nine, Toronto-based illustrator Adrian Hayles discovered the expressive
nature of the visual arts. With his continued artistic development, illustration became his
deepest passion and talent. His desire to learn and absorb from his surroundings led him on a
personal creative journey. As a graduate of the Graphic Design program at Humber College
with over 10 years of working experience behind him, Adrian has established his place in
Toronto’s modern art community. His style is provocative and inspiring and defies
categorization. Blurring the lines between graffiti and ultra realism, Adrian’s voice and vision is
instantly identifiable. His works include countless portraits and illustrations for various
magazines and collaborations with the City of Toronto to develop murals for vacant community
spaces. In the past Adrian has painted complete buildings and city blocks, designed award
winning video games and animated television shows. He has also successfully developed and
filed a functioning patent for the Stud Horse Foldable Drawing Bench and is the Principal and
Founder of Behind the Front Visual Arts Studio.
properties.description: Adrian Hayles chose to depict hands on his boxes as they contain tremendous character and are a key component for communication. Hands are also a metaphor for helping one another (lending a helping hand).
properties.title: Adrian Hayles

properties.description:
Each pillar highlights a different part of Corktown's past. One showcases its First Nations history and the early migration of European settlers who helped build the neighbourhood. A second depicts the area's working class roots and the third mural highlights education and 
and Toronto's first free school, Enoch Turner.  A fourth mural looks to the future with a bold cityscape.
properties.title: Shalak Attack

properties.description: This work attempts to call attention to the often-illusive nature of meaning, questioning how we create and compartmentalize systems as outlets to organize thoughts and actions.
properties.title: Timothy Walker & Denise St Marie

A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.

properties.description: The mural pays homage to the historical roots of Scarborough.  The north wall honours the significant contribution made by women working in the local ammunitions plant during WWII; while the north wall showcases the local area's unique history and pays tribute to its past as the Scarboro Junction.
properties.title: Omen

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to continue working with StART because they support the creation of art that makes our public realm a more beautiful and inviting place. StART has helped me create meaningful work that strengthens communities and enables me to develop my practice of using art as a way to build inclusive communities who celebrate their identity with pride. I would like to develop my leadership skills and am interested in mentorship opportunities where I can learn how to work more effectively with the city to realize large scale initiatives that give more artists and community members opportunities to feel empowered through the process of creating art in the public realm.

I am a Toronto based visual artist, community organizer, muralist, curator, and eternal optimist. My work is motivated by my desire to spread joy, nurture present minded living, cultivate gratitude, and foster new social interactions from a place of love and empathy. Using aerosol and acrylic paint, I work with bright colours and bold patterns to captivate people’s attention and fill them with delight and hope. I am passionate about creating art that both aesthetically and psychologically brightens the streets and work to build a community around positive living.

My belief that public art is a powerful tool for building community drives my practice. In 2017, I founded Womxn Paint, an annual street art jam that has produced 44 murals celebrating the strength and diversity of womxn. I would like to continue this initiative and grow it to include additional programming that supports the professional development of womxn artists and more opportunities for young girls to learn about mural arts. In 2016, I facilitated an intergenerational mural at Baycrest Health Sciences and would like work more with the senior community.

Over the last six years, I have created custom large-scale outdoor artworks for clients including The New Yorker, Tourism Canada, the City of Toronto, the City of Mississauga, the Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany in Toronto, the STEPS Initiative, Arts Etobicoke, East End Arts and private clients.
properties.description: Baraket Kezwar’s smile project is about creating an alternative dialogue within public space. Her goal is to remind people to view the glass as half full. This box promotes positive messaging and art. Smile creates a space for positive conversation and seeks to remind people that life is great! The bright colours and bold patterns are eye catching and immediately uplifting.
properties.title: Bareket Kezwer

properties.description:
The icebox mural was created as an interactive piece with the public, playing on the emotions in the heat during the summer, and vice versa in the dead of winter. This is the
ultimate juxtaposition, sticking out amongst the snow as if we really need more ice.
properties.title: Random

properties.artist_bio:
Peru is an internationally recognized muralist and graphic artist whose practice is informed by digital and traditional art forms and his 20+ years of painting graffiti. Peru’s professional career started when he moved from Lima to Ottawa at 16; he won every Visual Arts Award in his high school, a Canadian Heritage grant to paint a mural in Vancouver for the International Earth Festival, and a 2 mural commission for the National Capital Commission. At age 20 he moved to Montreal where he continued winning prizes and awards from design contests at his local skateshop to the Millennium Excellence Scholarship.

His passion for art lead him to rise to the top of the local art scene working for brands and companies such as Bell, Cirque du Soleil and he painted a series of murals with the collective En Masse at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. With En Masse, Peru was part of dozens of collaborative murals throughout Canada, US, Mexico and China, and participated in mentorship programs with the Quebec English School Boards Association. He was also a central muralist for MU since its inception in 2007 and continues to work with them, most recently in 2020 where he will be painting the exterior of a high school.

When Peru moved to Toronto a decade later he worked for Urban Outfitters for 5 years as a Lead Display Artist. In this role he built and installed window and store displays participating in store openings across North America including the company’s largest store opening at Herald Square in New York City. Peru used these experiences to expand his skill set and work on art installations at the Osheaga Music Festival as well for American Express for their Live Life Experience Installations around the world; All the while establishing himself as a muralist by assisting, collaborating, and consulting for nearly every arts organization in Toronto, and mentoring individuals, peers and on several occasions’ at-risk youth from the Oasis Skateboard Factory. Peru’s corporate and big brand murals allowed him to balance his work with grass-roots organizations, non-for-profits and BIA’s which make up most of his portfolio. Some of Peru’s corporate clients include Facebook, Nike, Adidas, Corus, Maple Leaf Sports, and Marriott Hotels.
properties.title: Dyer Jalea

properties.artist_bio: ‘Elicser’ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.
properties.title: Jabari Elliott (Elicser)

properties.artist_bio: Colin Turner Bloom has been involved in mural oriented community building projects since 2008 when he was 16. He was first involved in the LOFT painting program out of Christie Ossington Community Center. In 2011 Colin started his own mural company called Annex Creative Services, receiving a Youth Entrepreneurship (Summer Company) award for the business. Since 2011 through the Annex Creative Services Company Colin has produced dozens of pieces of work, predominantly murals, for a variety of private homeowners as well as commercial clients including the Miles Nadal JCC and Queen’s University. Colin also painted four boxes as part of the 2013 and 2014 Outside the Box programs. More recently Colin had a large city theme mural on display at the AGO for a First Thursday event in 2016.
properties.title: Colin Turner Bloom

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.
properties.title: Chris Perez

properties.description: The mural’s composition is derived from sound recordings made at the mural's Davenport Road location. A sound-based artwork derived from the recordings was translated into an abstract visual representation that was painted onto the walls. This creative process was inspired by synesthesia – a phenomenon in which stimulation of one sense leads to automatic, involuntary experience in a second sense.
properties.title: Paul Aloisi

properties.description: This design depicts the lighter side of Toronto, the city streets. They are places where people meet, walk, run and ride. The streets are an enjoyable part of Toronto, characteristic of the unique people, careers and personalities of a diverse people group.
properties.title: Sarah Collard

properties.description: Spud have become known for certain letters styles as well as some of his iconic characters. He chose to create a beautiful, colourful mash up collage of his iconic hand style S (S for Spudbomb) by painting the S over and over again, to bring life to the box through typography and colour.
properties.title: Spud

properties.description: The mural on the south entrance to the tunnel pays homage to the Rail Garden and local community, recognizing the determination of the mother's behind the creation of the garden. Images of the city and nature are highlighted as one travels through the tunnel. Murals at the north end pay homage to the thriving neighbourhoods and businesses that surround the park.

He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.title: Evond Blake (Mediah)

properties.address: Keele St & St Clair Ave W
properties.description:
When living in India, the artist spent a lot of time sketching cows and bulls, and has a feel
for their personality and visual elegance. The large volume of the animal makes it an ideal subject for outdoor public art.
properties.title: Rosalie Lam

A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.

properties.description: This piece titled From Darkness to Light “Floating Flowers” was painted to stimulate the unalterable part of humanity that is inherent and innate to human beings and not dependent on factors such as gender, race, culture, or class.
properties.title: Motto

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

properties.description: Mediah’s designs compliment Toronto’s dynamic nature. They depict both the speed and urban abstraction within the City. The boxes are meant to evoke a sense of curiosity and wonder.

properties.description: This box depicts a man on a diving board at an urban pool. The design shows how it is possible to find independence and thought in an urban environment. Here, a man has found an escape from the busied confusions of urban life.
properties.title: Colin Turner Bloom

A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. properties.description: Home is indeed where the heart is. Elicser has been a fixture on Queen West for well over a decade. The “Hug Me Tree” just east of this traffic box bearing Elicser’s self portrait continues to be celebrated as people recall the spot where they first met, where they were first engaged, where they might have been lost than found once the Elicser tree was in sight.
properties.title: Jabari Elliott (Elicser)

properties.address: Front St W & Blue Jays Way
properties.description: This piece was created with the idea of relating quite closely to its environment, reflecting elements of its surroundings as a sort of warped mirror — this is intended to create a heightened engagement on the part of the viewer to not only the box itself, but also that part of the city in which the box is found.
properties.title: Paul Byron

properties.description: The mural, depicting the migration of birds and butterflies, wraps around the west side of the underpass at Kingston Rd. at Danforth Ave. welcoming residents and visitors to the Birch Cliff community with a vibrant visual display of the Scarborough Bluffs, as well as the diverse flora and fauna and the many grasses and plants  that thrive in the region.
properties.title: Bill Wrigley, Patrick Gooding

properties.description:
Candy jars have enormous visual appeal. Multi-colored candies tempt the eyes.
The sweet memory of candy—recalling simple pleasures and instant happiness— tempt the tastebuds. Unlike real jars of candy, which tend to disappear all too quickly, this one will stay full for all to enjoy
properties.title: Rosalie Lam

properties.artist_bio:
My name is Jeff Blackburn and I am a visual artist based in Toronto. With over a decade of experience producing projects for exhibition and clients, my multi-disciplinary techniques are versatile, but also maintain a recognizable style. Inspired by illustration, graffiti, and comic books, my work is known for its emphasis on line and texture, and its exploration of form using interpretive contour lines. Paintings are constructed by merging pop art aesthetics with contemporary urban art materials and techniques.

My work explores themes that revel in a flippant joie de vivre, yet remain lightly steeped in some measure of memento mori. The combined effect is one of playfully self-assured yet shadowed cheek. My compositions tend to centre on a central figure, giving the piece a definitive focal point from which the viewer can explore. The subjects of my work are chosen for their relevance to the project or location, or simply for their relevance to me. Visual impact in my murals is further accomplished through a vibrant and textured usage of colour. In these paintings, colour is freed from its formal descriptive function and displays energy and motion through a build up of spray and acrylic paint layers.

I want to continue working with StART as I have been creating projects with their team since year one, and I greatly appreciate the opportunities that they’ve funded and helped bring to fruition for both my peers and myself.  I am hoping to grow the scale of my work in the public realm, while simultaneously gaining the key skills necessary in developing the business side of my career. With the backing of StART I have painted 14 traffic signal boxes, participated in roughly 10 StART funded mural jams, assisted American artist Andrew Schoultz in 2012 on one of the first Partnership Program murals, and most recently assisted BirdO on the first Monumental Program wall.
properties.title: Jeff Blackburn

properties.artist_bio:
SPUD1 has been a fixture in the Toronto urban and underground art scene for more than 18 years. An accomplished artist, he loves the thrill of finding unconventional spaces to showcase his talent.
SPUD1’s passion for art has grown along with his talent. He is a well-rounded artist that is capable of working with all types of mediums and images, and specializes in working collaboratively with other artists.
SpudBomb was founded by SPUD1 in 2010, when he traveled across Europe, covering many cities with his funny and happy SpudBomb characters and happy Grenades.
Team SpudBomb is comprised of Spud1 & his partner Brooke, together they curate and manage various artists projects and large scale murals, both collaboratively and on behalf of Spud1 himself.
Since 2014 Team SpudBomb – working under the event Wall Expressions; has been working in partnership and fully funded through StART to curate Laneway events that help to create live outdoor galleries in laneways that experience graffiti vandalism.  These events allow the community and artist to engage and reclaim public spaces, and create conversation about art and how it can serve the neighbourhood/community when incorporate in public spaces.
In 2016 SPUD1 was one of the featured artists in the Doors Open Toronto colouring book and was successful in his grant application with the Bloordale BIA to install a huge mural within that community, which has been exceptionally well received, and working with brands such as CAT, Converse, Mountain Dew, Universal Studios, and Crystal Head Vodka. In addition to this, his installation of the Pride Mural at Church and Wood received a special award for his dedication and activism in the TPS & StART Toronto partnership program.
In 2017 Spud completed a huge Mural called the Smile on Dufferin, the ribbon cutting and mural unveiling was opened by city councilor & Deputy Mayor Ana Bailao.
In 2018 Spud1 and Sean Martindale completed the mural “Tapestry of Movement at the Toronto Coach Terminal through the City’s StART partnership program with STEPS Initiative, and saw him working with brands such as Sketchers.
In 2019  Team Spudbomb was awarded a partnership Grant through the City of Toronto to paint an over 2,000 square foot underpass, an invitation to paint a large mural at Concrete canvas festival in Hamilton and a request to paint at Kotis Street Art in Greensboro, North Carolina.
These are just a few examples throughout the past 6 years where Spud1 has exemplified the type of artist he is, one which continually sees markets, festivals, other artists and brands wanting to work with him in addition to Team Spudbomb continuing to work with old school and emerging talents to bring together events that foster community engagements and relationships.
SPUD1’s dedication and commitment to seeing the projects he is involved in through is only overshadowed by his installations themselves.
SPUD1 continues to grow and evolve as an artist and is always looking for new and exciting opportunities to express himself and showcase his art., SPUD1 has been a fixture in the Toronto urban and underground art scene for more than 18 years. properties.artist_bio:
I would like to work with StART because I have a history of working on public and community-engaged mural projects and programs, many of which have been supported and in partnership with StART. I believe in the values of the StART programs and have experienced the dedication of the team to carrying out these values through supporting and partnering.

I am a visual artist passionate about arts engagement and education, collaborative art making, and murals. These practices bridge my background from a Bachelor of Fine Art in Drawing & Painting from OCAD University and a Community Arts Practice Certificate from York University. Since 2011, I have worn many ‘hats’ in the mural, art and community arts field; from artist, arts educator, facilitator, curator, arts administrator and project manager. I have had the opportunity to work and learn from these experiences, building adaptability and flexibility through working in unique situations including libraries, schools, art galleries, community centres, seniors centres, skate parks, abandoned storefronts (you name it!). I have built a strong rapport working with many artists and arts organizations such as Mural Routes, Vibe Arts, Nuit Blanche, Lakeshore Arts, Platform A, Scribble me Silly, Arts Etobicoke and East End Arts. In particular, I have worked closely with Mural Routes since 2011, as Program Coordinator, Facilitator, Curriculum Coordinator, and Program Director, with a focus on mentorship and the Mural Art Learning Institute programs.

My creative processes for involving community and youth in projects within their own neighbourhoods are based in facilitation style that creatively employs storytelling, brainstorming, and playful art techniques like collage to encourage conversations, confidence and to bring many ideas together into action. It gives me great joy to facilitate consultation, design, art making and mural making to bring community members together to reflect and re-imagine their neighbourhood. I love any opportunity to nurture participants’ creative abilities and create a safe space for exploration and connection through visual arts and storytelling. I see art as a tool for exploring themes, beginning conversation, gathering patterns and beginning important dialogue. Mural consultation and participation offers a space where artists and community members alike can share, exchange, grow and work together.
properties.title: Tara Dorey

properties.artist_bio: Will Gaydos (aka Rage Williams) is an artist and photographer from Toronto, Canada. He has an HBA from the University of Toronto in Urban Studies and Human Geography, and often utilizes themes from his studies in his work. As an artist he mainly focuses on large-scale mural work, incorporating text, vivid colour, and urban imagery to challenge the monotony of urban spaces.
properties.title: Will Gaydos

Since 2011 through the Annex Creative Services Company Colin has produced dozens of pieces of work, predominantly murals, for a variety of private homeowners as well as commercial clients including the Miles Nadal JCC and Queen’s University. Colin also painted four boxes as part of the 2013 and 2014 Outside the Box programs. More recently Colin had a large city theme mural on display at the AGO for a First Thursday event in 2016.
