properties.description: This piece highlights an incredibly beautiful relationship between bees and flowers, while also highlighting the relationship of bees today in urban environments to shed some light on the troubling numbers of current bee populations.
properties.title: Kelly Diamond

properties.description: This mural "Tempo, Toil, & Flow" depicts birds travelling in time to capture the rich history of dairy, from the  Massey Family Farm to present day.
properties.title: Community Centre 55 GRIP Crew

properties.artist_bio: Jim Bravo was born in Ecuador, South America in 1973. He is a graduate of The Ontario College of Art and Design University where he majored in Fine Art and studied monumental & public art. Bravo has been active in the street/public art arena since his 2006 graduation, completing several city-funded murals and an array of community engagement art projects.  Through his affiliation with various local arts organizations he has gained vast experience as an arts mentor for at-risk youth initiatives. Bravo is a 4 time award winning painter and muralist and he lives and works in the city of Toronto
properties.description: This mural is a continuation of the "Parkdale Food Stories" mural around the corner. It depicts the critters that make their home in the HOPE Community Garden and create a healthy ecosystem and environment for growing food.
properties.title: Jim Bravo

properties.address: Red Robin Way & Finch Avenue West
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals project has transformed utility cabinets into works of art. This piece depicts a vibrant and beautiful Russian doll.
properties.title: Natasha Kudashkina

properties.artist_bio:
At the tender age of nine, Toronto-based illustrator Adrian Hayles discovered the expressive
nature of the visual arts. With his continued artistic development, illustration became his
deepest passion and talent. His desire to learn and absorb from his surroundings led him on a
personal creative journey. As a graduate of the Graphic Design program at Humber College
with over 10 years of working experience behind him, Adrian has established his place in
Toronto’s modern art community. His style is provocative and inspiring and defies
categorization. Blurring the lines between graffiti and ultra realism, Adrian’s voice and vision is
instantly identifiable. His works include countless portraits and illustrations for various
magazines and collaborations with the City of Toronto to develop murals for vacant community
spaces. In the past Adrian has painted complete buildings and city blocks, designed award
winning video games and animated television shows. He has also successfully developed and
filed a functioning patent for the Stud Horse Foldable Drawing Bench and is the Principal and
Founder of Behind the Front Visual Arts Studio.
properties.description: This "Reggae Lane" mural, located in Toronto’s culturally-rich and creative Little Jamaica community, pays homage to the fact that this community produced more reggae than any other area outside of Jamaica by depicting local and legendary reggae artists.
properties.organizations: The STEPS (Sustainble Thinking and Expression on Public Spaces) Initiative
properties.title: Adrian Hayles

properties.artist_bio: ‘Elicser’ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.
properties.description: This mural, located beside the Bendale Library, celebrates reading and its ability to open the door to adventure and the discovery of new ideas, by depicting readers of all ages and backgrounds immersed in books and their imagination.
properties.title: Drew Mosley and Elicser

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals project has transformed utility cabinets into works of art. This abstract piece can be interpreted and enjoyed by viewers in their own way.
properties.title: Chris Perez

properties.artist_bio: Paula Gonzalez-Ossa is a mural artist who has been working with diverse communities producing street level public art, both in Canada and Latin America for over 25 years. Her ongoing work with StARToronto dates back to 2015. Her murals, like the most recent 500 ft. mural titled "Our Medicines"  located at the underpass at Dupont and Shaw, or "The Ancestral Tree Spirits" located at the Nordheimer Ravine's TTC station exit, depict a colourful  First Nations cosmovision in relation to the Original lands of Ontario, working closely with Anishnawbe  mentors, Elders and Knowledge Keepers. Gonzalez-Ossa is currently  the Indigenous Education Officer at the AGO’s Weston Learning Centre, as part of the Public Programming and Learning Department, and the Visual Arts instructor and mentoring artist at Na Me Res Sagatay Native Men's Residence. She brings 19 years experience as a  Community Youth Worker with youth at risk in Toronto's West.Some of her previous public works include: a 120 foot mural honoring First Nations from North and South America,  which was the recipient of  the 2014 Ward 27 City Builder’s Award, formerly at Allan Gardens. Other locations sport a ribbon-style mural at Women’s Residence, a women’s shelter at Dundas and Bathurst, in collaborations with an all women crew (2015), and a 4 wall rendition of the Medicine Wheel, inside of Na Me Res Sagatay’s courtyard (2016).  In sharp contrast she produced an indoor mural with 22 students from grades 6-8 at refugee host school Beverley Heights Middle School (2017).She recently served in the capacity of Resident Artist at the Power Plant gallery, developing mural arts programs at two satellite locations with youth from priority neighbouroods in Toronto’s West.(2017-2018). In 2018-2019 she worked closely with the 7Th Generation Image Makers at the Native Youth Resource Centre to mentor, facilitate and produce a mural with an all Indigenous women’s team, located  at the South facing wall at Christie Pits Park’s Alex Duff Memorial Pool. Her two most recent productions  funded by StART’s Partnership Grant in 2019,located at the front façade of Sagatay Naïve Men’s Residence, and the adjacent alley,  depict  “Medicines and Guardians”, as well as “The Wolves Running South”.Last but not least, Gonzalez-Ossa is one of the featured artists at the “You’ve Changed “ exhibit by STARToronto , at St Lawrence Market’s  “Market Gallery”. At the exhibit, the video display shows us her latest short documentary produced  for SART, about the basic protocols entailed when developing images in partnership with Indigenous Nations here in Canada.Gonzalez-Ossa  has been  voted Best Graffiti Artist for the City of Toronto by Now Magazine’s Reader’s Poll in 1997, in 2009, 2010, and 2011. In addition, she has been featured on  CBC (Radio and Television, varying shows), Much Music, MTV, Global Televison, City TV, TVO, CTV, Bell Fibe TV1, Rogers Television, and Telelatino, as well as various television  appearances in Chile, USA (NYC/California), and Jamaica.
properties.description: This mural incorporates a colourful ribbon protectively wrapping around the Women's Residence. The project was run by a women-led team and involved women from the Residence.
properties.title: Paula Gonzalez-Ossa (Bomba)

properties.description: The Bell Box Murals project has transformed utility cabinets into works of art. This piece depicts wildlife, including birds and toadstools.
properties.title: Aisha Ali

properties.artist_bio: Amir Akbari is a Greater Toronto Area (GTA) based Visual Artist, Educator, Community Advocate and Entrepreneur.   In 2002, he enrolled in OCAD University where he would go on to complete a Bachelors of Fine Arts with a focus on Drawing and Painting.  In 2003, Amir led his first community mural art project working with Urban Art Toronto.  The following year, he took on his first role with Street Art (then Graffiti Transformation Project) as the lead artist with Lamp Community Health Centre.  That project would be a launching pad for his eventual artistic and professional career.From 2003 to 2010 Amir continued to work with various community organizations and charities as an artist facilitator, youth works and educator.  He would go onto complete over 30 public murals throughout this time, working with and mentoring hundreds of youth across the GTA.In 2010 Amir founded Behind the Line with the purpose of providing existing support structures within the community with creative and artistic support.  Behind the Line has since worked closely with multiple organizations to enhance their arts programming and creative reach, from curriculum development, programming consultation and arts integration strategies.In the summer of 2019, Amir completed his largest mural production, the Susan Street Mural at 3847 Lawrence Ave. East.  This would be his 6th Street Art Partnership Project with the Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough and his 3rd partnership with Toronto Community Housing.  The large 14 story mural is the crowning achievement of his artistic journey as a community and mural artist.  Focused on creating designs that reflect, represent and inspire the communities that he is working with, this mural is a celebration of the collaborative and uplifting nature of public murals funded by Street Art Toronto.His work is rooted in the belief that self-expression can have a lasting impact on the development and growth of young people and their communities, and that there is a disproportional disadvantage across the board for those that face multiple barriers with accessing the arts.   He hopes to fill this void through innovative arts strategies, collaborative mural projects and local community partnerships.
properties.description: This mural celebrates music and portrays a visual representation of sound through an image of a guitar and a portrait of a woman playing the trumpet, from which abstract sound elements emerge.
properties.organizations: Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough
properties.title: Amir Akbari (Behind the Lines)

properties.artist_bio:
Early on, I perceived that my ambition was the act of painting itself, finding that the process coincided with the workings of my conscious and unconscious mind.Throughout my career I have also been fascinated by realism, specifically trompe l’oeil and it’s ability to affect the viewer. I have been creating trompe l’oeil murals in combination with my abstract works for over 20 years now. It has become for me a way to connect with the viewer on several different levels. I have discovered that painting illusions allows me to communicate with a larger audience, as people genuinely delighted when visually tricked. While both painting techniques claim to express reality truthfully, either suggests only a partial or incomplete view of a subject.
I am also extremely interested in the archival quality of work and how public art is produced, in an ethical and archival way. I have painted murals that are still on display over 20 years later. I feel that viewers of public work have an investment in the upkeep and archival quality of the work. Starting with the proper preparation, the production process should be considered when producing public art. When public art pieces become worn and decay after only a few seasons the public does not see the value in continuing to fund public art. Having worked for several years of trial and error I feel that I could offer proper preparation advice to many of the public art projects.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals project has transformed utility cabinets into works of art. This piece depicts rich red velvet curtains.
properties.title: Margaret Cresswell

properties.artist_bio:
Enlivened by his interest in spacial structures and interconnectivity, Andre Kan's paintings serve as excitable blueprints for a possible reality. Each work depicts the artists' signature imaginative building blocks that converge and begin to build upon each other and strengthening each other towards an ever transforming space. Kan's structures are substantial and complex but not yet anchored - they float suspended in his psychological space. In this way Kan's buildings remain a playful proposition for the viewer not yet tied to a specific place or function. With his dynamic formations, Kan propels us towards an ever optimistic future where new connections and constructions have yet to materialize.

His current work investigates the architectural interpretations that respond to our ever advancing society, and suggests what 'possibility' means through self discovery. Examining what mark making and its properties mean, as well as the significance in cause and effect, is important here. Kan's psychological structures depict change and evolution of space, while also questioning the fundamental nature of being and the world that encompasses it.

Andre Kan is a Toronto based painter. Since graduating from the Ontario College of Art & Design University in 2014, he continues his creative pursuits as an Artist, Muralist, Photographer, Curator, Producer, and Musician. His paintings have been showcased throughout Canada with permanent collections in the U.S and China. His murals can also be seen internationally including London, Spain, Portugal and Taiwan.



Email: andrekanart@gmail.com

properties.artist_bio:
Dan Bergeron is a public artist who employs a range of styles, themes and materials to activate and explore the meaning of our shared public spaces. The shape, texture and location of a site and its history or current uses dictate the form and content of his projects. Dan’s public installations aim to open a dialog with viewers, promoting engagement through both intimate familiarity and wonder at the unexpected.

Dan has created public art projects for municipalities across Canada (Toronto, Mississauga, Ottawa, Gaspe, Calgary, Richmond), working in both two-dimensional mediums (murals, photo-based wheat pasting) and three dimensional sculpture. He has also been commissioned by the AGO, MOCA Toronto, the ROM and corporate clients Nike, Converse and Vespa., Born and raised in the Cabbagetown neighbourhood of Toronto, I have participated in the city's street art community for over 20 years as a graffiti and mural artist. My goal is to continue to bring life to the city through public art. When I create street art I work predominantly with spraypaint but I also work with oil on canvas as a professional artist represented by Ingram Gallery. I consider each project unique and like to incorporate the surrounding environment, wall structure, and community when developing a mural design and concept. Passing on skills to the next generation of artists is not only beneficial to the community, but myself as well. Through my previous mentorship work I have formed new friendships and learnt from others.
properties.description: This mural references Flannery O' Connor's story collection titled "Everything That Rises" - a phrase that reflects the new, rising community at Lansdowne Ave and Dupont St and the former Lake Iroquois coastline that rose to what is now Davenport Road.
properties.title: Dan Bergeron and Ryan Dineen

properties.artist_bio:
Sean Martindale is an internationally recognized, award winning interdisciplinary artist and designer based in Toronto, Canada. His interventions activate public spaces to encourage engagement, and often focus on ecological and social issues. His playful works suggest alternate possibilities for existing spaces, infrastructures, and materials found in urban environments. Frequently, he uses salvaged goods in unexpected ways that prompt conversation.

Among other notable projects, he was the lead artist on the Community Rising, the tallest mural in the world from 2013 to 2018 (now the second tallest), the result of a community project in St James Town, Toronto, with local youth, STEPS and the Toronto Muralists. Martindale has been the lead artist for a number of the GTA’s largest mural projects. He continues to work closely with communities and organizations big and small; including partners such as Harbourfront Centre, the Art Gallery of Ontario, and the City of Toronto.

Martindale holds an MFA from the Interdisciplinary Masters of Art, Media and Design program at OCAD University in Toronto, and a BDes in Communication Design from Emily Carr University in Vancouver. He was the Decennial Hancock Lecturer at the University of Toronto’s Hart House, where his presentation was broadcast by TVO for their Big Ideas series. He is a recipient of the prestigious Artist Prize from Toronto Friends of the Visual Arts, numerous grants at municipal, provincial, and federal levels, and a Chalmers Arts Fellowship from the Ontario Arts Council. Martindale was profiled for the first episode of CBC’s Great Minds of Design, and his works have been featured digitally and published in traditional media around the world in multiple languages. His works have been exhibited publicly in many cities across the globe.

Recently, Martindale was Harbourfront Centre’s inaugural Visual Artist-in-Residence, and alongside his collaborator JP King, was also the first Artist-in-Residence with the City of Toronto, Solid Waste Management Services.

-------------

•	While I continue to be interested in traditional mural forms, I am also excited to keep exploring other media/materials in the public realm, spearhead new practices, and explore diverse approaches to community engagement. As well, I am interested in potentially growing other areas of my practice, and taking on more roles in related areas such as project coordination, program development, and consulting.

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.

properties.artist_bio:
Ted Hamer is a multidisciplinary Artist and educator based in Toronto. His work explores the juxtaposition of nature with human constructs through explorations into challenging humanities anthropocentric views towards ourselves and our environment. He merges historical approaches to realist and modern art to explore the nature vs culture divide through figures that examine various overlapping themes of anthropocenterism using natural and man made elements and materials.
Ted's work has exhibited in the Art Gallery of Ontario, the Steamwhistle Gallery, the RMG, The Station Gallery, Nathan Phillips Square, Bluffs Gallery, the Super Wonder Gallery and his Sculptural Mural Installation is the centerpiece installation of the Aurora Cultural Centre in Aurora Ontario.

In paint I work with Aerosol and acrylic and Latex. In Sculpture I work in clays, fibreglass, resins, bronze and wood and am now experimenting with 3D printed pieces. I would like to work with StART to develop more street art that challenges the urban landscape with art based on nature and animals. My practice is moving more to the 3D side of things and I would like to work with StART to fabricate more street level sculptural pieces as I see the need for that in Toronto.
I have mentored many emerging artists but I feel I could use help in taking my own practice to the next level possibly through mentor ship or guidance from another artist.
I also coordinate creative projects and have worked previously with StART on the Outside the Box Program, with the Bell Box Murals Project and with the Aurora Cultural Centre facilitating workshops, designing and creating artwork and mentoring emerging artists.

Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. properties.artist_bio:
Visual Artist

Christiano De Araujo is a self-taught artist who was born in Anápolis, Goiás, Brazil. His earliest memory as a child is the moment when he discovered his love of art. As a toddler, he remembers picking up a crayon that his older sister had left behind. When she found that Christiano had taken it, she grabbed it away from him, but in that short amount of time, he had fallen in love with colours and the ability to create.

His love of art and his talent for the drawing were evident when he was a student in school. His first passion was comics and cartoons and at age 12 he drew his first comic strip.

In his late teens, Christiano began working for Brazil’s highly circulated newspaper, Diário da Manhã, doing editorial cartoons and illustrations. He also continued to work for other local newspapers and magazines. Realizing that he wanted more opportunities than he could have in Brazil, Christiano chose to immigrate to Canada.

His first years in Canada were a struggle. Early on, he landed a job as a Bricklayer, which he did for a number of years. Christiano confronted his weaknesses and discovered his strengths, learned to laugh at his hardships, quickly moving on. He was able to overcome any adversities with a determination to succeed and a desire to make himself a better man. This led to his artwork being published in numerous magazines and newspapers in Toronto.

He also credits his success to a spiritual awakening that he had through meditation and self-hypnosis. It gave him clarity and focus. This experience gave him more confidence and the ability to control his emotions and himself. Christiano devotes much of his life to his art. His endeavours include drawing, oil and acrylic painting, airbrushing, cartooning and sculpting. He is an artist by trade, finds art fun and likes to explore new media and innovated techniques.

Christiano currently resides in Toronto, Canada. He is the founder of Toronto Artists Studio, a studio of visual artists, painters, digital artists and sculptors who design and produce murals and visual communication projects for audiences on a small and grand scale.

At the present moment, this very moment… Christiano is enjoying the wonderful interaction between the mind and the universe. This infinite universe in which we are all one!
properties.title: Christiano De Araujo

properties.artist_bio:
After two mural-filled decades across Canada, the United States and Europe, Montreal-based Labrona greets any mural opportunity with StreetARToronto with much enthusiasm.

Labrona inserts beauty into everyday life with his artwork, without ignoring the grittiness of the places where he finds himself painting, resulting in a synergy between traditional beauty and worn-down everyday realities that brings new life to wherever he paints.

Labrona's polychromatic faces and animals defined by dark features stem from his fascination with, and desire to convey raw human emotion. Labrona envisions his approach to murals as a celebration of residents + visitors, and, of nature.  The multi-coloured palate inherent in Labrona’s work embraces community values of family, diversity, inclusion and helping others.

BIO:
Angel Carrillo started his art journey as an urban artist, project coordinator, educator, and one of Toronto’s well-known street artist. Angel has created art for Holt Renfrew, Athlete’s World, Bell, Telus, Campbell’s, Rogers, MTV, City of Toronto, the O.P.P., OCAD, and University of Toronto. He has been featured in Pound Magazine, The Globe and Mail, Toronto Sun, TorontoStar, Inside Toronto, Champ Magazine and on CityTV, CTV, and Global. He has taught urban arts workshops for events like Nuit Blanche, Manifesto and Style in Progress. Angel is also very active in community and outreach programs like Laser Eagles and events which he has helped run for the City of Toronto, Mural Route, Schools without Borders and YMCA. He is a frequent speaker at discussion panels for the city’s graffiti laws and the need for public art space and funding.

properties.artist_bio:
I have previously created a site specific wall painting for StreetArt and enjoyed the process and dynamic result. So, would love the opportunity to create in a different setting as my speciality is site specific installation that draws on the expanded field of painting.
Multi-media artist, Rolande Souliere is best known for her large-scale site specific immersive installations created from caution and street barrier tape to address how colonial infrastructures define, mark and control space and the inhabitants within them.
For a decade, Souliere has been working with material and metaphors of the road to address how systems, namely political and cultural systems inform, construct and impact personal and collective histories in contemporary society.

Utilising repetitive strategies of wrapping, binding and layering, Souliere’s artworks incorporate reflective road signage, automobile headlights and brake lights, GPS systems, construction vests and delineators. These universal materials are stripped from their usual contexts, manipulated and repurposed into dynamic installations that discuss narratives that shape our understanding of infrastructural intervention, economic expansion and growth with the oncoming of colonial settlement.

Souliere is a member of Michipicoten First Nation, born in Toronto, Canada and is an Australian citizen. Souliere became an artist after moving to Sydney in the late 1990s. She has a PhD from Sydney College of the Arts, University of Sydney.  A selection of Souliere’s international solo and group shows include Frequent Stopping III, IV and V (2018), Form and Content, Part I and II (2019) (2018), Indigenous Womxn Banner Project (2019), Future Memories (Present Tense) (2017),  Living Systems No. 2 (2017) and the touring cross Canada exhibition Beat Nation (2012-2014). Her public art commissions include Mediating the Treaties (2017-2018) commissioned by The City of Winnipeg, Frequent Stopping III for How far do you travel? (2018) with Translink BC and CAG, Vancouver and Bringing Back Wabakinine (2015) commissioned by City of Toronto.
properties.description: Souliere’s mural for the Bala Underpass uses the colour symbolism of the Four Directions (red, white, black and yellow) in a way that simultaneously evokes the culture and spirituality of First Peoples’ beadwork and the visual language of barricades, urban roadways and boundaries.
properties.title: Rolande Souliere

properties.artist_bio:
Enlivened by his interest in spacial structures and interconnectivity, Andre Kan's paintings serve as excitable blueprints for a possible reality. Each work depicts the artists' signature imaginative building blocks that converge and begin to build upon each other and strengthening each other towards an ever transforming space. Kan's structures are substantial and complex but not yet anchored - they float suspended in his psychological space. In this way Kan's buildings remain a playful proposition for the viewer not yet tied to a specific place or function. With his dynamic formations, Kan propels us towards an ever optimistic future where new connections and constructions have yet to materialize.

His current work investigates the architectural interpretations that respond to our ever advancing society, and suggests what 'possibility' means through self discovery. Examining what mark making and its properties mean, as well as the significance in cause and effect, is important here. Kan's psychological structures depict change and evolution of space, while also questioning the fundamental nature of being and the world that encompasses it.

Andre Kan is a Toronto based painter. Since graduating from the Ontario College of Art & Design University in 2014, he continues his creative pursuits as an Artist, Muralist, Photographer, Curator, Producer, and Musician. His paintings have been showcased throughout Canada with permanent collections in the U.S and China. His murals can also be seen internationally including London, Spain, Portugal and Taiwan.



Email: andrekanart@gmail.com
Instagram: andrekan_
Twitter: @andrekanart

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to continue working with StART because they support the creation of art that makes our public realm a more beautiful and inviting place. StART has helped me create meaningful work that strengthens communities and enables me to develop my practice of using art as a way to build inclusive communities who celebrate their identity with pride. I would like to develop my leadership skills and am interested in mentorship opportunities where I can learn how to work more effectively with the city to realize large scale initiatives that give more artists and community members opportunities to feel empowered through the process of creating art in the public realm.

I am a Toronto based visual artist, community organizer, muralist, curator, and eternal optimist. My work is motivated by my desire to spread joy, nurture present minded living, cultivate gratitude, and foster new social interactions from a place of love and empathy. Using aerosol and acrylic paint, I work with bright colours and bold patterns to captivate people’s attention and fill them with delight and hope. I am passionate about creating art that both aesthetically and psychologically brightens the streets and work to build a community around positive living.

My belief that public art is a powerful tool for building community drives my practice. In 2017, I founded Womxn Paint, an annual street art jam that has produced 44 murals celebrating the strength and diversity of womxn. I would like to continue this initiative and grow it to include additional programming that supports the professional development of womxn artists and more opportunities for young girls to learn about mural arts. In 2016, I facilitated an intergenerational mural at Baycrest Health Sciences and would like work more with the senior community.

Over the last six years, I have created custom large-scale outdoor artworks for clients including The New Yorker, Tourism Canada, the City of Toronto, the City of Mississauga, the Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany in Toronto, the STEPS Initiative, Arts Etobicoke, East End Arts and private clients.
properties.description: This piece reminds people that smiling is contagious. The bright colours and bold geometric pattern are eye catching and immediately uplifting. The positive message encourages people to engage with their neighbours and brings joy into what can sometimes be a hectic, overwhelming, stressful environment.

He has worked with StART on several occasions (Wall Expressions, Buddies in Bad Times, Outside the Box) and has helped to organized several independent art shows, workshops, and mural project in and around the GTA (annually since 2011). Andres has also volunteered with the Society of Estonian Artists in Toronto (EKKT) for the past decade, and also volunteers much of his time with organized Labour groups, all with the aim to celebrate & promote public art & public services.

properties.artist_bio: ‘Elicser’ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.
properties.title: Elicser

properties.artist_bio: Paula Gonzalez-Ossa is a mural artist who has been working with diverse communities producing street level public art, both in Canada and Latin America for over 25 years. Her ongoing work with StARToronto dates back to 2015. Her murals, like the most recent 500 ft. mural titled "Our Medicines"  located at the underpass at Dupont and Shaw, or "The Ancestral Tree Spirits" located at the Nordheimer Ravine's TTC station exit, depict a colourful  First Nations cosmovision in relation to the Original lands of Ontario, working closely with Anishnawbe  mentors, Elders and Knowledge Keepers. Gonzalez-Ossa is currently  the Indigenous Education Officer at the AGO’s Weston Learning Centre, as part of the Public Programming and Learning Department, and the Visual Arts instructor and mentoring artist at Na Me Res Sagatay Native Men's Residence. She brings 19 years experience as a  Community Youth Worker with youth at risk in Toronto's West.Some of her previous public works include: a 120 foot mural honoring First Nations from North and South America,  which was the recipient of  the 2014 Ward 27 City Builder’s Award, formerly at Allan Gardens. Other locations sport a ribbon-style mural at Women’s Residence, a women’s shelter at Dundas and Bathurst, in collaborations with an all women crew (2015), and a 4 wall rendition of the Medicine Wheel, inside of Na Me Res Sagatay’s courtyard (2016).  In sharp contrast she produced an indoor mural with 22 students from grades 6-8 at refugee host school Beverley Heights Middle School (2017).She recently served in the capacity of Resident Artist at the Power Plant gallery, developing mural arts programs at two satellite locations with youth from priority neighbouroods in Toronto’s West.(2017-2018). In 2018-2019 she worked closely with the 7Th Generation Image Makers at the Native Youth Resource Centre to mentor, facilitate and produce a mural with an all Indigenous women’s team, located  at the South facing wall at Christie Pits Park’s Alex Duff Memorial Pool. Her two most recent productions  funded by StART’s Partnership Grant in 2019,located at the front façade of Sagatay Naïve Men’s Residence, and the adjacent alley,  depict  “Medicines and Guardians”, as well as “The Wolves Running South”.Last but not least, Gonzalez-Ossa is one of the featured artists at the “You’ve Changed “ exhibit by STARToronto , at St Lawrence Market’s  “Market Gallery”. At the exhibit, the video display shows us her latest short documentary produced  for SART, about the basic protocols entailed when developing images in partnership with Indigenous Nations here in Canada.Gonzalez-Ossa  has been  voted Best Graffiti Artist for the City of Toronto by Now Magazine’s Reader’s Poll in 1997, in 2009, 2010, and 2011. In addition, she has been featured on  CBC (Radio and Television, varying shows), Much Music, MTV, Global Televison, City TV, TVO, CTV, Bell Fibe TV1, Rogers Television, and Telelatino, as well as various television  appearances in Chile, USA (NYC/California), and Jamaica.
properties.description: The murals on all sides of the field house in Wells Hill Park illustrate the four seasons of life (childhood, adolescence, adulthood, elder) and identifies the park as a First Nations-friendly space, where residents and all community members can come to nature.
properties.title: Paula Gonzalez-Ossa (Bomba)

properties.artist_bio: Amir Akbari is a Greater Toronto Area (GTA) based Visual Artist, Educator, Community Advocate and Entrepreneur.   In 2002, he enrolled in OCAD University where he would go on to complete a Bachelors of Fine Arts with a focus on Drawing and Painting.  In 2003, Amir led his first community mural art project working with Urban Art Toronto.  The following year, he took on his first role with Street Art (then Graffiti Transformation Project) as the lead artist with Lamp Community Health Centre.  That project would be a launching pad for his eventual artistic and professional career.From 2003 to 2010 Amir continued to work with various community organizations and charities as an artist facilitator, youth works and educator.  He would go onto complete over 30 public murals throughout this time, working with and mentoring hundreds of youth across the GTA.In 2010 Amir founded Behind the Line with the purpose of providing existing support structures within the community with creative and artistic support.  Behind the Line has since worked closely with multiple organizations to enhance their arts programming and creative reach, from curriculum development, programming consultation and arts integration strategies.In the summer of 2019, Amir completed his largest mural production, the Susan Street Mural at 3847 Lawrence Ave. East.  This would be his 6th Street Art Partnership Project with the Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough and his 3rd partnership with Toronto Community Housing.  The large 14 story mural is the crowning achievement of his artistic journey as a community and mural artist.  Focused on creating designs that reflect, represent and inspire the communities that he is working with, this mural is a celebration of the collaborative and uplifting nature of public murals funded by Street Art Toronto.His work is rooted in the belief that self-expression can have a lasting impact on the development and growth of young people and their communities, and that there is a disproportional disadvantage across the board for those that face multiple barriers with accessing the arts.   He hopes to fill this void through innovative arts strategies, collaborative mural projects and local community partnerships.
properties.description: Inspired by the idea of creating an urban street gallery this mural complements the art work on the opposite side wall painted the previous year.  Lead artists Amir Akbari and Joshua Clark also trained local youth in the process of creating vibrant works of art.
properties.organizations: Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough
properties.title: Amir Akbari

properties.artist_bio:
I am a “maximalist” painter and believe “more is more” in art. I've been fortunate to be able to use art as a catalyst for community building and healing over the past decade plus, leading art groups for marginalized people, and creating large scale murals with youth in our community.

The first art movements that spoke to me were Surrealism, Expressionism, Graffiti and current street art. I usually hide a subtext within my work, that hints at broader social issues, but for the most part hope the viewer draws their own conclusions, creating a “choose your own adventure” story. No colours, patterns, or materials are off limits, and I enjoy mixing bits of history with comments on our digital, disposable, society.

Colour, texture, experimentation, and a sense of humour, are at the forefront of my creations.

My primary medium is acrylic based paints and treatments, due to flexible, resilient, and quick drying properties. I find acrylics span a range of price points and are accessible to all age groups. I have had success with acrylics for outdoor murals as they have good longevity and low VOC. I have also had success using an anti graffiti top coat, to remove the inevitable tags that show up once a mural is completed!

Born in Toronto, I was an avid sketcher and fashion designer, as a child. As a youth I spent most summers teaching arts and crafts to children.

I completed a Bachelor of Arts in Sociology from U of T and a diploma from OCAD in drawing and painting. In my third year I was selected for off campus study in Florence, Italy. I built a unique style of painting, which encompasses raw energy, and an eclectic approach to colour and material.
I settled in Berlin for a few months, inspired by the street art and Expressionist tradition. Upon graduation I worked in a Harm Reduction program for youth, and a treatment centre creating art with adults with complex disabilities.

I have continued to work with social service agencies in Toronto, using art as a tool for communication, healing, and strengthening community.

I completed several community mural projects, including two youth engagement, street art mural projects.

After my beloved mother died in 2017, I found it difficult to paint, and focused more on music production and performance. She was very proud of my mural work with youth, and I hope to pick this work back up in her honour.

Working with StART again, would allow me to continue to beautify our city, and continue to use art to promote inclusion, diversity, pride, and youth leadership. My past mural projects contained outward messages and representations of our city as a welcoming place that celebrates differences, and every type of human being, with all ranges of abilities reflected through art.

I also bring a style which is fun and painterly and encourages community participation, weaving the style of other participants, into an overall cohesive design.
properties.description: Developed in collaboration with students at Etobicoke Collegiate Institute and residents of the nearby Delmanor Seniors Residence this mural is inspired by the part of the Amnesty International Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
properties.title: Barri Biederman

properties.artist_bio:
Dan Bergeron is a public artist who employs a range of styles, themes and materials to activate and explore the meaning of our shared public spaces. The shape, texture and location of a site and its history or current uses dictate the form and content of his projects. Dan’s public installations aim to open a dialog with viewers, promoting engagement through both intimate familiarity and wonder at the unexpected.

Dan has created public art projects for municipalities across Canada (Toronto, Mississauga, Ottawa, Gaspe, Calgary, Richmond), working in both two-dimensional mediums (murals, photo-based wheat pasting) and three dimensional sculpture. He has also been commissioned by the AGO, MOCA Toronto, the ROM and corporate clients Nike, Converse and Vespa.
properties.description: These landmark multi-wall murals across two 12 and 14 story towers are a symbol of positive change within the  Kingston-Galloway community that complement the Pan Am Path, an 80KM multi-use trail connecting across the city.
properties.organizations: Friends of the Pan Am Path
properties.title: Dan Bergeron, Gabriel Specter

properties.artist_bio:
Ted Hamer is a multidisciplinary Artist and educator based in Toronto. His work explores the juxtaposition of nature with human constructs through explorations into challenging humanities anthropocentric views towards ourselves and our environment. He merges historical approaches to realist and modern art to explore the nature vs culture divide through figures that examine various overlapping themes of anthropocenterism using natural and man made elements and materials.
Ted's work has exhibited in the Art Gallery of Ontario, the Steamwhistle Gallery, the RMG, The Station Gallery, Nathan Phillips Square, Bluffs Gallery, the Super Wonder Gallery and his Sculptural Mural Installation is the centerpiece installation of the Aurora Cultural Centre in Aurora Ontario.

In paint I work with Aerosol and acrylic and Latex. In Sculpture I work in clays, fibreglass, resins, bronze and wood and am now experimenting with 3D printed pieces. I would like to work with StART to develop more street art that challenges the urban landscape with art based on nature and animals. My practice is moving more to the 3D side of things and I would like to work with StART to fabricate more street level sculptural pieces as I see the need for that in Toronto.
I have mentored many emerging artists but I feel I could use help in taking my own practice to the next level possibly through mentor ship or guidance from another artist.
I also coordinate creative projects and have worked previously with StART on the Outside the Box Program, with the Bell Box Murals Project and with the Aurora Cultural Centre facilitating workshops, designing and creating artwork and mentoring emerging artists.
properties.description: Created as part of a Toronto Community Housing (TCH) “ReSet” pilot program to renew aging buildings this mural 'Community Connections”, developed in partnership with residents establishes a welcoming, colorful and beautiful entrance.
properties.title: Ted Hamer, Brad Nechifresh

properties.artist_bio: Jim Bravo was born in Ecuador, South America in 1973. He is a graduate of The Ontario College of Art and Design University where he majored in Fine Art and studied monumental & public art. Bravo has been active in the street/public art arena since his 2006 graduation, completing several city-funded murals and an array of community engagement art projects.  Through his affiliation with various local arts organizations he has gained vast experience as an arts mentor for at-risk youth initiatives. Bravo is a 4 time award winning painter and muralist and he lives and works in the city of Toronto, I'm a Toronto-based fine artist, illustrator and mural artist. I'm very inspired by the things around me, and the people in my life. I utilize a lot of different mediums into my art practice such as oils, acrylics, watercolour, ink, graphite, spray paint and exterior latex paint. I have been involved in various community-led projects, private and commercial mural commissions. The most impactful projects that I've been apart of, have led me to mentor youth artists and that has been the most rewarding part of those projects. An extension of youth mentorship, I'm also the Artist-in-Residence at Waterfront Neighbourhood Centre. I instruct Room 13, an international Studio that guides a growing network of student-run arts studios in schools and community settings globally. In the past few years, I have been apart of numerous Bell Box Murals Project throughout the city as well as START Outside the Box in 2018.
properties.description: The murals by lead artist Jim Thierry Bravo with students from Marshall McLuhan Catholic Secondary School revitalized the field house in Eglinton Park, a familiar historical landmark that had fallen into a state of disrepair due to weathering, structural damage, and recurring vandalism.
properties.title: Jim Bravo, Lula Lunaj

properties.artist_bio: I've been painting murals since 1992. I have extensive experience designing, planning and painting interior and exterior murals. My design for the Gasworks outdoor mural competition judged by MURAD won 1st prize. (The design is on my website) I've worked in enamel and latex for restaurants, nightclubs, private residences, Parkdale Business Improvement Association, The Second City Theatre, Crescent School, Nuit Blanche 2019 etc. As a Canadian muralist of Mexican descent, my influences are Diego Rivera, Orozco, Tamayo and especially Siqueiros. I'm also a caricature artist, so my approach is a combination of humor and surrealism. I really enjoy working with the local community, incorporating their ideas into my mural design. See my website for examples of past mural work.

properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Toronto, I am a champion of this city. My work often depicts Toronto life - people, events and elements connected to the region. I have witnessed many changes and struggles in neighborhoods throughout the city and have contributed to developing community strength through several art projects.
I choose to create art that can be seen and appreciated by the public, free and accessible to anyone - bringing beauty to dingy, neglected areas of town. I enjoy working with communities to engage them in the process of change, establish personal connections and develop a sense of pride in their neighborhood.
My goal is to work on a larger scale projects with StART. I would like to be mentored/assisted in the use of aerosol painting as well as high murals requiring a lift. Working with StART, I would love to work with an Indigenous artist/group on a co-operative project to learn, exchange information and cultural practices. Indigenous art including Woodland style, Inuit sculpture, drawing and printmaking, are my favourite styles of art.
My artwork also addresses environmental concerns/issues; reminding us that everything has a purpose, even when it is not clear to us, what that is. I often find inspiration in ecology, the environment and site-specific surroundings the mural will be in. Figures, the body, and movement are recurring themes in my art.
As well as being a painter, I have been a professional photographer for over 25 years, creating images digitally as well as on film. Previously, I was the Resident Photography Artist at Mississauga Living Art Centre. While working at the TDSB, I was honoured to photograph Nelson Mandela on his first visit to Toronto. I collaborated with teachers and students on several art projects including a handmade book given to Mr. Mandela.
I am experienced in photographing events, fine art documentation, portraits, dance and theatre, products, buildings, magazine and commercial work. I also create digital designs including Op Art, tile patterns, floral, abstract; web design, preparing/repurposing images for web, email and print.
Materials and mediums I work with include photography, acrylic and latex paint, acrylic markers, aerosol paint, clay, wood and collage.

I have graduated from 3 art programs: Central Technical School Adult Art Program, Ryerson Still Photography and Humber College Audio/Visual Technology. As a multidisciplinary artist, my unique combination of art and technology skills brings strength of understanding to all my projects. Working as a full-time artist and art educator, I teach painting, drawing, ceramics, mixed media and photography throughout the GTA, to seniors, adults and children.

properties.artist_bio: Through his artistic journey Rob Matejka has embraced art as a medium for positive social intervention and enjoys animating the communities and people he works with - making art accessible to all through; workshops, mentoring, and adding to the growing outdoor public gallery. Rob has been an arts educator and mentor for over 12 years - having worked with organizations across Toronto such as; Lakeshore Arts, Mural Routes, TDSB, The Toronto Public Library, VIBE Arts, and more. Rob enjoys using murals to create spaces we enter and experience physically - while coordinating large scale projects engaging large numbers of community members to beautify communities and build community pride.
properties.description: Created in partnership with Cultural Hotspots and North York Arts, "Connections Mural" enhances the streetscape and provides a welcoming, colourful visual place maker for local residents and commuters travelling through this busy area.
properties.title: Rob Matejka

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.

properties.artist_bio:
Sean Martindale is an internationally recognized, award winning interdisciplinary artist and designer based in Toronto, Canada. His interventions activate public spaces to encourage engagement, and often focus on ecological and social issues. His playful works suggest alternate possibilities for existing spaces, infrastructures, and materials found in urban environments. Frequently, he uses salvaged goods in unexpected ways that prompt conversation.

Among other notable projects, he was the lead artist on the Community Rising, the tallest mural in the world from 2013 to 2018 (now the second tallest), the result of a community project in St James Town, Toronto, with local youth, STEPS and the Toronto Muralists. Martindale has been the lead artist for a number of the GTA’s largest mural projects. He continues to work closely with communities and organizations big and small; including partners such as Harbourfront Centre, the Art Gallery of Ontario, and the City of Toronto.

Martindale holds an MFA from the Interdisciplinary Masters of Art, Media and Design program at OCAD University in Toronto, and a BDes in Communication Design from Emily Carr University in Vancouver. He was the Decennial Hancock Lecturer at the University of Toronto’s Hart House, where his presentation was broadcast by TVO for their Big Ideas series. He is a recipient of the prestigious Artist Prize from Toronto Friends of the Visual Arts, numerous grants at municipal, provincial, and federal levels, and a Chalmers Arts Fellowship from the Ontario Arts Council. Martindale was profiled for the first episode of CBC’s Great Minds of Design, and his works have been featured digitally and published in traditional media around the world in multiple languages. His works have been exhibited publicly in many cities across the globe.

Recently, Martindale was Harbourfront Centre’s inaugural Visual Artist-in-Residence, and alongside his collaborator JP King, was also the first Artist-in-Residence with the City of Toronto, Solid Waste Management Services.

-------------

•	While I continue to be interested in traditional mural forms, I am also excited to keep exploring other media/materials in the public realm, spearhead new practices, and explore diverse approaches to community engagement. As well, I am interested in potentially growing other areas of my practice, and taking on more roles in related areas such as project coordination, program development, and consulting.

The mural boldly demonstrates the capacity and ability of people of all ages to contribute meaningfully and artistically to the streets of Toronto.

properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Toronto, I have been a full-time professional mural artist for over 27 years. My mural career includes works for private, commercial, corporate clients, educational institutions and public art projects. One highlight of my career was working with acclaimed American artist Frank Stella as the Studio Manager for his studios in Toronto, New York and Houston, Texas. During this time the studio created large scale mixed media murals based on Mr. Stella’s paper collages.
These works were commissioned by international galleries and museums from Japan to Germany and included Torontoʼs Princess of Wales Theatre.

I have worked with the StART team on several large scale projects and I have always been impressed with all of the support and encouragement that this program cultivates.  From the beginning, it was apparent how much the program focuses on bringing together artists and communities to create a lasting positive experience for all.  During the production of both my Park Lawn Underpass Mural and the Lake Shore Cycle Track Barrier Murals, I received an overwhelming amount of positive feedback and response from the individuals driving, biking, riding and walking by these public pieces of art.  So much of an artists' time is spent creating a piece of artwork alone in the studio.  The StART program allows for an "on the spot" engagement with the community during the development of a mural.  For me, this is the most rewarding part of these murals.  I am proud to bring my artistic vision to these public works of art through the StART program for all to enjoy no matter what their background, social status or familiarity with a traditional gallery/museum setting.
properties.description: Iin a palette that suggests a vintage feel, the mural's whimsical Pop Art collage approach includes a nod to the Mr. Christie's Cookie Factory Water Tower, the Humber Bay School first established in 1888, and the 1950's style motels which once lined Toronto's lakeshore, including a graphic element from the neon signage from the former Seahorse Motel.
properties.title: Cindy Scaife

properties.artist_bio:
SPUD1 has been a fixture in the Toronto urban and underground art scene for more than 18 years. An accomplished artist, he loves the thrill of finding unconventional spaces to showcase his talent.
SPUD1’s passion for art has grown along with his talent. He is a well-rounded artist that is capable of working with all types of mediums and images, and specializes in working collaboratively with other artists.
SpudBomb was founded by SPUD1 in 2010, when he traveled across Europe, covering many cities with his funny and happy SpudBomb characters and happy Grenades.
Team SpudBomb is comprised of Spud1 & his partner Brooke, together they curate and manage various artists projects and large scale murals, both collaboratively and on behalf of Spud1 himself.
Since 2014 Team SpudBomb – working under the event Wall Expressions; has been working in partnership and fully funded through StART to curate Laneway events that help to create live outdoor galleries in laneways that experience graffiti vandalism.  These events allow the community and artist to engage and reclaim public spaces, and create conversation about art and how it can serve the neighbourhood/community when incorporate in public spaces.
In 2016 SPUD1 was one of the featured artists in the Doors Open Toronto colouring book and was successful in his grant application with the Bloordale BIA to install a huge mural within that community, which has been exceptionally well received, and working with brands such as CAT, Converse, Mountain Dew, Universal Studios, and Crystal Head Vodka. In addition to this, his installation of the Pride Mural at Church and Wood received a special award for his dedication and activism in the TPS & StART Toronto partnership program.
In 2017 Spud completed a huge Mural called the Smile on Dufferin, the ribbon cutting and mural unveiling was opened by city councilor & Deputy Mayor Ana Bailao.
In 2018 Spud1 and Sean Martindale completed the mural “Tapestry of Movement at the Toronto Coach Terminal through the City’s StART partnership program with STEPS Initiative, and saw him working with brands such as Sketchers.
In 2019  Team Spudbomb was awarded a partnership Grant through the City of Toronto to paint an over 2,000 square foot underpass, an invitation to paint a large mural at Concrete canvas festival in Hamilton and a request to paint at Kotis Street Art in Greensboro, North Carolina.
These are just a few examples throughout the past 6 years where Spud1 has exemplified the type of artist he is, one which continually sees markets, festivals, other artists and brands wanting to work with him in addition to Team Spudbomb continuing to work with old school and emerging talents to bring together events that foster community engagements and relationships.
SPUD1’s dedication and commitment to seeing the projects he is involved in through is only overshadowed by his installations themselves.
SPUD1 continues to grow and evolve as an artist and is always looking for new and exciting opportunities to express himself and showcase his art., SPUD1 has been a fixture in the Toronto urban and underground art scene for more than 18 years. Spudbomb

properties.artist_bio: Rachel Wilmshurst is a Toronto-based multidisciplinary artist who has studied graphic design, painting & illustration with professional experience in a wide variety of art & design based roles. Skilled in fine art technique as well as digital processes, Rachel’s projects have included mural painting, public art installation and gallery exhibitions as well as illustration and graphic design for a growing list of local and international clients.Rachel's background in graphic design and fine art have collectively informed her style which is simultaneously geometric and organic. She uses a combination of brushed acrylic, aerosol and paint markers to achieve a tapestry of shape & colour, representing elements of the surrounding environment and what makes it special.
properties.description: The artist has incorporated what they consider to be three key mainstays to the progress of a community - peace, learning and love. Peace is illustrated through the hand gesture, love is depicted by the heart on the index finger and learning is portrayed by the building blocks on the sides.
properties.title: Rachel Wilmshurst

properties.description: The design is based on rug hooking and pixel art. The joy of the colour and patterning would contribute to a greater of well being in the community.

properties.artist_bio:
I want to work with StART because the projects I have completed with Street Art Toronto's help have been not only the most enjoyable projects I have worked on in my career, but also the most lucrative for me, in terms of both payment and scale of exposure. I learn something new on every project we do together and working with StART staff has taught me virtually everything I know about what goes into publicly-funded street art projects, all the moving parts that need to be accounted for, communicating with the public, coordinating materials and other artists, publicity, etc. I want to keep building on this knowledge and skill set as we continue to spread colourful mural projects into new parts of the city/GTA.

Bio:
Nick Sweetman is a multidisciplinary artist from Toronto whose practice has explored painting and its intersection with photography, video, installation, mixed media, and urban intervention. He has exhibited in galleries around Toronto since 2011, completing his MFA in 2014 from OCAD University in the Interdisciplinary Art, Media & Design program. He received a certificate from the Mural Routes Leadership Training in Mural-Making program the same year and since then has been working in public space on mural projects, often in collaboration with other artists, and in partnership with various non-profit organizations (David Suzuki Foundation, The STEPS Initiative) as well as Street Art Toronto. He has successfully managed many large-scale projects both independently and as lead artist over a team of volunteers, from children up to adults. He has dedicated many projects to raising awareness about the importance of pollinators, bees and butterflies in particular, from painting giant bees towering over busy city streets to coordinating 30 or more artists to paint butterflies on garages in Toronto's laneways. Most recently, Nick has been working abroad, participating in the Eureka Street Art Festival in Humboldt County, California as well as contributing a mural to the Bondi Beach Sea Wall in Sydney, Australia.

properties.artist_bio: Andres Musta (B.Ed.., B. Arch.) is a public school visual arts specialist teacher with a passion for street art, especially stickers and murals. He has worked with StART on several occasions (Wall Expressions, Buddies in Bad Times, Outside the Box) and has helped to organized several independent art shows, workshops, and mural project in and around the GTA (annually since 2011). Andres has also volunteered with the Society of Estonian Artists in Toronto (EKKT) for the past decade, and also volunteers much of his time with organized Labour groups, all with the aim to celebrate & promote public art & public services.

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to work with StART because I am interested in beautifying the cityscape with more public artwork. I would like to learn from and better my practices through the partnerships and opportunities that StART may be able to provide.

I am a freelance illustrator and mural painter based in Toronto. I like being outside. I like to move my body and to work with my hands. I enjoy working with people who share similar ideas and interests in food growing, environmental stewardship and getting outside. Some of the organizations I have worked with include: Greenest City, Urbane Cyclist, Mountain Equipment Co-op and Green Thumbs Growing Kids. I use bright hues and bold line work to create botanical patterns and compositions depicting moments of self-reflection.

My murals can be found across Toronto, in Indonesia, Nepal, Philippines and Hong Kong. I often collaborate with other artists–my most frequent collaborator being Andrea Manica–as well as with the Buck Teeth Girls Club.
properties.description: This design depicts two children discovering the natural world within their cityscape.

properties.artist_bio: Rodrigo Castro, aka “Bomi" was born in León, Mexico and is now based in Toronto. His artwork is highly representative of his Latin American culture and boasts colourful patterns, symbols, and geometric shapes through his distinctive minimalistic style.
properties.description: The design will contribute to a sense of identity in the local community because the work reflects a universal visual language through the use of patterns, symbols, hieroglyphs, geometry and colours that have existed across many cultures since the earliest cave drawings and images created by man. The designs are open to interpretation from each person who views them, allowing for a highly personal experience.

properties.description: This mural captures a sense of surrealism and absurdity though a group of bizarre creatures that aspire to brighten peoples’ day. This mural intends to make people laugh, and bring humor to their lives.

properties.artist_bio: Pam Lostracco is a Toronto mural artist and graphic designer. Her work forms connections with the local environment that create a sense of identity and belonging for those who live and work here. By integrating unique and diverse natural, cultural and historical influences, she transforms blank walls into inclusive and stunning spaces. She designs each mural with visual aesthetics that are familiar to a particular community, inviting people to engage in an uplifting and meaningful experience.
properties.description: Toronto Maze Map is an informativ overview of some of Toronto's green spaces and an interactive game to discover and identify with the city. The "You Are Here" marks the exact location or the painted box. The viewer must walk around all sides of the box to solve the puzzle, giving the sense of discovery while "traveling" through the map.
properties.title: Pam Lostracco

properties.artist_bio:
Graffiti and the various channels the practice exists in has allowed me find self, community and financial independence. To me, this world-culture is one of great value not only to individuals but also the larger community. I want to do all I can to participate in the production and instruction of this movement because of the freedom and joy that it can spread. My goals with StART would be to continue my Swirling of the city, help mentor young artists and create positive change in the community through the creation of large scale works/events, hopefully making our great city a hub for artistry in the light of this global movement.

BIO:
Flips is a Toronto based multi-media artist, life enthusiast and visual storyteller.
Inspired by the blending of cultural forces seen in Toronto and his homeland of Bulgaria, Flips’ focus is on promoting and celebrating world cultures and connectivity amongst people. His motto is that art has the power to unite people and aims to create works that inspire and instill this message.

Flips is best known in the streets of Toronto for his signature Swirl Style, which reflects the philosophy of unity through art in the swirling of color and line. Mirroring life, the Flips Swirl Clusters represent the state of flux that exists in life; a beautiful mess of movement and energy. At the heart of each swirl cluster exists a circle that represents the individual soul, linked to others through infinite ties. A grouping of swirls signifies a strong presence of community, creativity, and care.
properties.description: The artist's signature style lives in the swirling of line and colour. Mirroring life, the swirls represent the state of flux that life exists as. A beautiful mess of movement and energy. Represented by the circles in the middle, are people, all linked together through infinite ties.
properties.title: Ross (Flips) Iaydjiev

properties.artist_bio:
I have been painting and drawing my whole life. I started, according to my mother, at age 4. She still has a great little ship drawing I did at that age. Drawing came easy to me but I had to work hard to be a good painter - I’m still working. Painting for me is a process of meditation; it’s a constant pursuit to describe the mental landscape as influenced by its surroundings.
	As well as painting, I work as a photographer, shooting everything from events, editorials, and sometimes celebrities. My grandfather was an avid amateur photographer and gave me my first camera at a young age. Photography and painting have always gone hand in hand for me. One feeds the other. Photography as a tool has been employed by painters and artists since its invention. One could make a strong case that the advent of photography could not have been achieved without the help of painting and classical tools such as the camera obscura to help painters recreate scenes. I use photography in this way, creating images from reference subjects I capture.
	My work is an ongoing process. I try not to just do one thing, I don’t think standing still and producing one product time and time again is a good thing. An artist has to be careful to not let their work become stale.
 	1950s abstract expressionism is my jam. The New York school was a big influence on me as a young artist, but also the Montreal scene. The artist Jean-Paul Riopelle and Paul Emile Borduas were heroes of mine. Leader of the Automatistes and main author of the manifesto Refus Global, Borduas broke from all convention. I remember vividly seeing L’étoile Noir in person when I was young and being blown away by its bold simplicity. The surrealists also had a profound impact on my practice - specifically Dali for his character and brashness. His ambitious paintings and tight style always impressed  and humbled me.  H.R. Giger and Francis Bacon are also worth mentioning. Both artists’ approaches to painting were violent, sexual, and graphic. Food for the young artist.
	The world is too interesting to not reflect on. The sublime and terrifying are always in front of us and we often have to ignore them to get on with our day. I like to allow my paintings to shape themselves in my mind. The painting comes to life on its own, almost independently of the creator. That’s often where the satisfaction comes from - surpassing your expectations and vision. The opposite is also true, and depressing. The failed painting can often take weeks or months to get over.

properties.artist_bio:
Al “Runt” Currie is an iconic Canadian artist, with impressive works displayed both a home and internationally. His works are vibrant, colourful, abstract and fun, full of life and imagination, and accessible by people of all ages. His strong connection to Canada and, in particular, Toronto, is demonstrated by his works displayed, including Lee's Palace. At another recent internationally-recognized event, Runt was invited to represent Canada’s art scene as artistic lead for the International Fortune 500 event, held in September 2018, at Toronto’s Evergreen Brick Works, where he completed numerous art works including a 40-foot mural for an audience, comprised of international industry titans, policy and thought leaders, as well as Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.
What Critics Have Said…:
“Enter the world of Runt. At once familiar and unfamiliar, his works are of this world but definitely not of this world. Informed by a wide range of influences from Hieronymus Bosch to Dr. Seuss, Runt’s work embodies a love and critique of humanity as his monster scene-scapes play out in front of the viewer’s eyes. If one could press “play” on any of his scenes and advance them, the scenes would look entirely different. Runt’s characters capture the joy and aggression of our urban existence. But the beauty in Runt’s works is that they don't judge, they simply present. Known for his large murals, Lee’s Palace and The Electric Mud BBQ, Runt’s art is found in many private collections. Runt’s passionate adventure has turned into a career as one of Canada’s singular visionaries, on par with other 80s icons such as Keith Haring and Kenny Scharf.”
Runt is interested in participating in the StArt project, as he looks forward to continuing his contributions to the Toronto arts scene and community, sharing his experiences and expertise with other artists while also learning from them.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Alex Currie (Runt)

properties.artist_bio: I would love to continue my involvement for StART because I love creating work for my city! My work is happy and Toronto-centric, every piece I create is aimed to make the community smile, laugh, and think. After 5 years of doing street art and illustration full-time, I’ve been lucky enough to have the opportunity to travel and bring my Toronto raccoon murals around the world, but this will always be my favourite place to make art. I hope to up my scale this year and bring more colour into our already vibrant communities.
properties.description: The traffic box is transformed into a historic Toronto low-rise apartment building. Throughout the windows and fire escpaes I have a gang of everyone's facourite Toronto mascot - racoons, of course - climbing around and causing mischief, as they do.
properties.title: Emily May Rose

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.
properties.description: The artist would like to touch on the importance of what it means to be Canadian and how our cultural heritage and background contribute to the ever growing Canadian landscape and identity.
