properties.artist_bio:
Early on, I perceived that my ambition was the act of painting itself, finding that the process coincided with the workings of my conscious and unconscious mind.Throughout my career I have also been fascinated by realism, specifically trompe l’oeil and it’s ability to affect the viewer. I have been creating trompe l’oeil murals in combination with my abstract works for over 20 years now. It has become for me a way to connect with the viewer on several different levels. I have discovered that painting illusions allows me to communicate with a larger audience, as people genuinely delighted when visually tricked. While both painting techniques claim to express reality truthfully, either suggests only a partial or incomplete view of a subject.
I am also extremely interested in the archival quality of work and how public art is produced, in an ethical and archival way. I have painted murals that are still on display over 20 years later. I feel that viewers of public work have an investment in the upkeep and archival quality of the work. Starting with the proper preparation, the production process should be considered when producing public art. When public art pieces become worn and decay after only a few seasons the public does not see the value in continuing to fund public art. Having worked for several years of trial and error I feel that I could offer proper preparation advice to many of the public art projects.
properties.title: Margaret Cresswell

properties.artist_bio:
Marley Allen-Ash is an illustrator and artist working in Toronto, Canada. She uses traditional printmaking and digital media to create illustrations and explore both historical and personal narratives.  In addition to illustration, she enjoys work on murals and self publishing comics with her collective, Grab Bag Club.  She studied at OCAD University, completing a bachelor of design and majoring in illustration. Her illustration work has been recognized by American Illustration, 3x3 Magazine and Creative Quarterly. Selected Clients include The Globe and Mail, CANADALAND, Cottage Life and Lenny Letter.

I have worked with StART before, through the Lakeshore Bike Lane Murals, Concrete Barrier Art Program, and Outside the Box. I'd love to be involved in more group and individual mural projects, such as laneway mural projects or painting underpasses. I'm really open to any type of opportunity, though in the past I've worked with exterior latex paint for murals, as well as creating digital files to be printed and used as vinyl wraps.
properties.title: Marley Allen Ash

properties.description: The design deals with how personal experience forms our identity. The faces sit pieced togeted side-by-side, like personalities which up the prts of our city lives. They rest against each other, but don't interfere with each other. The image is a metaphore for neighbourhood community as it exists in the city.
properties.title: Darren De Genova (Mr Hydde)

properties.artist_bio:
Enlivened by his interest in spacial structures and interconnectivity, Andre Kan's paintings serve as excitable blueprints for a possible reality. Each work depicts the artists' signature imaginative building blocks that converge and begin to build upon each other and strengthening each other towards an ever transforming space. Kan's structures are substantial and complex but not yet anchored - they float suspended in his psychological space. In this way Kan's buildings remain a playful proposition for the viewer not yet tied to a specific place or function. With his dynamic formations, Kan propels us towards an ever optimistic future where new connections and constructions have yet to materialize.

His current work investigates the architectural interpretations that respond to our ever advancing society, and suggests what 'possibility' means through self discovery. Examining what mark making and its properties mean, as well as the significance in cause and effect, is important here. Kan's psychological structures depict change and evolution of space, while also questioning the fundamental nature of being and the world that encompasses it.

Andre Kan is a Toronto based painter. Since graduating from the Ontario College of Art & Design University in 2014, he continues his creative pursuits as an Artist, Muralist, Photographer, Curator, Producer, and Musician. His paintings have been showcased throughout Canada with permanent collections in the U.S and China. His murals can also be seen internationally including London, Spain, Portugal and Taiwan.



Email: andrekanart@gmail.com
Instagram: andrekan_
Twitter: @andrekanart
properties.description: The design depicts busy, fast paced cargo boxes implementing forward movement and change. The bright colours are meant to be inviting for the viewer and its architectural qualities subtly reference Toronto architecture.
properties.title: Andre Kan

properties.description: Tthe murals remind everyone to treat surrounding wildlife with dignity and respect by giving residents the opportunity to engage with their environment more closely. The mural aims to fulfill the same goal by depicting only plant and animal life native to the area. The artist's illustrative, character-based works depict the creatures of his imagined world, in which they appear frozen and in mid-mission. With the artist's use of three-dimensional views and deep shadows, a convincing atmosphere is evoked within this fantastical world.
properties.title: Drew Mosley

properties.description: The design is done in the classic Ukrainian "Petrykivka" art style featuring a variety of intricate decorative elements inspired by nature. This box design would be instantly recognizable by anyone with Eastern European roots, but could also be appreciated by all Torontonians due to its vibrant colour scheme.
properties.title: Anna Bucciarelli

properties.description: The design touches on a modern timeless twist of art history incorporating industrial and environmental elements - a total machine age beauty.
properties.title: Courtney Binns

properties.description: For six months of the year it is hard to see variety of colours around the city. Colours are associated to happiness, movement, emotions. These feelings are meant to be given to others through the colour of this mural.
properties.title: Christian Castelblanco

properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: David “Meggs” Hooke & Kevin Ledo

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Mediah (Evond)

properties.description: This design was inspired by the flora and fauna of the city – the hardy pigeons that are seen every day, and the cherry blossoms in High Park that fill the spring with joy. The beautiful nature within Toronto was captured within the design, in the hopes that it fills people with joy and respect for the animals and plants we coexist with.
properties.title: Aisha Ali

properties.description: Toronto is raccoon city. We live together, we share, we fight and we have a grudging respect of each other. But Toronto's unofficial symbol is lacking form the body of woodland style art. The box represents the location of one of the artist's first encounters with Toronto's secondary population.
properties.title: Paul Hollingsworth

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to continue working with StART because they support the creation of art that makes our public realm a more beautiful and inviting place. StART has helped me create meaningful work that strengthens communities and enables me to develop my practice of using art as a way to build inclusive communities who celebrate their identity with pride. I would like to develop my leadership skills and am interested in mentorship opportunities where I can learn how to work more effectively with the city to realize large scale initiatives that give more artists and community members opportunities to feel empowered through the process of creating art in the public realm.

I am a Toronto based visual artist, community organizer, muralist, curator, and eternal optimist. My work is motivated by my desire to spread joy, nurture present minded living, cultivate gratitude, and foster new social interactions from a place of love and empathy. Using aerosol and acrylic paint, I work with bright colours and bold patterns to captivate people’s attention and fill them with delight and hope. I am passionate about creating art that both aesthetically and psychologically brightens the streets and work to build a community around positive living.

My belief that public art is a powerful tool for building community drives my practice. In 2017, I founded Womxn Paint, an annual street art jam that has produced 44 murals celebrating the strength and diversity of womxn. I would like to continue this initiative and grow it to include additional programming that supports the professional development of womxn artists and more opportunities for young girls to learn about mural arts. In 2016, I facilitated an intergenerational mural at Baycrest Health Sciences and would like work more with the senior community.

Over the last six years, I have created custom large-scale outdoor artworks for clients including The New Yorker, Tourism Canada, the City of Toronto, the City of Mississauga, the Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany in Toronto, the STEPS Initiative, Arts Etobicoke, East End Arts and private clients.
properties.description: SMILE is about creating a space for a more positive conversation. Rather than hearing the ubiquitous marketing message that the latest consumer product can cure a manufactured sense of inadequacy, SMILE reminds people that life is great as is. It
properties.title: Bareket Kezwer

properties.description: The design is based around a local Toronto Beaches summer event: celebratory fireworks. Annually on Victoria Day and Canada Day the beach comes alive with lights and a festive atmosphere. The fireworks bring together both members of the Beaches community as well as those from outside the immediate area. Fireworks represent multicultural identity in the context of the Beaches neighbourhood in a larger Toronto community.
properties.title: Devlin Ralph

properties.description: It is a single maze with no entrance or exit that covers the entire box. The maze is a universal and simple form that engages at many levels, accessible to anyone – archaic and archetypal.
properties.title: Rob Gill

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Chris Perez

properties.address: Sheppard Ave W & Wilson Heights Blvd
properties.description: A whimsical and colourful celebration of art that anyone can relate to.
properties.title: Tak Bui

properties.artist_bio: Emmanuel Jarus is a Canadian-born artist and muralist inspired by the visual human experience. His work reimagines how art can exist in public spaces. For the past 8 years, Jarus has been working with communities across Canada and around the globe to produce large-scale portraits and figures among other images on wall surfaces. They can be found within major cities as well as across rural settings. He has had notable international recognition as a contemporary muralist and figurative painter. He studied briefly at the Academy of Realist Art in Toronto but attributes his knowledge of art to various influences including his grandmother, inspiration from graffiti, and resources found on the internet. The narrative Jarus depicts in his approach communicates a story of individual spirit relevant to the metabolism of that particular neighbourhood. A combination of acrylic, latex and aerosol paint is used to create representations of the people he’s inspired by along his travels. He enjoys painting in public space so that he can understand its context and express it through his work.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Jason Dinney & David Loran

properties.address: Queen St E & Glen Manor Dr
properties.description: The artist aims to transform a traffic signal box, somehting that is often overlooked in everyday life, into an aesthetic object that could be appreciated by anyone.
properties.title: Yi Zhang

properties.artist_bio: I am always interested in participating in mural projects with Street Art Toronto, as it is an amazing opportunity to work with community members and share art in a non-exclusive setting. I have been painting murals for six years now, on brick, wood, concrete, and aluminum surfaces. I generally use bright shades of outdoor acrylics applied with rollers and brush, but occasionally I use spray paint. My subject matter is often nature-focused, depicting flowers insects and animals. Painting in the city, I want the organic, colourful images I create to shine in an otherwise muted and industrialized landscape. I want to create work that can be viewed by anyone, with a message of hope, growth and positive change. I am part of the artist collective The Buck Teeth Girls Club, and through my involvement have grown accustomed to collaboration.
properties.title: Andrea Manica

properties.description: The Bluejay is the most famous Canadian bird for being so unique in it’s colour, with a bold beautiful blue the intention of these designs is to transform the iconic bird into an energetic bustle of waves and spirals. The design is made to inspire the public with their own hometown bird and to remind the community that we truly have something special living in Toronto.
properties.title: Tomas Del Balso

properties.artist_bio:
Peru is an internationally recognized muralist and graphic artist whose practice is informed by digital and traditional art forms and his 20+ years of painting graffiti. Peru’s professional career started when he moved from Lima to Ottawa at 16; he won every Visual Arts Award in his high school, a Canadian Heritage grant to paint a mural in Vancouver for the International Earth Festival, and a 2 mural commission for the National Capital Commission. At age 20 he moved to Montreal where he continued winning prizes and awards from design contests at his local skateshop to the Millennium Excellence Scholarship.

His passion for art lead him to rise to the top of the local art scene working for brands and companies such as Bell, Cirque du Soleil and he painted a series of murals with the collective En Masse at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. With En Masse, Peru was part of dozens of collaborative murals throughout Canada, US, Mexico and China, and participated in mentorship programs with the Quebec English School Boards Association. He was also a central muralist for MU since its inception in 2007 and continues to work with them, most recently in 2020 where he will be painting the exterior of a high school.

When Peru moved to Toronto a decade later he worked for Urban Outfitters for 5 years as a Lead Display Artist. In this role he built and installed window and store displays participating in store openings across North America including the company’s largest store opening at Herald Square in New York City. Peru used these experiences to expand his skill set and work on art installations at the Osheaga Music Festival as well for American Express for their Live Life Experience Installations around the world; All the while establishing himself as a muralist by assisting, collaborating, and consulting for nearly every arts organization in Toronto, and mentoring individuals, peers and on several occasions’ at-risk youth from the Oasis Skateboard Factory. Peru’s corporate and big brand murals allowed him to balance his work with grass-roots organizations, non-for-profits and BIA’s which make up most of his portfolio. Some of Peru’s corporate clients include Facebook, Nike, Adidas, Corus, Maple Leaf Sports, and Marriott Hotels.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Peru Dyer

properties.address: Bloor St W & High Park Ave
properties.description: The work aims at aesthetic or cute-fun ends to connect to people. The peacock is a natural beauty. Change the stroke of your day -- slow down to appreciate the detail of somehting in your immediate experience.
properties.title: Makes Collective

properties.description: As the city with the largest raccoon population in the world, raccoons play a part in Toronto's identity. This box pays tribute ot the noble raccoon.
properties.title: Jeannette Nguyen

properties.artist_bio: Andre is a Mexican born artist, who immigrated to Canada in 2006. Since coming to Toronto he’s been creating intricate psychedelic artwork featuring animal and human subjects juxtaposed with abstract form. His paintings have been used for custom clothing design and his illustrations for band posters and psychedelic trance music events. As of 2012 Andre has been focused on murals and street art, working on wall art for private businesses and city sponsored projects.In his work Andre explores the use of bold colour, geometric shapes, space landscapes and his special interest in architectural and industrial design. Andre feels there’s an incredible necessity to self-express through art and equal need to inspire emerging artists to create and feel free to self-express themselves in their own ways.
properties.description: The design represents he cosmos and unity of all beings contained within it. The shapes and colours embody every single person on earth.
properties.title: Andre Castro

properties.description: This design represents traditional Polish folk art. This design also celebrates the diviersity of cultures within Toronto. The artist's goal is to keep this traditional kind of art relevant and modern to be appreciated for generations to come. This piece is a contribution to make the city beautiful and culturally rich and vibrant.
properties.title: Kathryn Durst

properties.artist_bio: Based in Toronto since 1973, Ingrid Mayrhofer holds a BFA and MA from York University. Mayrhofer is a visual artist, curator and community arts practitioner. Her personal and collective projects have employed a wide range of media including printmaking, photography, mural painting, installation, sculpture, and video. During the past 20 years, she has served on numerous individual and organizational grant juries at arts councils, on foundation and municipal advisories, and worked as granting officer at the Ontario Arts Council.
properties.description: The patterns are Central European in origin, the practice of cross-stitch emroidery is known internationally. The patterns are recreated from those of the artist's granmother. The proposed pattern connects members of urban communities to the origin of designs in nature, a creative human gourney tat bears value for people of many diverse cultures.
properties.title: Ingrid Mayrhofer

properties.artist_bio: I would love to continue my involvement for StART because I love creating work for my city! My work is happy and Toronto-centric, every piece I create is aimed to make the community smile, laugh, and think. After 5 years of doing street art and illustration full-time, I’ve been lucky enough to have the opportunity to travel and bring my Toronto raccoon murals around the world, but this will always be my favourite place to make art. I hope to up my scale this year and bring more colour into our already vibrant communities.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Emily May Rose

properties.description: The design is an homage to one of Canada’s most beloved pink candy popcorn snack foods. This food signifies the epitome of fun, celebration and joy; the best and most celebrated aspects of our neighbourhoods. The text has been transformed to convey the messages of LOVE & UNITY, RESPECT, and FEEL FREE.
properties.title: Anna May Henry

properties.artist_bio: I studied art in Ukraine, Kharkov school of Fine Art. I also attended the course of Figurative painting at Toronto School of Art, Toronto, Canada.I worked in different artistic fields including graphic design and animation. Recently I can say that I am becoming a full-time fine artist. My favorite medium is canvas oil painting but I am open to a different form of art and medium.
properties.description: The box highlights things that High Park offers its neighbourhood. Cheery blossoms, bird watchers, nature lovers.
properties.title: Olga Voronovska

properties.artist_bio:
Biography: Monique Aura Bedard is a Onyota'a: ka (Oneida) artist, currently based in Tkaronto. She graduated from the University of Lethbridge with a BFA (Studio Art) and is a DTATI Candidate. Through her art practice, she focuses on art as healing, identity, empowerment, and mothering. She looks to the community to collectively explore personal storytelling and truth-sharing.

Artist Statement: I am inspired by storytelling and healing, individually and as a community. Currently, I combine painting, drawing, beadwork, textiles, image transfers, and collage to express my own stories. I aim to address intergenerational trauma with an emphasis on intergenerational healing to communicate experiences from the inside out. By unearthing my own stories, I can strengthen connections where the process creates awareness and understanding; this experience is ultimately part of the healing journey.
properties.description: The box acknolwedges the past, present and future of Indigenous people and the land. The shadow beneath the Fancy Shawl Dancer's feet emulates the idea of time passin and movement. This reflects the importance of the path that was taken in order to survive. The florals grow out of her feet emphasizing strength, peace, protection, femininity, movement, identity, voice, love and truth.
properties.title: Aura Last (Monique Bedard)

properties.artist_bio:
Jacquie Comrie is a Toronto- base, multidisciplinary artist whose vibrant body of work intersects contemporary art and wellness at a global scale, using colour as a medium of social impact and mental health.

 Whether as murals on buildings, large scale structures, or canvases, her body of work is a dynamic exploration of the science of colour as the universal language of human emotion, producing works in Canada and internationally.  Colour has been proven to have a direct effect to human emotion, for which her palettes are consciously designed and orchestrated aiming to cater to mental wellbeing at large.

In such divisive times, and with mental health issues on the rise across the globe, her work aims to contribute to much needed spaces of mental elevation and reset,  to ultimately help improve quality of life of all individuals- one wall at a time.
properties.description: "March of the Suffragettes" takes the College Street community back in tme to Victorian Toronto.
properties.title: Jacqueline Comrie

properties.artist_bio: Sari Richter grew up in Ancaster, Ontario and moved to Toronto where she completed a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting at Ontario College of Art and Design University and a Masters Certification from the Toronto Art Therapy Institute. She works in traditional and non-traditional drawing, painting and printmaking media and looks forward to challenging commissions. Sari is also a published children’s book illustrator, storyboard artist and muralist. She is currently employed as an art therapist and works with transitional aged youth.
properties.description: The very sprawling, organic and loose style is a means to set off a very rigid, standardized box. Tying natural elements into a man-made metallic object is not a new concept by any means, but the reason it works so well is that it can be surprising, intriguing and often refreshing.
properties.title: Sari Richter

properties.description: The box design consists of two character talking to each other using a string telephone. Both characters made out of the same visual shapes/ silhouette. One character is from the past. Whereas the other is a modern hip character. Both of them connected and intertwined by the cable of the string telephone which wraps around the box.
properties.title: Julian Raigoza

properties.artist_bio: A resident of Toronto, ON,  Tarantino, received a Bachelor of Fine Arts through OCADU and Bachelor of Education, while actively participating in the artistic community as Founder and Director of C1 art space from 2004-10 and Co- founding Director of AWOL Gallery and Studios Co-operative from 1996-2012. She is a past recipient of the Visual Artist Grant  Exhibition Assistance Grant and Artist in Education Grant from the Ontario Arts Council. Her artwork is in private and corporate collections across Canada, U.S.A and Europe. She currently teaches visual arts and ceramics at Avenue Road Arts School as well as provides mural and arts programming to communities and schools with VIBE Arts organization and other. Tarantino’s personal artwork incorporates both painting and sculptural modes through her shaped canvases and ceramic sculpture.She is a 2016 artist for the Outside the Box initiative, having designed the  Avenue Road and Wilson traffic box.
properties.description: The design aspires to encapsulate the essence and diversity within the community. Chickadee birds and trees are superimposed on photographic imagery manipulated into vibrant, colourful graphic stamp images of people in various activity.
properties.title: Sandra Tarantino

properties.description: The murals are titled Morning Ride and Trillium Path.  The artist was especially receptive to community input during the creation of the murals, subtly integrating elements such as the Donalda House Barns (originally a gristmill in the area), David Duncan House and Milne House, all of which enhance the murals' uniqueness to Don Mills. These and other elements are embedded in a colourful palatte representative of natural ecosystems found in the Don Valley.
properties.title: Sarah Collard

properties.description: The artist aims to transform a traffic signal box, somehting that is often overlooked in everyday life, into an aesthetic object that could be appreciated by anyone.
properties.title: Yi Zhang

properties.description: The work explores what it looks like to live in the body of a woman, and imagines utopias where an objectifying male gaze doesn't exist. It shows women spending time together, exploring nature, and participating in behaviours viewed as male, such as hunting.
properties.title: Louise Reimer

properties.description: On all four extremities where the pillars at Wilson subway station begin, the artist has painted four strong and beautiful feminine gatekeepers who hold up the bridges above them, acting as mythical-like guardians protecting those who pass by. The mural goes on to celebrate the “Weaver” as a timeless and powerful creator through a vibrant and fantastical array of symbolic imagery.
properties.title: Shalak Attack

properties.description: The blue Portuguese design is a symbol of heritage. It is easily recognized as a motif of Portuguese identity.
properties.title: Stephanie Anacleto

properties.artist_bio:
Blaze Wiradharma is an OCADU Graduate with a BDES in Illustration. After living in Singapore for the last two years,  he has returned to Toronto to continue freelancing as a Mural / Graffiti Artist, Illustrator and Graphic Designer. In his early beginnings, his interest in visual communication was sparked by graffiti and street art. These forms influenced him heavily, his style reflecting the vibrant and often bold nature of urban art. This also encouraged the development of letters, calligraphy & characters which are a large part of his work.

Blaze takes inspiration from all facets of his own life experiences, and strives to create imagery which reflects lessons that he has learned along with social commentary. He believes that large mural artwork in the public sphere has a responsibility to create questions in the viewers mind and encourage critical thinking. Blaze utilises spray paint and exterior latex to create his exterior and interior work. He strives to work with StART's amazing team to further develop his mural work, add to the already impressive visual landscape of Toronto, and also creating opportunities for emerging artists to grow and develop along side him.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Blaze Wiradharma

properties.description: Work has a focus on nature and nostalgia. The box located at High Park is painted with Cherry Blossoms in an attempt to keep them there all year round.  Thousands of tourists flood the park in an effort to see them in their short lifespan, this box honours the park, the nature and the nostalgia.
properties.title: Misi Farkas

properties.artist_bio: Loren was born in Toronto, Canada to Chinese immigrant parents. Her work is supported by a background of traditional drawing and painting since childhood, and supplemented by secondary education focused in communications design and illustration. In 2013, she moved to New York City to study art and lived there for 7 years, culminating in 2020 with experience ranging from digital image making to hand painted murals. She continues to enjoy working on creative projects, especially with community groups and POC/women-led independent businesses.
properties.description: This desing was developed on location drawing at cafes, a space where communities have formed positively and naturally. Cafe culture is a relatable concept that is easily identifiable with as both a place of productivity and relaxation. This design draws directly from people and places themselves.
properties.title: Loren Yueng

properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Lovebot

properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Joy Young

properties.description: The desing showcases ‘spirit’ animals that are Toronto specific; the pigeon and the moose. The pigeon is a perfect example of an animal that has moved into the city and made a home here, no matter the conditions, where that home may be or where they came from. The moose image harkens back to the installation of the ‘Moose in the city’ – while not native to Toronto, it’s another fun little nod to TO history.
properties.title: Andrew Patterson

properties.address: Birchmount Rd, 350m north of Bonis Ave
properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Toronto, I am a champion of this city. My work often depicts Toronto life - people, events and elements connected to the region. I have witnessed many changes and struggles in neighborhoods throughout the city and have contributed to developing community strength through several art projects.
I choose to create art that can be seen and appreciated by the public, free and accessible to anyone - bringing beauty to dingy, neglected areas of town. I enjoy working with communities to engage them in the process of change, establish personal connections and develop a sense of pride in their neighborhood.
My goal is to work on a larger scale projects with StART. I would like to be mentored/assisted in the use of aerosol painting as well as high murals requiring a lift. Working with StART, I would love to work with an Indigenous artist/group on a co-operative project to learn, exchange information and cultural practices. Indigenous art including Woodland style, Inuit sculpture, drawing and printmaking, are my favourite styles of art.
My artwork also addresses environmental concerns/issues; reminding us that everything has a purpose, even when it is not clear to us, what that is. I often find inspiration in ecology, the environment and site-specific surroundings the mural will be in. Figures, the body, and movement are recurring themes in my art.
As well as being a painter, I have been a professional photographer for over 25 years, creating images digitally as well as on film. Previously, I was the Resident Photography Artist at Mississauga Living Art Centre. While working at the TDSB, I was honoured to photograph Nelson Mandela on his first visit to Toronto. I collaborated with teachers and students on several art projects including a handmade book given to Mr. Mandela.
I am experienced in photographing events, fine art documentation, portraits, dance and theatre, products, buildings, magazine and commercial work. I also create digital designs including Op Art, tile patterns, floral, abstract; web design, preparing/repurposing images for web, email and print.
Materials and mediums I work with include photography, acrylic and latex paint, acrylic markers, aerosol paint, clay, wood and collage.

I have graduated from 3 art programs: Central Technical School Adult Art Program, Ryerson Still Photography and Humber College Audio/Visual Technology. As a multidisciplinary artist, my unique combination of art and technology skills brings strength of understanding to all my projects. Working as a full-time artist and art educator, I teach painting, drawing, ceramics, mixed media and photography throughout the GTA, to seniors, adults and children.
properties.description: Tango, salsa, swing, breakdancing and hip hop all originated as underground, street dances. The design speaks to the joy, entertainment and vibrancy of Toronto's cosmopolitan dance community that exists in every nook and cranny of the city.
properties.title: Karen Roberts

properties.description: The design is meant as a lightedhearted expression of coomunication between people, especially between driver, pedestrians and cyclists in a fast-moving urban landscape. Without words, the punctuation makes the statement.
properties.title: Zeesy Powers

properties.artist_bio:
I want to work with StART because the projects I have completed with Street Art Toronto's help have been not only the most enjoyable projects I have worked on in my career, but also the most lucrative for me, in terms of both payment and scale of exposure. I learn something new on every project we do together and working with StART staff has taught me virtually everything I know about what goes into publicly-funded street art projects, all the moving parts that need to be accounted for, communicating with the public, coordinating materials and other artists, publicity, etc. I want to keep building on this knowledge and skill set as we continue to spread colourful mural projects into new parts of the city/GTA.

Bio:
Nick Sweetman is a multidisciplinary artist from Toronto whose practice has explored painting and its intersection with photography, video, installation, mixed media, and urban intervention. He has exhibited in galleries around Toronto since 2011, completing his MFA in 2014 from OCAD University in the Interdisciplinary Art, Media & Design program. He received a certificate from the Mural Routes Leadership Training in Mural-Making program the same year and since then has been working in public space on mural projects, often in collaboration with other artists, and in partnership with various non-profit organizations (David Suzuki Foundation, The STEPS Initiative) as well as Street Art Toronto. He has successfully managed many large-scale projects both independently and as lead artist over a team of volunteers, from children up to adults. He has dedicated many projects to raising awareness about the importance of pollinators, bees and butterflies in particular, from painting giant bees towering over busy city streets to coordinating 30 or more artists to paint butterflies on garages in Toronto's laneways. Most recently, Nick has been working abroad, participating in the Eureka Street Art Festival in Humboldt County, California as well as contributing a mural to the Bondi Beach Sea Wall in Sydney, Australia.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Nick Sweetman

properties.description: "Dreamers Worldview" depicts many clouds with a rond head with eyes covered by a revolving image reel. Every person dreams and likes the idea of seeing the world around them.
properties.title: Charles Weiss

properties.artist_bio:
I'm an Honors OCAD graduate in Fine Arts, a visual artist and community mural painter. My most recent project, The Richmond Hill Traffic Box Murals Project 2019 was made possible through a Richmond Hill Community and Cultural Grant.   I am a StART Concrete Barrier artist and I took part in the Lakeshore Barrier Bike Lane project in 2019. I have created murals for StreeARToronto, The F.H. Varley Art Gallery of Markham and The Toronto Public Library. Last September, I was a muralist for the 2018 StreetARToronto Light up the Laneway Project, (Euclid Palmerston Laneway), and I’ve been accepted three times for StreetARToronto Outside the Box Program.  In 2017 I executed a Canada 150 Bell Box Community Mural Project.  In Toronto, I was hired for the The Coxwell Laneway Mosaic at Coxwell TTC Subway in 2016. Other initiatives include Nuit Blanche and The Henderson CN Bridge Mural,(2014), revisited in January 2020.
My ideas are closely tied into Toronto Public Library, where I have worked for over 45 years as a public service worker. My recent positions there have included Children's Programming and Special Collections initiatives, where I have made use of my artistic skills to help community with library projects similar in scope to mural initiatives. Public service includes mural work.  It includes any tools that we can use to help community and helping community through the gifts I can offer has been my life's work.  Truly I believe that there are many avenues available to help needful communities achieve sustainability and gain a sense of pride, both where public spaces are concerned and where housing is concerned.  Mural making is just one of those tools - as are library materials and services, and other community initiatives.

My goals with StART include partnering the library or offering my librarianship skills to promote and to encourage any initiatives that might be developed by StART, through mural work, to connect the community with literacy in all it's forms, including digital and creative literacy. The way to reach community is to involve them in positive and exciting ways that will give them something of value to add to their lives. Again, there are so many ways we can do this - especially if our important various avenues public service can partner together in creative endeavours to mentor community.
Every day at the library or when we are painting murals on walls, we have opportunities to mentor others.  Sometimes this takes on a formal role and sometimes not, but every time we take an interest in a member of our community and show them something they need to know, this is mentoring. Every time we answer a question from a passerby about a project or initiative that has been built to help them - this is mentoring. If possible I would like to take part in a short term or small project mentoring program developed by StART, as I do in the library, with Children's STEM Programming.

Again, there are many avenues open to mentorship possibilities. I would;d be open to any and all of them, as developed by and at the discretion of StART. I have ideas that would lend themselves to partnership of library and mural making and public consultation for these ideas would include mentorship of community members. iMy most ambitious upcoming project is one I would like to submit next year to the StART Partnership program, to include a large library component to a mural initiative to be developed in central North York near a library.
properties.description: The Jukebox design here is particularly amusing conversation piece and engages passersby on their way to visit the many public institutions nearby.
properties.title: Robin Hesse

properties.description: The layout is designed in a grid-system approach. To keep things fun,  colourful and contemporary palettes as well as geometrical graphic elements have been chosen. The black and white lines are a tribute to the connectivity of streetcars that keep the areas well accessible.
properties.title: Jin-Tian Wu

properties.description: City Animals' attemps to face the complicated relationship that exists between city dwellers and the wildlife that lives among us.
properties.title: Jen Bulthuis

properties.artist_bio:
Erin Zimerman is an artist and educator currently employed with the Toronto District School Board as an Occasional Teacher and with Unity Charity as a Workshop Facilitator. His experience in
graffiti art led him to working with the City of Toronto’s Graffiti Transformation Project for 10+ years, first as an artist, then facilitator and coordinator. Erin is a key fixture in Toronto's graffiti subculture, having painted in the city for 25+ years. His artworks have been featured in the books, “Dot Dot Dash,” “World Graffiti,” and in the video game “The Warriors.”
Erin holds a BFA from OCADU and a BEd from York University.
properties.description: The artwork incorporates graffiti tropes and are designed to subvert traditional graffiti to make it more accessible. This work aims to bridge gaps, interest and appreciation, between communities and local street artists.
properties.title: Erin Zimerman

properties.artist_bio:
My name is Jeff Blackburn and I am a visual artist based in Toronto. With over a decade of experience producing projects for exhibition and clients, my multi-disciplinary techniques are versatile, but also maintain a recognizable style. Inspired by illustration, graffiti, and comic books, my work is known for its emphasis on line and texture, and its exploration of form using interpretive contour lines. Paintings are constructed by merging pop art aesthetics with contemporary urban art materials and techniques.

My work explores themes that revel in a flippant joie de vivre, yet remain lightly steeped in some measure of memento mori. The combined effect is one of playfully self-assured yet shadowed cheek. My compositions tend to centre on a central figure, giving the piece a definitive focal point from which the viewer can explore. The subjects of my work are chosen for their relevance to the project or location, or simply for their relevance to me. Visual impact in my murals is further accomplished through a vibrant and textured usage of colour. In these paintings, colour is freed from its formal descriptive function and displays energy and motion through a build up of spray and acrylic paint layers.

I want to continue working with StART as I have been creating projects with their team since year one, and I greatly appreciate the opportunities that they’ve funded and helped bring to fruition for both my peers and myself.  I am hoping to grow the scale of my work in the public realm, while simultaneously gaining the key skills necessary in developing the business side of my career. With the backing of StART I have painted 14 traffic signal boxes, participated in roughly 10 StART funded mural jams, assisted American artist Andrew Schoultz in 2012 on one of the first Partnership Program murals, and most recently assisted BirdO on the first Monumental Program wall.
properties.description: This design brings wildlife and vibrancy to the city  - bright and textural, something out of the ordinary. It clashes with the surrounding concrete and is an antithesis to the greys and browns used to disguise the signal boxes.
properties.title: Jeff Blackburn

properties.description: Toront's diversity and creativity shine on an international scale. Toronto sparkles, and deserves to be shown in a mudium that is as multifaceted as the city. Using a mictur of acrulic and GLITTER paint the artist will capture the 'hidden gem' that is the Toronto arist community. The desing depicts a rainbow of coloured glittered gemstones over a Toronto skyline, outlined/framed as an artist's paint palette.
properties.title: Alex Karakis

properties.description: The deisgn takes advantage of the shape of the traffic signal box. Within the clock, a child swings in place of a pendulum. The front and back of the box differ, encouraging the viewer to pause and interact with the box to experience the narrative in full. It is an image that envokes emotion for the viewer, whether this be a positive memory form childhood or a smile.
properties.title: Jean-Luc Bonifay

properties.description: Playful and intriguing design - using the natural shape of the box, the design is a matchbox. On the wide side it has an equation created out of match sticks that is not correct. The sign "fix with one move" nspires thinking and finding the solution.
properties.title: Emilia Jajus

properties.artist_bio:
Marley Allen-Ash is an illustrator and artist working in Toronto, Canada. She uses traditional printmaking and digital media to create illustrations and explore both historical and personal narratives.  In addition to illustration, she enjoys work on murals and self publishing comics with her collective, Grab Bag Club.  She studied at OCAD University, completing a bachelor of design and majoring in illustration. Her illustration work has been recognized by American Illustration, 3x3 Magazine and Creative Quarterly. Selected Clients include The Globe and Mail, CANADALAND, Cottage Life and Lenny Letter.

I have worked with StART before, through the Lakeshore Bike Lane Murals, Concrete Barrier Art Program, and Outside the Box. I'd love to be involved in more group and individual mural projects, such as laneway mural projects or painting underpasses. I'm really open to any type of opportunity, though in the past I've worked with exterior latex paint for murals, as well as creating digital files to be printed and used as vinyl wraps.
properties.title: Marley Allen- Ash

properties.artist_bio:
Visual Artist

Christiano De Araujo is a self-taught artist who was born in Anápolis, Goiás, Brazil. His earliest memory as a child is the moment when he discovered his love of art. As a toddler, he remembers picking up a crayon that his older sister had left behind. When she found that Christiano had taken it, she grabbed it away from him, but in that short amount of time, he had fallen in love with colours and the ability to create.

His love of art and his talent for the drawing were evident when he was a student in school. His first passion was comics and cartoons and at age 12 he drew his first comic strip.

In his late teens, Christiano began working for Brazil’s highly circulated newspaper, Diário da Manhã, doing editorial cartoons and illustrations. He also continued to work for other local newspapers and magazines. Realizing that he wanted more opportunities than he could have in Brazil, Christiano chose to immigrate to Canada.

His first years in Canada were a struggle. Early on, he landed a job as a Bricklayer, which he did for a number of years. Christiano confronted his weaknesses and discovered his strengths, learned to laugh at his hardships, quickly moving on. He was able to overcome any adversities with a determination to succeed and a desire to make himself a better man. This led to his artwork being published in numerous magazines and newspapers in Toronto.

He also credits his success to a spiritual awakening that he had through meditation and self-hypnosis. It gave him clarity and focus. This experience gave him more confidence and the ability to control his emotions and himself. Christiano devotes much of his life to his art. His endeavours include drawing, oil and acrylic painting, airbrushing, cartooning and sculpting. He is an artist by trade, finds art fun and likes to explore new media and innovated techniques.

Christiano currently resides in Toronto, Canada. He is the founder of Toronto Artists Studio, a studio of visual artists, painters, digital artists and sculptors who design and produce murals and visual communication projects for audiences on a small and grand scale.

At the present moment, this very moment… Christiano is enjoying the wonderful interaction between the mind and the universe. This infinite universe in which we are all one!

properties.title: Christiano De Araujo

The design has many hidden parts to make it almost like a game. Every time someone looks at it they'll find something new.
properties.title: Jackie Saik

properties.artist_bio:
Al “Runt” Currie is an iconic Canadian artist, with impressive works displayed both a home and internationally. His works are vibrant, colourful, abstract and fun, full of life and imagination, and accessible by people of all ages. His strong connection to Canada and, in particular, Toronto, is demonstrated by his works displayed, including Lee's Palace. At another recent internationally-recognized event, Runt was invited to represent Canada’s art scene as artistic lead for the International Fortune 500 event, held in September 2018, at Toronto’s Evergreen Brick Works, where he completed numerous art works including a 40-foot mural for an audience, comprised of international industry titans, policy and thought leaders, as well as Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.
What Critics Have Said…:
“Enter the world of Runt. At once familiar and unfamiliar, his works are of this world but definitely not of this world. Informed by a wide range of influences from Hieronymus Bosch to Dr. Seuss, Runt’s work embodies a love and critique of humanity as his monster scene-scapes play out in front of the viewer’s eyes. If one could press “play” on any of his scenes and advance them, the scenes would look entirely different. Runt’s characters capture the joy and aggression of our urban existence. But the beauty in Runt’s works is that they don't judge, they simply present. Known for his large murals, Lee’s Palace and The Electric Mud BBQ, Runt’s art is found in many private collections. Runt’s passionate adventure has turned into a career as one of Canada’s singular visionaries, on par with other 80s icons such as Keith Haring and Kenny Scharf.”
Runt is interested in participating in the StArt project, as he looks forward to continuing his contributions to the Toronto arts scene and community, sharing his experiences and expertise with other artists while also learning from them., I had the privilege to make a mural with StART and Mural Routes in 2017 (Underpass Park). I really enjoyed this experience and would like to renew it by realizing, this time, a larger work. I find StART's approach involving the community in the process of setting up murals in the city very interesting. I also appreciate the openness of the organization to the diversity of aesthetics and the freedom of creation that it allows. If a project with StART could be possible, a larger scale project, I will be interested to be assisted by local artists in the realization of the work, for a mutual enrichment.

I am interested in the pictorial representation of patterns and textile materials of various origins, their symbolic values, and the senses created by their juxtaposition and context. My creations revisit the traditional notions of trompe-l'œil (optical illusion) to create textile landscapes from which emanates an enveloping atmosphere. My works take the shape of organic patchworks: their sampled components differ in patterns, colors and origins. They express coherent and structured ensembles.

I come from Quebec City and I live and practice in Montreal since 2006. I hold a DESS in Management of Cultural Organizations from HEC Montréal, and I obtained my Bachelor degree in Visual Arts at Laval University in 2002. I've done my first mural in 2000. I’m a professional member of the Conseil des métiers d'art du Québec since 2005, an organization that recognizes mural art as a profession.

I am mainly dedicated to mural art since the end of my Bachelor's degree in visual arts. I have accomplished or participated in the realization of dozens of large-format projects, as site and team manager, designer, teacher or assistant. I have realized many large-scale projects, many of them in partnership with MU organization from Montreal. I have also worked for various companies operating in the field of mural art, decorative arts and scenic scenery. On the international scene, I was invited in 2001 by the city of Namur in Belgium to paint a collaborative work. In 2005, I have done a mural art training at Cité-Création, in Oullins, France. In 2006 and 2019, I was invited to Mexico City to lead the realization of collaborative murals for the Faro de Oriente Cultural Center. I also participated in the Street Art 2017 event of Robespierre Gallery in Grande-Synthe, the Festival Internacional de Arte Urbano Barrio Vivo and the CIMU Festival in Mexico City in 2019. I also participated this year in the Imagine Mural Festival of Louisville, Kentucky.

I mainly work with exterior or interior acrylic paints, applied by brush, roller or paint gun. The various projects I did led me to work on various media such as brick, plaster, concrete, crezon and PVC. I have been working in scaffolding since 2000. I have my license to operate lifting platforms since 2011, and license for basket lift since 2015. I also attended the general health course on construction sites in 2010., Christopher Ross (aka GAWD) is a surrealist artist from Montreal. Ross has created murals and exhibition pieces in various Canadian and international cities and has been an important part of Montréal’s street art community since the nineties.

Among the hundreds of jobs Christopher completed while pursuing art, was fixing egg machines. Christopher soon discovered the ink used to date eggs was an interesting medium for painting,  directly influencing his signature splatters and eventually the use of liquid watercolour. Along with occasional access to painting materials, Christopher’s various jobs made him more aware of the working class struggle, and, relationships among people, nature and the environment., Biography: Monique Aura Bedard is a Onyota'a: ka (Oneida) artist, currently based in Tkaronto. She graduated from the University of Lethbridge with a BFA (Studio Art) and is a DTATI Candidate. Through her art practice, she focuses on art as healing, identity, empowerment, and mothering. She looks to the community to collectively explore personal storytelling and truth-sharing.

Artist Statement: I am inspired by storytelling and healing, individually and as a community. Currently, I combine painting, drawing, beadwork, textiles, image transfers, and collage to express my own stories. I aim to address intergenerational trauma with an emphasis on intergenerational healing to communicate experiences from the inside out. By unearthing my own stories, I can strengthen connections where the process creates awareness and understanding; this experience is ultimately part of the healing journey.
properties.description: Created by artists from across Canada the vibrant street art on the 13 pillars that form 'Multiplicity' reinforce Underpass Park as a community gathering place and showcase our nation's creative talent and diversity.
properties.title: AL Runt, Andrew Dexel, Annie Hamel, Aura, Chief Lady Bird, Carlos Delgado, FONKi, Christopher Ross (GAWD), Jill Stanton, Kalkidan Assefa, Layla & Lacey, Meaghan Claire Kehoe, OMEN, and Ness Lee.

properties.description: This series of murals was developed to celebrate the contributions of First Nations Peoples to the artistic and cultural life of communities and bring the diverse residents of this west end community together.
properties.title: guest artists from Chile, Jose Ortega and emerging young artists in the neighbourhood.

properties.artist_bio: ‘Elicser’ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.
properties.description: Based on the theme 'You Are Here', this mural project initiated by the Tranzac Club, a music and performance venue, expanded to include two abutting laneways, and brought the creative energy of the entire neighbourhood together.
properties.title: Elicser

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.description: These two visually powerful murals on the north and south facing sides of a two-storey building were designed to be a talking point and foster a sense of pride of place in the local community.
properties.title: Evond Blake (Mediah)

properties.artist_bio: Amir Akbari is a Greater Toronto Area (GTA) based Visual Artist, Educator, Community Advocate and Entrepreneur.   In 2002, he enrolled in OCAD University where he would go on to complete a Bachelors of Fine Arts with a focus on Drawing and Painting.  In 2003, Amir led his first community mural art project working with Urban Art Toronto.  The following year, he took on his first role with Street Art (then Graffiti Transformation Project) as the lead artist with Lamp Community Health Centre.  That project would be a launching pad for his eventual artistic and professional career.From 2003 to 2010 Amir continued to work with various community organizations and charities as an artist facilitator, youth works and educator.  He would go onto complete over 30 public murals throughout this time, working with and mentoring hundreds of youth across the GTA.In 2010 Amir founded Behind the Line with the purpose of providing existing support structures within the community with creative and artistic support.  Behind the Line has since worked closely with multiple organizations to enhance their arts programming and creative reach, from curriculum development, programming consultation and arts integration strategies.In the summer of 2019, Amir completed his largest mural production, the Susan Street Mural at 3847 Lawrence Ave. East.  This would be his 6th Street Art Partnership Project with the Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough and his 3rd partnership with Toronto Community Housing.  The large 14 story mural is the crowning achievement of his artistic journey as a community and mural artist.  Focused on creating designs that reflect, represent and inspire the communities that he is working with, this mural is a celebration of the collaborative and uplifting nature of public murals funded by Street Art Toronto.His work is rooted in the belief that self-expression can have a lasting impact on the development and growth of young people and their communities, and that there is a disproportional disadvantage across the board for those that face multiple barriers with accessing the arts.   He hopes to fill this void through innovative arts strategies, collaborative mural projects and local community partnerships.
properties.description: Based on the theme 'Our Heroes', this mural is the first in a series of murals of different sizes designed to support community engagement and strengthen the sense of belonging for all.
properties.organizations: East Scarborough Boys and Girls Club
properties.title: Amir Akbari

properties.artist_bio:
Philip Cote, MFA
Artist, Activist, Historian and Traditional Wisdom Keeper.
Moose Deer Point First Nation: Shawnee, Lakota, Potawatomi, and Ojibway.

A graduate of OCAD University’s Interdisciplinary Art Media and Design Masters program in 2015, Cote has been exploring new ways to imbue Mural Painting through oral traditions of storytelling and with traditional spiritual perspectives. Cote studied Beaux-Arts Style painting/drawing at OCAD under the direction of Carmen Cereceda Bianchi (Diego Rivera’s assistant).

Philip Cote emphasizes the resurgent power of nature and the importance of listening to Indigenous teachings through his Mural Art. lluminating 13,500+ years of Indigenous peoples history on Turtle Island showing their cosmology, mapping their place within the Universe and its beginnings, with light and dark showing their world linked to the underworld (Underwater World) and spirit world (Sky World).

In 2017, Cote received a grant from the Toronto Arts Council to create a mural depicting the Niagara Treaty for University of Toronto’s Massey College with the theme of Truth and Reconciliation/Canada 150.

Cote has been a tour guide with First Story since 1999, a three-hour tour providing an Indigenous history of Toronto uncovering the last 13,500 years. Cote’s academic practice includes public speaking, land acknowledgements, Indigenous Cosmology and cultural interpretation offered at York University, the Art Gallery of Ontario, University of Toronto, Ryerson University, OCAD University, and the Toronto District School Board through the Aboriginal Education Centre. In these Institutions, Cote shares his knowledge on the teachings of the Seven Grandfathers, the Medicine Wheel, Pipe, Naming and Sacred Fire Ceremonies, and the History of the Land.

As an Indigenous painter and Muralist, the purpose of Cote’s research is to unearth, and reveal, his cultural experience and knowledge of signs of Indigenous symbols, language and interpretation. Openings are thus created both within the archive/academia and broader public that enable these imbedded stereotypes to transform under the gaze of an Indigenous based interpreted presence and intervene in the cross generational colonial bias., Kwest is a key pioneer in the fusion of graffiti and sculpture approaching public art opportunities
holistically as a self-taught carpenter and designer. He has a unique ability to create site-specific
installations, which maintain relevance to the location while emphasizing contemporary aesthetics.

Kwest has completed projects for Evergreen Brick Works Pillar Murals (Toronto), UP Here Festival (Sudbury - Largest Mural in Canada), Tweed (Smith Falls, ON), and the Roskilde Festival (Denmark). For Toronto's Nuit Blanche 2017, Kwest collaborated with Drake music producer, Noah “40” Shebib in an interactive sculptural installation, “TRUTH”, at Yonge and Dundas Square. Blending his different crafts allows for a new style of mural + sculpture rooted in the project’s neighbourhood, as much as it is shaped by his knowledge of graffiti, building and designing indoor and outdoor spaces., Emmanuel Jarus is a Canadian-born artist and muralist inspired by the visual human experience. His work reimagines how art can exist in public spaces. For the past 8 years, Jarus has been working with communities across Canada and around the globe to produce large-scale portraits and figures among other images on wall surfaces. They can be found within major cities as well as across rural settings. He has had notable international recognition as a contemporary muralist and figurative painter. He studied briefly at the Academy of Realist Art in Toronto but attributes his knowledge of art to various influences including his grandmother, inspiration from graffiti, and resources found on the internet. The narrative Jarus depicts in his approach communicates a story of individual spirit relevant to the metabolism of that particular neighbourhood. A combination of acrylic, latex and aerosol paint is used to create representations of the people he’s inspired by along his travels. He enjoys painting in public space so that he can understand its context and express it through his work.
properties.description: Located in the Humber River Valley, an important Indigenous hunting area and trail, 'First Timeline' features ten large-scale murals by iconic Toronto artists Philip Cote, Kwest and Jarus to create a visual storyboard illustrating 12,500+ years of the history of cultural and ecological heritage.
properties.medium: Acrylic paint, latex paint, spray paint, sealant
properties.title: Philip Cote, Kwest, Jarus

properties.description: Created by Justus Roe as part of an international exchange with Chicago – a Partnership City of Toronto – this mural covers the foot and cycling path above a rail corridor, the major road and a highway that connects the urban area with the waterfront.
properties.title: Justus Roe and others

properties.description: Created to honour veterans on Canada's 150th anniversary the sites for this series of murals in frequently vandalised locations were also selected to demonstrate how artistic talent can be channeled in positive and powerful ways.
