properties.artist_bio: Paula Gonzalez-Ossa is a mural artist who has been working with diverse communities producing street level public art, both in Canada and Latin America for over 25 years. Her ongoing work with StARToronto dates back to 2015. Her murals, like the most recent 500 ft. mural titled "Our Medicines"  located at the underpass at Dupont and Shaw, or "The Ancestral Tree Spirits" located at the Nordheimer Ravine's TTC station exit, depict a colourful  First Nations cosmovision in relation to the Original lands of Ontario, working closely with Anishnawbe  mentors, Elders and Knowledge Keepers. Gonzalez-Ossa is currently  the Indigenous Education Officer at the AGO’s Weston Learning Centre, as part of the Public Programming and Learning Department, and the Visual Arts instructor and mentoring artist at Na Me Res Sagatay Native Men's Residence. She brings 19 years experience as a  Community Youth Worker with youth at risk in Toronto's West.Some of her previous public works include: a 120 foot mural honoring First Nations from North and South America,  which was the recipient of  the 2014 Ward 27 City Builder’s Award, formerly at Allan Gardens. Other locations sport a ribbon-style mural at Women’s Residence, a women’s shelter at Dundas and Bathurst, in collaborations with an all women crew (2015), and a 4 wall rendition of the Medicine Wheel, inside of Na Me Res Sagatay’s courtyard (2016).  In sharp contrast she produced an indoor mural with 22 students from grades 6-8 at refugee host school Beverley Heights Middle School (2017).She recently served in the capacity of Resident Artist at the Power Plant gallery, developing mural arts programs at two satellite locations with youth from priority neighbouroods in Toronto’s West.(2017-2018). In 2018-2019 she worked closely with the 7Th Generation Image Makers at the Native Youth Resource Centre to mentor, facilitate and produce a mural with an all Indigenous women’s team, located  at the South facing wall at Christie Pits Park’s Alex Duff Memorial Pool. Her two most recent productions  funded by StART’s Partnership Grant in 2019,located at the front façade of Sagatay Naïve Men’s Residence, and the adjacent alley,  depict  “Medicines and Guardians”, as well as “The Wolves Running South”.Last but not least, Gonzalez-Ossa is one of the featured artists at the “You’ve Changed “ exhibit by STARToronto , at St Lawrence Market’s  “Market Gallery”. At the exhibit, the video display shows us her latest short documentary produced  for SART, about the basic protocols entailed when developing images in partnership with Indigenous Nations here in Canada.Gonzalez-Ossa  has been  voted Best Graffiti Artist for the City of Toronto by Now Magazine’s Reader’s Poll in 1997, in 2009, 2010, and 2011. In addition, she has been featured on  CBC (Radio and Television, varying shows), Much Music, MTV, Global Televison, City TV, TVO, CTV, Bell Fibe TV1, Rogers Television, and Telelatino, as well as various television  appearances in Chile, USA (NYC/California), and Jamaica.
properties.description: Created by lead artist Paula Gonzalez(-Ossa) and Na-Me-Res, First Nations Cosmovision of Nature depicts the trees and plants that supported life in the area 150+ years ago and reminds us to respect and honour nature.
properties.title: Paula Gonzalez and Na-Me-Res artsits

properties.artist_bio:
At the tender age of nine, Toronto-based illustrator Adrian Hayles discovered the expressive
nature of the visual arts. With his continued artistic development, illustration became his
deepest passion and talent. His desire to learn and absorb from his surroundings led him on a
personal creative journey. As a graduate of the Graphic Design program at Humber College
with over 10 years of working experience behind him, Adrian has established his place in
Toronto’s modern art community. His style is provocative and inspiring and defies
categorization. Blurring the lines between graffiti and ultra realism, Adrian’s voice and vision is
instantly identifiable. His works include countless portraits and illustrations for various
magazines and collaborations with the City of Toronto to develop murals for vacant community
spaces. In the past Adrian has painted complete buildings and city blocks, designed award
winning video games and animated television shows. He has also successfully developed and
filed a functioning patent for the Stud Horse Foldable Drawing Bench and is the Principal and
Founder of Behind the Front Visual Arts Studio.
properties.description: An artistic collaboration undertaken by the Chester Le community this mural is a shout-out to the beauty of the community and creative talent and resilience of the residents.
properties.title: Adrian Hayles

properties.artist_bio:
Sean Martindale is an internationally recognized, award winning interdisciplinary artist and designer based in Toronto, Canada. His interventions activate public spaces to encourage engagement, and often focus on ecological and social issues. His playful works suggest alternate possibilities for existing spaces, infrastructures, and materials found in urban environments. Frequently, he uses salvaged goods in unexpected ways that prompt conversation.

Among other notable projects, he was the lead artist on the Community Rising, the tallest mural in the world from 2013 to 2018 (now the second tallest), the result of a community project in St James Town, Toronto, with local youth, STEPS and the Toronto Muralists. Martindale has been the lead artist for a number of the GTA’s largest mural projects. He continues to work closely with communities and organizations big and small; including partners such as Harbourfront Centre, the Art Gallery of Ontario, and the City of Toronto.

Martindale holds an MFA from the Interdisciplinary Masters of Art, Media and Design program at OCAD University in Toronto, and a BDes in Communication Design from Emily Carr University in Vancouver. He was the Decennial Hancock Lecturer at the University of Toronto’s Hart House, where his presentation was broadcast by TVO for their Big Ideas series. He is a recipient of the prestigious Artist Prize from Toronto Friends of the Visual Arts, numerous grants at municipal, provincial, and federal levels, and a Chalmers Arts Fellowship from the Ontario Arts Council. Martindale was profiled for the first episode of CBC’s Great Minds of Design, and his works have been featured digitally and published in traditional media around the world in multiple languages. His works have been exhibited publicly in many cities across the globe.

Recently, Martindale was Harbourfront Centre’s inaugural Visual Artist-in-Residence, and alongside his collaborator JP King, was also the first Artist-in-Residence with the City of Toronto, Solid Waste Management Services.

-------------

•	While I continue to be interested in traditional mural forms, I am also excited to keep exploring other media/materials in the public realm, spearhead new practices, and explore diverse approaches to community engagement. As well, I am interested in potentially growing other areas of my practice, and taking on more roles in related areas such as project coordination, program development, and consulting.
properties.description: Inspired by the diversity of lived experiences of the people who come, leave and stay in Toronto, a city built on migration, this mural titled 'Tapestry of Movement' is a visual reflection of the community's past, present and future.
properties.title: Team Spudbomb - Sean Martindale

properties.description: Created to honour veterans on Canada's 150th anniversary the sites for this series of murals in frequently vandalised locations were also selected to demonstrate how artistic talent can be channeled in positive and powerful ways.
properties.title: Magicfinnga WonG

properties.artist_bio:
Dan Bergeron is a public artist who employs a range of styles, themes and materials to activate and explore the meaning of our shared public spaces. The shape, texture and location of a site and its history or current uses dictate the form and content of his projects. Dan’s public installations aim to open a dialog with viewers, promoting engagement through both intimate familiarity and wonder at the unexpected.

Dan has created public art projects for municipalities across Canada (Toronto, Mississauga, Ottawa, Gaspe, Calgary, Richmond), working in both two-dimensional mediums (murals, photo-based wheat pasting) and three dimensional sculpture. He has also been commissioned by the AGO, MOCA Toronto, the ROM and corporate clients Nike, Converse and Vespa.
properties.description: The light rays, bright colours and forward flowing design of this mural entitled 'Beacon' are a welcoming sign that reflects the imagery and dynamics of the DUKE Heights community and provides a glimpse into its future.
properties.title: Dan Bergeron and Gabriel Specter

properties.artist_bio: Paula Gonzalez-Ossa is a mural artist who has been working with diverse communities producing street level public art, both in Canada and Latin America for over 25 years. Her ongoing work with StARToronto dates back to 2015. Her murals, like the most recent 500 ft. mural titled "Our Medicines"  located at the underpass at Dupont and Shaw, or "The Ancestral Tree Spirits" located at the Nordheimer Ravine's TTC station exit, depict a colourful  First Nations cosmovision in relation to the Original lands of Ontario, working closely with Anishnawbe  mentors, Elders and Knowledge Keepers. Gonzalez-Ossa is currently  the Indigenous Education Officer at the AGO’s Weston Learning Centre, as part of the Public Programming and Learning Department, and the Visual Arts instructor and mentoring artist at Na Me Res Sagatay Native Men's Residence. She brings 19 years experience as a  Community Youth Worker with youth at risk in Toronto's West.Some of her previous public works include: a 120 foot mural honoring First Nations from North and South America,  which was the recipient of  the 2014 Ward 27 City Builder’s Award, formerly at Allan Gardens. Other locations sport a ribbon-style mural at Women’s Residence, a women’s shelter at Dundas and Bathurst, in collaborations with an all women crew (2015), and a 4 wall rendition of the Medicine Wheel, inside of Na Me Res Sagatay’s courtyard (2016).  In sharp contrast she produced an indoor mural with 22 students from grades 6-8 at refugee host school Beverley Heights Middle School (2017).She recently served in the capacity of Resident Artist at the Power Plant gallery, developing mural arts programs at two satellite locations with youth from priority neighbouroods in Toronto’s West.(2017-2018). In 2018-2019 she worked closely with the 7Th Generation Image Makers at the Native Youth Resource Centre to mentor, facilitate and produce a mural with an all Indigenous women’s team, located  at the South facing wall at Christie Pits Park’s Alex Duff Memorial Pool. Her two most recent productions  funded by StART’s Partnership Grant in 2019,located at the front façade of Sagatay Naïve Men’s Residence, and the adjacent alley,  depict  “Medicines and Guardians”, as well as “The Wolves Running South”.Last but not least, Gonzalez-Ossa is one of the featured artists at the “You’ve Changed “ exhibit by STARToronto , at St Lawrence Market’s  “Market Gallery”. At the exhibit, the video display shows us her latest short documentary produced  for SART, about the basic protocols entailed when developing images in partnership with Indigenous Nations here in Canada.Gonzalez-Ossa  has been  voted Best Graffiti Artist for the City of Toronto by Now Magazine’s Reader’s Poll in 1997, in 2009, 2010, and 2011. In addition, she has been featured on  CBC (Radio and Television, varying shows), Much Music, MTV, Global Televison, City TV, TVO, CTV, Bell Fibe TV1, Rogers Television, and Telelatino, as well as various television  appearances in Chile, USA (NYC/California), and Jamaica.

properties.artist_bio:
Working with StArt and seeing the positive impact it has on neighbourhoods, people and the development of artists is inspiring and makes me proud to be a part of.

Canadian graffiti artist Alexander Bacon began painting in the 90’s as a teenager.  He is best known for his colourful works lining the alleys and streets of Toronto and achieved international recognition.  Bacon describes the art form as being passed down from one generation to the next.
His work has evolved to deconstructing traditional graffiti spray paint techniques to create an abstract graffiti style while maintaining letter form.  His use of a mature colour pallet and mixing of realism with the stylized graffiti fonts gives his work a unique look with smooth transitions and texture.
Most recently Bacon has been doing large scale murals and Canvas work while maintaining the disciplines of graffiti.  His work can be seen all over Toronto.

properties.artist_bio: ‘Elicser’ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.

properties.artist_bio: I would love to continue my involvement for StART because I love creating work for my city! My work is happy and Toronto-centric, every piece I create is aimed to make the community smile, laugh, and think. After 5 years of doing street art and illustration full-time, I’ve been lucky enough to have the opportunity to travel and bring my Toronto raccoon murals around the world, but this will always be my favourite place to make art. I hope to up my scale this year and bring more colour into our already vibrant communities.

properties.artist_bio: Will Gaydos (aka Rage Williams) is an artist and photographer from Toronto, Canada. He has an HBA from the University of Toronto in Urban Studies and Human Geography, and often utilizes themes from his studies in his work. As an artist he mainly focuses on large-scale mural work, incorporating text, vivid colour, and urban imagery to challenge the monotony of urban spaces.
properties.description: “Greetings From…” is a striking, graphic mural that stands out with strong colour and lines, but also acts as something of a postcard for the neighbourhood. For the viewer, this can be seen as a “welcome” sign for the neighbourhood, but can also, more literally, be a digital postcard when shared on social media.
properties.title: Will Gaydos

properties.artist_bio:
Jason has spent years developing his aerosol skills since discovering graffiti as as Toronto youth. Art making has been a life affirming escape and a way to process his surroundings. OCAD opened his eyes to different approaches and techniques. Focusing on the dissection of colour and light into geometric shapes and patterns, Jason's artwork creates a juxtaposition between the abstract and the representational. This style lends well to a mural site and its organic blend into the community. Thinking critically about the transformation of public spaces, Jason looks for interesting ways to use colour, form, and shape to create visual landmarks to promote and evolve the aesthetic narrative of the city.

Most recently, his commercial commissions include: Yonge + Dundas Square Toronto Musician series, Fet Zun restaurant exterior signage, Ubisoft Assasin's Creed Fan Mural, and, MLB Blue Jays temporary mural at Union Station.

properties.artist_bio:
Working with StArt and seeing the positive impact it has on neighbourhoods, people and the development of artists is inspiring and makes me proud to be a part of.

Canadian graffiti artist Alexander Bacon began painting in the 90’s as a teenager.  He is best known for his colourful works lining the alleys and streets of Toronto and achieved international recognition.  Bacon describes the art form as being passed down from one generation to the next.
His work has evolved to deconstructing traditional graffiti spray paint techniques to create an abstract graffiti style while maintaining letter form.  His use of a mature colour pallet and mixing of realism with the stylized graffiti fonts gives his work a unique look with smooth transitions and texture.
Most recently Bacon has been doing large scale murals and Canvas work while maintaining the disciplines of graffiti.  His work can be seen all over Toronto., I am a Nipissing First Nation born artist. I started life learning my cultures teachings, approaches and ceremonies through visual healing art forms. Painting, dancing, leatherwork and story telling were taught through traditional Ojibway and Odawa ways. My mentors encouraged me to be creative and to not let anything go to waste with what I share in art.
As a traditional Anishnawbe first nations graffiti artist, my work has matured from quick pieces into large street art projects and canvas work. Using my teachings and different methods I focus on unique painting styles and techniques to create smooth transitions of colour, blending abstract form with realism and expressionism.
I take interactions of my daily life, the city I live in and my Anishnawbe culture. I use it as a challenge for me to try out new styles and incorporate new subject matter. My love of nature and animals is prominent through my work because of its deep meaning and connection to life. I aspire for my artistic evolution to form a distinct look and feeling.
I call my style, Making the woodlands dance. Norval Morrisseau best describes how I approach my painting, he says as “If you can imagine an x-ray photo of spirit”. My goal
is to portray the teachings of my ancestors, sacred geometry and shapes in all my art forms.
My art has allowed me to work closely with art directors, city officials and corporate clients to make their visions come to life. I enjoy working with people and have collaborated with many artists on projects of all scales from graphic books to videos to murals around the world. I love travelling and seeing art. Most of all, I love to paint and have people enjoy my work.
b.
I’m always inspired by new opportunities to share my art. I am grateful to have the ability to transform neighborhoods, buildings and interior and turn them into popular destinations for people to visit, admire and enjoy. Working on murals allows me to engage in the community, bring people together and inspire others.
c.
Over the years, I have worked with community led designs which allow me to bring the community’s vision to life. I work closely with team members to ensure everyone has a
clear understanding and vision of the design required to meet the project expectations. In the past I have worked as the project lead and director on numerous projects and have extensive experience with coordinating artists of various skill sets and backgrounds. I am

flexible and easy to work with, good at problem solving, communicating, and can work in any situation.
properties.title: Alexander Bacon & Quentin Rockford

properties.artist_bio:
Early on, I perceived that my ambition was the act of painting itself, finding that the process coincided with the workings of my conscious and unconscious mind.Throughout my career I have also been fascinated by realism, specifically trompe l’oeil and it’s ability to affect the viewer. I have been creating trompe l’oeil murals in combination with my abstract works for over 20 years now. It has become for me a way to connect with the viewer on several different levels. I have discovered that painting illusions allows me to communicate with a larger audience, as people genuinely delighted when visually tricked. While both painting techniques claim to express reality truthfully, either suggests only a partial or incomplete view of a subject.
I am also extremely interested in the archival quality of work and how public art is produced, in an ethical and archival way. I have painted murals that are still on display over 20 years later. I feel that viewers of public work have an investment in the upkeep and archival quality of the work. Starting with the proper preparation, the production process should be considered when producing public art. When public art pieces become worn and decay after only a few seasons the public does not see the value in continuing to fund public art. Having worked for several years of trial and error I feel that I could offer proper preparation advice to many of the public art projects.
properties.title: Margaret Cresswell

properties.artist_bio:
Jacquie Comrie is a Toronto- base, multidisciplinary artist whose vibrant body of work intersects contemporary art and wellness at a global scale, using colour as a medium of social impact and mental health.

 Whether as murals on buildings, large scale structures, or canvases, her body of work is a dynamic exploration of the science of colour as the universal language of human emotion, producing works in Canada and internationally.  Colour has been proven to have a direct effect to human emotion, for which her palettes are consciously designed and orchestrated aiming to cater to mental wellbeing at large.

In such divisive times, and with mental health issues on the rise across the globe, her work aims to contribute to much needed spaces of mental elevation and reset,  to ultimately help improve quality of life of all individuals- one wall at a time.
properties.description: With a wellness approach, the work entitled 'Inteligencia Emociónal' aims to shed a light on the importance of mental wellness and positive human emotion.
properties.title: Jacqueline Comrie

properties.artist_bio: I am always interested in participating in mural projects with Street Art Toronto, as it is an amazing opportunity to work with community members and share art in a non-exclusive setting. I have been painting murals for six years now, on brick, wood, concrete, and aluminum surfaces. I generally use bright shades of outdoor acrylics applied with rollers and brush, but occasionally I use spray paint. My subject matter is often nature-focused, depicting flowers insects and animals. Painting in the city, I want the organic, colourful images I create to shine in an otherwise muted and industrialized landscape. I want to create work that can be viewed by anyone, with a message of hope, growth and positive change. I am part of the artist collective The Buck Teeth Girls Club, and through my involvement have grown accustomed to collaboration.
properties.description: The design is a very simple rendering of night and day. It is a subtle look at city life, inspired from patios and porches. The daytime cup of coffee and the night time glass of wine hint at cafes and bars in Toronto.

properties.artist_bio: Emmanuel Jarus is a Canadian-born artist and muralist inspired by the visual human experience. His work reimagines how art can exist in public spaces. For the past 8 years, Jarus has been working with communities across Canada and around the globe to produce large-scale portraits and figures among other images on wall surfaces. They can be found within major cities as well as across rural settings. He has had notable international recognition as a contemporary muralist and figurative painter. He studied briefly at the Academy of Realist Art in Toronto but attributes his knowledge of art to various influences including his grandmother, inspiration from graffiti, and resources found on the internet. The narrative Jarus depicts in his approach communicates a story of individual spirit relevant to the metabolism of that particular neighbourhood. A combination of acrylic, latex and aerosol paint is used to create representations of the people he’s inspired by along his travels. He enjoys painting in public space so that he can understand its context and express it through his work.
properties.description: The mural covers both the east and west side of the underpass, and features two children from the community.
properties.title: Emmanuel Jarus

properties.artist_bio:
Enlivened by his interest in spacial structures and interconnectivity, Andre Kan's paintings serve as excitable blueprints for a possible reality. Each work depicts the artists' signature imaginative building blocks that converge and begin to build upon each other and strengthening each other towards an ever transforming space. Kan's structures are substantial and complex but not yet anchored - they float suspended in his psychological space. In this way Kan's buildings remain a playful proposition for the viewer not yet tied to a specific place or function. With his dynamic formations, Kan propels us towards an ever optimistic future where new connections and constructions have yet to materialize.

His current work investigates the architectural interpretations that respond to our ever advancing society, and suggests what 'possibility' means through self discovery. Examining what mark making and its properties mean, as well as the significance in cause and effect, is important here. Kan's psychological structures depict change and evolution of space, while also questioning the fundamental nature of being and the world that encompasses it.

Andre Kan is a Toronto based painter. Since graduating from the Ontario College of Art & Design University in 2014, he continues his creative pursuits as an Artist, Muralist, Photographer, Curator, Producer, and Musician. His paintings have been showcased throughout Canada with permanent collections in the U.S and China. His murals can also be seen internationally including London, Spain, Portugal and Taiwan.



Email: andrekanart@gmail.com
Instagram: andrekan_
Twitter: @andrekanart

properties.title: Andre Kan

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to work with StART because I am interested in beautifying the cityscape with more public artwork. I would like to learn from and better my practices through the partnerships and opportunities that StART may be able to provide.

I am a freelance illustrator and mural painter based in Toronto. I like being outside. I like to move my body and to work with my hands. I enjoy working with people who share similar ideas and interests in food growing, environmental stewardship and getting outside. Some of the organizations I have worked with include: Greenest City, Urbane Cyclist, Mountain Equipment Co-op and Green Thumbs Growing Kids. I use bright hues and bold line work to create botanical patterns and compositions depicting moments of self-reflection.

My murals can be found across Toronto, in Indonesia, Nepal, Philippines and Hong Kong. I often collaborate with other artists–my most frequent collaborator being Andrea Manica–as well as with the Buck Teeth Girls Club.

I would like the opportunity to create permanent large scale light mural installations in the city of Toronto and internationally. I have extensive experience organizing and coordinating events, murals, and spaces for artists and would like to collaborate with start to create some awe inspiring and internationally acclaimed pieces of art. My last big project was the Reclamation Project. Since then I opened Area51Toronto Creative Studios and have been travelling but Im eager to get back into Murals in the city.

properties.artist_bio: My name is Katrina Canedo and I am a Toronto-based freelance visual artist and live painter. I typically work with acrylic paint and digital art. However, recently I've been getting more into creating murals for commercials spaces (with spray paint and house paint) and would really love to participate and learn more from StrART projects and how the organization beautifies the city. Generally, my work is influenced by how colours and how they shape a subject can express universal stories or emotions especially applying them on portraits to elaborate on the subject's nuanced story/mood. Since my work is essentially influenced by formless colours and emotions, my process basically involves trying to form or incorporate these colours/shapes into the subject I'm reinterpreting into my style. My overall goal for getting involved with StART is to essentially learn and challenge myself in new ways to express that colourful vision.
properties.description: It is an abstract style and take on how the city and its multicultural citizens somehow come together and harmoniously flourish like a beautiful garden. Through the colour palette, the artwork has a magical and even almost a fairy-tale like quality to reflect Toronto being such a multifaceted place that has (and always will) overcome the challenges that come with growing a strong and diverse community.
properties.title: Katrina Canedo

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets

properties.artist_bio:
Aitak Sorahitalab is a visual artist, art educator, and art administrator. She holds a Master’s Degree from the University of Art of Tehran, had several exhibitions of her artwork, and was commissioned to create public art in Iran and Canada (Toronto). She worked as a lecturer at the University of Applied Science Technology in Tehran, Manager of Art and Creation Department, at KANOON (Institute for Intellectual Development for Children and Young Adults), and worked with UNICEF, UNODC and Royal Museum of The Netherland. Since immigrating to Canada, she continued working as an artist, art teacher, and administrator. Aitak worked as a sculptural ceramic artist and mural artist. Passionate about social development, Sorahitalab has co-founded a non-profit organization, Airsa, to help and support new Canadians in the arts in Toronto. She received several art grants and awards (including Newcomer Mentorship, Career Development, RBC Access Fund, Toronto Leaders LAB and etc) from Ontario Art Council and Toronto Art Council as an individual artist and a non-profit organization.
www.aitak.ca
www.airsa.org

properties.description:
ARTIST STATEMENT - Tannis Nielsen:
“The Elder/Honor wall "N’ gekaajig Kidowog" is created to recognize and honour the Indigenous Elders and Leaders of the local Toronto community. The wall features 28 portraits of Peoples named by the local community and 'framed' with floral designs. The name and Nation of each individual will appear under each portrait along with a quote/teaching they have given in relation to the Land, creating an entranceway into traditional ecological knowledge and an awareness of the planet's fragility. It is my intention that all who see this mural will gain a better understanding of where they are located geographically, be reminded that Toronto is located upon Indigenous territory, and deepen their consciousness politically, socially and environmentally.”

In Water Wall (east side of the underpass), the Artist honours water teachings and those who walk for the water, such as Anishinaabe Elder and water-rights advocateJosephine Mandamin.
properties.title: Tannis Neilsen

properties.artist_bio: Hello! I’m Vicky, a young Torontonian and software developer. Truthfully, I’ve been an artist much longer than I’ve been a programmer. I enjoy painting en plein air, attending life drawing, and when possible, applying for opportunities like these. After assisting both friends and professionals with their own murals over the years, I earned opportunities to paint an Outside the Box mural in 2017 (Wilson and Dufferin) and a Bell Box Mural in 2019 (College and University). I’m incredibly grateful to have had opportunities to paint the streets of Toronto, and had wonderful experiences interacting with the community while creating each artwork.
properties.description: The design aims to be simple and non-intrusive, yet enthusiastic. It is reminiscent of confetti, and thus a reminder to viewers that there is always something to celebrate.
properties.title: Vicky Bilbily

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Chris Perez

properties.description: “Positive Vibes” intends to be both striking and energetic. This work manipulates the dimensionality of the box to transform it into a sculptural object; not to take away from the box, but to highlight it as a significant element in the built environment.
properties.title: Kevin Henriques

properties.artist_bio:
hi my names troy, 30, i've lived in toronto 12 yrs. I feel like a multi-faceted artist, having received a graphic design degree at OCADU in 2012 i tend to stratal the line between designer and artist. My passion is painting, but i have a real eye for design and typography

I often work with my concepts digitally, mostly on adobe illustrator and photoshop, sometimes even design and self publish books of my photography and painting.

 My interest in public art comes from my roots in skateboarding. The experience of using the downtown as a space to skate  exposed me to graffiti and street art. From a young age I began to take note of the writing and imagery on the walls. At age 13 i began my endeavour into the graffiti culture. Today, 17 years later,  still a practitioner, i want to stay connected and collaborate with the new generation of artists working here in toronto, i think stART is great for that connection. Creating art in public space is very important to me, i believe cities with little public art are dead cities, narrow minded cities. I judge a city based on how colourful the streets are!

Previous murals i've painted in the city have been graffiti productions or have been more straight-forward text based installations. Recently I've moved some of my painting practice back to the studio, creating landscape work that borders the line of impressionism and abstraction.

i use various mediums, fluent in spray paint, acrylic brush work,  vector based work, sculpture and installation
properties.description: Inspired by vintage advertising and produce boxes, a series of words and phrases have been magnified to create an interesting abstract composition that focus on the formal elements of typography rather then its words.
properties.title: Troy Pynn

properties.description: This is a playful take on the cities transit. By showing connections, pathways and transit icons in a notional way in an arcade styled format, the artist aims to connect different groups of people to show it is a broken game that needs careful and complex consideration of planning.
properties.title: Jon Neilon

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.description: The artwork entitled ‘ASSERTA REPRISE’ is an abstract piece that has a majestic undertone.
properties.title: Evond Blake (Mediah)

properties.description: For six months it is hard to see variety of colors around the city, and colors are associate to happiness movement emotions. The box aims to give people a feeling of positivity through art.
properties.title: Christian Castelblanco

properties.artist_bio: Keight MacLean is a Toronto-based painter, born and raised in Kingston, Ontario. MacLean is an OCAD University graduate and alumna of the school’s revered Florence Program, in Florence, Italy.Inspired by her time studying the old masters first hand, MacLean’s paintings combine the old with the new, reproducing historical portraits by hand before applying contemporary and experimental methods such as fluorescent spray paint, re-harvested artists’ mediums and destructive techniques.With a love for European history, MacLean’s focus on women was born after years of reading male driven histories. Her work now seeks to celebrate the many women in historical portraits, either without name, known only in reference to their male relations or entirely unknown, giving a voice to the silenced.
properties.description: "The Dance" celebrate Toronto's history of diversity as community as a literal dance, everyone holding hands in a continuous circle around the box, jumping and dacing barefoot and smiling and laughing. Bright fluorescent splashes of colour weaving in and out of the dancing group to further highlight how people come together i Toronto to form a unique tapestry.
properties.title: Keight McLean

properties.description: This piece is about an exploration into perception.
properties.title: Huy Lam

properties.description: An improtant part of Toronto is the artistic culture. The design displays music and art through the ages. The primates in the piece symbolise the primitive aspect people share with other creatures of the Earth.
properties.title: Matthew Kapetaneas

properties.artist_bio:
I received my MD in Fine Arts, specialty Textile in Academy of Fine Arts, Sofia, Bulgaria.
I participated in multiple street art projects including garage door and traffic signal box painting, skate parks, charity actions and also took part of the Tomorrowland bridge, Belgium.
I think of my mural art as of geometric fragments, including different native worldwide folklore patterns or anamorphic elements mixed with realistic human character shapes or real life actions.
My arrangements are schematic, inviting the viewer to move into a space of thinking, inspiring to question our making of the world through design and movement images.  I rely on our desire for beauty, poetic and seduction… also not being afraid of taking it to a critical view of social, political and cultural issues.
My work subject matter tends to be inspired by the history, shape, architectural structure, location and community spirit of the wall.
I use different techniques from hand cut stencil to paint printing techniques and free hand painting, spray paint and brush.
properties.description: Every big, modern city has its great patios prepared to make city's habitants like more pleasurable. Patios are an importnt place where different groups get together and socialize. Table patios are essential to the city's life and its urban diversity.
properties.title: Julia Antohi

properties.address: Royal York Rd & Strath Humber Ct
properties.artist_bio:
I want to continue co-collaborating with StART to keep growing as an artist in my skill set, practice and portfolio. With StART’s support I want to be mentored in my mural career with any opportunities to connect with seasoned mural/street artists and get on a swing-stage, aerial lift, use a spray gun, while learning to comprehend XL large walls and huge quantities of paint among advanced techniques of execution and project production. I’ve currently reached the stage of painting garages in Toronto and am interested and ready to go larger.

Bio & Artist Statement
Anya Mielniczek is a Toronto based multidisciplinary artist who combines her fine art background with raw material grit in both private and public sectors creating mixed-media installations, mural work and facilitating community art activations.
The artists approach to mediums includes latex, aerosol and up-cycled waste, working with the mechanical application of spray and the energy of hand brushed strokes (infused with powerful female portraits and garbage bits if possible).
A Queen’s University graduate, Anya’s worked with various organizations, municipalities and businesses creating public art within communities around Toronto and internationally. Recent corporate projects include lead production on HideSeek, a 7000sq foot immersive art experience in Toronto and collaborations with BACARDI, QUO Makeup, Moroccanoil, DELL, RBC, 1800GOTJUNK and Chevrolet. Her commitment to her practice especially when aligned with public spaces is to create with purpose by giving nature a voice while defining a conversation with the viewer that may inspire and bring awareness for sustainable change.
properties.description: The theme behind the design is for it to be informative and current, a helpful hand in spreading awareness and fostering community interest and engagement in practices beneficial to pollinators.
properties.title: Anya Mielniczek

properties.description: The pattern made from the map of the area directly reflects the layout of the community. The design based on the city will allow people to enjoy their public space within their area.
properties.title: Fionna Hanna

properties.artist_bio:
Early on, I perceived that my ambition was the act of painting itself, finding that the process coincided with the workings of my conscious and unconscious mind.Throughout my career I have also been fascinated by realism, specifically trompe l’oeil and it’s ability to affect the viewer. I have been creating trompe l’oeil murals in combination with my abstract works for over 20 years now. It has become for me a way to connect with the viewer on several different levels. I have discovered that painting illusions allows me to communicate with a larger audience, as people genuinely delighted when visually tricked. While both painting techniques claim to express reality truthfully, either suggests only a partial or incomplete view of a subject.
I am also extremely interested in the archival quality of work and how public art is produced, in an ethical and archival way. I have painted murals that are still on display over 20 years later. I feel that viewers of public work have an investment in the upkeep and archival quality of the work. Starting with the proper preparation, the production process should be considered when producing public art. When public art pieces become worn and decay after only a few seasons the public does not see the value in continuing to fund public art. Having worked for several years of trial and error I feel that I could offer proper preparation advice to many of the public art projects.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Margaret Cresswell

properties.artist_bio:
Lynnette Postuma is a landscape architect, designer and muralist.

As a landscape architect, I am interested in the space between buildings and the relationship of objects in their surroundings. I am especially curious about the interactions of people in public places and how to create meaning in the urban environment. I am motivated by a desire to contribute to city building. For the past 15 years, I have worked for some of the world’s best landscape architecture firms in Toronto and beyond.

As a designer, my focus is on the seen and unseen: the influence of soil and water on vegetation and the effect of seasons or time of use. My creative works bring attention to ephemeral and subtle materials such as air, water, decay, light and shadow. I am motivated to make visible the natural processes and histories of our surrounding environment. In recent years, I have completed temporary and permanent installations for the Toronto Design Offsite Festival, Grow Op at the Gladstone Hotel, and Luminato. Current interests include exploring color on a daily basis (@366daysofcolor) and using color to create objects that tell a personal story.

As a muralist, I am keen to explore colour, texture and material. Completed in 2018, "Gradation" is a 12,000 sq’ outdoor mural of stylized colour changes moving from blue to green and informed by the existing vegetation and building materials on the West Toronto Railpath. Ideas that merge past and present history as well as local ecologies are key components of my work. Nothing is a blank slate; subsequent mural projects tie into themes connecting colour with existing material and texture.

Working with StART has opened new possibilities and synergies between landscape and art in the public realm. I am motivated to explore new mural projects, mixed-media art projects and expanding connections through networking and community building.
properties.description: Each of the 14,508 cinder blocks in this work titled ‘Gradation’ are painted in in minute variations of blue and green to integrate this building into its adjacent surroundings and transform this otherwise monotonous grey façade into a dynamic element within Toronto’s West Toronto Railpath. Produced by StART in collaboration with Parks, Forestry and Recreation, Friends of the West Toronto Railpath and deRail.
properties.title: Lynnette Postuma

properties.artist_bio: Rodrigo Castro, aka “Bomi" was born in León, Mexico and is now based in Toronto. His artwork is highly representative of his Latin American culture and boasts colourful patterns, symbols, and geometric shapes through his distinctive minimalistic style.
properties.description: The design contributes to a sense of identity in the local community as the work reflects visual language through the use of patterns, symbols, hieroglyphs, geometry and colours that have existed across many cultures since the earliest cave drawings and images created by man.
properties.title: Rodrigo Castro

properties.address: Kingston Rd & Cromwell Rd & Guildwood Pkwy
properties.title: Untitled

properties.description: Raccoons and Toronto go hand in hand. Usually though they are seen as pesky bandits. This box puts them in a happier light, hanging out in nature and being swept up in various elements of the ravines around the city.
properties.title: Justin Pape

properties.artist_bio:
Vivian Rosas is a Toronto based Latinx illustrator and designer. Since graduating from OCADU, her primary work has been in editorial illustration, as well as in the animated video sphere. Her work is created in a variety of mediums including digital and screen-printing. She seeks to explore themes of feminism, empowerment, and diversity. Play and discovery are key to her practice, especially when she gets a chance to work on a mural.

As a Latinx illustrator, I like to focus on representation and cultural diversity in my work. I strive to create imagery that expresses a sense of inclusiveness and community. I'd love to work with StART so that I can continue creating fun, bold and vibrant pieces to brighten up the city of Toronto. I want to share my vision of a diverse and eclectic city and have people to feel represented in my work. I think my modern take and designs can bring new life to the city.
properties.description: The design is inspired by the young vibrant community of people in the city. The people can be seen in the local farmer’s markets, on trendy Queen west, headed to yoga, or delivering your lunch. Showing the range of diversity, and creativity the community has.
properties.title: Vivian Rosas

properties.description: The design incorporates two Islamic geometric paterns in heavenly shades of blue. The design can be enjoyed for its own safe or it can bea window into the infinite.
properties.title: Aneesa Patel

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & Superior Ave
properties.description: The design is an aquarium of endangered species, emphasizing humans' relationship with animals in the wild and the mystery that these creatures hold.
properties.title: Jen Bulthuis

properties.artist_bio:
Al “Runt” Currie is an iconic Canadian artist, with impressive works displayed both a home and internationally. His works are vibrant, colourful, abstract and fun, full of life and imagination, and accessible by people of all ages. His strong connection to Canada and, in particular, Toronto, is demonstrated by his works displayed, including Lee's Palace. At another recent internationally-recognized event, Runt was invited to represent Canada’s art scene as artistic lead for the International Fortune 500 event, held in September 2018, at Toronto’s Evergreen Brick Works, where he completed numerous art works including a 40-foot mural for an audience, comprised of international industry titans, policy and thought leaders, as well as Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.
What Critics Have Said…:
“Enter the world of Runt. At once familiar and unfamiliar, his works are of this world but definitely not of this world. Informed by a wide range of influences from Hieronymus Bosch to Dr. Seuss, Runt’s work embodies a love and critique of humanity as his monster scene-scapes play out in front of the viewer’s eyes. If one could press “play” on any of his scenes and advance them, the scenes would look entirely different. Runt’s characters capture the joy and aggression of our urban existence. But the beauty in Runt’s works is that they don't judge, they simply present. Known for his large murals, Lee’s Palace and The Electric Mud BBQ, Runt’s art is found in many private collections. Runt’s passionate adventure has turned into a career as one of Canada’s singular visionaries, on par with other 80s icons such as Keith Haring and Kenny Scharf.”
Runt is interested in participating in the StArt project, as he looks forward to continuing his contributions to the Toronto arts scene and community, sharing his experiences and expertise with other artists while also learning from them.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Runt

properties.description: Post-war bungalows are prevalent in East York, this iconic architecture forms the pedestrian-oriented block pattern neighbourhoods. The single story pitched roof bungalow is a motif in forming a mosaic abstract pattern. The design and colour scheme is largely inspired by the particular light of Southwest Ontario, and the artist Greg Curnoe.
properties.title: Stefan Berg

properties.artist_bio:
Blaze Wiradharma is an OCADU Graduate with a BDES in Illustration. After living in Singapore for the last two years,  he has returned to Toronto to continue freelancing as a Mural / Graffiti Artist, Illustrator and Graphic Designer. In his early beginnings, his interest in visual communication was sparked by graffiti and street art. These forms influenced him heavily, his style reflecting the vibrant and often bold nature of urban art. This also encouraged the development of letters, calligraphy & characters which are a large part of his work.

Blaze takes inspiration from all facets of his own life experiences, and strives to create imagery which reflects lessons that he has learned along with social commentary. He believes that large mural artwork in the public sphere has a responsibility to create questions in the viewers mind and encourage critical thinking. Blaze utilises spray paint and exterior latex to create his exterior and interior work. He strives to work with StART's amazing team to further develop his mural work, add to the already impressive visual landscape of Toronto, and also creating opportunities for emerging artists to grow and develop along side him.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Blaze Wiradharma

properties.artist_bio:
For the last three years, I've had the fortune to be part of various StART projects and it is truly inspiring for me as a street artist to see the support from the city towards this art form. I'd love to continue working with StART and be part of this art movement!
Bio: My artistic work is the result of my experiences living and working in various parts of Latin America. The rich and vibrant cultures of the places I’ve visited have been my main inspiration to create and share my artistic vision with others. As a Canadian-Colombian artist is empowering for me to paint around the themes of culture, nature, and identity enriching Canadian multiculturalism. Most of my murals are found in Canada and Colombia, my wish is to continue painting across Canada and the world.
properties.description: The box is a Pre-Columbian figure inspired by the Flora and Fauna from Latin America, especially the Amazons.
properties.title: Daniela Rocha

properties.artist_bio: Life is a learning process. The intuitive pull to create has been part of my learning process for as long as I can remember. I have been creating public and street art in some fashion since childhood.  I’ve painted from coast to coast and internationally as well as for a range of clients from charities to mom and pops shops to multinational corporations. I’ve worked on several StART programs over the years and truly appreciate the projects and processes that the team puts forward. I’ve been fortunate enough to engage with artists, cultural representatives, and residents through these city programs. People I might otherwise not have connected and built relationships with, which is why I hope to continue to create, Grow and learn with the StART team in this great place we call Toronto.
properties.description: The artist's abstract designs are representative of their life’s story and the journey through it alongside the people and communities around them. The design is representative of the journeys that the community is taking.
properties.title: Zachary Scott-Cheetham

properties.artist_bio:
SPUD1 has been a fixture in the Toronto urban and underground art scene for more than 18 years. An accomplished artist, he loves the thrill of finding unconventional spaces to showcase his talent.
SPUD1’s passion for art has grown along with his talent. He is a well-rounded artist that is capable of working with all types of mediums and images, and specializes in working collaboratively with other artists.
SpudBomb was founded by SPUD1 in 2010, when he traveled across Europe, covering many cities with his funny and happy SpudBomb characters and happy Grenades.
Team SpudBomb is comprised of Spud1 & his partner Brooke, together they curate and manage various artists projects and large scale murals, both collaboratively and on behalf of Spud1 himself.
Since 2014 Team SpudBomb – working under the event Wall Expressions; has been working in partnership and fully funded through StART to curate Laneway events that help to create live outdoor galleries in laneways that experience graffiti vandalism.  These events allow the community and artist to engage and reclaim public spaces, and create conversation about art and how it can serve the neighbourhood/community when incorporate in public spaces.
In 2016 SPUD1 was one of the featured artists in the Doors Open Toronto colouring book and was successful in his grant application with the Bloordale BIA to install a huge mural within that community, which has been exceptionally well received, and working with brands such as CAT, Converse, Mountain Dew, Universal Studios, and Crystal Head Vodka. In addition to this, his installation of the Pride Mural at Church and Wood received a special award for his dedication and activism in the TPS & StART Toronto partnership program.
In 2017 Spud completed a huge Mural called the Smile on Dufferin, the ribbon cutting and mural unveiling was opened by city councilor & Deputy Mayor Ana Bailao.
In 2018 Spud1 and Sean Martindale completed the mural “Tapestry of Movement at the Toronto Coach Terminal through the City’s StART partnership program with STEPS Initiative, and saw him working with brands such as Sketchers.
In 2019  Team Spudbomb was awarded a partnership Grant through the City of Toronto to paint an over 2,000 square foot underpass, an invitation to paint a large mural at Concrete canvas festival in Hamilton and a request to paint at Kotis Street Art in Greensboro, North Carolina.
These are just a few examples throughout the past 6 years where Spud1 has exemplified the type of artist he is, one which continually sees markets, festivals, other artists and brands wanting to work with him in addition to Team Spudbomb continuing to work with old school and emerging talents to bring together events that foster community engagements and relationships.
SPUD1’s dedication and commitment to seeing the projects he is involved in through is only overshadowed by his installations themselves.
SPUD1 continues to grow and evolve as an artist and is always looking for new and exciting opportunities to express himself and showcase his art., SPUD1 has been a fixture in the Toronto urban and underground art scene for more than 18 years.
