properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: five8 / BirdO & Friends

properties.description: The design is an homage to dancer. In our current world, where most people work at highly sedentary jobs, it is important to promote movement and an active lifestyle. Dance is not only exercise, but expressive, non competitive, and joyful. All cultures have some form of dance, which brings people together and allows for joy and expression. Contemporary dance is the result of a lot of work done by pioneering women, and especially queer people, and people of colour, which deserves to be honoured. These groups of people are all cultural producers in Toronto who still struggle for space and recognition within the art world.
properties.title: Louise Reimer

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to work with StART because I have a history of working on public and community-engaged mural projects and programs, many of which have been supported and in partnership with StART. I believe in the values of the StART programs and have experienced the dedication of the team to carrying out these values through supporting and partnering.

I am a visual artist passionate about arts engagement and education, collaborative art making, and murals. These practices bridge my background from a Bachelor of Fine Art in Drawing & Painting from OCAD University and a Community Arts Practice Certificate from York University. Since 2011, I have worn many ‘hats’ in the mural, art and community arts field; from artist, arts educator, facilitator, curator, arts administrator and project manager. I have had the opportunity to work and learn from these experiences, building adaptability and flexibility through working in unique situations including libraries, schools, art galleries, community centres, seniors centres, skate parks, abandoned storefronts (you name it!). I have built a strong rapport working with many artists and arts organizations such as Mural Routes, Vibe Arts, Nuit Blanche, Lakeshore Arts, Platform A, Scribble me Silly, Arts Etobicoke and East End Arts. In particular, I have worked closely with Mural Routes since 2011, as Program Coordinator, Facilitator, Curriculum Coordinator, and Program Director, with a focus on mentorship and the Mural Art Learning Institute programs.

My creative processes for involving community and youth in projects within their own neighbourhoods are based in facilitation style that creatively employs storytelling, brainstorming, and playful art techniques like collage to encourage conversations, confidence and to bring many ideas together into action. It gives me great joy to facilitate consultation, design, art making and mural making to bring community members together to reflect and re-imagine their neighbourhood. I love any opportunity to nurture participants’ creative abilities and create a safe space for exploration and connection through visual arts and storytelling. I see art as a tool for exploring themes, beginning conversation, gathering patterns and beginning important dialogue. Mural consultation and participation offers a space where artists and community members alike can share, exchange, grow and work together.
properties.description: The design is inspired by the design of vintage travel posters, and is meant to playfully “advertise” local neighbourhood sights.
properties.title: Tara Dorey

properties.address: Dundas St W & Howard Park Ave
properties.description: To aboriginial peoples living by the water, the Lake Ontario salmon was sacred and an important part of their diet. The vision of the spirits of salmon on the box offersa reminder of the lake that lies nearby, and a moment to admire the magnificence of these creatures, who are returning home.
properties.title: Claire Correia

properties.artist_bio:
I’d love to work with StreetARToronto because I’m inspired by the artistic legacy they are building in the City of Toronto. StART’s vision to create beautiful and safer public spaces with a mandate to act inclusively, celebrate our strengths in diversity, to acknowledge and respect the cultures and lands of Indigenous persons, and mentor emerging talents, all reflect my own values in my professional and personal life.

I’ve been an artist for 20 years in the public realm, having exhibited in public art galleries, artist-run centres, art festivals, and having worked with public/private planning teams to create permanent public art with budgets up to $56,000.00 (Holland Bloorview Kids Rehabilitation Hospital). I work in several disciplines including sculpture (polyurethane resins, concrete, casting techniques), installation art (interactive works that light up, make noise, or move - typically destined for art festivals/events such as Nuit Blanche, Animating Our Waterfront, Hamilton Supercrawl), and painting murals.

My passion for community arts participation cemented over 15 years ago when I sat on the board of Carfac Ontario as Vice Chair, with Merlin Homer as Chair, a Mohawk Elder whom I consider as a mentor. We had an exceptional team of strong arts leaders and my experience at Carfac helped mould my understanding of fair remuneration, cultural/ethnic/language/gender challenges that artists’ face, and the importance of advocating for one another’s communities.  Profoundly affected by this experience, I’ve continued to work with communities and have co-founded three successful art collectives, Open Field Collective, KJ Bit, and Creativo Collective, whose mandates are to create artwork and murals in public spaces while being inclusive of surrounding communities. In 2017, the Open Field Collective was awarded the national ArtBridges award for “Innovation” in recognition of our dedication to community engagement and our “Street Projects” where we invented miniature art galleries to create and display artwork in public spaces such as residential front yards, King Street (Public Realm), and Guelph. We’ve partnered with Scouts Canada, Neilson Creative Centre (Etobicoke), King Edward PS, been sponsored by Waterfront Toronto, and supported by Neighbourhood Associations and private and corporate donors.

Last year, I was lead coordinator for one of StreetARToronto’s laneway mural/graffiti projects. It was a wonderful opportunity to mentor my KJ Bit collaborator, June Kim, as a facilitator in the project. This summer, we’ll be coordinating the second phase of this Euclid/Palmerston laneway with a roster of 40 artists and be presenting a WalkShop tour of this laneway for delegates of the National Association of City Transportation Officials. This September, we’ll be painting a mural in partnership with StreetARToronto and TTC at Finch Station. My goal is to continue painting more murals, participating in more laneway jams and creating new, innovative street art events. I’d love to continue working with StreetARToronto because I believe we have mutual respect for the experience and expertise that both sides bring to the table. Above all, I love learning new things, and StreetARToronto has given me a great opportunity to grow as an artist and a facilitator.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Erika James

properties.artist_bio: OTB artist in 2019 and 2018. Bell Box mural artist in 2012 as well as other Toronto public murals and public sculptures including for the TTC dating back to 1999. Past experiences also include art instructor and community engagement via art initiatives in the far North as well as here in Southern Ontario.
properties.title: Jungle Ling

properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Ben Johnston

properties.description: Box reflects the women of Toronto to celebrate their differences.
properties.title: Samantha Chiusolo

properties.description: The design serves as a beacon to connect the mixed-use strip of Queen Street East to the nearby beaches. The playful design is speaks to the character of the Beaches neighbourhood and celebrates the natural assets of the beach and its year- round fun. The design includes beach-themed items that not only nod to summer activities but also to the people who surf year-round, and to the public art winter installations (Winter Stations) recognized by the life preserver.
properties.title: Studio Jaywall

properties.address: Warden Ave & St Clair Ave E
properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.
properties.description: A leaf-like form revolves around the box creating a sense of motion or continuation. The pattern-like aesthetic creates a tone of movement using the idea of repetition and constant.
properties.title: Chris Perez

properties.artist_bio: Karun is an emerging artist & educator based out of Etobicoke, ON. Born and raised in South India, He immigrated to Canada in 2015 to pursue a career in Visual Art. He is a graduate and President's Medal winner from the Visual and Digital Arts program at Humber College. His work displays abstract and representational conceptual art that engages with narrative, environmental, technological and fantastical elements. Inspired by Climate Change, diversity and sustainability, Karun's work always aims to constantly inquire about the social, moral and ethical norms of post-modern society.  Karun has experience as an animator on TV shows, has an impeccable academic track record, art & design installation experience at festivals and venues like Winterstations, EDIT Design festival, Hamilton Artists Inc. and VAC Clarington.  He is currently an applicant for the Toronto Outdoor Art Fair.
properties.description: The design is a minimalistic attempt to shed light upon some of the most pressing issues of the 21st century.
properties.title: Karun Ramani

properties.artist_bio:
Christopher Ross (aka GAWD) is a surrealist artist from Montreal. Ross has created murals and exhibition pieces in various Canadian and international cities and has been an important part of Montréal’s street art community since the nineties.

Among the hundreds of jobs Christopher completed while pursuing art, was fixing egg machines. Christopher soon discovered the ink used to date eggs was an interesting medium for painting,  directly influencing his signature splatters and eventually the use of liquid watercolour. Along with occasional access to painting materials, Christopher’s various jobs made him more aware of the working class struggle, and, relationships among people, nature and the environment.
properties.title: Christopher Ross

properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Ben Johnston

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to continue working with StART because they support the creation of art that makes our public realm a more beautiful and inviting place. StART has helped me create meaningful work that strengthens communities and enables me to develop my practice of using art as a way to build inclusive communities who celebrate their identity with pride. I would like to develop my leadership skills and am interested in mentorship opportunities where I can learn how to work more effectively with the city to realize large scale initiatives that give more artists and community members opportunities to feel empowered through the process of creating art in the public realm.

I am a Toronto based visual artist, community organizer, muralist, curator, and eternal optimist. My work is motivated by my desire to spread joy, nurture present minded living, cultivate gratitude, and foster new social interactions from a place of love and empathy. Using aerosol and acrylic paint, I work with bright colours and bold patterns to captivate people’s attention and fill them with delight and hope. I am passionate about creating art that both aesthetically and psychologically brightens the streets and work to build a community around positive living.

My belief that public art is a powerful tool for building community drives my practice. In 2017, I founded Womxn Paint, an annual street art jam that has produced 44 murals celebrating the strength and diversity of womxn. I would like to continue this initiative and grow it to include additional programming that supports the professional development of womxn artists and more opportunities for young girls to learn about mural arts. In 2016, I facilitated an intergenerational mural at Baycrest Health Sciences and would like work more with the senior community.

Over the last six years, I have created custom large-scale outdoor artworks for clients including The New Yorker, Tourism Canada, the City of Toronto, the City of Mississauga, the Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany in Toronto, the STEPS Initiative, Arts Etobicoke, East End Arts and private clients.
properties.description: This design is  motivated by the artist's desire to spread joy, nurture present minded living, cultivate gratitude, and foster new social interactions. The artist's mission to connect with people through art and grow the collective conversation about the power of optimism feels closely aligned with CAMH’s vision, mission, and goals.
properties.title: Bareket Kezwer

properties.artist_bio: An active painter and sculptor living in downtown Toronto, I completed my MA in Contemporary and Modern Art History at the University of Toronto (2013) and earned an Honours BA in Visual Art from the University of Ottawa. I have exhibited locally, nationally and internationally at professional venues including Mercer Union (Toronto), Division Gallery, Clark House Mumbai, and the Queen’s Museum of Art, N.Y. An active member of the local arts community, I am also Co-Director of Akin, an organization that provides affordable studio space to over three hundred artists and free programming toToronto’s creative community. Recently, my artwork has continued to evolve as I consider new avenues for display and exhibition, pursuing opportunities to create public artworks in new, everyday settings. Outside The Box 2019 would enable me to not only beautify Toronto, but insert vibrancy, pattern and passion into the everyday lives of our citizens.
properties.description: The design is inspired by nature (leaves, waves) and the ability of urban centers and it’s public to change and radiate in different ways at once- emotively, architecturally, demographically and more.
properties.title: Michael Vickers

properties.artist_bio: Sari Richter grew up in Ancaster, Ontario and moved to Toronto where she completed a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting at Ontario College of Art and Design University and a Masters Certification from the Toronto Art Therapy Institute. She works in traditional and non-traditional drawing, painting and printmaking media and looks forward to challenging commissions. Sari is also a published children’s book illustrator, storyboard artist and muralist. She is currently employed as an art therapist and works with transitional aged youth.
properties.description: Autumn Path' is a reflection of many of the areas in Toronto. It is a take on a style which could also possibly recall the Group Of Seven's artwork, which on the box would also integrate a Canadian art history and identity as a whole.
properties.title: Sari Richter

properties.description: Commemorate!' is about acknowledging the passion and kindness people bring to our communities with an uplifting, whimsical illustration.
properties.title: Suharu Ogawa

properties.artist_bio: Emmanuel Jarus is a Canadian-born artist and muralist inspired by the visual human experience. His work reimagines how art can exist in public spaces. For the past 8 years, Jarus has been working with communities across Canada and around the globe to produce large-scale portraits and figures among other images on wall surfaces. They can be found within major cities as well as across rural settings. He has had notable international recognition as a contemporary muralist and figurative painter. He studied briefly at the Academy of Realist Art in Toronto but attributes his knowledge of art to various influences including his grandmother, inspiration from graffiti, and resources found on the internet. The narrative Jarus depicts in his approach communicates a story of individual spirit relevant to the metabolism of that particular neighbourhood. A combination of acrylic, latex and aerosol paint is used to create representations of the people he’s inspired by along his travels. He enjoys painting in public space so that he can understand its context and express it through his work.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Emmanuel Jarus

properties.description: The box is inspired by the nearby Allan Gardens Conservatory.
properties.title: Angelica Fernandes

properties.artist_bio: I am a Canadian Illustrator and designer currently working and residing in Toronto, Ontario. Through my work, I largely explore themes of popular culture and everyday objects. Using tongue in cheek characters and whimsical settings and scenarios I enjoy paying homage to the seemingly mundane and understated. My work can be experienced in a range of formats, such as animations, comics, as well as an array of handmade wearableitems and housewares which I both love to design and craft. My work can also be experienced through my freelance jobs including both indoor and outdoor sign-painting, a large-scale mural at the corner of Peter and Richmond in downtown Toronto in 2016, as well as my past Outside the Box traffic box that I painted at the corner of Brimley and Lawrence in the summer of 2017 which was a wonderful experience.
properties.description: The design aims to explore the concepts of Toronto's ever-changing architecture. The design hopes to relfect the idea of building, re-birth and growth.
properties.title: Meg Dearlove

properties.description: The design is an ode to randomness and playfulness. With a black background nd bright neon line drawings on top, it looks very similar to chal drawings. The ones made by neighbourhood kids on sidewalks in the summer It is a reminder to show how something so simpe can bring so much joy.
properties.title: Katey Simerson

properties.description: The design focuses upon the little things that makes a community a whole.
properties.title: Alice Zhang

properties.address: St Clair Ave W & Avenue Rd
properties.artist_bio:
My murals play with patterning, painted as if successive layers of wallpaper have been carelessly removed, casually revealing the contrasting elements that lay beneath. Pattern, in the form of repeating decorative motifs, is a ubiquitous form of human expression. Many designs are so distinct they instantly call to mind a particular culture or part of the world. Some repeat over and over again throughout history.

The motifs that are revealed in my layered murals are from a broad range of eras and cultures. In the tremendously diverse reality of a contemporary globalized world, my paintings are a commentary on the fact that we are all in this together: collaborating, teaching, learning from, and inspiring one another.

I have ten years experience as a working artist, and have created numerous large-scale murals, many with the support of StART. I deeply appreciate the opportunities StART has given me, which have included larger and larger walls, international locations, and a lot of support in troubleshooting the many complexities that arise with mural creation!

My goals in the future are to move to creating multi-level murals (ie. more than 2 stories tall), to increase the number of assistants I use (thereby increasing mentorship, which I love to do, while decreasing installation time), and to paint more nationally and internationally. I would also love to continue to increase my knowledge of materials, and develop a "starting a mural" checklist, with timelines (ie. "Book Lift - 1 month ahead", "Order Paint - 2 weeks ahead"). I see a lot of big artists painting at festivals, where the timelines are tight, so increasing my speed is another goal for the years ahead.
properties.description: This design is a playful remix of contemporary design trends popular in Toronto. Inspired by 80s design and dance culture, Art Deco and Pop Art, and contemporary architecture, it plays on motifs seen along Queen street, at underground zine fairs like Canzine and the Toronto Art Book Fair, and at galleries throughout the city. It is a remix of the fun elements and cutting-edge aesthetics that make up contemporary Toronto’s street scenes. The bold geometric shapes hint at the surrounding architecture, while the frenetic patterns emphasize the people and energy of the people in the streets.
properties.title: Kirsten McCrea

properties.artist_bio: Paula Gonzalez-Ossa is a mural artist who has been working with diverse communities producing street level public art, both in Canada and Latin America for over 25 years. Her ongoing work with StARToronto dates back to 2015. Her murals, like the most recent 500 ft. mural titled "Our Medicines"  located at the underpass at Dupont and Shaw, or "The Ancestral Tree Spirits" located at the Nordheimer Ravine's TTC station exit, depict a colourful  First Nations cosmovision in relation to the Original lands of Ontario, working closely with Anishnawbe  mentors, Elders and Knowledge Keepers. Gonzalez-Ossa is currently  the Indigenous Education Officer at the AGO’s Weston Learning Centre, as part of the Public Programming and Learning Department, and the Visual Arts instructor and mentoring artist at Na Me Res Sagatay Native Men's Residence. She brings 19 years experience as a  Community Youth Worker with youth at risk in Toronto's West.Some of her previous public works include: a 120 foot mural honoring First Nations from North and South America,  which was the recipient of  the 2014 Ward 27 City Builder’s Award, formerly at Allan Gardens. Other locations sport a ribbon-style mural at Women’s Residence, a women’s shelter at Dundas and Bathurst, in collaborations with an all women crew (2015), and a 4 wall rendition of the Medicine Wheel, inside of Na Me Res Sagatay’s courtyard (2016).  In sharp contrast she produced an indoor mural with 22 students from grades 6-8 at refugee host school Beverley Heights Middle School (2017).She recently served in the capacity of Resident Artist at the Power Plant gallery, developing mural arts programs at two satellite locations with youth from priority neighbouroods in Toronto’s West.(2017-2018). In 2018-2019 she worked closely with the 7Th Generation Image Makers at the Native Youth Resource Centre to mentor, facilitate and produce a mural with an all Indigenous women’s team, located  at the South facing wall at Christie Pits Park’s Alex Duff Memorial Pool. Her two most recent productions  funded by StART’s Partnership Grant in 2019,located at the front façade of Sagatay Naïve Men’s Residence, and the adjacent alley,  depict  “Medicines and Guardians”, as well as “The Wolves Running South”.Last but not least, Gonzalez-Ossa is one of the featured artists at the “You’ve Changed “ exhibit by STARToronto , at St Lawrence Market’s  “Market Gallery”. At the exhibit, the video display shows us her latest short documentary produced  for SART, about the basic protocols entailed when developing images in partnership with Indigenous Nations here in Canada.Gonzalez-Ossa  has been  voted Best Graffiti Artist for the City of Toronto by Now Magazine’s Reader’s Poll in 1997, in 2009, 2010, and 2011. In addition, she has been featured on  CBC (Radio and Television, varying shows), Much Music, MTV, Global Televison, City TV, TVO, CTV, Bell Fibe TV1, Rogers Television, and Telelatino, as well as various television  appearances in Chile, USA (NYC/California), and Jamaica.
properties.description: Created by lead artist Paula Gonzalez-Ossa and Na-Me-Res this mural features a vibrant design of the lands, water, flora and fauna that once existed in the areas around Garrison Creek.
properties.title: Paula Gonzalez-Ossa (Bomba)

properties.artist_bio: I'm a Toronto-based fine artist, illustrator and mural artist. I'm very inspired by the things around me, and the people in my life. I utilize a lot of different mediums into my art practice such as oils, acrylics, watercolour, ink, graphite, spray paint and exterior latex paint. I have been involved in various community-led projects, private and commercial mural commissions. The most impactful projects that I've been apart of, have led me to mentor youth artists and that has been the most rewarding part of those projects. An extension of youth mentorship, I'm also the Artist-in-Residence at Waterfront Neighbourhood Centre. I instruct Room 13, an international Studio that guides a growing network of student-run arts studios in schools and community settings globally. In the past few years, I have been apart of numerous Bell Box Murals Project throughout the city as well as START Outside the Box in 2018.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals Project, by Michael Cavanaugh, transforms non-descript outdoor utilities infrastructure into local works of art making the streets more inviting to residents and visitors, and act as a skills-building gateway into mural-making for emerging artists.
properties.title: Tak Bui and Lula Lumaj

properties.artist_bio: Nicole D'Amario is an illustrator and mural artist, who dabbles in ceramics. Since 2016 she has been teaching children how to create public art though weekly classes. Nicole has collaborated with the Beaches International Jazz Festival to give children and the general public the opportunity to create public artwork (including murals) for their own spaces such as libraries, schools and hospitals. Much of Nicole's public mural work has been as a part of the Buck Teeth Girls Club, a female collective consisting of Melissa Luk, Caitlin Taguibao, Andrea Manica and herself. Clients include Good for Her, Mountain Equipment Coop, The City of Toronto and more.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals Project, by Michael Cavanaugh, transforms non-descript outdoor utilities infrastructure into local works of art making the streets more inviting to residents and visitors, and act as a skills-building gateway into mural-making for emerging artists.
properties.title: Nicole D’Amario

properties.artist_bio: Mahjabeen Kabir (Mahja) (b. 1993, Abu Dhabi, UAE)  is an emerging visual mixed media artist living and studying in Toronto, ON. Previously having a background in Science, she is currently exploring her creative pursuit and hoping to have a career in Design. Her style uses vibrant colours, shapes and patterns to form dreamlike depictions of altered realities. She draws inspiration from nature and is always on the search of greater understanding. She delves into the emotions of memories to capture the essence of what once was, questions realities, explores curiosities within the self and surroundings and hopes to inspire people to explore themselves and question the world.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals Project, by Michael Cavanaugh, transforms non-descript outdoor utilities infrastructure into local works of art making the streets more inviting to residents and visitors, and act as a skills-building gateway into mural-making for emerging artists.
properties.title: Mahabeer Kabir

properties.description: The Bell Box Murals Project, by Michael Cavanaugh, transforms non-descript outdoor utilities infrastructure into local works of art making the streets more inviting to residents and visitors, and act as a skills-building gateway into mural-making for emerging artists.
properties.title: Christian Castelblanco

properties.artist_bio:
Ted Hamer is a multidisciplinary Artist and educator based in Toronto. His work explores the juxtaposition of nature with human constructs through explorations into challenging humanities anthropocentric views towards ourselves and our environment. He merges historical approaches to realist and modern art to explore the nature vs culture divide through figures that examine various overlapping themes of anthropocenterism using natural and man made elements and materials.
Ted's work has exhibited in the Art Gallery of Ontario, the Steamwhistle Gallery, the RMG, The Station Gallery, Nathan Phillips Square, Bluffs Gallery, the Super Wonder Gallery and his Sculptural Mural Installation is the centerpiece installation of the Aurora Cultural Centre in Aurora Ontario.

In paint I work with Aerosol and acrylic and Latex. In Sculpture I work in clays, fibreglass, resins, bronze and wood and am now experimenting with 3D printed pieces. I would like to work with StART to develop more street art that challenges the urban landscape with art based on nature and animals. My practice is moving more to the 3D side of things and I would like to work with StART to fabricate more street level sculptural pieces as I see the need for that in Toronto.
I have mentored many emerging artists but I feel I could use help in taking my own practice to the next level possibly through mentor ship or guidance from another artist.
I also coordinate creative projects and have worked previously with StART on the Outside the Box Program, with the Bell Box Murals Project and with the Aurora Cultural Centre facilitating workshops, designing and creating artwork and mentoring emerging artists.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals Project, by Michael Cavanaugh, transforms non-descript outdoor utilities infrastructure into local works of art making the streets more inviting to residents and visitors, and act as a skills-building gateway into mural-making for emerging artists.
properties.title: Ted Hamer & Seniors Group

properties.description: This series of murals along Dundas Street West created as part of a cultural exchange celebrates the relationship between Canada and Chile and, in particular the cities of Toronto and Valparaiso.
properties.title: Rodrigo Ardiles

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.description: These two landmark murals titled 'DRIFT APPENDAR', contrast the warm organic communities with the coldness of the adjacent industrial area and enliven this southwest Scarborough neighbourhood
properties.title: Evond Blake (MEDIAH)

properties.artist_bio:
Jacquie Comrie is a Toronto- base, multidisciplinary artist whose vibrant body of work intersects contemporary art and wellness at a global scale, using colour as a medium of social impact and mental health.

 Whether as murals on buildings, large scale structures, or canvases, her body of work is a dynamic exploration of the science of colour as the universal language of human emotion, producing works in Canada and internationally.  Colour has been proven to have a direct effect to human emotion, for which her palettes are consciously designed and orchestrated aiming to cater to mental wellbeing at large.

In such divisive times, and with mental health issues on the rise across the globe, her work aims to contribute to much needed spaces of mental elevation and reset,  to ultimately help improve quality of life of all individuals- one wall at a time.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals Project, by Michael Cavanaugh, transforms non-descript outdoor utilities infrastructure into local works of art making the streets more inviting to residents and visitors, and act as a skills-building gateway into mural-making for emerging artists.
properties.title: Jacquie Comrie

properties.artist_bio: Through his artistic journey Rob Matejka has embraced art as a medium for positive social intervention and enjoys animating the communities and people he works with - making art accessible to all through; workshops, mentoring, and adding to the growing outdoor public gallery. Rob has been an arts educator and mentor for over 12 years - having worked with organizations across Toronto such as; Lakeshore Arts, Mural Routes, TDSB, The Toronto Public Library, VIBE Arts, and more. Rob enjoys using murals to create spaces we enter and experience physically - while coordinating large scale projects engaging large numbers of community members to beautify communities and build community pride.
properties.description: Celebrating the Canada-China Year of Tourism 2018, and the 20th anniversary of the Chinese Culture Centre, this mural illustrates 'multiculturalism, coming together, sharing and harmony" and promotes mutual respect, unity and prosperity.
properties.title: Rob Matejka

properties.artist_bio:
Jieun June Kim is a Toronto based, Korean born painter and muralist.  She has exhibited her paintings around the world since 2010 at notable galleries and events, exploring the idea of “home” as an immigrant and creating safe space.
Jieun completed the Mural Art Career Development program offered by Mural Routes in 2017 and has since worked with various arts organizations, city of Toronto as well as corporate partners such as Samsung, Up Canada, and Collective Arts Brewery.
 She is the co-founder of KJ Bit Collective who creates murals and street art events, and a member of the Mural Routes advisory committee team. She is also the recipient of the Newcomer and Refugee Artist Mentorship grant from the Toronto Arts Council (2018).
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals Project, by Michael Cavanaugh, transforms non-descript outdoor utilities infrastructure into local works of art making the streets more inviting to residents and visitors, and act as a skills-building gateway into mural-making for emerging artists.
properties.title: Jieun June Kim

properties.address: Lawrence Ave East Underpass, west of Carnforth Road
properties.artist_bio:
Dan Bergeron is a public artist who employs a range of styles, themes and materials to activate and explore the meaning of our shared public spaces. The shape, texture and location of a site and its history or current uses dictate the form and content of his projects. Dan’s public installations aim to open a dialog with viewers, promoting engagement through both intimate familiarity and wonder at the unexpected.

Dan has created public art projects for municipalities across Canada (Toronto, Mississauga, Ottawa, Gaspe, Calgary, Richmond), working in both two-dimensional mediums (murals, photo-based wheat pasting) and three dimensional sculpture. He has also been commissioned by the AGO, MOCA Toronto, the ROM and corporate clients Nike, Converse and Vespa.
properties.description: Representing the divergent themes of nature and architecture this visually striking mural relates to both the physical and historical aspects of the surrounding community.
properties.title: Dan Bergeron

properties.artist_bio: I'm a Toronto-based fine artist, illustrator and mural artist. I'm very inspired by the things around me, and the people in my life. I utilize a lot of different mediums into my art practice such as oils, acrylics, watercolour, ink, graphite, spray paint and exterior latex paint. I have been involved in various community-led projects, private and commercial mural commissions. The most impactful projects that I've been apart of, have led me to mentor youth artists and that has been the most rewarding part of those projects. An extension of youth mentorship, I'm also the Artist-in-Residence at Waterfront Neighbourhood Centre. I instruct Room 13, an international Studio that guides a growing network of student-run arts studios in schools and community settings globally. In the past few years, I have been apart of numerous Bell Box Murals Project throughout the city as well as START Outside the Box in 2018.

properties.artist_bio: Monica Gutierrez is a Colombian-born artist based in Scarborough. She is a Visual Arts graduate (York U), and a graduate of the Mural Art Career Development program (Mural Routes). Monica has participated in artist residencies and exhibitions and screenings both locally and abroad. Having worked at Scarborough Arts, VIBE Arts and Art Starts as an arts administrator, she has extensive experience in the production of community arts projects and mural projects. In 2015 she coordinated a Pan Am Games mural project that involved multiple artists painting work across the Province on multiple panels. Since 2018 Monica has been executing her own outdoor murals in the east end of Toronto.

properties.title: Okuda San Miguel

properties.artist_bio: Amir Akbari is a Greater Toronto Area (GTA) based Visual Artist, Educator, Community Advocate and Entrepreneur.   In 2002, he enrolled in OCAD University where he would go on to complete a Bachelors of Fine Arts with a focus on Drawing and Painting.  In 2003, Amir led his first community mural art project working with Urban Art Toronto.  The following year, he took on his first role with Street Art (then Graffiti Transformation Project) as the lead artist with Lamp Community Health Centre.  That project would be a launching pad for his eventual artistic and professional career.From 2003 to 2010 Amir continued to work with various community organizations and charities as an artist facilitator, youth works and educator.  He would go onto complete over 30 public murals throughout this time, working with and mentoring hundreds of youth across the GTA.In 2010 Amir founded Behind the Line with the purpose of providing existing support structures within the community with creative and artistic support.  Behind the Line has since worked closely with multiple organizations to enhance their arts programming and creative reach, from curriculum development, programming consultation and arts integration strategies.In the summer of 2019, Amir completed his largest mural production, the Susan Street Mural at 3847 Lawrence Ave. East.  This would be his 6th Street Art Partnership Project with the Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough and his 3rd partnership with Toronto Community Housing.  The large 14 story mural is the crowning achievement of his artistic journey as a community and mural artist.  Focused on creating designs that reflect, represent and inspire the communities that he is working with, this mural is a celebration of the collaborative and uplifting nature of public murals funded by Street Art Toronto.His work is rooted in the belief that self-expression can have a lasting impact on the development and growth of young people and their communities, and that there is a disproportional disadvantage across the board for those that face multiple barriers with accessing the arts.   He hopes to fill this void through innovative arts strategies, collaborative mural projects and local community partnerships.
properties.description: As part of an ongoing strategic partnership this mural has had an immediate positive impact on the community engaging and mentoring 50+ aspiring youth artists and giving local residents an active voice in the neighbourhood regeneration process.
properties.organizations: East Scarborough Boys and Girls Club
properties.title: Amir Akbari

properties.description: This mural by AKIN Collective (lead artist Moises Frank), inspired by local residents, celebrates a community leader and the diversity of the neighbourhood.
properties.title: Moises Frank

properties.artist_bio:
Enlivened by his interest in spacial structures and interconnectivity, Andre Kan's paintings serve as excitable blueprints for a possible reality. Each work depicts the artists' signature imaginative building blocks that converge and begin to build upon each other and strengthening each other towards an ever transforming space. Kan's structures are substantial and complex but not yet anchored - they float suspended in his psychological space. In this way Kan's buildings remain a playful proposition for the viewer not yet tied to a specific place or function. With his dynamic formations, Kan propels us towards an ever optimistic future where new connections and constructions have yet to materialize.

His current work investigates the architectural interpretations that respond to our ever advancing society, and suggests what 'possibility' means through self discovery. Examining what mark making and its properties mean, as well as the significance in cause and effect, is important here. Kan's psychological structures depict change and evolution of space, while also questioning the fundamental nature of being and the world that encompasses it.

Andre Kan is a Toronto based painter. Since graduating from the Ontario College of Art & Design University in 2014, he continues his creative pursuits as an Artist, Muralist, Photographer, Curator, Producer, and Musician. His paintings have been showcased throughout Canada with permanent collections in the U.S and China. His murals can also be seen internationally including London, Spain, Portugal and Taiwan.



Email: andrekanart@gmail.com
Instagram: andrekan_
Twitter: @andrekanart

properties.artist_bio:
I was born after the revolution in Iran. The idea of freedom greatly influenced my whole life not only as an artist but as a human being. I began painting at an art university. My style draws upon elements of traditional Persian painting (Persian Miniatures), the “flatness” and unique composition of which are surprisingly contemporary.
After getting my BFA, I studied Graphic Design at TM university in Tehran. Meanwhile, I started working as a freelance illustrator. Over the past 10 years I have illustrated more than 30 children’s books in Turkey and Iran and all the time I was trying to tell my story with my special language, picture language.
My works have been shown in exhibitions and book fairs in Iran, The Emirates, and South Korea but I got inspired by this idea a few years ago which is that the art that we should be doing today in the 21st century should not be just for the museum, it’s art for the street and for people in their daily lives. Also thinking about freedom and social justice in my country lead me to express what I’m feeling through my artworks on street walls so after I answered a call for submissions from Tehran City Hall I started to learn about and experience mural painting.
Since then, I’ve opened my mind and eyes to observe other mural artists' experiences. After coming to Toronto I’ve found a great number of mural artists and I’ve seen their artworks in the city. Having this great chance to learn from one of them , one of the greatest ones, Nick Sweetman as mentor through a mentorship program by Toronto Ar Council, since then I did some mural projects, trying to improve my skills and techniques an learn more and more. makes me feel so excited and enthusiastic. My style has changed from Miniature to Mural but, like my work as an illustrator, I try to use this medium's potential for telling stories.

properties.artist_bio:
Visual Artist

Christiano De Araujo is a self-taught artist who was born in Anápolis, Goiás, Brazil. His earliest memory as a child is the moment when he discovered his love of art. As a toddler, he remembers picking up a crayon that his older sister had left behind. When she found that Christiano had taken it, she grabbed it away from him, but in that short amount of time, he had fallen in love with colours and the ability to create.

His love of art and his talent for the drawing were evident when he was a student in school. His first passion was comics and cartoons and at age 12 he drew his first comic strip.

In his late teens, Christiano began working for Brazil’s highly circulated newspaper, Diário da Manhã, doing editorial cartoons and illustrations. He also continued to work for other local newspapers and magazines. Realizing that he wanted more opportunities than he could have in Brazil, Christiano chose to immigrate to Canada.

His first years in Canada were a struggle. Early on, he landed a job as a Bricklayer, which he did for a number of years. Christiano confronted his weaknesses and discovered his strengths, learned to laugh at his hardships, quickly moving on. He was able to overcome any adversities with a determination to succeed and a desire to make himself a better man. This led to his artwork being published in numerous magazines and newspapers in Toronto.

He also credits his success to a spiritual awakening that he had through meditation and self-hypnosis. It gave him clarity and focus. This experience gave him more confidence and the ability to control his emotions and himself. Christiano devotes much of his life to his art. His endeavours include drawing, oil and acrylic painting, airbrushing, cartooning and sculpting. He is an artist by trade, finds art fun and likes to explore new media and innovated techniques.

Christiano currently resides in Toronto, Canada. He is the founder of Toronto Artists Studio, a studio of visual artists, painters, digital artists and sculptors who design and produce murals and visual communication projects for audiences on a small and grand scale.

At the present moment, this very moment… Christiano is enjoying the wonderful interaction between the mind and the universe. This infinite universe in which we are all one!
properties.description: This mural illustrates 'family' as reflected by local residents and businesses and the diversity of Toronto.
properties.title: Christiano De Araujo

properties.artist_bio: Mahjabeen Kabir (Mahja) (b. 1993, Abu Dhabi, UAE)  is an emerging visual mixed media artist living and studying in Toronto, ON. Previously having a background in Science, she is currently exploring her creative pursuit and hoping to have a career in Design. Her style uses vibrant colours, shapes and patterns to form dreamlike depictions of altered realities. She draws inspiration from nature and is always on the search of greater understanding. She delves into the emotions of memories to capture the essence of what once was, questions realities, explores curiosities within the self and surroundings and hopes to inspire people to explore themselves and question the world.

properties.artist_bio:
I want to work with StART because the projects I have completed with Street Art Toronto's help have been not only the most enjoyable projects I have worked on in my career, but also the most lucrative for me, in terms of both payment and scale of exposure. I learn something new on every project we do together and working with StART staff has taught me virtually everything I know about what goes into publicly-funded street art projects, all the moving parts that need to be accounted for, communicating with the public, coordinating materials and other artists, publicity, etc. I want to keep building on this knowledge and skill set as we continue to spread colourful mural projects into new parts of the city/GTA.

Bio:
Nick Sweetman is a multidisciplinary artist from Toronto whose practice has explored painting and its intersection with photography, video, installation, mixed media, and urban intervention. He has exhibited in galleries around Toronto since 2011, completing his MFA in 2014 from OCAD University in the Interdisciplinary Art, Media & Design program. He received a certificate from the Mural Routes Leadership Training in Mural-Making program the same year and since then has been working in public space on mural projects, often in collaboration with other artists, and in partnership with various non-profit organizations (David Suzuki Foundation, The STEPS Initiative) as well as Street Art Toronto. He has successfully managed many large-scale projects both independently and as lead artist over a team of volunteers, from children up to adults. He has dedicated many projects to raising awareness about the importance of pollinators, bees and butterflies in particular, from painting giant bees towering over busy city streets to coordinating 30 or more artists to paint butterflies on garages in Toronto's laneways. Most recently, Nick has been working abroad, participating in the Eureka Street Art Festival in Humboldt County, California as well as contributing a mural to the Bondi Beach Sea Wall in Sydney, Australia.
properties.description: This mural is designed to encourage community members, particularly children and youth, to explore the local lakeshore ecology and the issues facing plants and wildlife.
properties.title: Nick Sweetman

properties.description: This series of murals along Dundas Street West created as part of a cultural exchange celebrates the relationship between Canada and Chile and, in particular the cities of Toronto and Valparaiso.
properties.title: Rodrigo Ardiles

properties.artist_bio:
I’d love to work with StreetARToronto because I’m inspired by the artistic legacy they are building in the City of Toronto. StART’s vision to create beautiful and safer public spaces with a mandate to act inclusively, celebrate our strengths in diversity, to acknowledge and respect the cultures and lands of Indigenous persons, and mentor emerging talents, all reflect my own values in my professional and personal life.

I’ve been an artist for 20 years in the public realm, having exhibited in public art galleries, artist-run centres, art festivals, and having worked with public/private planning teams to create permanent public art with budgets up to $56,000.00 (Holland Bloorview Kids Rehabilitation Hospital). I work in several disciplines including sculpture (polyurethane resins, concrete, casting techniques), installation art (interactive works that light up, make noise, or move - typically destined for art festivals/events such as Nuit Blanche, Animating Our Waterfront, Hamilton Supercrawl), and painting murals.

My passion for community arts participation cemented over 15 years ago when I sat on the board of Carfac Ontario as Vice Chair, with Merlin Homer as Chair, a Mohawk Elder whom I consider as a mentor. We had an exceptional team of strong arts leaders and my experience at Carfac helped mould my understanding of fair remuneration, cultural/ethnic/language/gender challenges that artists’ face, and the importance of advocating for one another’s communities.  Profoundly affected by this experience, I’ve continued to work with communities and have co-founded three successful art collectives, Open Field Collective, KJ Bit, and Creativo Collective, whose mandates are to create artwork and murals in public spaces while being inclusive of surrounding communities. In 2017, the Open Field Collective was awarded the national ArtBridges award for “Innovation” in recognition of our dedication to community engagement and our “Street Projects” where we invented miniature art galleries to create and display artwork in public spaces such as residential front yards, King Street (Public Realm), and Guelph. We’ve partnered with Scouts Canada, Neilson Creative Centre (Etobicoke), King Edward PS, been sponsored by Waterfront Toronto, and supported by Neighbourhood Associations and private and corporate donors.

Last year, I was lead coordinator for one of StreetARToronto’s laneway mural/graffiti projects. It was a wonderful opportunity to mentor my KJ Bit collaborator, June Kim, as a facilitator in the project. This summer, we’ll be coordinating the second phase of this Euclid/Palmerston laneway with a roster of 40 artists and be presenting a WalkShop tour of this laneway for delegates of the National Association of City Transportation Officials. This September, we’ll be painting a mural in partnership with StreetARToronto and TTC at Finch Station. My goal is to continue painting more murals, participating in more laneway jams and creating new, innovative street art events. I’d love to continue working with StreetARToronto because I believe we have mutual respect for the experience and expertise that both sides bring to the table. Above all, I love learning new things, and StreetARToronto has given me a great opportunity to grow as an artist and a facilitator.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals Project, by Michael Cavanaugh, transforms non-descript outdoor utilities infrastructure into local works of art making the streets more inviting to residents and visitors, and act as a skills-building gateway into mural-making for emerging artists.

properties.artist_bio: Born and raised in the Cabbagetown neighbourhood of Toronto, I have participated in the city's street art community for over 20 years as a graffiti and mural artist. My goal is to continue to bring life to the city through public art. When I create street art I work predominantly with spraypaint but I also work with oil on canvas as a professional artist represented by Ingram Gallery. I consider each project unique and like to incorporate the surrounding environment, wall structure, and community when developing a mural design and concept. Passing on skills to the next generation of artists is not only beneficial to the community, but myself as well. Through my previous mentorship work I have formed new friendships and learnt from others.
properties.description: This painted/mixed media mural developed through a community-created design process informed by local children and youth reminds us of the beauty and essential need to respect the environment.
properties.title: Ryan Dineen

properties.artist_bio:
Aitak Sorahitalab is a visual artist, art educator, and art administrator. She holds a Master’s Degree from the University of Art of Tehran, had several exhibitions of her artwork, and was commissioned to create public art in Iran and Canada (Toronto). She worked as a lecturer at the University of Applied Science Technology in Tehran, Manager of Art and Creation Department, at KANOON (Institute for Intellectual Development for Children and Young Adults), and worked with UNICEF, UNODC and Royal Museum of The Netherland. Since immigrating to Canada, she continued working as an artist, art teacher, and administrator. Aitak worked as a sculptural ceramic artist and mural artist. Passionate about social development, Sorahitalab has co-founded a non-profit organization, Airsa, to help and support new Canadians in the arts in Toronto. She received several art grants and awards (including Newcomer Mentorship, Career Development, RBC Access Fund, Toronto Leaders LAB and etc) from Ontario Art Council and Toronto Art Council as an individual artist and a non-profit organization.
www.aitak.ca
www.airsa.org

properties.artist_bio:
Jim Bravo was born in Ecuador, South America in 1973. He is a graduate of The Ontario College of Art and Design University where he majored in Fine Art and studied monumental & public art. Bravo has been active in the street/public art arena since his 2006 graduation, completing several city-funded murals and an array of community engagement art projects.  Through his affiliation with various local arts organizations he has gained vast experience as an arts mentor for at-risk youth initiatives. Bravo is a 4 time award winning painter and muralist and he lives and works in the city of Toronto, Philip Cote, MFA
Artist, Activist, Historian and Traditional Wisdom Keeper.
Moose Deer Point First Nation: Shawnee, Lakota, Potawatomi, and Ojibway.

A graduate of OCAD University’s Interdisciplinary Art Media and Design Masters program in 2015, Cote has been exploring new ways to imbue Mural Painting through oral traditions of storytelling and with traditional spiritual perspectives. Cote studied Beaux-Arts Style painting/drawing at OCAD under the direction of Carmen Cereceda Bianchi (Diego Rivera’s assistant).

Philip Cote emphasizes the resurgent power of nature and the importance of listening to Indigenous teachings through his Mural Art. lluminating 13,500+ years of Indigenous peoples history on Turtle Island showing their cosmology, mapping their place within the Universe and its beginnings, with light and dark showing their world linked to the underworld (Underwater World) and spirit world (Sky World).

In 2017, Cote received a grant from the Toronto Arts Council to create a mural depicting the Niagara Treaty for University of Toronto’s Massey College with the theme of Truth and Reconciliation/Canada 150.

Cote has been a tour guide with First Story since 1999, a three-hour tour providing an Indigenous history of Toronto uncovering the last 13,500 years. Cote’s academic practice includes public speaking, land acknowledgements, Indigenous Cosmology and cultural interpretation offered at York University, the Art Gallery of Ontario, University of Toronto, Ryerson University, OCAD University, and the Toronto District School Board through the Aboriginal Education Centre. In these Institutions, Cote shares his knowledge on the teachings of the Seven Grandfathers, the Medicine Wheel, Pipe, Naming and Sacred Fire Ceremonies, and the History of the Land.

As an Indigenous painter and Muralist, the purpose of Cote’s research is to unearth, and reveal, his cultural experience and knowledge of signs of Indigenous symbols, language and interpretation. Openings are thus created both within the archive/academia and broader public that enable these imbedded stereotypes to transform under the gaze of an Indigenous based interpreted presence and intervene in the cross generational colonial bias.
properties.description: This mural replaced a romantic colonial scene with imagery that reflects the Indigenous roots of the area as well as the present urban community and vision for a sustainable future.
properties.title: Jim Bravo & Philip Cote

properties.artist_bio:
Ted Hamer is a multidisciplinary Artist and educator based in Toronto. His work explores the juxtaposition of nature with human constructs through explorations into challenging humanities anthropocentric views towards ourselves and our environment. He merges historical approaches to realist and modern art to explore the nature vs culture divide through figures that examine various overlapping themes of anthropocenterism using natural and man made elements and materials.
Ted's work has exhibited in the Art Gallery of Ontario, the Steamwhistle Gallery, the RMG, The Station Gallery, Nathan Phillips Square, Bluffs Gallery, the Super Wonder Gallery and his Sculptural Mural Installation is the centerpiece installation of the Aurora Cultural Centre in Aurora Ontario.

In paint I work with Aerosol and acrylic and Latex. In Sculpture I work in clays, fibreglass, resins, bronze and wood and am now experimenting with 3D printed pieces. I would like to work with StART to develop more street art that challenges the urban landscape with art based on nature and animals. My practice is moving more to the 3D side of things and I would like to work with StART to fabricate more street level sculptural pieces as I see the need for that in Toronto.
I have mentored many emerging artists but I feel I could use help in taking my own practice to the next level possibly through mentor ship or guidance from another artist.
I also coordinate creative projects and have worked previously with StART on the Outside the Box Program, with the Bell Box Murals Project and with the Aurora Cultural Centre facilitating workshops, designing and creating artwork and mentoring emerging artists.
properties.description: The Bell Box Murals Project, by Michael Cavanaugh, transforms non-descript outdoor utilities infrastructure into local works of art making the streets more inviting to residents and visitors, and act as a skills-building gateway into mural-making for emerging artists.
properties.title: Ted Hamer

properties.artist_bio:
I want to continue co-collaborating with StART to keep growing as an artist in my skill set, practice and portfolio. With StART’s support I want to be mentored in my mural career with any opportunities to connect with seasoned mural/street artists and get on a swing-stage, aerial lift, use a spray gun, while learning to comprehend XL large walls and huge quantities of paint among advanced techniques of execution and project production. I’ve currently reached the stage of painting garages in Toronto and am interested and ready to go larger.

Bio & Artist Statement
Anya Mielniczek is a Toronto based multidisciplinary artist who combines her fine art background with raw material grit in both private and public sectors creating mixed-media installations, mural work and facilitating community art activations.
The artists approach to mediums includes latex, aerosol and up-cycled waste, working with the mechanical application of spray and the energy of hand brushed strokes (infused with powerful female portraits and garbage bits if possible).
A Queen’s University graduate, Anya’s worked with various organizations, municipalities and businesses creating public art within communities around Toronto and internationally. Recent corporate projects include lead production on HideSeek, a 7000sq foot immersive art experience in Toronto and collaborations with BACARDI, QUO Makeup, Moroccanoil, DELL, RBC, 1800GOTJUNK and Chevrolet. Her commitment to her practice especially when aligned with public spaces is to create with purpose by giving nature a voice while defining a conversation with the viewer that may inspire and bring awareness for sustainable change.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Anya Mielniczek

properties.description: Artists gathered in the St. Clair West neighbourhood to paint dozens of murals in Feel Good Lane — a laneway named after a local rapper who passed away in 2014.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd E & Carlaw Ave
properties.artist_bio:
I would like to work with StART because I am interested in beautifying the cityscape with more public artwork. I would like to learn from and better my practices through the partnerships and opportunities that StART may be able to provide.

I am a freelance illustrator and mural painter based in Toronto. I like being outside. I like to move my body and to work with my hands. I enjoy working with people who share similar ideas and interests in food growing, environmental stewardship and getting outside. Some of the organizations I have worked with include: Greenest City, Urbane Cyclist, Mountain Equipment Co-op and Green Thumbs Growing Kids. I use bright hues and bold line work to create botanical patterns and compositions depicting moments of self-reflection.

My murals can be found across Toronto, in Indonesia, Nepal, Philippines and Hong Kong. I often collaborate with other artists–my most frequent collaborator being Andrea Manica–as well as with the Buck Teeth Girls Club.
properties.description: The box shows cosmos flowers against a night sky–flowers that are quite common in gardens and that often add a touch of delicate playfulness to a neighbourhood.
properties.title: Caitlin Taguibao

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio:
Jieun June Kim is a Toronto based, Korean born painter and muralist.  She has exhibited her paintings around the world since 2010 at notable galleries and events, exploring the idea of “home” as an immigrant and creating safe space.
Jieun completed the Mural Art Career Development program offered by Mural Routes in 2017 and has since worked with various arts organizations, city of Toronto as well as corporate partners such as Samsung, Up Canada, and Collective Arts Brewery.
 She is the co-founder of KJ Bit Collective who creates murals and street art events, and a member of the Mural Routes advisory committee team. She is also the recipient of the Newcomer and Refugee Artist Mentorship grant from the Toronto Arts Council (2018).
properties.description: An array of artists enhanced the 1.4km cycle track along Lake Shore Boulevard West from Norris Crescent to First Street, west of Mimico Waterfront Park in Etobicoke.
properties.title: Jieun Kim

properties.description: This laneway was beautified over a weekend by more than 20 of Toronto's most-talented artists to bring awareness to a loss of habitat for butterflies.
properties.organizations: David Suzuki Foundation & Friends of Felstead Park
properties.title: Untitled

properties.artist_bio:
My murals play with patterning, painted as if successive layers of wallpaper have been carelessly removed, casually revealing the contrasting elements that lay beneath. Pattern, in the form of repeating decorative motifs, is a ubiquitous form of human expression. Many designs are so distinct they instantly call to mind a particular culture or part of the world. Some repeat over and over again throughout history.

The motifs that are revealed in my layered murals are from a broad range of eras and cultures. In the tremendously diverse reality of a contemporary globalized world, my paintings are a commentary on the fact that we are all in this together: collaborating, teaching, learning from, and inspiring one another.

I have ten years experience as a working artist, and have created numerous large-scale murals, many with the support of StART. I deeply appreciate the opportunities StART has given me, which have included larger and larger walls, international locations, and a lot of support in troubleshooting the many complexities that arise with mural creation!

My goals in the future are to move to creating multi-level murals (ie. more than 2 stories tall), to increase the number of assistants I use (thereby increasing mentorship, which I love to do, while decreasing installation time), and to paint more nationally and internationally. I would also love to continue to increase my knowledge of materials, and develop a "starting a mural" checklist, with timelines (ie. "Book Lift - 1 month ahead", "Order Paint - 2 weeks ahead"). I see a lot of big artists painting at festivals, where the timelines are tight, so increasing my speed is another goal for the years ahead.
properties.title: Kirsten McCrea

properties.artist_bio:
Marley Allen-Ash is an illustrator and artist working in Toronto, Canada. She uses traditional printmaking and digital media to create illustrations and explore both historical and personal narratives.  In addition to illustration, she enjoys work on murals and self publishing comics with her collective, Grab Bag Club.  She studied at OCAD University, completing a bachelor of design and majoring in illustration. Her illustration work has been recognized by American Illustration, 3x3 Magazine and Creative Quarterly. Selected Clients include The Globe and Mail, CANADALAND, Cottage Life and Lenny Letter.

I have worked with StART before, through the Lakeshore Bike Lane Murals, Concrete Barrier Art Program, and Outside the Box. I'd love to be involved in more group and individual mural projects, such as laneway mural projects or painting underpasses. I'm really open to any type of opportunity, though in the past I've worked with exterior latex paint for murals, as well as creating digital files to be printed and used as vinyl wraps.
properties.description: Toronto is lucky to have such a high concentration of park areas for the public to use and explore. The design shows some of the many plants native to the Rouge Valley area, as well as a diverse group of tiny people exploring that nature.
properties.title: Marley Allen-Ash

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Chris Perez

properties.description: The box showcases observational sketches of Torontonians from all over the city. It represents a true cross-section of Toronto, illustrating its diverse population. When citizens and visitors view the design, they are reminded that Toronto is a home for everyone, and feel welcome and appreciated.
properties.title: Sophie Berg

properties.description: The key elements of the design, a young woman and a bus, represent students and their school life. A yellow bus is part of many children’s daily routine. Some have fun, others day dream all while traveling to school and the many experiences that will likely shape their life.
properties.title: WAP Collective
