properties.title: Untitled

properties.artist_bio:
Graffiti and the various channels the practice exists in has allowed me find self, community and financial independence. To me, this world-culture is one of great value not only to individuals but also the larger community. I want to do all I can to participate in the production and instruction of this movement because of the freedom and joy that it can spread. My goals with StART would be to continue my Swirling of the city, help mentor young artists and create positive change in the community through the creation of large scale works/events, hopefully making our great city a hub for artistry in the light of this global movement.

BIO:
Flips is a Toronto based multi-media artist, life enthusiast and visual storyteller.
Inspired by the blending of cultural forces seen in Toronto and his homeland of Bulgaria, Flips’ focus is on promoting and celebrating world cultures and connectivity amongst people. His motto is that art has the power to unite people and aims to create works that inspire and instill this message.

Flips is best known in the streets of Toronto for his signature Swirl Style, which reflects the philosophy of unity through art in the swirling of color and line. Mirroring life, the Flips Swirl Clusters represent the state of flux that exists in life; a beautiful mess of movement and energy. At the heart of each swirl cluster exists a circle that represents the individual soul, linked to others through infinite ties. A grouping of swirls signifies a strong presence of community, creativity, and care.
properties.description: The artist's signature style lives in the swirling of color and line. Mirroring life, the swirls represent the state of flux that exists in life, a beautiful mess of movement and energy
properties.title: Ross Jaydjiev

properties.artist_bio:
I would love to continue to work with StART as I believe that art should be available to everyone and public art such as murals, makes art accessible to more people. Every time I make work for the public I learn something new; whether that’s a new painting technique or speaking to someone in the community and how the artwork affects them. Working with StART would allow me these special opportunities.

Bio
Jenn Kitagawa is an award-winning multidisciplinary illustrator and artist who grew up in the prairies and cities of Alberta, Canada. She is of Japanese descent and is 4th generation, or Yonsei. She graduated from the MacEwan University and the Alberta College of Art & Design, studying both graphic design and illustration. Shortly after receiving her Bachelors of Design, Jenn moved to New York where she interned for illustrator and artist Mike Perry and for the fashion magazine Nylon.

Jenn’s body of work- illustration, gifs, painted murals and installations, engages in a dialogue of openness and curiosity. Her creative explorations are unbounded by medium specificity- they are instead inspired by playfulness, colour, and positivity. She pushes the boundaries between art and design, blurs the lines between tangible and intangible goods and inspires wonder.

Jenn has created work for clients ranging from Facebook to Arts & Crafts Records, and had the honour of creating the album artwork for Gord Downie’s record Introduce Yerself. She has previously assisted muralist Kirsten McCrea on a community engaged mural for Telus in Scarborough, painted for the city of Toronto with the StART Project, and last year for Bell Box Mural Projects. She has also painting for the arts market Market Collective in Calgary, leading a community based paint-by-number mural and in May 2019 she painted a large interactive mural.
properties.description: The outstretched arms are a metaphor for exploring the idea of making things by hand and away from screens. Bold and bright colours and have used this palette intentionally to create a world of inclusivity.
properties.title: Jenn Kitagawa

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.
properties.description: The design revolves around capturing surrounding colours and organic abstracted shapes. It takes the environmental elements of colour from the area around the box and implements it into the artwork.
properties.title: Chris Perez

properties.artist_bio:
I want to work with StART because the projects I have completed with Street Art Toronto's help have been not only the most enjoyable projects I have worked on in my career, but also the most lucrative for me, in terms of both payment and scale of exposure. I learn something new on every project we do together and working with StART staff has taught me virtually everything I know about what goes into publicly-funded street art projects, all the moving parts that need to be accounted for, communicating with the public, coordinating materials and other artists, publicity, etc. I want to keep building on this knowledge and skill set as we continue to spread colourful mural projects into new parts of the city/GTA.

Bio:
Nick Sweetman is a multidisciplinary artist from Toronto whose practice has explored painting and its intersection with photography, video, installation, mixed media, and urban intervention. He has exhibited in galleries around Toronto since 2011, completing his MFA in 2014 from OCAD University in the Interdisciplinary Art, Media & Design program. He received a certificate from the Mural Routes Leadership Training in Mural-Making program the same year and since then has been working in public space on mural projects, often in collaboration with other artists, and in partnership with various non-profit organizations (David Suzuki Foundation, The STEPS Initiative) as well as Street Art Toronto. He has successfully managed many large-scale projects both independently and as lead artist over a team of volunteers, from children up to adults. He has dedicated many projects to raising awareness about the importance of pollinators, bees and butterflies in particular, from painting giant bees towering over busy city streets to coordinating 30 or more artists to paint butterflies on garages in Toronto's laneways. Most recently, Nick has been working abroad, participating in the Eureka Street Art Festival in Humboldt County, California as well as contributing a mural to the Bondi Beach Sea Wall in Sydney, Australia.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Nick Sweetman

properties.title: Untitled

properties.artist_bio:
Peru is an internationally recognized muralist and graphic artist whose practice is informed by digital and traditional art forms and his 20+ years of painting graffiti. Peru’s professional career started when he moved from Lima to Ottawa at 16; he won every Visual Arts Award in his high school, a Canadian Heritage grant to paint a mural in Vancouver for the International Earth Festival, and a 2 mural commission for the National Capital Commission. At age 20 he moved to Montreal where he continued winning prizes and awards from design contests at his local skateshop to the Millennium Excellence Scholarship.

His passion for art lead him to rise to the top of the local art scene working for brands and companies such as Bell, Cirque du Soleil and he painted a series of murals with the collective En Masse at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. With En Masse, Peru was part of dozens of collaborative murals throughout Canada, US, Mexico and China, and participated in mentorship programs with the Quebec English School Boards Association. He was also a central muralist for MU since its inception in 2007 and continues to work with them, most recently in 2020 where he will be painting the exterior of a high school.

When Peru moved to Toronto a decade later he worked for Urban Outfitters for 5 years as a Lead Display Artist. In this role he built and installed window and store displays participating in store openings across North America including the company’s largest store opening at Herald Square in New York City. Peru used these experiences to expand his skill set and work on art installations at the Osheaga Music Festival as well for American Express for their Live Life Experience Installations around the world; All the while establishing himself as a muralist by assisting, collaborating, and consulting for nearly every arts organization in Toronto, and mentoring individuals, peers and on several occasions’ at-risk youth from the Oasis Skateboard Factory. Peru’s corporate and big brand murals allowed him to balance his work with grass-roots organizations, non-for-profits and BIA’s which make up most of his portfolio. Some of Peru’s corporate clients include Facebook, Nike, Adidas, Corus, Maple Leaf Sports, and Marriott Hotels.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Peru Dyer Jalea

properties.description: This laneway was beautified over a weekend by more than 20 of Toronto's most-talented artists to bring awareness to a loss of habitat for butterflies.
properties.organizations: David Suzuki Foundation & Friends of Felstead Park
properties.title: Untitled

properties.artist_bio:
I'm an Honors OCAD graduate in Fine Arts, a visual artist and community mural painter. My most recent project, The Richmond Hill Traffic Box Murals Project 2019 was made possible through a Richmond Hill Community and Cultural Grant.   I am a StART Concrete Barrier artist and I took part in the Lakeshore Barrier Bike Lane project in 2019. I have created murals for StreeARToronto, The F.H. Varley Art Gallery of Markham and The Toronto Public Library. Last September, I was a muralist for the 2018 StreetARToronto Light up the Laneway Project, (Euclid Palmerston Laneway), and I’ve been accepted three times for StreetARToronto Outside the Box Program.  In 2017 I executed a Canada 150 Bell Box Community Mural Project.  In Toronto, I was hired for the The Coxwell Laneway Mosaic at Coxwell TTC Subway in 2016. Other initiatives include Nuit Blanche and The Henderson CN Bridge Mural,(2014), revisited in January 2020.
My ideas are closely tied into Toronto Public Library, where I have worked for over 45 years as a public service worker. My recent positions there have included Children's Programming and Special Collections initiatives, where I have made use of my artistic skills to help community with library projects similar in scope to mural initiatives. Public service includes mural work.  It includes any tools that we can use to help community and helping community through the gifts I can offer has been my life's work.  Truly I believe that there are many avenues available to help needful communities achieve sustainability and gain a sense of pride, both where public spaces are concerned and where housing is concerned.  Mural making is just one of those tools - as are library materials and services, and other community initiatives.

My goals with StART include partnering the library or offering my librarianship skills to promote and to encourage any initiatives that might be developed by StART, through mural work, to connect the community with literacy in all it's forms, including digital and creative literacy. The way to reach community is to involve them in positive and exciting ways that will give them something of value to add to their lives. Again, there are so many ways we can do this - especially if our important various avenues public service can partner together in creative endeavours to mentor community.
Every day at the library or when we are painting murals on walls, we have opportunities to mentor others.  Sometimes this takes on a formal role and sometimes not, but every time we take an interest in a member of our community and show them something they need to know, this is mentoring. Every time we answer a question from a passerby about a project or initiative that has been built to help them - this is mentoring. If possible I would like to take part in a short term or small project mentoring program developed by StART, as I do in the library, with Children's STEM Programming.

Again, there are many avenues open to mentorship possibilities. I would;d be open to any and all of them, as developed by and at the discretion of StART. I have ideas that would lend themselves to partnership of library and mural making and public consultation for these ideas would include mentorship of community members. iMy most ambitious upcoming project is one I would like to submit next year to the StART Partnership program, to include a large library component to a mural initiative to be developed in central North York near a library.
properties.description: The design aims to maintain the original character and charm of the adjacent fire station tower, with many of its most prominent design elements and colors featured and replicated in this intricate hand painted concept. The carved stone medallion with the motto “Semper Paratus" has been included to honor the firefighters.
properties.title: Robin Hesse

properties.description: Reflecting on the theme of “Uplifting Each Other,” twenty-nine emerging and established Toronto-based, female-identifying artists will turned this laneway into an outdoor art gallery for the entire neighbourhood to enjoy.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.artist_bio: I would love to continue my involvement for StART because I love creating work for my city! My work is happy and Toronto-centric, every piece I create is aimed to make the community smile, laugh, and think. After 5 years of doing street art and illustration full-time, I’ve been lucky enough to have the opportunity to travel and bring my Toronto raccoon murals around the world, but this will always be my favourite place to make art. I hope to up my scale this year and bring more colour into our already vibrant communities.
properties.description: The box is an illustrative building covered in a cast of mischievous Toronto raccoons. The colour palette is bold and bright. The box aims to complement its surroundings while giving residents a design that is fun and relatable that will make them smile.
properties.title: Emily May Rose

properties.description: Reflecting on the theme of “Uplifting Each Other,” twenty-nine emerging and established Toronto-based, female-identifying artists will turned this laneway into an outdoor art gallery for the entire neighbourhood to enjoy.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.artist_bio:
Roshni Wijayasinha is a Toronto based visual artist who specializes in large abstract expressionist paintings that are inspired by nature and its energy. Using acrylic and mixed media, these paintings experiment with light, colours, textures and finishes, and many of her pieces can be transformed under a black light, or glow in the dark. Her work has been featured at several juried exhibits and galleries across North America, in product launches, at a food festival, in a permanent collection at a Hilton Hotel in Toronto, in publications, and can be found on the streets of Toronto on 6 traffic boxes.

My experience painting the START traffic box at Front & John Street was a wonderful collaboration with the public, inviting people of all ages and different nationalities (high tourist traffic) make a small mark on this piece. I'm interested in participating in more street art around Toronto, to help liven our streets, bring energy and positivity to our neighbourhoods and people. Engaging our community in the process, I would love the opportunity to be able to deliver happiness and surprise and delight passers by as I do with my vivid glow in the dark paintings. I welcome the opportunity to work with other more established street artists, to learn more about outdoor art and public engagement, share our skills and techniques and grow together. I would also love to share my love of colour and light with other emerging artists, teaching them about how different materials can be used to create different lighting effects.
properties.description: This piece aims to use various bright colours, energetic lines and shapes that interact with each other, similar to the vibrant and diverse people, communities and landscapes that shape Toronto.
properties.title: Roshni Wijayasinha

properties.description: Reflecting on the theme of “Uplifting Each Other,” twenty-nine emerging and established Toronto-based, female-identifying artists will turned this laneway into an outdoor art gallery for the entire neighbourhood to enjoy.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.title: Henry Tyminski

properties.description: This design pays homage to the sometimes pesky, always adorable furry critters Torontonians share the city with.  A fox is on the front of the box, ready to eat; around the side of the box, a rabbit realizes he’s being eyed as the fox’s dinner. On the back of the box a raccoon shares his banana with a skunk depicted on the remaining side of the box.
properties.title: Jeannette Nguyen

properties.artist_bio: Christina Mazzulla is a Toronto based multi-disciplinary artist who specializes in spray paint and mixed-media work. She is well known for her mural contributions throughout the city and paintings comprised of intricate cutouts and exploration of combined media. Her artwork is heavily informed by psychedelic imagery, incorporating wildlife, fantasy, landscapes, and electric colour gradients. Christina has been working as a professional artist and showcasing work having graduated from OCADU in 2012, with a Bachelor of Fine Arts. Her passion for street art combined with traditional fine art training has helped her form a unique style, and gain a large following throughout North America. Christina continues her creative pursuits within the gallery scene, while also remaining one of the few active female graffiti artists within Toronto. She has provided many commissioned murals for large businesses and non-profit organizations including American Express, Universal Music, Chevrolet Canada, PangeaSeed Foundation, and The David Suzuki Foundation. She has worked with City of Toronto BIA's and StArt Toronto, along with many privately funded mural projects, with hopes to continue working with other street art initiatives.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Christina Mazzulla

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio:
Natalie Very B. is an illustrator, muralist, and teacher of Polish-Canadian decent.
Having grown up in a country with a strong patriarchal regime and an obvious system of inequality, she finds solace in painting ethereal shapes of female figures and the stories that they tell. As an immigrant artist she often explores the concept of “home”, and the sense of wistful longing and nostalgia that it brings out in her work.
Her childhood experience became a strong incentive for her to make illustrations that depict women as beautiful, empowered, and strong. As a result, her current work is devoted to the investigation of whimsical shapes of feminism in today’s world.

I would like to work with StART as I have had wonderful experiences working with you in the past, and I would like to keep this collaboration growing. You allow me to express myself, educate people, and beautify Toronto with my skills and ideas.
properties.description: An array of artists enhanced the 1.4km cycle track along Lake Shore Boulevard West from Norris Crescent to First Street, west of Mimico Waterfront Park in Etobicoke.
properties.title: Natalie Very B

properties.artist_bio: Working with stART is a great way to connect and network with other creatives and align myself with new opportunities. My goal is to find likeminded artists and project coordinators to achieve thought provoking work for the upcoming year. My work focuses on nature and the fragile state of the environment. I paint indoor and outdoor murals with themes such as local wildlife and climate change in effort to educate and celebrate the beauty and importance of local ecosystems. I believe communities are stronger when they have a connection to the natural world that exists amidst their neighbourhood. “Knowing your neighbour” is the first step to caring and protecting them. This stewardship brings communities together. I hope to work with stART to celebrate local communities of Toronto –including the people, plants and animals.
properties.description: The design is of a flowering apple branch with whimsical honeybees that are a familiar and positive sight in Toronto. The bees also serve as a symbol of a healthy community as well as a healthy ecosystem.
properties.title: Stacey Kinder

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio:
I would like to continue working with StART because they support the creation of art that makes our public realm a more beautiful and inviting place. StART has helped me create meaningful work that strengthens communities and enables me to develop my practice of using art as a way to build inclusive communities who celebrate their identity with pride. I would like to develop my leadership skills and am interested in mentorship opportunities where I can learn how to work more effectively with the city to realize large scale initiatives that give more artists and community members opportunities to feel empowered through the process of creating art in the public realm.

I am a Toronto based visual artist, community organizer, muralist, curator, and eternal optimist. My work is motivated by my desire to spread joy, nurture present minded living, cultivate gratitude, and foster new social interactions from a place of love and empathy. Using aerosol and acrylic paint, I work with bright colours and bold patterns to captivate people’s attention and fill them with delight and hope. I am passionate about creating art that both aesthetically and psychologically brightens the streets and work to build a community around positive living.

My belief that public art is a powerful tool for building community drives my practice. In 2017, I founded Womxn Paint, an annual street art jam that has produced 44 murals celebrating the strength and diversity of womxn. I would like to continue this initiative and grow it to include additional programming that supports the professional development of womxn artists and more opportunities for young girls to learn about mural arts. In 2016, I facilitated an intergenerational mural at Baycrest Health Sciences and would like work more with the senior community.

Over the last six years, I have created custom large-scale outdoor artworks for clients including The New Yorker, Tourism Canada, the City of Toronto, the City of Mississauga, the Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany in Toronto, the STEPS Initiative, Arts Etobicoke, East End Arts and private clients.
properties.description: An array of artists enhanced the 1.4km cycle track along Lake Shore Boulevard West from Norris Crescent to First Street, west of Mimico Waterfront Park in Etobicoke.
properties.title: Bareket Kezwer

properties.address: Burlington St & Lake Shore Blvd W
properties.artist_bio: I am a printmaker and illustrator living in Toronto. My practice is primarily print: silkscreen and block prints on textile and paper. However, I am trained to work with a number of different mediums, including paint.From 2009-2017, my main project was The Political Circus, a collection of works featuring Canadian Politicians. The collection included finger puppets, postcards, trading cards and paper doll sets. As the Political Circus, I did site specific installations about Canadian politics. For example, for Chinatown Remixed (Ottawa 2012), I created a series of portraits of Chinese Canadians in politics that were hung in a Chinese restaurant. Currently my work focuses on birds and plants.Last summer I painted a box and absolutely loved the experience. I loved talking to people and getting to know the neighbourhood. I would very much like to participate again.
properties.description: The box features the birds of Toronto.
properties.title: Gabe Thirlwall

properties.artist_bio: Andre is a Mexican born artist, who immigrated to Canada in 2006. Since coming to Toronto he’s been creating intricate psychedelic artwork featuring animal and human subjects juxtaposed with abstract form. His paintings have been used for custom clothing design and his illustrations for band posters and psychedelic trance music events. As of 2012 Andre has been focused on murals and street art, working on wall art for private businesses and city sponsored projects.In his work Andre explores the use of bold colour, geometric shapes, space landscapes and his special interest in architectural and industrial design. Andre feels there’s an incredible necessity to self-express through art and equal need to inspire emerging artists to create and feel free to self-express themselves in their own ways.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Andre Castro

properties.artist_bio:
My name is Jeff Blackburn and I am a visual artist based in Toronto. With over a decade of experience producing projects for exhibition and clients, my multi-disciplinary techniques are versatile, but also maintain a recognizable style. Inspired by illustration, graffiti, and comic books, my work is known for its emphasis on line and texture, and its exploration of form using interpretive contour lines. Paintings are constructed by merging pop art aesthetics with contemporary urban art materials and techniques.

My work explores themes that revel in a flippant joie de vivre, yet remain lightly steeped in some measure of memento mori. The combined effect is one of playfully self-assured yet shadowed cheek. My compositions tend to centre on a central figure, giving the piece a definitive focal point from which the viewer can explore. The subjects of my work are chosen for their relevance to the project or location, or simply for their relevance to me. Visual impact in my murals is further accomplished through a vibrant and textured usage of colour. In these paintings, colour is freed from its formal descriptive function and displays energy and motion through a build up of spray and acrylic paint layers.

I want to continue working with StART as I have been creating projects with their team since year one, and I greatly appreciate the opportunities that they’ve funded and helped bring to fruition for both my peers and myself.  I am hoping to grow the scale of my work in the public realm, while simultaneously gaining the key skills necessary in developing the business side of my career. With the backing of StART I have painted 14 traffic signal boxes, participated in roughly 10 StART funded mural jams, assisted American artist Andrew Schoultz in 2012 on one of the first Partnership Program murals, and most recently assisted BirdO on the first Monumental Program wall.
properties.description: Producing vibrantly coloured creatures throughout the city is the artist's way to colour an otherwise tonally muted space - with vibrant animals part of a larger series around the city.
properties.title: Jeff Blackburn

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & Fort York Blvd
properties.artist_bio: I am an emerging artist working in Toronto. I studied Theatre at the University of Ottawa before completing a Bachelor of Design in Illustration at OCAD University. I create images that exist on paper, walls, objects, spaces, and stages. I am interested in using imagery as an opportunity to explore the world, the environment and social issues. I want the public art that I make to be bright and colourful, something that might attract someone's attention as they walk by. I like to create dense images where flat colourful shapes fill the entire wall/object, which can deter graffiti but also can allow for the viewer to notice something new after repeated viewings. In recent projects “Night on the town” or “Canoe with wildlife” (attached below), I tried to connect the imagery to something interesting about the area: the former is a reference to jazz clubs that used to exist in the east side of toronto, and the latter is a tribute the canoe butterfly gardens that can be found in parks throughout the city. I draw people with a looseness in their form, joyously moving and interacting. I would love to be involved with START and create more community engaged art and collaborate with other artists. I am interested in creating images for different spaces and it is a goal of mine to create work in different cities in Canada and internationally.
properties.description: The box is bright and colourful, fun and evocative of nature.
properties.title: Erin McCluskey

properties.description: Reflecting on the theme of “Uplifting Each Other,” twenty-nine emerging and established Toronto-based, female-identifying artists will turned this laneway into an outdoor art gallery for the entire neighbourhood to enjoy.

properties.description: Here is an eggciting peek into the world of some legged eggs. They’re fun and whimsical.The design shows a few regular eggs living their lives in the city, from a downtown Toronto tour for kindergarteners to Lord Legless and his eggxotic body guards. One relaxes at the beach, absolutely fried from work. These little guys are very eggstra, frolicking and dancing all over the place. They love an audience!
properties.title: Ling Bi

properties.description: Artists gathered in the St. Clair West neighbourhood to paint dozens of murals in Feel Good Lane — a laneway named after a local rapper who passed away in 2014.

properties.title: Untitled

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & Hillside Ave
properties.artist_bio: OTB artist in 2019 and 2018. Bell Box mural artist in 2012 as well as other Toronto public murals and public sculptures including for the TTC dating back to 1999. Past experiences also include art instructor and community engagement via art initiatives in the far North as well as here in Southern Ontario.
properties.description: This design pays homage to the Atlantic Salmon which was a species of fish indigenous to the rivers, streams and lakes within the GTA and the surrounding areas. The image hopes to evoke queries about these fish, and also lead to larger questions about our roles in effecting the environment.
properties.title: Jungle Ling

properties.description: Artists gathered in the St. Clair West neighbourhood to paint dozens of murals in Feel Good Lane — a laneway named after a local rapper who passed away in 2014.

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio: I bring it every time, got a good track record of big colour and positive results.
properties.description: An array of artists enhanced the 1.4km cycle track along Lake Shore Boulevard West from Norris Crescent to First Street, west of Mimico Waterfront Park in Etobicoke.
properties.title: Dudeman

properties.artist_bio: As a freelance illustrator since 1998, I have produced artwork for a variety of editorial and design projects. My client list includes the New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, and Real Simple Magazine. Since 2015, I have worked as a children's book author and illustrator. In that time, I have published nine picture books with another picture book scheduled for 2021. My clients include Owlkids Books, Penguin Random House Canada and Henry Holt Books for Young Readers.
properties.description: The design is meant to remind people in Toronto of the lake that we live alongside. In the summer, this design will be a promise of what is available to all of us at Toronto’s many beaches. In the colder months, it will be a reminder of what is waiting for us when summer finally arrives.
properties.title: Carey Sookocheff

properties.description: Reflecting on the theme of “Uplifting Each Other,” twenty-nine emerging and established Toronto-based, female-identifying artists will turned this laneway into an outdoor art gallery for the entire neighbourhood to enjoy.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.artist_bio:
Roshni Wijayasinha is a Toronto based visual artist who specializes in large abstract expressionist paintings that are inspired by nature and its energy. Using acrylic and mixed media, these paintings experiment with light, colours, textures and finishes, and many of her pieces can be transformed under a black light, or glow in the dark. Her work has been featured at several juried exhibits and galleries across North America, in product launches, at a food festival, in a permanent collection at a Hilton Hotel in Toronto, in publications, and can be found on the streets of Toronto on 6 traffic boxes.

My experience painting the START traffic box at Front & John Street was a wonderful collaboration with the public, inviting people of all ages and different nationalities (high tourist traffic) make a small mark on this piece. I'm interested in participating in more street art around Toronto, to help liven our streets, bring energy and positivity to our neighbourhoods and people. Engaging our community in the process, I would love the opportunity to be able to deliver happiness and surprise and delight passers by as I do with my vivid glow in the dark paintings. I welcome the opportunity to work with other more established street artists, to learn more about outdoor art and public engagement, share our skills and techniques and grow together. I would also love to share my love of colour and light with other emerging artists, teaching them about how different materials can be used to create different lighting effects.
properties.description: This piece aims to use various bright colours, energetic lines and shapes that interact with each other, similar to the vibrant and diverse people, communities and landscapes that shape Toronto.
properties.title: Roshni Wijayasinha

properties.description: Artists gathered in the St. Clair West neighbourhood to paint dozens of murals in Feel Good Lane — a laneway named after a local rapper who passed away in 2014.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.description: Artists gathered in the St. Clair West neighbourhood to paint dozens of murals in Feel Good Lane — a laneway named after a local rapper who passed away in 2014.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.artist_bio:
Jason has spent years developing his aerosol skills since discovering graffiti as as Toronto youth. Art making has been a life affirming escape and a way to process his surroundings. OCAD opened his eyes to different approaches and techniques. Focusing on the dissection of colour and light into geometric shapes and patterns, Jason's artwork creates a juxtaposition between the abstract and the representational. This style lends well to a mural site and its organic blend into the community. Thinking critically about the transformation of public spaces, Jason looks for interesting ways to use colour, form, and shape to create visual landmarks to promote and evolve the aesthetic narrative of the city.

Most recently, his commercial commissions include: Yonge + Dundas Square Toronto Musician series, Fet Zun restaurant exterior signage, Ubisoft Assasin's Creed Fan Mural, and, MLB Blue Jays temporary mural at Union Station.
properties.title: Jason Pinney

properties.description: Artists gathered in the St. Clair West neighbourhood to paint dozens of murals in Feel Good Lane — a laneway named after a local rapper who passed away in 2014.

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio:
Enlivened by his interest in spacial structures and interconnectivity, Andre Kan's paintings serve as excitable blueprints for a possible reality. Each work depicts the artists' signature imaginative building blocks that converge and begin to build upon each other and strengthening each other towards an ever transforming space. Kan's structures are substantial and complex but not yet anchored - they float suspended in his psychological space. In this way Kan's buildings remain a playful proposition for the viewer not yet tied to a specific place or function. With his dynamic formations, Kan propels us towards an ever optimistic future where new connections and constructions have yet to materialize.

His current work investigates the architectural interpretations that respond to our ever advancing society, and suggests what 'possibility' means through self discovery. Examining what mark making and its properties mean, as well as the significance in cause and effect, is important here. Kan's psychological structures depict change and evolution of space, while also questioning the fundamental nature of being and the world that encompasses it.

Andre Kan is a Toronto based painter. Since graduating from the Ontario College of Art & Design University in 2014, he continues his creative pursuits as an Artist, Muralist, Photographer, Curator, Producer, and Musician. His paintings have been showcased throughout Canada with permanent collections in the U.S and China. His murals can also be seen internationally including London, Spain, Portugal and Taiwan.



Email: andrekanart@gmail.com
Instagram: andrekan_
Twitter: @andrekanart
properties.description: An array of artists enhanced the 1.4km cycle track along Lake Shore Boulevard West from Norris Crescent to First Street, west of Mimico Waterfront Park in Etobicoke.
properties.title: Andre Kan

properties.artist_bio: I am a Russian-Canadian visual artist and muralist based in Toronto ON. I hold a BFA from Emily Carr University and Certificate in Mural Art from Mural Routes. Majority of my paintings revolve around relationship between figure and abstract space, as I tend to explore themes of personal identity, duality and shifting perceptions.In the past two years I have been working in public spaces painting murals. These projects have become meaningful and rewarding experiences for me as I got a chance to share my narrative with my community, alter spaces and engage public. I’ve participated in collaborative murals with Mural Routes and Artbarn School. I have also completed my own projects as a lead artist in a cafe, Art Fair and Public School. Last summer I was thrilled to participate in the StART OTB program and Bellbox Mural programs.

properties.artist_bio:
I have worked varying disciplines of art including illustrating over 40 children's books, editorial, packaging, corporate. I have shown my personal works since 2003 and in recent years have been shifting my focus in the fine art world working in sculpture. I am represented by Galerie Youn in Montreal and have shown in various fairs including Miami Pulse 2018 during Art Basel Miami having a sold out show and at Art Toronto at the Metro Convention Centre in 2019
It was Cindy Scaife who started following me on instagram after my work was in an art gallery and she noticed my wall art pieces and asked if i wanted to participate in the bicycle barrier project and with a little encouragement from my partner...Dudeman, I worked on my first street art project and hope to do more.
properties.description: An array of artists enhanced the 1.4km cycle track along Lake Shore Boulevard West from Norris Crescent to First Street, west of Mimico Waterfront Park in Etobicoke.

properties.description: Artists gathered in the St. Clair West neighbourhood to paint dozens of murals in Feel Good Lane — a laneway named after a local rapper who passed away in 2014.
properties.title: Untitled

properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Toronto, I have been a full-time professional mural artist for over 27 years. My mural career includes works for private, commercial, corporate clients, educational institutions and public art projects. One highlight of my career was working with acclaimed American artist Frank Stella as the Studio Manager for his studios in Toronto, New York and Houston, Texas. During this time the studio created large scale mixed media murals based on Mr. Stella’s paper collages.
These works were commissioned by international galleries and museums from Japan to Germany and included Torontoʼs Princess of Wales Theatre.

I have worked with the StART team on several large scale projects and I have always been impressed with all of the support and encouragement that this program cultivates.  From the beginning, it was apparent how much the program focuses on bringing together artists and communities to create a lasting positive experience for all.  During the production of both my Park Lawn Underpass Mural and the Lake Shore Cycle Track Barrier Murals, I received an overwhelming amount of positive feedback and response from the individuals driving, biking, riding and walking by these public pieces of art.  So much of an artists' time is spent creating a piece of artwork alone in the studio.  The StART program allows for an "on the spot" engagement with the community during the development of a mural.  For me, this is the most rewarding part of these murals.  I am proud to bring my artistic vision to these public works of art through the StART program for all to enjoy no matter what their background, social status or familiarity with a traditional gallery/museum setting.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Cindy Scaife

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio: I would love to continue my involvement for StART because I love creating work for my city! My work is happy and Toronto-centric, every piece I create is aimed to make the community smile, laugh, and think. After 5 years of doing street art and illustration full-time, I’ve been lucky enough to have the opportunity to travel and bring my Toronto raccoon murals around the world, but this will always be my favourite place to make art. I hope to up my scale this year and bring more colour into our already vibrant communities.

properties.artist_bio: I am an artist and graphic designer born and raised in downtown Toronto. Themes that often emerge from my work include identity, nature and whimsy, and I express my ideas using a wide variety of mediums, including acrylic and oil painting, murals, paper cutting, printmaking and digital graphics.In the summer of 2019, I painted a large mural in Jean Sibelius Park, in partnership with StART. I’ve also painted a utility box with Outside the Box and completed two Bell Box murals. My mural painting experience also includes a mural at a community garden in Parkdale and assisting on large scale murals for William Lazos in Liberty Village and Phil Cote at Dundas and Jarvis.I hold a Master of Design degree from Carleton University and a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree from Queen’s University, and I have exhibited in galleries across Ontario.
properties.description: This design uses the theme of food to reflect the diversity and character of Toronto.
properties.title: Talie Shalmon

properties.artist_bio: Stephanie Bellefleur is a Contemporary Visual Artist who was born in Venezuela, South America, Stephanie’s work incorporates bold colours with strong graphic lines. Stephanie has created a contemporary style that embodies both elegance and grit. She has been hired to create for Municipalities, Non Profits, and Corporate Businesses such as Street Art Toronto, Facebook, Skechers, Vancouver BIA, Mississauga Living Arts Centre, Daniel Spectrum, the University of Toronto and Baycrest Foundations Brain Project.Her most relevant high impact projects include contributing to the 8 story Phlegm mural at Yonge and St.Clair, Most recently, Stephanie contributed to the unique 23 story “Equilibrium Mural” alongside International Muralist-Okuda San Miguel. Stephanie has experience as an Arts administrator and Production coordinator for award winning Public Arts Organizations. She is a champion of social innovation and all things inclusive, Stephanie is humbled to serve the public in order to progress a spectrum of unity and colour.
properties.description: The design ia simple, clean and inclusive. This design is meant for all ages and people. In use of the power of the rainbow – the artist highlights that within these colours love, culture, kindness and diversity can be embraced.
properties.title: Stephanie Bellefleur

properties.artist_bio: I am always interested in participating in mural projects with Street Art Toronto, as it is an amazing opportunity to work with community members and share art in a non-exclusive setting. I have been painting murals for six years now, on brick, wood, concrete, and aluminum surfaces. I generally use bright shades of outdoor acrylics applied with rollers and brush, but occasionally I use spray paint. My subject matter is often nature-focused, depicting flowers insects and animals. Painting in the city, I want the organic, colourful images I create to shine in an otherwise muted and industrialized landscape. I want to create work that can be viewed by anyone, with a message of hope, growth and positive change. I am part of the artist collective The Buck Teeth Girls Club, and through my involvement have grown accustomed to collaboration.
properties.description: The word “compassion” is translated into multiple languages & the roses symbolize peace and harmony.
properties.title: Andrea Manica

properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Iran, I moved to Canada as a teenager. I studied at OCAD University, where I gained exposure to a variety of disciplines from Fine Arts to Graphic Design & Advertising. After obtaining my Bachelor’s degree, I began working as a Visual Communications Coordinator at a large corporation. After 7 years, I decided to pursue my own art and design practice. I have since been awarded and published a number of times, had a solo exhibition and have created a number of murals around Toronto. I create colourful and whimsical paintings, digital art and GIFs that focus on life as a woman, spirituality and everyday life. I’m a shameless coffee addict and frequent the local cafes. Dancing, yoga and biking are my preferred ways of recharging.
I started my street art work since 2018 at which point I painted on a utility box for StreetARToronto and since then I have painted multiple small scale murals around Toronto for StreetART, Bell Box Murals including garage doors and concrete walls. I would like to continue expanding my street art practice and beautify the city further.
properties.description: The design is a beehive to not only bring a bit of nature into the city but to emphasize and remind the passersby of the importance of bees and protecting their habitat which is the environment as a whole. The warm and vibrant colour scheme has a positive effect on the viewers.
properties.title: Gazalah Rastgar

properties.artist_bio:
I am a Toronto-based illustrator, muralist and comics artist working out of a studio space on Dupont that I share with other 3 artists. While a lot of my illustration work is done for editorial or corporate clients, I’ve also had the opportunity to work on some community-based and public artwork projects over the past 2 years that I’ve been especially excited about. Through involvement with StART, I would love to find out about more opportunities to create public mural art that lives in and complements the community it is a part of. I think art in the public realm is so interesting to me because of how impactful it can be on mundane life – a visual break in the expected city patterns of shopfront, garage door, lamppost, parking meter. Even an escape. Themes of the idiosyncratic in the ordinary, the dichotomy between real and imagined, are things that my own work is interested in exploring, along with a sense of whimsy and play.

During the past few summers, I’ve been able to work on the Outside the Box traffic signal mural project, Womxn Paint in Toronto and in Rexdale, and the Lightup Laneway project. The outdoor murals I’ve completed have used a combination of exterior latex paint and spray paint, and in the future I’d like to explore more of how these mediums can work together, as well as improve on my ability to use spray paint which I was introduced to through Womxn Paint. Through public hoarding projects with PATCH (Mississauga and Region of Peel Watermain hoarding near Celebration Square; Bay Adelaide hoarding) I also have experience producing digital images for large-scale digital printing.

This upcoming year, I hope to have more opportunities to learn about making public artwork that supports the community it is a part of. I also want to challenge myself to work on larger, more varied projects that offer the opportunity for diversity in imagery and representation. I want to try new painting techniques with elements such as gradients and textures, and involve spray painting more in my mural work. I’m also interested in obtaining heights certification so that I’m able to work on larger walls should the opportunity arise. And I’d like to think about how – in mural making as in other life practises – I can do so with greater attention to sustainable practises and to the impact of what I’m doing. In general, I’d love increased opportunities to help make the site I’m painting in both reflective of and interesting to the imaginations of those who live here.
properties.description: “Animal City” is about how nice it is to spot all the living things in the city, especially late at night: albino squirrels, wandering cats, subway rats, sleeping pigeons, & the tail end of a trash panda. When you’re biking home at 4 am, there’s lots of other creatures out there with you.
properties.title: Wenting Li

properties.artist_bio: I am an award winning illustrator and OCAD U graduate. Primarily I am a freelance designer and painter. My paintings have shown at galleries in Toronto and New York. I enjoy working in a variety of media and scale. My work has taken forms such as apparel, a kids book, signs and branding.My mural experience started in 2016 in Owen Sound with a mural commissioned by Koodo and designed by Emily May Rose. I would continue to create large scale works along side Emily for personal collections as well as clients such as Tridel. I have gone on my own participating in stART projects such as Light Up Laneway and the Mimico bike lane barriers this past year. Furthermore I have been commissioned for murals in local residences.

properties.artist_bio:
MONICA WICKELER
As a trained visual artist who has worked in the large scale painting industry in Toronto for many years, in outdoor advertising as a mural artist and in the film and television industry as a scenic artist, Monica Wickeler has found a love of community and public art. As well as painting community murals in playgrounds, on wading pools and in pedestrian laneways, she has recently enjoyed working with students to inspire them to approach large scale paintings in their own community and taking ownership and pride in who they are and in their neighborhoods.
ARTISTIC STATEMENT
I have always been inspired by the newest STREET/PUBLIC artist projects around the world. When I start a project my sketches will often be uploaded and worked on digitally to see how my ideas respond to the space it will be painted on I can digitally mock up and idea and can easily share it with the client. Once at the wall producing the work, that amazing feeling of working in the public eye kicks in and the getting feedback from pedestrians is always an inspiration. Recently I have been using a combination of brushwork and aerosol painting techniques and I am thrilled with the vibrancy of color and effects produced. Finding the connection between the visual landscape and the images the community connects with is my biggest goal during my design process.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Monica Wickler

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio:
Graffiti and the various channels the practice exists in has allowed me find self, community and financial independence. To me, this world-culture is one of great value not only to individuals but also the larger community. I want to do all I can to participate in the production and instruction of this movement because of the freedom and joy that it can spread. My goals with StART would be to continue my Swirling of the city, help mentor young artists and create positive change in the community through the creation of large scale works/events, hopefully making our great city a hub for artistry in the light of this global movement.

BIO:
Flips is a Toronto based multi-media artist, life enthusiast and visual storyteller.
Inspired by the blending of cultural forces seen in Toronto and his homeland of Bulgaria, Flips’ focus is on promoting and celebrating world cultures and connectivity amongst people. His motto is that art has the power to unite people and aims to create works that inspire and instill this message.

Flips is best known in the streets of Toronto for his signature Swirl Style, which reflects the philosophy of unity through art in the swirling of color and line. Mirroring life, the Flips Swirl Clusters represent the state of flux that exists in life; a beautiful mess of movement and energy. At the heart of each swirl cluster exists a circle that represents the individual soul, linked to others through infinite ties. A grouping of swirls signifies a strong presence of community, creativity, and care.

properties.title: Flips

properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio:
I want to continue co-collaborating with StART to keep growing as an artist in my skill set, practice and portfolio. With StART’s support I want to be mentored in my mural career with any opportunities to connect with seasoned mural/street artists and get on a swing-stage, aerial lift, use a spray gun, while learning to comprehend XL large walls and huge quantities of paint among advanced techniques of execution and project production. I’ve currently reached the stage of painting garages in Toronto and am interested and ready to go larger.

Bio & Artist Statement
Anya Mielniczek is a Toronto based multidisciplinary artist who combines her fine art background with raw material grit in both private and public sectors creating mixed-media installations, mural work and facilitating community art activations.
The artists approach to mediums includes latex, aerosol and up-cycled waste, working with the mechanical application of spray and the energy of hand brushed strokes (infused with powerful female portraits and garbage bits if possible).
A Queen’s University graduate, Anya’s worked with various organizations, municipalities and businesses creating public art within communities around Toronto and internationally. Recent corporate projects include lead production on HideSeek, a 7000sq foot immersive art experience in Toronto and collaborations with BACARDI, QUO Makeup, Moroccanoil, DELL, RBC, 1800GOTJUNK and Chevrolet. Her commitment to her practice especially when aligned with public spaces is to create with purpose by giving nature a voice while defining a conversation with the viewer that may inspire and bring awareness for sustainable change.

properties.artist_bio: Rodrigo Castro, aka “Bomi" was born in León, Mexico and is now based in Toronto. His artwork is highly representative of his Latin American culture and boasts colourful patterns, symbols, and geometric shapes through his distinctive minimalistic style.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Rodrigo Castro

properties.artist_bio: I honestly cannot remember not being interested in art. From a young age, the idea of creating my own world has intrigued me. It was a no-brainer for me to go to college for it when I was ready to choose my post-secondary education. After receiving my fine arts diploma from Centennial College, I have participated in numerous art shows (beginning in 2013, refer to attached CV for details). I have worked at the art supplies store DeSerres since 2009-2018; being there has taught me about a broad spectrum of art materials. In addition to working as a sales person, I have also directed and taught art lessons to children aged 5-12 at the DeSerres art studio.
properties.description: While often referred to as “rats of the sky”, pigeons are actually quite beautiful when looked at closely. With speckled feathers which colours often vary from grey, white, to green, and purple, not a single pigeon will look same as another. They embody the city and deserve to be seen in a different, more positive light.
properties.title: Nina Gandolfo

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio: I want to work with StART to continue to develop my mural skills and portfolio. I hope to learn to use spray paint so that I can begin to create bigger and more detailed works faster in order to take my practice to the next level. I am also interested in the community aspect that stART has created. Through the various projects I have met and made connections with other artists who continue to support my practice outside of the StART realm. Having a studio art practice can keep me very isolated and can be difficult to make connections so StART has been very beneficial to me in that way.
properties.description: An array of artists enhanced the 1.4km cycle track along Lake Shore Boulevard West from Norris Crescent to First Street, west of Mimico Waterfront Park in Etobicoke.
properties.title: Sarah Cannon

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio:
My name is Jeff Blackburn and I am a visual artist based in Toronto. With over a decade of experience producing projects for exhibition and clients, my multi-disciplinary techniques are versatile, but also maintain a recognizable style. Inspired by illustration, graffiti, and comic books, my work is known for its emphasis on line and texture, and its exploration of form using interpretive contour lines. Paintings are constructed by merging pop art aesthetics with contemporary urban art materials and techniques.

My work explores themes that revel in a flippant joie de vivre, yet remain lightly steeped in some measure of memento mori. The combined effect is one of playfully self-assured yet shadowed cheek. My compositions tend to centre on a central figure, giving the piece a definitive focal point from which the viewer can explore. The subjects of my work are chosen for their relevance to the project or location, or simply for their relevance to me. Visual impact in my murals is further accomplished through a vibrant and textured usage of colour. In these paintings, colour is freed from its formal descriptive function and displays energy and motion through a build up of spray and acrylic paint layers.

I want to continue working with StART as I have been creating projects with their team since year one, and I greatly appreciate the opportunities that they’ve funded and helped bring to fruition for both my peers and myself.  I am hoping to grow the scale of my work in the public realm, while simultaneously gaining the key skills necessary in developing the business side of my career. With the backing of StART I have painted 14 traffic signal boxes, participated in roughly 10 StART funded mural jams, assisted American artist Andrew Schoultz in 2012 on one of the first Partnership Program murals, and most recently assisted BirdO on the first Monumental Program wall.
properties.description: An array of artists enhanced the 1.4km cycle track along Lake Shore Boulevard West from Norris Crescent to First Street, west of Mimico Waterfront Park in Etobicoke.
properties.title: Jeff Blackburn

properties.artist_bio:
In all that I do, I strive to bring people together with inspiration. I have a particular interest in supporting the art experience of families and children, and I carry my creativity and desire to connect through to my teaching practice. I have experience managing, curating, and instructing Art and Art History lessons at various schools and art studios in the GTA. I have taught art curriculums for school aged children, as well as individual workshops for all ages and groups, and I teach English as a foreign language.

My projects vary, but I am always thrilled by new possibilities, forever thinking of ways to apply myself. My illustrations are often concerned with the quality of a moment - perhaps the mystery of an unknown figure or the delight of a nostalgic object. Use of soft colours, gentle line art, and figurative subject matter has often been a characteristic of my work. The projects and materials I engage with may vary greatly, as I am always open to new inspirations and chances to grow.

I hope to always be conscious of the potential my work has to inspire, represent, and encourage — particularly with young viewers. Art has a profound impact on our every days lives — it builds character, opens minds, and forges relationships. My ardent desire to contribute to the street art scene is rooted in my conviction that art is for everyone. I am profoundly grateful to those artists who transform the city (and my experience of it) with their work. As a creator, I feel I must remain aware of how I can make artwork more accessible, in part by bringing my illustrations to the streets.

Programs like StART create a vital link between artists and communities. While I am motivated to make my artwork more accessible to the public, StART makes my goals as an artist more viable when too often I am inhibited by the financial barriers of creating and distributing art independently. I am deeply appreciative of this program and I am invigorated as an artist by the opportunities StART offers each year to learn and to share.
properties.description: The design draws its inspiration from the population of iconic feathered fowls that inhabit the streets, skyscrapers and busy landscape of Toronto.
properties.title: Morgan Groombridge

properties.artist_bio:
Working with StArt and seeing the positive impact it has on neighbourhoods, people and the development of artists is inspiring and makes me proud to be a part of.

Canadian graffiti artist Alexander Bacon began painting in the 90’s as a teenager.  He is best known for his colourful works lining the alleys and streets of Toronto and achieved international recognition.  Bacon describes the art form as being passed down from one generation to the next.
His work has evolved to deconstructing traditional graffiti spray paint techniques to create an abstract graffiti style while maintaining letter form.  His use of a mature colour pallet and mixing of realism with the stylized graffiti fonts gives his work a unique look with smooth transitions and texture.
Most recently Bacon has been doing large scale murals and Canvas work while maintaining the disciplines of graffiti.  His work can be seen all over Toronto., I bring it every time, got a good track record of big colour and positive results.
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Dudeman & Bacon

properties.artist_bio:
My murals play with patterning, painted as if successive layers of wallpaper have been carelessly removed, casually revealing the contrasting elements that lay beneath. Pattern, in the form of repeating decorative motifs, is a ubiquitous form of human expression. Many designs are so distinct they instantly call to mind a particular culture or part of the world. Some repeat over and over again throughout history.

The motifs that are revealed in my layered murals are from a broad range of eras and cultures. In the tremendously diverse reality of a contemporary globalized world, my paintings are a commentary on the fact that we are all in this together: collaborating, teaching, learning from, and inspiring one another.

I have ten years experience as a working artist, and have created numerous large-scale murals, many with the support of StART. I deeply appreciate the opportunities StART has given me, which have included larger and larger walls, international locations, and a lot of support in troubleshooting the many complexities that arise with mural creation!

My goals in the future are to move to creating multi-level murals (ie. more than 2 stories tall), to increase the number of assistants I use (thereby increasing mentorship, which I love to do, while decreasing installation time), and to paint more nationally and internationally. I would also love to continue to increase my knowledge of materials, and develop a "starting a mural" checklist, with timelines (ie. "Book Lift - 1 month ahead", "Order Paint - 2 weeks ahead"). I see a lot of big artists painting at festivals, where the timelines are tight, so increasing my speed is another goal for the years ahead.
properties.title: Kirsten McCrea

properties.artist_bio:
Roshni Wijayasinha is a Toronto based visual artist who specializes in large abstract expressionist paintings that are inspired by nature and its energy. Using acrylic and mixed media, these paintings experiment with light, colours, textures and finishes, and many of her pieces can be transformed under a black light, or glow in the dark. Her work has been featured at several juried exhibits and galleries across North America, in product launches, at a food festival, in a permanent collection at a Hilton Hotel in Toronto, in publications, and can be found on the streets of Toronto on 6 traffic boxes.

My experience painting the START traffic box at Front & John Street was a wonderful collaboration with the public, inviting people of all ages and different nationalities (high tourist traffic) make a small mark on this piece. I'm interested in participating in more street art around Toronto, to help liven our streets, bring energy and positivity to our neighbourhoods and people. Engaging our community in the process, I would love the opportunity to be able to deliver happiness and surprise and delight passers by as I do with my vivid glow in the dark paintings. I welcome the opportunity to work with other more established street artists, to learn more about outdoor art and public engagement, share our skills and techniques and grow together. I would also love to share my love of colour and light with other emerging artists, teaching them about how different materials can be used to create different lighting effects.
properties.description: This piece aims to use various bright colours, energetic lines and shapes that interact with each other, similar to the vibrant and diverse people, communities and landscapes that shape Toronto.
properties.title: Roshni Wijayasinha

properties.artist_bio:
I want to work with StART because the projects I have completed with Street Art Toronto's help have been not only the most enjoyable projects I have worked on in my career, but also the most lucrative for me, in terms of both payment and scale of exposure. I learn something new on every project we do together and working with StART staff has taught me virtually everything I know about what goes into publicly-funded street art projects, all the moving parts that need to be accounted for, communicating with the public, coordinating materials and other artists, publicity, etc. I want to keep building on this knowledge and skill set as we continue to spread colourful mural projects into new parts of the city/GTA.

Bio:
Nick Sweetman is a multidisciplinary artist from Toronto whose practice has explored painting and its intersection with photography, video, installation, mixed media, and urban intervention. He has exhibited in galleries around Toronto since 2011, completing his MFA in 2014 from OCAD University in the Interdisciplinary Art, Media & Design program. He received a certificate from the Mural Routes Leadership Training in Mural-Making program the same year and since then has been working in public space on mural projects, often in collaboration with other artists, and in partnership with various non-profit organizations (David Suzuki Foundation, The STEPS Initiative) as well as Street Art Toronto. He has successfully managed many large-scale projects both independently and as lead artist over a team of volunteers, from children up to adults. He has dedicated many projects to raising awareness about the importance of pollinators, bees and butterflies in particular, from painting giant bees towering over busy city streets to coordinating 30 or more artists to paint butterflies on garages in Toronto's laneways. Most recently, Nick has been working abroad, participating in the Eureka Street Art Festival in Humboldt County, California as well as contributing a mural to the Bondi Beach Sea Wall in Sydney, Australia.
properties.title: Nick Sweetman

properties.artist_bio: My name is Katrina Canedo and I am a Toronto-based freelance visual artist and live painter. I typically work with acrylic paint and digital art. However, recently I've been getting more into creating murals for commercials spaces (with spray paint and house paint) and would really love to participate and learn more from StrART projects and how the organization beautifies the city. Generally, my work is influenced by how colours and how they shape a subject can express universal stories or emotions especially applying them on portraits to elaborate on the subject's nuanced story/mood. Since my work is essentially influenced by formless colours and emotions, my process basically involves trying to form or incorporate these colours/shapes into the subject I'm reinterpreting into my style. My overall goal for getting involved with StART is to essentially learn and challenge myself in new ways to express that colourful vision.
properties.description: "Outstretched Branches” is a love letter to Toronto. The design’s vibe is pleasant and welcoming in hopes it is reminiscent of how Canada prides itself as more of a cultural mosaic than a melting pot.
properties.title: Katrina Canedo

properties.artist_bio:
Enlivened by his interest in spacial structures and interconnectivity, Andre Kan's paintings serve as excitable blueprints for a possible reality. Each work depicts the artists' signature imaginative building blocks that converge and begin to build upon each other and strengthening each other towards an ever transforming space. Kan's structures are substantial and complex but not yet anchored - they float suspended in his psychological space. In this way Kan's buildings remain a playful proposition for the viewer not yet tied to a specific place or function. With his dynamic formations, Kan propels us towards an ever optimistic future where new connections and constructions have yet to materialize.

His current work investigates the architectural interpretations that respond to our ever advancing society, and suggests what 'possibility' means through self discovery. Examining what mark making and its properties mean, as well as the significance in cause and effect, is important here. Kan's psychological structures depict change and evolution of space, while also questioning the fundamental nature of being and the world that encompasses it.

Andre Kan is a Toronto based painter. Since graduating from the Ontario College of Art & Design University in 2014, he continues his creative pursuits as an Artist, Muralist, Photographer, Curator, Producer, and Musician. His paintings have been showcased throughout Canada with permanent collections in the U.S and China. His murals can also be seen internationally including London, Spain, Portugal and Taiwan.



Email: andrekanart@gmail.com
Instagram: andrekan_
Twitter: @andrekanart

properties.artist_bio:
I create art so that I can reflect my sense of life.
My bold and playful spirit is an integral part of my creativity, employing various techniques that include, but not limited to painting, collaging, hand sewing, never settling to one style. Though I shift between styles, one strong commonality in my work is the intent to stimulate human curiosity by negating the familiar, and twisting notions or ideas perceived by society.
Growing up in Japan until age 20, I’ve always been drawn to the vintage photography, religious imagery, and advertising of Americana. It was only for personal enjoyment when I first began collecting such imageries, yet soon I developed one of my recurring techniques: photo collage. Combining what at first seems contradictory, my photo collages are a sensational and compositional fusion of found items as a way to access the unconscious mind.

In parallel with photo collages, I am focused on making artworks with intense simplistic forms and bold blocks of colour, and by forgoing visual details. This is because I’m nearly blind without the help of glasses, which makes seeing the details of the world secondary.
Such poor eyesight, always making collages: cutting shapes and pasting them, all that attest to the very process I perceive and compose.
I tantalize the boundaries between abstraction and representation of a familiar object or a scene, inviting viewers to insinuate a new meaning without lingering to past knowledge or future thought.
properties.title: Leeay Aikawa

properties.artist_bio: Working with stART is a great way to connect and network with other creatives and align myself with new opportunities. My goal is to find likeminded artists and project coordinators to achieve thought provoking work for the upcoming year. My work focuses on nature and the fragile state of the environment. I paint indoor and outdoor murals with themes such as local wildlife and climate change in effort to educate and celebrate the beauty and importance of local ecosystems. I believe communities are stronger when they have a connection to the natural world that exists amidst their neighbourhood. “Knowing your neighbour” is the first step to caring and protecting them. This stewardship brings communities together. I hope to work with stART to celebrate local communities of Toronto –including the people, plants and animals.

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.description: This piece is inspired by the life affirming power of the sun and the God-given light it provides to the Earth. The bright colour tones are reminiscent of looking through an old Nikon lens with a loose mount allowing rainbow coloured light to leak into view.
properties.title: Evond Blake (Mediah)

properties.artist_bio: I am an award winning illustrator and OCAD U graduate. Primarily I am a freelance designer and painter. My paintings have shown at galleries in Toronto and New York. I enjoy working in a variety of media and scale. My work has taken forms such as apparel, a kids book, signs and branding.My mural experience started in 2016 in Owen Sound with a mural commissioned by Koodo and designed by Emily May Rose. I would continue to create large scale works along side Emily for personal collections as well as clients such as Tridel. I have gone on my own participating in stART projects such as Light Up Laneway and the Mimico bike lane barriers this past year. Furthermore I have been commissioned for murals in local residences.
