properties.artist_bio:
Working with StArt and seeing the positive impact it has on neighbourhoods, people and the development of artists is inspiring and makes me proud to be a part of.

Canadian graffiti artist Alexander Bacon began painting in the 90’s as a teenager.  He is best known for his colourful works lining the alleys and streets of Toronto and achieved international recognition.  Bacon describes the art form as being passed down from one generation to the next.
His work has evolved to deconstructing traditional graffiti spray paint techniques to create an abstract graffiti style while maintaining letter form.  His use of a mature colour pallet and mixing of realism with the stylized graffiti fonts gives his work a unique look with smooth transitions and texture.
Most recently Bacon has been doing large scale murals and Canvas work while maintaining the disciplines of graffiti.  His work can be seen all over Toronto.

properties.artist_bio:
Marley Allen-Ash is an illustrator and artist working in Toronto, Canada. She uses traditional printmaking and digital media to create illustrations and explore both historical and personal narratives.  In addition to illustration, she enjoys work on murals and self publishing comics with her collective, Grab Bag Club.  She studied at OCAD University, completing a bachelor of design and majoring in illustration. Her illustration work has been recognized by American Illustration, 3x3 Magazine and Creative Quarterly. Selected Clients include The Globe and Mail, CANADALAND, Cottage Life and Lenny Letter.

I have worked with StART before, through the Lakeshore Bike Lane Murals, Concrete Barrier Art Program, and Outside the Box. I'd love to be involved in more group and individual mural projects, such as laneway mural projects or painting underpasses. I'm really open to any type of opportunity, though in the past I've worked with exterior latex paint for murals, as well as creating digital files to be printed and used as vinyl wraps.

For the last three years, I've had the fortune to be part of various StART projects and it is truly inspiring for me as a street artist to see the support from the city towards this art form. I'd love to continue working with StART and be part of this art movement!
Bio: My artistic work is the result of my experiences living and working in various parts of Latin America. The rich and vibrant cultures of the places I’ve visited have been my main inspiration to create and share my artistic vision with others. As a Canadian-Colombian artist is empowering for me to paint around the themes of culture, nature, and identity enriching Canadian multiculturalism. Most of my murals are found in Canada and Colombia, my wish is to continue painting across Canada and the world.

properties.artist_bio:
I am an educator and a painter, with a background in science and art, and am strongly interested in extending my personal practice into the realm of public art. I created a painting for the 2018 'Outside the Box' programme, and would like to become more involved in public art in Toronto.

Public art themes I am interested in exploring involve (re)connecting with nature, in particular the sky – the Moon, the Sun, the planets and stars, and the seasonal rhythms throughout the year. As a trained astronomer, I feel a strong connection to the celestial, and my work deals with the essential interconnected nature of humans and the Universe. I feel that in our urban environment, we have lost many elements of our relationship with nature. I would propose artwork which would kindle a reconnection and help deepen awareness of our place in the local landscape, and in the wider Universe as a whole. With the diversity of our backgrounds - our origins, our orientations, our outlooks -  we all experience one sky. Connecting with nature is a fundamental aspect of the universal human experience, and given the stresses and distractions of our digital and built environments, is something we all need to be attentive to, and cultivate.

I have a strong interest in colour and feel that the use of colour in public art is key as it is uplifting and inspires joy – crucial elements for art in the public realm. Although my training and practice lies in painting, I also have a desire to extend my practice into sculpture; in particular, public artworks which mark seasonal changes in the sky. One goal is to create artwork which makes people look up.

I am also interested in becoming more involved in the community and facilitating workshops (with all ages) which explore interconnections between science and art, and using the artmaking process as a way of deepening our understanding of nature. I have facilitated workshops in the past, and currently teach at York University in the Faculty of Science's Division of Natural Science. I also am a member of Propeller Gallery.

For me, the opportunity to make public art represents a natural extension and culmination point for my backgrounds in art, science and education. I seek wider opportunities to engage the public, both visually and conceptually, as well as including them in the artmaking process.

I would be interested in participating in any of the StART programmes, and would be happy to work as a team member in larger scale projects on other artists' designs.
properties.description: In our busy day-to-day city lives, we have become disconnected from nature and lost our sense of wonder for our Universe. Look Up!, with its bright and whimsical colours will draw our attention away from our state of disconnection, and bring us back to being present within our local urban environment.
properties.title: Robin Kingsburgh

properties.artist_bio:
Jieun June Kim is a Toronto based, Korean born painter and muralist.  She has exhibited her paintings around the world since 2010 at notable galleries and events, exploring the idea of “home” as an immigrant and creating safe space.
Jieun completed the Mural Art Career Development program offered by Mural Routes in 2017 and has since worked with various arts organizations, city of Toronto as well as corporate partners such as Samsung, Up Canada, and Collective Arts Brewery.
 She is the co-founder of KJ Bit Collective who creates murals and street art events, and a member of the Mural Routes advisory committee team. She is also the recipient of the Newcomer and Refugee Artist Mentorship grant from the Toronto Arts Council (2018).
properties.description: StART Support provides materials for the creation of graffiti art and art murals on properties with a history of repeated graffiti vandalism on walls exposed to city streets
properties.title: Eric Kristmanson (Poser) & Jieun Kim

properties.artist_bio:
Natalie Very B. is an illustrator, muralist, and teacher of Polish-Canadian decent.
Having grown up in a country with a strong patriarchal regime and an obvious system of inequality, she finds solace in painting ethereal shapes of female figures and the stories that they tell. As an immigrant artist she often explores the concept of “home”, and the sense of wistful longing and nostalgia that it brings out in her work.
Her childhood experience became a strong incentive for her to make illustrations that depict women as beautiful, empowered, and strong. As a result, her current work is devoted to the investigation of whimsical shapes of feminism in today’s world.

I would like to work with StART as I have had wonderful experiences working with you in the past, and I would like to keep this collaboration growing. You allow me to express myself, educate people, and beautify Toronto with my skills and ideas.
properties.description: The design highlights Toronto’s most dreaded bird: the pigeon. There are a lot negative emotions that are linked to our city’s inhabitant, and the artist would like to change that bias. Their shimmering, iridescent feathery collars are remarkable, yet not many of us take the time to admire them.
properties.title: Natalie VeryB

properties.artist_bio: Pam Lostracco is a Toronto mural artist and graphic designer. Her work forms connections with the local environment that create a sense of identity and belonging for those who live and work here. By integrating unique and diverse natural, cultural and historical influences, she transforms blank walls into inclusive and stunning spaces. She designs each mural with visual aesthetics that are familiar to a particular community, inviting people to engage in an uplifting and meaningful experience.
properties.description: An array of artists enhanced the 1.4km cycle track along Lake Shore Boulevard West from Norris Crescent to First Street, west of Mimico Waterfront Park in Etobicoke.
properties.title: Pam Lostracco

properties.artist_bio:
Early on, I perceived that my ambition was the act of painting itself, finding that the process coincided with the workings of my conscious and unconscious mind.Throughout my career I have also been fascinated by realism, specifically trompe l’oeil and it’s ability to affect the viewer. I have been creating trompe l’oeil murals in combination with my abstract works for over 20 years now. It has become for me a way to connect with the viewer on several different levels. I have discovered that painting illusions allows me to communicate with a larger audience, as people genuinely delighted when visually tricked. While both painting techniques claim to express reality truthfully, either suggests only a partial or incomplete view of a subject.
I am also extremely interested in the archival quality of work and how public art is produced, in an ethical and archival way. I have painted murals that are still on display over 20 years later. I feel that viewers of public work have an investment in the upkeep and archival quality of the work. Starting with the proper preparation, the production process should be considered when producing public art. When public art pieces become worn and decay after only a few seasons the public does not see the value in continuing to fund public art. Having worked for several years of trial and error I feel that I could offer proper preparation advice to many of the public art projects.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Margaret Cresswell

properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Toronto, I am a champion of this city. My work often depicts Toronto life - people, events and elements connected to the region. I have witnessed many changes and struggles in neighborhoods throughout the city and have contributed to developing community strength through several art projects.
I choose to create art that can be seen and appreciated by the public, free and accessible to anyone - bringing beauty to dingy, neglected areas of town. I enjoy working with communities to engage them in the process of change, establish personal connections and develop a sense of pride in their neighborhood.
My goal is to work on a larger scale projects with StART. I would like to be mentored/assisted in the use of aerosol painting as well as high murals requiring a lift. Working with StART, I would love to work with an Indigenous artist/group on a co-operative project to learn, exchange information and cultural practices. Indigenous art including Woodland style, Inuit sculpture, drawing and printmaking, are my favourite styles of art.
My artwork also addresses environmental concerns/issues; reminding us that everything has a purpose, even when it is not clear to us, what that is. I often find inspiration in ecology, the environment and site-specific surroundings the mural will be in. Figures, the body, and movement are recurring themes in my art.
As well as being a painter, I have been a professional photographer for over 25 years, creating images digitally as well as on film. Previously, I was the Resident Photography Artist at Mississauga Living Art Centre. While working at the TDSB, I was honoured to photograph Nelson Mandela on his first visit to Toronto. I collaborated with teachers and students on several art projects including a handmade book given to Mr. Mandela.
I am experienced in photographing events, fine art documentation, portraits, dance and theatre, products, buildings, magazine and commercial work. I also create digital designs including Op Art, tile patterns, floral, abstract; web design, preparing/repurposing images for web, email and print.
Materials and mediums I work with include photography, acrylic and latex paint, acrylic markers, aerosol paint, clay, wood and collage.

I have graduated from 3 art programs: Central Technical School Adult Art Program, Ryerson Still Photography and Humber College Audio/Visual Technology. As a multidisciplinary artist, my unique combination of art and technology skills brings strength of understanding to all my projects. Working as a full-time artist and art educator, I teach painting, drawing, ceramics, mixed media and photography throughout the GTA, to seniors, adults and children.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Karen Roberts

properties.artist_bio:
I'm an Honors OCAD graduate in Fine Arts, a visual artist and community mural painter. My most recent project, The Richmond Hill Traffic Box Murals Project 2019 was made possible through a Richmond Hill Community and Cultural Grant.   I am a StART Concrete Barrier artist and I took part in the Lakeshore Barrier Bike Lane project in 2019. I have created murals for StreeARToronto, The F.H. Varley Art Gallery of Markham and The Toronto Public Library. Last September, I was a muralist for the 2018 StreetARToronto Light up the Laneway Project, (Euclid Palmerston Laneway), and I’ve been accepted three times for StreetARToronto Outside the Box Program.  In 2017 I executed a Canada 150 Bell Box Community Mural Project.  In Toronto, I was hired for the The Coxwell Laneway Mosaic at Coxwell TTC Subway in 2016. Other initiatives include Nuit Blanche and The Henderson CN Bridge Mural,(2014), revisited in January 2020.
My ideas are closely tied into Toronto Public Library, where I have worked for over 45 years as a public service worker. My recent positions there have included Children's Programming and Special Collections initiatives, where I have made use of my artistic skills to help community with library projects similar in scope to mural initiatives. Public service includes mural work.  It includes any tools that we can use to help community and helping community through the gifts I can offer has been my life's work.  Truly I believe that there are many avenues available to help needful communities achieve sustainability and gain a sense of pride, both where public spaces are concerned and where housing is concerned.  Mural making is just one of those tools - as are library materials and services, and other community initiatives.

My goals with StART include partnering the library or offering my librarianship skills to promote and to encourage any initiatives that might be developed by StART, through mural work, to connect the community with literacy in all it's forms, including digital and creative literacy. The way to reach community is to involve them in positive and exciting ways that will give them something of value to add to their lives. Again, there are so many ways we can do this - especially if our important various avenues public service can partner together in creative endeavours to mentor community.
Every day at the library or when we are painting murals on walls, we have opportunities to mentor others.  Sometimes this takes on a formal role and sometimes not, but every time we take an interest in a member of our community and show them something they need to know, this is mentoring. Every time we answer a question from a passerby about a project or initiative that has been built to help them - this is mentoring. If possible I would like to take part in a short term or small project mentoring program developed by StART, as I do in the library, with Children's STEM Programming.

Again, there are many avenues open to mentorship possibilities. I would;d be open to any and all of them, as developed by and at the discretion of StART. I have ideas that would lend themselves to partnership of library and mural making and public consultation for these ideas would include mentorship of community members. iMy most ambitious upcoming project is one I would like to submit next year to the StART Partnership program, to include a large library component to a mural initiative to be developed in central North York near a library.

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Toronto, I have been a full-time professional mural artist for over 27 years. My mural career includes works for private, commercial, corporate clients, educational institutions and public art projects. One highlight of my career was working with acclaimed American artist Frank Stella as the Studio Manager for his studios in Toronto, New York and Houston, Texas. During this time the studio created large scale mixed media murals based on Mr. Stella’s paper collages.
These works were commissioned by international galleries and museums from Japan to Germany and included Torontoʼs Princess of Wales Theatre.

I have worked with the StART team on several large scale projects and I have always been impressed with all of the support and encouragement that this program cultivates.  From the beginning, it was apparent how much the program focuses on bringing together artists and communities to create a lasting positive experience for all.  During the production of both my Park Lawn Underpass Mural and the Lake Shore Cycle Track Barrier Murals, I received an overwhelming amount of positive feedback and response from the individuals driving, biking, riding and walking by these public pieces of art.  So much of an artists' time is spent creating a piece of artwork alone in the studio.  The StART program allows for an "on the spot" engagement with the community during the development of a mural.  For me, this is the most rewarding part of these murals.  I am proud to bring my artistic vision to these public works of art through the StART program for all to enjoy no matter what their background, social status or familiarity with a traditional gallery/museum setting.

properties.artist_bio:
Visual Artist

Christiano De Araujo is a self-taught artist who was born in Anápolis, Goiás, Brazil. His earliest memory as a child is the moment when he discovered his love of art. As a toddler, he remembers picking up a crayon that his older sister had left behind. When she found that Christiano had taken it, she grabbed it away from him, but in that short amount of time, he had fallen in love with colours and the ability to create.

His love of art and his talent for the drawing were evident when he was a student in school. His first passion was comics and cartoons and at age 12 he drew his first comic strip.

In his late teens, Christiano began working for Brazil’s highly circulated newspaper, Diário da Manhã, doing editorial cartoons and illustrations. He also continued to work for other local newspapers and magazines. Realizing that he wanted more opportunities than he could have in Brazil, Christiano chose to immigrate to Canada.

His first years in Canada were a struggle. Early on, he landed a job as a Bricklayer, which he did for a number of years. Christiano confronted his weaknesses and discovered his strengths, learned to laugh at his hardships, quickly moving on. He was able to overcome any adversities with a determination to succeed and a desire to make himself a better man. This led to his artwork being published in numerous magazines and newspapers in Toronto.

He also credits his success to a spiritual awakening that he had through meditation and self-hypnosis. It gave him clarity and focus. This experience gave him more confidence and the ability to control his emotions and himself. Christiano devotes much of his life to his art. His endeavours include drawing, oil and acrylic painting, airbrushing, cartooning and sculpting. He is an artist by trade, finds art fun and likes to explore new media and innovated techniques.

Christiano currently resides in Toronto, Canada. He is the founder of Toronto Artists Studio, a studio of visual artists, painters, digital artists and sculptors who design and produce murals and visual communication projects for audiences on a small and grand scale.

At the present moment, this very moment… Christiano is enjoying the wonderful interaction between the mind and the universe. This infinite universe in which we are all one!
properties.title: Christiano De Arujo, Natasha Ditchburn

properties.address: St Clair Ave W & Oakwood Ave
properties.description: This design serves as an homage to Jane Jacobs, the celebrated author, urban theorist, and activist who called Toronto home for many decades. It celebrates Jane’s legacy in advocating for the preservation of Toronto’s neighbourhoods, streets, and buildings. The design features one of Jane’s most poetic quotes: “What will remain of us is cities and songs”.
properties.title: Jay Wall

properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Iran, I moved to Canada as a teenager. I studied at OCAD University, where I gained exposure to a variety of disciplines from Fine Arts to Graphic Design & Advertising. After obtaining my Bachelor’s degree, I began working as a Visual Communications Coordinator at a large corporation. After 7 years, I decided to pursue my own art and design practice. I have since been awarded and published a number of times, had a solo exhibition and have created a number of murals around Toronto. I create colourful and whimsical paintings, digital art and GIFs that focus on life as a woman, spirituality and everyday life. I’m a shameless coffee addict and frequent the local cafes. Dancing, yoga and biking are my preferred ways of recharging.
I started my street art work since 2018 at which point I painted on a utility box for StreetARToronto and since then I have painted multiple small scale murals around Toronto for StreetART, Bell Box Murals including garage doors and concrete walls. I would like to continue expanding my street art practice and beautify the city further.

properties.artist_bio: I want to work with StART to continue to develop my mural skills and portfolio. I hope to learn to use spray paint so that I can begin to create bigger and more detailed works faster in order to take my practice to the next level. I am also interested in the community aspect that stART has created. Through the various projects I have met and made connections with other artists who continue to support my practice outside of the StART realm. Having a studio art practice can keep me very isolated and can be difficult to make connections so StART has been very beneficial to me in that way.
properties.description: The design offers a peek into the world of the tiny and often overlooked members of the diverse ecosystems that can be found in Toronto Parks and Ravines.

properties.description: Toronto is a mosaic of cultures and a shining model for the rest of the world. The mosaic consists of tiles, glass beads, shards of pottery with various patterns on them.
properties.title: Thomas Dannenberg

properties.artist_bio:
Early on, I perceived that my ambition was the act of painting itself, finding that the process coincided with the workings of my conscious and unconscious mind.Throughout my career I have also been fascinated by realism, specifically trompe l’oeil and it’s ability to affect the viewer. I have been creating trompe l’oeil murals in combination with my abstract works for over 20 years now. It has become for me a way to connect with the viewer on several different levels. I have discovered that painting illusions allows me to communicate with a larger audience, as people genuinely delighted when visually tricked. While both painting techniques claim to express reality truthfully, either suggests only a partial or incomplete view of a subject.
I am also extremely interested in the archival quality of work and how public art is produced, in an ethical and archival way. I have painted murals that are still on display over 20 years later. I feel that viewers of public work have an investment in the upkeep and archival quality of the work. Starting with the proper preparation, the production process should be considered when producing public art. When public art pieces become worn and decay after only a few seasons the public does not see the value in continuing to fund public art. Having worked for several years of trial and error I feel that I could offer proper preparation advice to many of the public art projects.
properties.description: This painting is inspired not only by the birch trees found in the many neighbourhood in Toronto (Scarborough – Birch Cliff, specifically) but the artist's many trips to Canada’s north to paint the beauty and try capturing its wild nature.
properties.title: Margaret Cresswell

properties.artist_bio:
I’d love to work with StreetARToronto because I’m inspired by the artistic legacy they are building in the City of Toronto. StART’s vision to create beautiful and safer public spaces with a mandate to act inclusively, celebrate our strengths in diversity, to acknowledge and respect the cultures and lands of Indigenous persons, and mentor emerging talents, all reflect my own values in my professional and personal life.

I’ve been an artist for 20 years in the public realm, having exhibited in public art galleries, artist-run centres, art festivals, and having worked with public/private planning teams to create permanent public art with budgets up to $56,000.00 (Holland Bloorview Kids Rehabilitation Hospital). I work in several disciplines including sculpture (polyurethane resins, concrete, casting techniques), installation art (interactive works that light up, make noise, or move - typically destined for art festivals/events such as Nuit Blanche, Animating Our Waterfront, Hamilton Supercrawl), and painting murals.

My passion for community arts participation cemented over 15 years ago when I sat on the board of Carfac Ontario as Vice Chair, with Merlin Homer as Chair, a Mohawk Elder whom I consider as a mentor. We had an exceptional team of strong arts leaders and my experience at Carfac helped mould my understanding of fair remuneration, cultural/ethnic/language/gender challenges that artists’ face, and the importance of advocating for one another’s communities.  Profoundly affected by this experience, I’ve continued to work with communities and have co-founded three successful art collectives, Open Field Collective, KJ Bit, and Creativo Collective, whose mandates are to create artwork and murals in public spaces while being inclusive of surrounding communities. In 2017, the Open Field Collective was awarded the national ArtBridges award for “Innovation” in recognition of our dedication to community engagement and our “Street Projects” where we invented miniature art galleries to create and display artwork in public spaces such as residential front yards, King Street (Public Realm), and Guelph. We’ve partnered with Scouts Canada, Neilson Creative Centre (Etobicoke), King Edward PS, been sponsored by Waterfront Toronto, and supported by Neighbourhood Associations and private and corporate donors.

Last year, I was lead coordinator for one of StreetARToronto’s laneway mural/graffiti projects. It was a wonderful opportunity to mentor my KJ Bit collaborator, June Kim, as a facilitator in the project. This summer, we’ll be coordinating the second phase of this Euclid/Palmerston laneway with a roster of 40 artists and be presenting a WalkShop tour of this laneway for delegates of the National Association of City Transportation Officials. This September, we’ll be painting a mural in partnership with StreetARToronto and TTC at Finch Station. My goal is to continue painting more murals, participating in more laneway jams and creating new, innovative street art events. I’d love to continue working with StreetARToronto because I believe we have mutual respect for the experience and expertise that both sides bring to the table. Above all, I love learning new things, and StreetARToronto has given me a great opportunity to grow as an artist and a facilitator.

properties.artist_bio:
I want to continue co-collaborating with StART to keep growing as an artist in my skill set, practice and portfolio. With StART’s support I want to be mentored in my mural career with any opportunities to connect with seasoned mural/street artists and get on a swing-stage, aerial lift, use a spray gun, while learning to comprehend XL large walls and huge quantities of paint among advanced techniques of execution and project production. I’ve currently reached the stage of painting garages in Toronto and am interested and ready to go larger.

Bio & Artist Statement
Anya Mielniczek is a Toronto based multidisciplinary artist who combines her fine art background with raw material grit in both private and public sectors creating mixed-media installations, mural work and facilitating community art activations.
The artists approach to mediums includes latex, aerosol and up-cycled waste, working with the mechanical application of spray and the energy of hand brushed strokes (infused with powerful female portraits and garbage bits if possible).
A Queen’s University graduate, Anya’s worked with various organizations, municipalities and businesses creating public art within communities around Toronto and internationally. Recent corporate projects include lead production on HideSeek, a 7000sq foot immersive art experience in Toronto and collaborations with BACARDI, QUO Makeup, Moroccanoil, DELL, RBC, 1800GOTJUNK and Chevrolet. Her commitment to her practice especially when aligned with public spaces is to create with purpose by giving nature a voice while defining a conversation with the viewer that may inspire and bring awareness for sustainable change.
properties.description: The design illustrates native species and creates a piece that not only beautifies but also serves as a point of information for the community.
properties.title: Anya Mielniczek

properties.artist_bio: I'm a Toronto-based fine artist, illustrator and mural artist. I'm very inspired by the things around me, and the people in my life. I utilize a lot of different mediums into my art practice such as oils, acrylics, watercolour, ink, graphite, spray paint and exterior latex paint. I have been involved in various community-led projects, private and commercial mural commissions. The most impactful projects that I've been apart of, have led me to mentor youth artists and that has been the most rewarding part of those projects. An extension of youth mentorship, I'm also the Artist-in-Residence at Waterfront Neighbourhood Centre. I instruct Room 13, an international Studio that guides a growing network of student-run arts studios in schools and community settings globally. In the past few years, I have been apart of numerous Bell Box Murals Project throughout the city as well as START Outside the Box in 2018.

properties.artist_bio:
SPUD1 has been a fixture in the Toronto urban and underground art scene for more than 18 years. An accomplished artist, he loves the thrill of finding unconventional spaces to showcase his talent.
SPUD1’s passion for art has grown along with his talent. He is a well-rounded artist that is capable of working with all types of mediums and images, and specializes in working collaboratively with other artists.
SpudBomb was founded by SPUD1 in 2010, when he traveled across Europe, covering many cities with his funny and happy SpudBomb characters and happy Grenades.
Team SpudBomb is comprised of Spud1 & his partner Brooke, together they curate and manage various artists projects and large scale murals, both collaboratively and on behalf of Spud1 himself.
Since 2014 Team SpudBomb – working under the event Wall Expressions; has been working in partnership and fully funded through StART to curate Laneway events that help to create live outdoor galleries in laneways that experience graffiti vandalism.  These events allow the community and artist to engage and reclaim public spaces, and create conversation about art and how it can serve the neighbourhood/community when incorporate in public spaces.
In 2016 SPUD1 was one of the featured artists in the Doors Open Toronto colouring book and was successful in his grant application with the Bloordale BIA to install a huge mural within that community, which has been exceptionally well received, and working with brands such as CAT, Converse, Mountain Dew, Universal Studios, and Crystal Head Vodka. In addition to this, his installation of the Pride Mural at Church and Wood received a special award for his dedication and activism in the TPS & StART Toronto partnership program.
In 2017 Spud completed a huge Mural called the Smile on Dufferin, the ribbon cutting and mural unveiling was opened by city councilor & Deputy Mayor Ana Bailao.
In 2018 Spud1 and Sean Martindale completed the mural “Tapestry of Movement at the Toronto Coach Terminal through the City’s StART partnership program with STEPS Initiative, and saw him working with brands such as Sketchers.
In 2019  Team Spudbomb was awarded a partnership Grant through the City of Toronto to paint an over 2,000 square foot underpass, an invitation to paint a large mural at Concrete canvas festival in Hamilton and a request to paint at Kotis Street Art in Greensboro, North Carolina.
These are just a few examples throughout the past 6 years where Spud1 has exemplified the type of artist he is, one which continually sees markets, festivals, other artists and brands wanting to work with him in addition to Team Spudbomb continuing to work with old school and emerging talents to bring together events that foster community engagements and relationships.
SPUD1’s dedication and commitment to seeing the projects he is involved in through is only overshadowed by his installations themselves.
SPUD1 continues to grow and evolve as an artist and is always looking for new and exciting opportunities to express himself and showcase his art., SPUD1 has been a fixture in the Toronto urban and underground art scene for more than 18 years. properties.artist_bio:
For the last three years, I've had the fortune to be part of various StART projects and it is truly inspiring for me as a street artist to see the support from the city towards this art form. I'd love to continue working with StART and be part of this art movement!
Bio: My artistic work is the result of my experiences living and working in various parts of Latin America. The rich and vibrant cultures of the places I’ve visited have been my main inspiration to create and share my artistic vision with others. As a Canadian-Colombian artist is empowering for me to paint around the themes of culture, nature, and identity enriching Canadian multiculturalism. Most of my murals are found in Canada and Colombia, my wish is to continue painting across Canada and the world.
properties.description: An array of artists enhanced the 1.4km cycle track along Lake Shore Boulevard West from Norris Crescent to First Street, west of Mimico Waterfront Park in Etobicoke.
properties.title: Daniela Rocha

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.

properties.artist_bio:
Jieun June Kim is a Toronto based, Korean born painter and muralist.  She has exhibited her paintings around the world since 2010 at notable galleries and events, exploring the idea of “home” as an immigrant and creating safe space.
Jieun completed the Mural Art Career Development program offered by Mural Routes in 2017 and has since worked with various arts organizations, city of Toronto as well as corporate partners such as Samsung, Up Canada, and Collective Arts Brewery.
 She is the co-founder of KJ Bit Collective who creates murals and street art events, and a member of the Mural Routes advisory committee team. She is also the recipient of the Newcomer and Refugee Artist Mentorship grant from the Toronto Arts Council (2018).
properties.description: In this design, the past and present homes and worlds coexist peacefully and combine with one other to create new unexplored territories. People can relate to this art as it addresses cultural differences and asks the viewer to question where they feel their home is.
properties.title: Jieun June Kim

properties.artist_bio:
BIO:
Angel Carrillo started his art journey as an urban artist, project coordinator, educator, and one of Toronto’s well-known street artist. Angel has created art for Holt Renfrew, Athlete’s World, Bell, Telus, Campbell’s, Rogers, MTV, City of Toronto, the O.P.P., OCAD, and University of Toronto. He has been featured in Pound Magazine, The Globe and Mail, Toronto Sun, TorontoStar, Inside Toronto, Champ Magazine and on CityTV, CTV, and Global. He has taught urban arts workshops for events like Nuit Blanche, Manifesto and Style in Progress. Angel is also very active in community and outreach programs like Laser Eagles and events which he has helped run for the City of Toronto, Mural Route, Schools without Borders and YMCA. He is a frequent speaker at discussion panels for the city’s graffiti laws and the need for public art space and funding.
properties.description: This project transformed the Euclid/ Palmerston laneway into a giant canvas of colourful garages painted by an amazing array of Toronto’s mural and street artists.
properties.title: Angel Carrillo "Cruz"

properties.artist_bio:
I create art so that I can reflect my sense of life.
My bold and playful spirit is an integral part of my creativity, employing various techniques that include, but not limited to painting, collaging, hand sewing, never settling to one style. Though I shift between styles, one strong commonality in my work is the intent to stimulate human curiosity by negating the familiar, and twisting notions or ideas perceived by society.
Growing up in Japan until age 20, I’ve always been drawn to the vintage photography, religious imagery, and advertising of Americana. It was only for personal enjoyment when I first began collecting such imageries, yet soon I developed one of my recurring techniques: photo collage. Combining what at first seems contradictory, my photo collages are a sensational and compositional fusion of found items as a way to access the unconscious mind.

In parallel with photo collages, I am focused on making artworks with intense simplistic forms and bold blocks of colour, and by forgoing visual details. This is because I’m nearly blind without the help of glasses, which makes seeing the details of the world secondary.
Such poor eyesight, always making collages: cutting shapes and pasting them, all that attest to the very process I perceive and compose.
I tantalize the boundaries between abstraction and representation of a familiar object or a scene, inviting viewers to insinuate a new meaning without lingering to past knowledge or future thought.
properties.title: Leeay Aikawa

properties.artist_bio: Jim Bravo was born in Ecuador, South America in 1973. He is a graduate of The Ontario College of Art and Design University where he majored in Fine Art and studied monumental & public art. Bravo has been active in the street/public art arena since his 2006 graduation, completing several city-funded murals and an array of community engagement art projects.  Through his affiliation with various local arts organizations he has gained vast experience as an arts mentor for at-risk youth initiatives. Bravo is a 4 time award winning painter and muralist and he lives and works in the city of Toronto

properties.artist_bio: I am a Russian-Canadian visual artist and muralist based in Toronto ON. I hold a BFA from Emily Carr University and Certificate in Mural Art from Mural Routes. Majority of my paintings revolve around relationship between figure and abstract space, as I tend to explore themes of personal identity, duality and shifting perceptions.In the past two years I have been working in public spaces painting murals. These projects have become meaningful and rewarding experiences for me as I got a chance to share my narrative with my community, alter spaces and engage public. I’ve participated in collaborative murals with Mural Routes and Artbarn School. I have also completed my own projects as a lead artist in a cafe, Art Fair and Public School. Last summer I was thrilled to participate in the StART OTB program and Bellbox Mural programs.

properties.artist_bio:
I have been painting and drawing my whole life. I started, according to my mother, at age 4. She still has a great little ship drawing I did at that age. Drawing came easy to me but I had to work hard to be a good painter - I’m still working. Painting for me is a process of meditation; it’s a constant pursuit to describe the mental landscape as influenced by its surroundings.
	As well as painting, I work as a photographer, shooting everything from events, editorials, and sometimes celebrities. My grandfather was an avid amateur photographer and gave me my first camera at a young age. Photography and painting have always gone hand in hand for me. One feeds the other. Photography as a tool has been employed by painters and artists since its invention. One could make a strong case that the advent of photography could not have been achieved without the help of painting and classical tools such as the camera obscura to help painters recreate scenes. I use photography in this way, creating images from reference subjects I capture.
	My work is an ongoing process. I try not to just do one thing, I don’t think standing still and producing one product time and time again is a good thing. An artist has to be careful to not let their work become stale.
 	1950s abstract expressionism is my jam. The New York school was a big influence on me as a young artist, but also the Montreal scene. The artist Jean-Paul Riopelle and Paul Emile Borduas were heroes of mine. Leader of the Automatistes and main author of the manifesto Refus Global, Borduas broke from all convention. I remember vividly seeing L’étoile Noir in person when I was young and being blown away by its bold simplicity. The surrealists also had a profound impact on my practice - specifically Dali for his character and brashness. His ambitious paintings and tight style always impressed  and humbled me.  H.R. Giger and Francis Bacon are also worth mentioning. Both artists’ approaches to painting were violent, sexual, and graphic. Food for the young artist.
	The world is too interesting to not reflect on. The sublime and terrifying are always in front of us and we often have to ignore them to get on with our day. I like to allow my paintings to shape themselves in my mind. The painting comes to life on its own, almost independently of the creator. That’s often where the satisfaction comes from - surpassing your expectations and vision. The opposite is also true, and depressing. The failed painting can often take weeks or months to get over.

properties.title: JBALL

properties.artist_bio: I am an emerging artist working in Toronto. I studied Theatre at the University of Ottawa before completing a Bachelor of Design in Illustration at OCAD University. I create images that exist on paper, walls, objects, spaces, and stages. I am interested in using imagery as an opportunity to explore the world, the environment and social issues. I want the public art that I make to be bright and colourful, something that might attract someone's attention as they walk by. I like to create dense images where flat colourful shapes fill the entire wall/object, which can deter graffiti but also can allow for the viewer to notice something new after repeated viewings. In recent projects “Night on the town” or “Canoe with wildlife” (attached below), I tried to connect the imagery to something interesting about the area: the former is a reference to jazz clubs that used to exist in the east side of toronto, and the latter is a tribute the canoe butterfly gardens that can be found in parks throughout the city. I draw people with a looseness in their form, joyously moving and interacting. I would love to be involved with START and create more community engaged art and collaborate with other artists. I am interested in creating images for different spaces and it is a goal of mine to create work in different cities in Canada and internationally.

properties.artist_bio: Stephanie Bellefleur is a Contemporary Visual Artist who was born in Venezuela, South America, Stephanie’s work incorporates bold colours with strong graphic lines. Stephanie has created a contemporary style that embodies both elegance and grit. She has been hired to create for Municipalities, Non Profits, and Corporate Businesses such as Street Art Toronto, Facebook, Skechers, Vancouver BIA, Mississauga Living Arts Centre, Daniel Spectrum, the University of Toronto and Baycrest Foundations Brain Project.Her most relevant high impact projects include contributing to the 8 story Phlegm mural at Yonge and St.Clair, Most recently, Stephanie contributed to the unique 23 story “Equilibrium Mural” alongside International Muralist-Okuda San Miguel. Stephanie has experience as an Arts administrator and Production coordinator for award winning Public Arts Organizations. She is a champion of social innovation and all things inclusive, Stephanie is humbled to serve the public in order to progress a spectrum of unity and colour.

properties.artist_bio:
Yasaman Mehrsa is a visual artist, graphic designer and photographer living and working in Toronto. Born and raised in Tehran/Iran, Yasaman’s love of art began as a child and further Shaped by her studies at Brock University in Visual Arts, and Visual Communication and Graphic Design from Iran. Her unique art works are mainly influenced by nature.
Striving to create work that is distinctive, engaging and above all, memorable, she conveys a story or invokes a certain emotion in each of her works. She believes art is one of the purest forms of communication. In addition to painting and design she contributes to public and street art as well. Her goal is to be more engaged in beautifying city and involving in the community.
----------------------------------------------------------------
I’m passionate about creativity. When I start to create a piece of art, my mind and body become united and empowered in the process of making! Nature is my inspiration. Usually I spend some time in nature , taking some photos ( I do professional photography as well) and I try to incorporate what I see in my paintings but not in a realistic way. I get inspired by forms, colours or even sounds. I transfer my feeling and emotion into the painting surface; It’s my way of story telling.

I would like to be involved with StART because with my background in creativity and art, I see myself growing in public art and I want to put any effort to be engage in communities. I love to do art for people and see them enjoy their environments. In my opinion, Art is communication; it allows people from different cultures and different times to communicate with each other via images, sounds and stories. My responsibility as an artist is to be engage in my society and help people to get more connected with each other and their environment.
I want to do bigger projects and experience different platforms. I’m interested in both individual projects and team projects.
properties.description: The design aims to share a colourful scene with Toronto residents to wake them up, inspire them, motivates them, make them think, or maybe help them enjoy their surrounding for even couple of seconds.
properties.title: Yasaman Mehrsa

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio:
Early on, I perceived that my ambition was the act of painting itself, finding that the process coincided with the workings of my conscious and unconscious mind.Throughout my career I have also been fascinated by realism, specifically trompe l’oeil and it’s ability to affect the viewer. I have been creating trompe l’oeil murals in combination with my abstract works for over 20 years now. It has become for me a way to connect with the viewer on several different levels. I have discovered that painting illusions allows me to communicate with a larger audience, as people genuinely delighted when visually tricked. While both painting techniques claim to express reality truthfully, either suggests only a partial or incomplete view of a subject.
I am also extremely interested in the archival quality of work and how public art is produced, in an ethical and archival way. I have painted murals that are still on display over 20 years later. I feel that viewers of public work have an investment in the upkeep and archival quality of the work. Starting with the proper preparation, the production process should be considered when producing public art. When public art pieces become worn and decay after only a few seasons the public does not see the value in continuing to fund public art. Having worked for several years of trial and error I feel that I could offer proper preparation advice to many of the public art projects.

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

properties.artist_bio: Katherine is an artist and graphic designer living in Toronto. She holds a Bachelor of Design from OCAD University. Outside of her design practice, she creates physical manifestations of her design work. Often working with the bright colours inherent in mass produced materials, she creates simple works which comment on obsession, compulsion, spectacle, and the translation between the digital and physical world.Katherine currently works at a design studio called RallyRally where she has submitted and been part of the ideation and creation of 2 previous Outside the Box murals. She also had the opportunity to be part of the Concrete Barrier Art Program last fall.

properties.artist_bio:
MONICA WICKELER
As a trained visual artist who has worked in the large scale painting industry in Toronto for many years, in outdoor advertising as a mural artist and in the film and television industry as a scenic artist, Monica Wickeler has found a love of community and public art. As well as painting community murals in playgrounds, on wading pools and in pedestrian laneways, she has recently enjoyed working with students to inspire them to approach large scale paintings in their own community and taking ownership and pride in who they are and in their neighborhoods.
ARTISTIC STATEMENT
I have always been inspired by the newest STREET/PUBLIC artist projects around the world. When I start a project my sketches will often be uploaded and worked on digitally to see how my ideas respond to the space it will be painted on I can digitally mock up and idea and can easily share it with the client. Once at the wall producing the work, that amazing feeling of working in the public eye kicks in and the getting feedback from pedestrians is always an inspiration. Recently I have been using a combination of brushwork and aerosol painting techniques and I am thrilled with the vibrancy of color and effects produced. Finding the connection between the visual landscape and the images the community connects with is my biggest goal during my design process.

properties.artist_bio:
For the last three years, I've had the fortune to be part of various StART projects and it is truly inspiring for me as a street artist to see the support from the city towards this art form. I'd love to continue working with StART and be part of this art movement!
Bio: My artistic work is the result of my experiences living and working in various parts of Latin America. The rich and vibrant cultures of the places I’ve visited have been my main inspiration to create and share my artistic vision with others. As a Canadian-Colombian artist is empowering for me to paint around the themes of culture, nature, and identity enriching Canadian multiculturalism. Most of my murals are found in Canada and Colombia, my wish is to continue painting across Canada and the world.

properties.address: Lake Shore Blvd W & First St
properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Toronto, I am a champion of this city. My work often depicts Toronto life - people, events and elements connected to the region. I have witnessed many changes and struggles in neighborhoods throughout the city and have contributed to developing community strength through several art projects.
I choose to create art that can be seen and appreciated by the public, free and accessible to anyone - bringing beauty to dingy, neglected areas of town. I enjoy working with communities to engage them in the process of change, establish personal connections and develop a sense of pride in their neighborhood.
My goal is to work on a larger scale projects with StART. I would like to be mentored/assisted in the use of aerosol painting as well as high murals requiring a lift. Working with StART, I would love to work with an Indigenous artist/group on a co-operative project to learn, exchange information and cultural practices. Indigenous art including Woodland style, Inuit sculpture, drawing and printmaking, are my favourite styles of art.
My artwork also addresses environmental concerns/issues; reminding us that everything has a purpose, even when it is not clear to us, what that is. I often find inspiration in ecology, the environment and site-specific surroundings the mural will be in. Figures, the body, and movement are recurring themes in my art.
As well as being a painter, I have been a professional photographer for over 25 years, creating images digitally as well as on film. Previously, I was the Resident Photography Artist at Mississauga Living Art Centre. While working at the TDSB, I was honoured to photograph Nelson Mandela on his first visit to Toronto. I collaborated with teachers and students on several art projects including a handmade book given to Mr. Mandela.
I am experienced in photographing events, fine art documentation, portraits, dance and theatre, products, buildings, magazine and commercial work. I also create digital designs including Op Art, tile patterns, floral, abstract; web design, preparing/repurposing images for web, email and print.
Materials and mediums I work with include photography, acrylic and latex paint, acrylic markers, aerosol paint, clay, wood and collage.

I have graduated from 3 art programs: Central Technical School Adult Art Program, Ryerson Still Photography and Humber College Audio/Visual Technology. As a multidisciplinary artist, my unique combination of art and technology skills brings strength of understanding to all my projects. Working as a full-time artist and art educator, I teach painting, drawing, ceramics, mixed media and photography throughout the GTA, to seniors, adults and children.

properties.artist_bio: Dave is a self-taught artist whose practice has developed from 2-dimensional drawing to stain glass to 3-dimensional sculpture. His drawings are inspired by nature & insects. Animals & plants can all be found in the repetitive detail in his artworks. His use of the mandala evolved as he became more interested in the fractal mathematical structure of his drawings.  His most important work to-date was produced over an 18-year period. Dave has been a proud Brain Artist over the past two years. 2020 bring his third exhibition at Toronto’s Artist Project and he will spend the month of November at an artist residency at the Chateau Orquevaux, France.

properties.title: Dave Bagley (the bagman)

properties.artist_bio: ‘Elicser’ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.

properties.artist_bio:
I am from Neyaashiinigmiing Chippewas of Nawash Unceded First Nations and the Delaware Nation at Moraviantown. I have an eclectic range of interests and experiences from which to draw inspiration; a love of creativity in all its forms; a love of culture and the similarities/differences between us all, which makes this world so beautiful.I am inspired by pen & ink fairy tale illustrations, the female form & nature motifs of art nouveau and art deco, the connection of spirit between us and nature of indigenous art, the images/icons/emblems of indigenous culture, and depicting my emotions relating to family/history/current affairs. My favourite medium is dipped pen and ink, especially blue ink: blue like at twilight a time of transition, blue like the water which is women's privilege to cherish and protect.
    I am known for my blue dipped pen & ink drawings which incorporate science, history, current affairs, empathy and
gracefulness with beautiful female figures in my unique style I call N8V (native) Nouveau. In the past couple of years, I have painted 7 murals ranging in size from 5' x 8' up to 19' x 50'. One of these murals is a RECLAMATION of Indigenous Science in acrylic paint. Indigenous Science and the discoveries we use every day, but which are thought of as "Western Scientific Ingenuity”. The chemical structures and formulas in the background are pre-contact scientific knowledge commonly used by the many indigenous peoples of the Western Hemisphere, the people of the Condor and the Eagle. One of the three murals I have at the Bickford Center is a female empowering mural about the Three Sisters companion planting practice of the Haudenosaunee. Three beautiful strong sisters who support, protect and nurture each other for the benefit of the Haudenosaunee people.
   I have taken on the duty to represent our indigenous culture in a contemporary context. My artistic styles will create a mural that is very much a part of present-day life, imbued with indigenous knowledge of environmental responsibility, holistic wellness, a place of community and family with a shared future for all.

properties.artist_bio:
Early on, I perceived that my ambition was the act of painting itself, finding that the process coincided with the workings of my conscious and unconscious mind.Throughout my career I have also been fascinated by realism, specifically trompe l’oeil and it’s ability to affect the viewer. I have been creating trompe l’oeil murals in combination with my abstract works for over 20 years now. It has become for me a way to connect with the viewer on several different levels. I have discovered that painting illusions allows me to communicate with a larger audience, as people genuinely delighted when visually tricked. While both painting techniques claim to express reality truthfully, either suggests only a partial or incomplete view of a subject.
I am also extremely interested in the archival quality of work and how public art is produced, in an ethical and archival way. I have painted murals that are still on display over 20 years later. I feel that viewers of public work have an investment in the upkeep and archival quality of the work. Starting with the proper preparation, the production process should be considered when producing public art. When public art pieces become worn and decay after only a few seasons the public does not see the value in continuing to fund public art. Having worked for several years of trial and error I feel that I could offer proper preparation advice to many of the public art projects.

properties.address: Kay Gardiner Beltline Trail & Yonge Street
properties.description: 'The Iron Horse' features 12 life size silhouettes of horses which draw attention to the 19th Century defunct railroad bridge on which they stand. When steam locomotive first appeared, it was commonly referred to as 'The Iron Horse'. Just as horses were replaced by trains, the rail bridge is no longer used for its original intent. The silhouetted horses and the bridge, an artifact from our industrial heritage, are surrounded by more modern forms of transportation with Yonge St below and the subway to the west. Originally installed in 1994, the new sculpture is made of 90% recycled fibreglass materials. A solar-powered LED lighting system will soon illuminate the horses and the pedestrian pathway and make the silhouettes more visible at night.  Photos by Tyler Radell.
properties.organizations: City of Toronto & Midtown Yonge BIA
properties.title: Robert Sprachman

properties.artist_bio:
ARTIST STATEMENT
In my public work, my aim is to create a connection between art and its environment. I look for themes or visuals alive in the neighbourhood and try to continue the conversation. Finally, I explore opportunities to inject illusion or magic. The result is a backdrop that honours the beauty of urban life.

This summer I will complete Muralroutes' Mural Art Career Development programme. I'm eager to paint more murals and further incorporate painting into my practice. I gravitate particularly towards public work for its accessibility and power to interact directly with its environment. Coming from a commercial background, I also appreciate the possibilities to intersect both cultural and commercial spaces.

I'm excited to work with StART on projects that bring our city to life.

BIO
Nuff has a hard time colouring inside the lines. He makes apps, brand identities and installations. His independent practice spans commerce and culture, across client, self-driven and public projects. He is a member of Ryerson University's Design Fabrication Zone and the 2018-19 Akin Studio Program at the Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA) Toronto.

properties.artist_bio:
I want to work with StART because the projects I have completed with Street Art Toronto's help have been not only the most enjoyable projects I have worked on in my career, but also the most lucrative for me, in terms of both payment and scale of exposure. I learn something new on every project we do together and working with StART staff has taught me virtually everything I know about what goes into publicly-funded street art projects, all the moving parts that need to be accounted for, communicating with the public, coordinating materials and other artists, publicity, etc. I want to keep building on this knowledge and skill set as we continue to spread colourful mural projects into new parts of the city/GTA.

Bio:
Nick Sweetman is a multidisciplinary artist from Toronto whose practice has explored painting and its intersection with photography, video, installation, mixed media, and urban intervention. He has exhibited in galleries around Toronto since 2011, completing his MFA in 2014 from OCAD University in the Interdisciplinary Art, Media & Design program. He received a certificate from the Mural Routes Leadership Training in Mural-Making program the same year and since then has been working in public space on mural projects, often in collaboration with other artists, and in partnership with various non-profit organizations (David Suzuki Foundation, The STEPS Initiative) as well as Street Art Toronto. He has successfully managed many large-scale projects both independently and as lead artist over a team of volunteers, from children up to adults. He has dedicated many projects to raising awareness about the importance of pollinators, bees and butterflies in particular, from painting giant bees towering over busy city streets to coordinating 30 or more artists to paint butterflies on garages in Toronto's laneways. Most recently, Nick has been working abroad, participating in the Eureka Street Art Festival in Humboldt County, California as well as contributing a mural to the Bondi Beach Sea Wall in Sydney, Australia.

properties.artist_bio:
I am a Filipnx 26-year-old multidisciplinary Scarborough-based artist. Inspired by indigenous Filipinx art, abstract contemporary art and graffiti, my work is both cathartic and shares the narrative of Filipinx and POC identities facing diaspora and poverty in urban areas, encouraging viewers to tap into their ancestral energies and power.

I love to combine many elements in my work, mediums , styles and tools to create. I feel the more mediums , styles and tools create more infinite forms and and ever lasting growing process.

Through these practices, he has established a signature style of his own called, 'Ancient Graffuturism'.
In this he combines elements of abstract art,Manga,international Architecture, Calligraphy, Graffiti & Ancient Filipino Design Inspired Images & Symbols.
Being a Diaspora, Rowell likes to blend his asian heritage into his work to feel more connected with himself.


I want to work with StART because I Share a common Thread with the organization which is to create and protect communities and businesses. I do this for a living so If I can join forces with the organization we could become more of a powerful positive force and spread love through mural art. I would like to learn from StART anything that comes with mural making, Mural planning, community engagement, outreach. I know a little bit about each element but there will always be more to learn. I am good at working with people. I have colloborated many times in the city and internationally on Murals. I am open to learning and working with new people in StART . I feel there is so much that Artists, StART's Organization have to offer and looking forward to seeing what stART has in store.

properties.artist_bio: Amir Akbari is a Greater Toronto Area (GTA) based Visual Artist, Educator, Community Advocate and Entrepreneur.   In 2002, he enrolled in OCAD University where he would go on to complete a Bachelors of Fine Arts with a focus on Drawing and Painting.  In 2003, Amir led his first community mural art project working with Urban Art Toronto.  The following year, he took on his first role with Street Art (then Graffiti Transformation Project) as the lead artist with Lamp Community Health Centre.  That project would be a launching pad for his eventual artistic and professional career.From 2003 to 2010 Amir continued to work with various community organizations and charities as an artist facilitator, youth works and educator.  He would go onto complete over 30 public murals throughout this time, working with and mentoring hundreds of youth across the GTA.In 2010 Amir founded Behind the Line with the purpose of providing existing support structures within the community with creative and artistic support.  Behind the Line has since worked closely with multiple organizations to enhance their arts programming and creative reach, from curriculum development, programming consultation and arts integration strategies.In the summer of 2019, Amir completed his largest mural production, the Susan Street Mural at 3847 Lawrence Ave. East.  This would be his 6th Street Art Partnership Project with the Boys & Girls Club of East Scarborough and his 3rd partnership with Toronto Community Housing.  The large 14 story mural is the crowning achievement of his artistic journey as a community and mural artist.  Focused on creating designs that reflect, represent and inspire the communities that he is working with, this mural is a celebration of the collaborative and uplifting nature of public murals funded by Street Art Toronto.His work is rooted in the belief that self-expression can have a lasting impact on the development and growth of young people and their communities, and that there is a disproportional disadvantage across the board for those that face multiple barriers with accessing the arts.   He hopes to fill this void through innovative arts strategies, collaborative mural projects and local community partnerships.
properties.description: The mural honours and represents all the women and caregivers in the community who work hard to support and maintain a healthy community where children have opportunities to grow and thrive.
properties.title: Amir Akbari

properties.address: Finch Avenue West between Islington Ave and Kipling Ave
properties.artist_bio: Through his artistic journey Rob Matejka has embraced art as a medium for positive social intervention and enjoys animating the communities and people he works with - making art accessible to all through; workshops, mentoring, and adding to the growing outdoor public gallery. Rob has been an arts educator and mentor for over 12 years - having worked with organizations across Toronto such as; Lakeshore Arts, Mural Routes, TDSB, The Toronto Public Library, VIBE Arts, and more. Rob enjoys using murals to create spaces we enter and experience physically - while coordinating large scale projects engaging large numbers of community members to beautify communities and build community pride.
properties.description: Arts Etobicoke, in partnership with Mural Routes, The STEPS Initiative and Womxn Paint, presented Augmented Representations: The North Etobicoke Mural Project. Spanning 576 feet along Finch Avenue West between Kipling and Islington, the series of murals weave together images inspired by Indigenous narratives, personal experiences of local residents and the landscape of the Humber River into a collection of meaningful and vibrant public artworks.
properties.organizations: Arts Etobicoke, Mural Routes, STEPS Initiative, Womxn Paint
properties.title: g

properties.artist_bio:
Working with StArt and seeing the positive impact it has on neighbourhoods, people and the development of artists is inspiring and makes me proud to be a part of.

Canadian graffiti artist Alexander Bacon began painting in the 90’s as a teenager.  He is best known for his colourful works lining the alleys and streets of Toronto and achieved international recognition.  Bacon describes the art form as being passed down from one generation to the next.
His work has evolved to deconstructing traditional graffiti spray paint techniques to create an abstract graffiti style while maintaining letter form.  His use of a mature colour pallet and mixing of realism with the stylized graffiti fonts gives his work a unique look with smooth transitions and texture.
Most recently Bacon has been doing large scale murals and Canvas work while maintaining the disciplines of graffiti.  His work can be seen all over Toronto.
properties.description: A large scale mural in the heart of the entertainment district. The mural depicts dancers and a musician of various cultures. A celebration of culture and art.
properties.title: Bacon

properties.artist_bio:
Jacquie Comrie is a Toronto- base, multidisciplinary artist whose vibrant body of work intersects contemporary art and wellness at a global scale, using colour as a medium of social impact and mental health.

 Whether as murals on buildings, large scale structures, or canvases, her body of work is a dynamic exploration of the science of colour as the universal language of human emotion, producing works in Canada and internationally.  Colour has been proven to have a direct effect to human emotion, for which her palettes are consciously designed and orchestrated aiming to cater to mental wellbeing at large.

In such divisive times, and with mental health issues on the rise across the globe, her work aims to contribute to much needed spaces of mental elevation and reset,  to ultimately help improve quality of life of all individuals- one wall at a time.
properties.description: Through colour as the science  of human emotion and tool of social change, this mural is a homage to the idea of ALL COLOURS AS EQUAL, celebrating the spectrum of colour that is our human kind.
properties.title: Jacquie Comrie

properties.artist_bio:
Leyland Adams is mural artist with a love for graffiti, illustration and community building through art. Leyland completed his
Advanced Diploma in Visual Creative Arts at Sheridan College in 2014. Since then he has travelled across the country and the globe to create large scale murals and create art on shoes. He is a creative entrepreneur who lives to empower and inspire his community through innovative art and collaboration.
properties.description: Together, we co-created a dynamic mural in collaboration with students with a message of hope, respect, diversity, and community.
properties.medium: Acrylic Paint, Latex Paint, Spray Paint
