properties.artist_bio:
MONICA WICKELER
As a trained visual artist who has worked in the large scale painting industry in Toronto for many years, in outdoor advertising as a mural artist and in the film and television industry as a scenic artist, Monica Wickeler has found a love of community and public art. As well as painting community murals in playgrounds, on wading pools and in pedestrian laneways, she has recently enjoyed working with students to inspire them to approach large scale paintings in their own community and taking ownership and pride in who they are and in their neighborhoods.
ARTISTIC STATEMENT
I have always been inspired by the newest STREET/PUBLIC artist projects around the world. When I start a project my sketches will often be uploaded and worked on digitally to see how my ideas respond to the space it will be painted on I can digitally mock up and idea and can easily share it with the client. Once at the wall producing the work, that amazing feeling of working in the public eye kicks in and the getting feedback from pedestrians is always an inspiration. Recently I have been using a combination of brushwork and aerosol painting techniques and I am thrilled with the vibrancy of color and effects produced. Finding the connection between the visual landscape and the images the community connects with is my biggest goal during my design process.
properties.description: Re-Collect is an intergenerational project onsite at Fudger House Long Term Care Home which brought together local youth from St. James Town and the senior residents. This community shared their stories through visual arts in a series of workshops and artwork from the workshops has been incorporated into the beautiful outdoor murals.
properties.title: Monica Wickeler

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.description: INTEROH GALE combines to mean “a gateway to a sustainable future by using renewable resources, such as wind.” The artwork illustrates the complex balance of preserving green space while continuing to develop industry and expand urban growth by painting elements of nature and symbols of renewable energy sources amongst a futuristic looking, abstract backdrop.
properties.medium: Acrylic Paint, Latex Paint, Spray Paint
properties.title: Evond Blake

properties.artist_bio: Paula Gonzalez-Ossa is a mural artist who has been working with diverse communities producing street level public art, both in Canada and Latin America for over 25 years. Her ongoing work with StARToronto dates back to 2015. Her murals, like the most recent 500 ft. mural titled "Our Medicines"  located at the underpass at Dupont and Shaw, or "The Ancestral Tree Spirits" located at the Nordheimer Ravine's TTC station exit, depict a colourful  First Nations cosmovision in relation to the Original lands of Ontario, working closely with Anishnawbe  mentors, Elders and Knowledge Keepers. Gonzalez-Ossa is currently  the Indigenous Education Officer at the AGO’s Weston Learning Centre, as part of the Public Programming and Learning Department, and the Visual Arts instructor and mentoring artist at Na Me Res Sagatay Native Men's Residence. She brings 19 years experience as a  Community Youth Worker with youth at risk in Toronto's West.Some of her previous public works include: a 120 foot mural honoring First Nations from North and South America,  which was the recipient of  the 2014 Ward 27 City Builder’s Award, formerly at Allan Gardens. Other locations sport a ribbon-style mural at Women’s Residence, a women’s shelter at Dundas and Bathurst, in collaborations with an all women crew (2015), and a 4 wall rendition of the Medicine Wheel, inside of Na Me Res Sagatay’s courtyard (2016).  In sharp contrast she produced an indoor mural with 22 students from grades 6-8 at refugee host school Beverley Heights Middle School (2017).She recently served in the capacity of Resident Artist at the Power Plant gallery, developing mural arts programs at two satellite locations with youth from priority neighbouroods in Toronto’s West.(2017-2018). In 2018-2019 she worked closely with the 7Th Generation Image Makers at the Native Youth Resource Centre to mentor, facilitate and produce a mural with an all Indigenous women’s team, located  at the South facing wall at Christie Pits Park’s Alex Duff Memorial Pool. Her two most recent productions  funded by StART’s Partnership Grant in 2019,located at the front façade of Sagatay Naïve Men’s Residence, and the adjacent alley,  depict  “Medicines and Guardians”, as well as “The Wolves Running South”.Last but not least, Gonzalez-Ossa is one of the featured artists at the “You’ve Changed “ exhibit by STARToronto , at St Lawrence Market’s  “Market Gallery”. At the exhibit, the video display shows us her latest short documentary produced  for SART, about the basic protocols entailed when developing images in partnership with Indigenous Nations here in Canada.Gonzalez-Ossa  has been  voted Best Graffiti Artist for the City of Toronto by Now Magazine’s Reader’s Poll in 1997, in 2009, 2010, and 2011. In addition, she has been featured on  CBC (Radio and Television, varying shows), Much Music, MTV, Global Televison, City TV, TVO, CTV, Bell Fibe TV1, Rogers Television, and Telelatino, as well as various television  appearances in Chile, USA (NYC/California), and Jamaica.
properties.description: This project draws from the visual information found in the 4 directions of our planet, as per the Anishnaabe Medicine Wheel, is meant to primarily create a colourful landscape that mixes historic natural knowledge and modern, abstract use of colour and composition.
properties.title: Paula Gonzalez

properties.artist_bio:
I want to work with StART because the projects I have completed with Street Art Toronto's help have been not only the most enjoyable projects I have worked on in my career, but also the most lucrative for me, in terms of both payment and scale of exposure. I learn something new on every project we do together and working with StART staff has taught me virtually everything I know about what goes into publicly-funded street art projects, all the moving parts that need to be accounted for, communicating with the public, coordinating materials and other artists, publicity, etc. I want to keep building on this knowledge and skill set as we continue to spread colourful mural projects into new parts of the city/GTA.

He has exhibited in galleries around Toronto since 2011, completing his MFA in 2014 from OCAD University in the Interdisciplinary Art, Media & Design program. He received a certificate from the Mural Routes Leadership Training in Mural-Making program the same year and since then has been working in public space on mural projects, often in collaboration with other artists, and in partnership with various non-profit organizations (David Suzuki Foundation, The STEPS Initiative) as well as Street Art Toronto. He has successfully managed many large-scale projects both independently and as lead artist over a team of volunteers, from children up to adults. He has dedicated many projects to raising awareness about the importance of pollinators, bees and butterflies in particular, from painting giant bees towering over busy city streets to coordinating 30 or more artists to paint butterflies on garages in Toronto's laneways. properties.description: In partnership with StART, David Suzuki Foundation, and Dallington Public School a large-scale mural was painted on the south side of school with a theme of pollinators and biodiversity, to recognize and celebrate the work being done to improve the lives of local pollinators.
properties.title: Nick Sweetman

properties.artist_bio:
Peru is an internationally recognized muralist and graphic artist whose practice is informed by digital and traditional art forms and his 20+ years of painting graffiti. Peru’s professional career started when he moved from Lima to Ottawa at 16; he won every Visual Arts Award in his high school, a Canadian Heritage grant to paint a mural in Vancouver for the International Earth Festival, and a 2 mural commission for the National Capital Commission. At age 20 he moved to Montreal where he continued winning prizes and awards from design contests at his local skateshop to the Millennium Excellence Scholarship.

His passion for art lead him to rise to the top of the local art scene working for brands and companies such as Bell, Cirque du Soleil and he painted a series of murals with the collective En Masse at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. With En Masse, Peru was part of dozens of collaborative murals throughout Canada, US, Mexico and China, and participated in mentorship programs with the Quebec English School Boards Association. He was also a central muralist for MU since its inception in 2007 and continues to work with them, most recently in 2020 where he will be painting the exterior of a high school.

When Peru moved to Toronto a decade later he worked for Urban Outfitters for 5 years as a Lead Display Artist. In this role he built and installed window and store displays participating in store openings across North America including the company’s largest store opening at Herald Square in New York City. Peru used these experiences to expand his skill set and work on art installations at the Osheaga Music Festival as well for American Express for their Live Life Experience Installations around the world; All the while establishing himself as a muralist by assisting, collaborating, and consulting for nearly every arts organization in Toronto, and mentoring individuals, peers and on several occasions’ at-risk youth from the Oasis Skateboard Factory. Peru’s corporate and big brand murals allowed him to balance his work with grass-roots organizations, non-for-profits and BIA’s which make up most of his portfolio. Some of Peru’s corporate clients include Facebook, Nike, Adidas, Corus, Maple Leaf Sports, and Marriott Hotels., Working with StArt and seeing the positive impact it has on neighbourhoods, people and the development of artists is inspiring and makes me proud to be a part of.

Canadian graffiti artist Alexander Bacon began painting in the 90’s as a teenager.  He is best known for his colourful works lining the alleys and streets of Toronto and achieved international recognition.  Bacon describes the art form as being passed down from one generation to the next.
His work has evolved to deconstructing traditional graffiti spray paint techniques to create an abstract graffiti style while maintaining letter form.  His use of a mature colour pallet and mixing of realism with the stylized graffiti fonts gives his work a unique look with smooth transitions and texture.
Most recently Bacon has been doing large scale murals and Canvas work while maintaining the disciplines of graffiti.  His work can be seen all over Toronto.
properties.description: With Blueprint I wanted to create something uplifting that would beautify an artistically neglected area of town, but also improve the daily lives of residents, delivery people and visitors. Blueprint aims to inspire and visually enrich the community of Caledonia-Fairbank. I also hope that it can help to soothe spirits worn down by the daily grind of modern life.
properties.title: Peru 143, Bacon, Fats Patrol

properties.artist_bio:
I am from Neyaashiinigmiing Chippewas of Nawash Unceded First Nations and the Delaware Nation at Moraviantown. I have an eclectic range of interests and experiences from which to draw inspiration; a love of creativity in all its forms; a love of culture and the similarities/differences between us all, which makes this world so beautiful.I am inspired by pen & ink fairy tale illustrations, the female form & nature motifs of art nouveau and art deco, the connection of spirit between us and nature of indigenous art, the images/icons/emblems of indigenous culture, and depicting my emotions relating to family/history/current affairs. My favourite medium is dipped pen and ink, especially blue ink: blue like at twilight a time of transition, blue like the water which is women's privilege to cherish and protect.
    I am known for my blue dipped pen & ink drawings which incorporate science, history, current affairs, empathy and
gracefulness with beautiful female figures in my unique style I call N8V (native) Nouveau. In the past couple of years, I have painted 7 murals ranging in size from 5' x 8' up to 19' x 50'. One of these murals is a RECLAMATION of Indigenous Science in acrylic paint. Indigenous Science and the discoveries we use every day, but which are thought of as "Western Scientific Ingenuity”. The chemical structures and formulas in the background are pre-contact scientific knowledge commonly used by the many indigenous peoples of the Western Hemisphere, the people of the Condor and the Eagle. One of the three murals I have at the Bickford Center is a female empowering mural about the Three Sisters companion planting practice of the Haudenosaunee. Three beautiful strong sisters who support, protect and nurture each other for the benefit of the Haudenosaunee people.
   I have taken on the duty to represent our indigenous culture in a contemporary context. My artistic styles will create a mural that is very much a part of present-day life, imbued with indigenous knowledge of environmental responsibility, holistic wellness, a place of community and family with a shared future for all.
properties.description: The Indigenous Murals project at Bickford Centre achieved 12 new murals painted by artists that came together under the banner RUN - Red Urban Nation Arts Collective, with a focus on cultural celebration and reclamation. Traditional teachings, food, plants and medicines are an important theme of all the murals. 'Plants As Medicine' was a guiding statement and each artist branched out with their own creativity from that starting point.
properties.organizations: RUN Red Urban Nation Art Collective
properties.title: Johl Whiteduck Ringuette, Keitha Keeshig-Tobias

properties.address: Bloor Street West & St. Helens Avenue
properties.description: The theme of this mural surrounds the City of Toronto’s motto: Diversity our Strength. The location and neighborhoods that border this underpass illustrate the diversity of the city and the mural highlights the communities found in Portugal, Italy, Latin America, Pakistan & Sri Lanka through abstract design.
properties.title: Spud, Brad Longmore, Lianken Breau

properties.artist_bio:
Sean Martindale is an internationally recognized, award winning interdisciplinary artist and designer based in Toronto, Canada. His interventions activate public spaces to encourage engagement, and often focus on ecological and social issues. His playful works suggest alternate possibilities for existing spaces, infrastructures, and materials found in urban environments. Frequently, he uses salvaged goods in unexpected ways that prompt conversation.

Among other notable projects, he was the lead artist on the Community Rising, the tallest mural in the world from 2013 to 2018 (now the second tallest), the result of a community project in St James Town, Toronto, with local youth, STEPS and the Toronto Muralists. Martindale has been the lead artist for a number of the GTA’s largest mural projects. He continues to work closely with communities and organizations big and small; including partners such as Harbourfront Centre, the Art Gallery of Ontario, and the City of Toronto.

Martindale holds an MFA from the Interdisciplinary Masters of Art, Media and Design program at OCAD University in Toronto, and a BDes in Communication Design from Emily Carr University in Vancouver. He was the Decennial Hancock Lecturer at the University of Toronto’s Hart House, where his presentation was broadcast by TVO for their Big Ideas series. He is a recipient of the prestigious Artist Prize from Toronto Friends of the Visual Arts, numerous grants at municipal, provincial, and federal levels, and a Chalmers Arts Fellowship from the Ontario Arts Council. Martindale was profiled for the first episode of CBC’s Great Minds of Design, and his works have been featured digitally and published in traditional media around the world in multiple languages. His works have been exhibited publicly in many cities across the globe.

Recently, Martindale was Harbourfront Centre’s inaugural Visual Artist-in-Residence, and alongside his collaborator JP King, was also the first Artist-in-Residence with the City of Toronto, Solid Waste Management Services.

-------------

•	While I continue to be interested in traditional mural forms, I am also excited to keep exploring other media/materials in the public realm, spearhead new practices, and explore diverse approaches to community engagement. As well, I am interested in potentially growing other areas of my practice, and taking on more roles in related areas such as project coordination, program development, and consulting.
properties.description: Artist Sean Martindale and supporting artists worked with inspiration from the local community to design an artwork that integrated connective themes into the final mural design.

properties.artist_bio: Andre is a Mexican born artist, who immigrated to Canada in 2006. Since coming to Toronto he’s been creating intricate psychedelic artwork featuring animal and human subjects juxtaposed with abstract form. His paintings have been used for custom clothing design and his illustrations for band posters and psychedelic trance music events. As of 2012 Andre has been focused on murals and street art, working on wall art for private businesses and city sponsored projects.In his work Andre explores the use of bold colour, geometric shapes, space landscapes and his special interest in architectural and industrial design. Andre feels there’s an incredible necessity to self-express through art and equal need to inspire emerging artists to create and feel free to self-express themselves in their own ways.
properties.description: “Waves” is inspired by how we communicate. Radio waves, television and the internet are satellites transmitting information. The idea of art as a satellite is intriguing to the artist. Art broadcasts information that is universally understood, transcending cultural and language barriers. “Waves” is a visual representation  of universal connection and unity.

I want to continue co-collaborating with StART to keep growing as an artist in my skill set, practice and portfolio. With StART’s support I want to be mentored in my mural career with any opportunities to connect with seasoned mural/street artists and get on a swing-stage, aerial lift, use a spray gun, while learning to comprehend XL large walls and huge quantities of paint among advanced techniques of execution and project production. I’ve currently reached the stage of painting garages in Toronto and am interested and ready to go larger.

Bio & Artist Statement
Anya Mielniczek is a Toronto based multidisciplinary artist who combines her fine art background with raw material grit in both private and public sectors creating mixed-media installations, mural work and facilitating community art activations.
The artists approach to mediums includes latex, aerosol and up-cycled waste, working with the mechanical application of spray and the energy of hand brushed strokes (infused with powerful female portraits and garbage bits if possible).
A Queen’s University graduate, Anya’s worked with various organizations, municipalities and businesses creating public art within communities around Toronto and internationally. Recent corporate projects include lead production on HideSeek, a 7000sq foot immersive art experience in Toronto and collaborations with BACARDI, QUO Makeup, Moroccanoil, DELL, RBC, 1800GOTJUNK and Chevrolet. Her commitment to her practice especially when aligned with public spaces is to create with purpose by giving nature a voice while defining a conversation with the viewer that may inspire and bring awareness for sustainable change.

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to continue working with StART because they support the creation of art that makes our public realm a more beautiful and inviting place. StART has helped me create meaningful work that strengthens communities and enables me to develop my practice of using art as a way to build inclusive communities who celebrate their identity with pride. I would like to develop my leadership skills and am interested in mentorship opportunities where I can learn how to work more effectively with the city to realize large scale initiatives that give more artists and community members opportunities to feel empowered through the process of creating art in the public realm.

I am a Toronto based visual artist, community organizer, muralist, curator, and eternal optimist. My work is motivated by my desire to spread joy, nurture present minded living, cultivate gratitude, and foster new social interactions from a place of love and empathy. Using aerosol and acrylic paint, I work with bright colours and bold patterns to captivate people’s attention and fill them with delight and hope. I am passionate about creating art that both aesthetically and psychologically brightens the streets and work to build a community around positive living.

My belief that public art is a powerful tool for building community drives my practice. In 2017, I founded Womxn Paint, an annual street art jam that has produced 44 murals celebrating the strength and diversity of womxn. I would like to continue this initiative and grow it to include additional programming that supports the professional development of womxn artists and more opportunities for young girls to learn about mural arts. In 2016, I facilitated an intergenerational mural at Baycrest Health Sciences and would like work more with the senior community.

Over the last six years, I have created custom large-scale outdoor artworks for clients including The New Yorker, Tourism Canada, the City of Toronto, the City of Mississauga, the Consulate General of the Federal Republic of Germany in Toronto, the STEPS Initiative, Arts Etobicoke, East End Arts and private clients.

Together,
  we can build inclusive, multilingual neighbourhoods that celebrate diversity.
  Smile at your neighbours, connect with strangers. Open your hearts and
  embrace your community. By helping other people find their light, we can all

properties.artist_bio:
I would like to work with StART because I am interested in beautifying the cityscape with more public artwork. I would like to learn from and better my practices through the partnerships and opportunities that StART may be able to provide.

I am a freelance illustrator and mural painter based in Toronto. I like being outside. I like to move my body and to work with my hands. I enjoy working with people who share similar ideas and interests in food growing, environmental stewardship and getting outside. Some of the organizations I have worked with include: Greenest City, Urbane Cyclist, Mountain Equipment Co-op and Green Thumbs Growing Kids. I use bright hues and bold line work to create botanical patterns and compositions depicting moments of self-reflection.

My murals can be found across Toronto, in Indonesia, Nepal, Philippines and Hong Kong. I often collaborate with other artists–my most frequent collaborator being Andrea Manica–as well as with the Buck Teeth Girls Club.

properties.artist_bio: Colin Turner Bloom has been involved in mural oriented community building projects since 2008 when he was 16. He was first involved in the LOFT painting program out of Christie Ossington Community Center. In 2011 Colin started his own mural company called Annex Creative Services, receiving a Youth Entrepreneurship (Summer Company) award for the business. Since 2011 through the Annex Creative Services Company Colin has produced dozens of pieces of work, predominantly murals, for a variety of private homeowners as well as commercial clients including the Miles Nadal JCC and Queen’s University. Colin also painted four boxes as part of the 2013 and 2014 Outside the Box programs. More recently Colin had a large city theme mural on display at the AGO for a First Thursday event in 2016.

properties.artist_bio: Inspired by nature, I create mixed media drawings and paintings of insect portraits, insect ecology, and endangered species to motivate people to actively engage in sustainable living and to respect the little creatures that we rely on for existence.  Although I did not study art in college or university, I have been drawing and painting since I was 4. Without computers, I paint unique mixed media backgrounds with realistic paintings/drawings of insects and animals, which stir the viscera in observers and spark a desire in them to learn more about the insects and why we need them. Creating visual art is a Spiritual experience for me as I am presently reclaiming my family’s lost Indigenous genealogy from the East coast of Turtle Island. Painting animals is connecting me to ancestors I didn't know about until two years ago. I live in Toronto with my son.
properties.description:
Dragonflies are fast-flying protectors and pollinators that
  curtail the spread of malaria, yellow fever, dog heartworms, and tularemia.
  By eating mosquitoes, horse and deer flies, they reduce the use of pesticides
  that kill disease-spreading insects.  
  
    
    Front:  dragonfly preying a
  mosquito.  Fire = solar energy
  dragonfly wings rely on for rapid maneuvering.  Blue = air. 
    
    Back:  blue energy-lines present
  dragonflies as ecological signifiers of healthy & unhealthy fresh
  water.

properties.artist_bio:
MEDIAH has proved that he can execute a mural project of this scale as he has worked with the Street Art Toronto staff for over the past five years to execute 5 large-scale, landmark art murals around the City (RADI’AAL ENCOMPASS mural on the Woodbine/Gerrard bridge underpass, TERRA STRAT’AA bridge on the Leslie/Eglinton Ave underpass, Leslieville Bike Share mural, LANTERN SHELL murals on O’Connor Drive, and the wrapped DRIFT APPENDAR mural for Westbury National on Warden Ave, in Scarborough). In each case, MEDIAH has proved that he can stay on schedule and within budget. He was also invited and commissioned by a Nuit Blanche curator to create a large-scale vinyl wrap installation for the 2018 Nuit Blanche’s exhibition in Scarborough Town Centre’s subway station and worked cooperatively with all involved. This 2018 Nuit Blanche installation was a huge success. Abroad, MEDIAH has been commissioned to paint large scale art murals all over the world in locations such as; Barbados, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, Italy, Germany, South Africa, and throughout the United States of America and Canada.

With 25 years of experience, MEDIAH has become a staple and is considered a pioneer of the Canadian street art movement. ­An internationally renowned visual artist, MEDIAH is a trendsetter sparking new ideas and originality by blurring the lines between post-graffiti and dynamic abstraction. Blake’s work consists of weaving traditional street art forms with traditional painterly techniques. Heavily inspired by avionics, mechanical engineering, and schematics, the artwork glorifies and captures the essence of speed, motion, dynamism, and force to create movement on the image surface.

As an artist, MEDIAH strives to create visual content that inspires, intrigues and uplifts his audience. Blake’s past work has very rarely been vandalized or damaged due to his pedigree as an international visual artist. He has been described as ‘one of the most respected and revered graffiti artists in Canada’ by both vandals and street artists due to his extensive and prolific career painting large-scale murals, participating in solo and group art exhibitions, and creating immersive, cinematic video and animation productions.

His formal education in broadcast design, motion graphics, VFX and video post-production, combined with his past work experience (Fox soccer, Rogers Sportsnet, Rubberpixel, and Sinking Ship Entertainment) are pivotal to his production and project planning. MEDIAH is formally trained in Digital media and Visual Effects, allowing him to be able to document large-scale projects with cinema and broadcast quality video, graphics, and photography to create a polished package.
properties.description: MANDIVITE  is an original artwork by Canadian multi-disciplinary artist MEDIAH. It is inspired by dynamic abstraction and mechanical design using Canadian nature based colour tones.

properties.title: Evond Blake

properties.artist_bio:
I was born after the revolution in Iran. The idea of freedom greatly influenced my whole life not only as an artist but as a human being. I began painting at an art university. My style draws upon elements of traditional Persian painting (Persian Miniatures), the “flatness” and unique composition of which are surprisingly contemporary.
After getting my BFA, I studied Graphic Design at TM university in Tehran. Meanwhile, I started working as a freelance illustrator. Over the past 10 years I have illustrated more than 30 children’s books in Turkey and Iran and all the time I was trying to tell my story with my special language, picture language.
My works have been shown in exhibitions and book fairs in Iran, The Emirates, and South Korea but I got inspired by this idea a few years ago which is that the art that we should be doing today in the 21st century should not be just for the museum, it’s art for the street and for people in their daily lives. Also thinking about freedom and social justice in my country lead me to express what I’m feeling through my artworks on street walls so after I answered a call for submissions from Tehran City Hall I started to learn about and experience mural painting.
Since then, I’ve opened my mind and eyes to observe other mural artists' experiences. After coming to Toronto I’ve found a great number of mural artists and I’ve seen their artworks in the city. Having this great chance to learn from one of them , one of the greatest ones, Nick Sweetman as mentor through a mentorship program by Toronto Ar Council, since then I did some mural projects, trying to improve my skills and techniques an learn more and more. makes me feel so excited and enthusiastic. My style has changed from Miniature to Mural but, like my work as an illustrator, I try to use this medium's potential for telling stories.
properties.description: The work entitled Alquimia, pays homage to the power of the female mind and body, its miraculous, transformative nature, strength and resilience.

properties.artist_bio:
My name is Jeff Blackburn and I am a visual artist based in Toronto. With over a decade of experience producing projects for exhibition and clients, my multi-disciplinary techniques are versatile, but also maintain a recognizable style. Inspired by illustration, graffiti, and comic books, my work is known for its emphasis on line and texture, and its exploration of form using interpretive contour lines. Paintings are constructed by merging pop art aesthetics with contemporary urban art materials and techniques.

My work explores themes that revel in a flippant joie de vivre, yet remain lightly steeped in some measure of memento mori. The combined effect is one of playfully self-assured yet shadowed cheek. My compositions tend to centre on a central figure, giving the piece a definitive focal point from which the viewer can explore. The subjects of my work are chosen for their relevance to the project or location, or simply for their relevance to me. Visual impact in my murals is further accomplished through a vibrant and textured usage of colour. In these paintings, colour is freed from its formal descriptive function and displays energy and motion through a build up of spray and acrylic paint layers.

I want to continue working with StART as I have been creating projects with their team since year one, and I greatly appreciate the opportunities that they’ve funded and helped bring to fruition for both my peers and myself.  I am hoping to grow the scale of my work in the public realm, while simultaneously gaining the key skills necessary in developing the business side of my career. With the backing of StART I have painted 14 traffic signal boxes, participated in roughly 10 StART funded mural jams, assisted American artist Andrew Schoultz in 2012 on one of the first Partnership Program murals, and most recently assisted BirdO on the first Monumental Program wall.
properties.description: These vibrantly painted wildlife-in-a-box animals can be seen found in numerous locations around the GTA. How many have you seen?

properties.artist_bio:
I would love to continue to work with StART as I believe that art should be available to everyone and public art such as murals, makes art accessible to more people. Every time I make work for the public I learn something new; whether that’s a new painting technique or speaking to someone in the community and how the artwork affects them. Working with StART would allow me these special opportunities.

Bio
Jenn Kitagawa is an award-winning multidisciplinary illustrator and artist who grew up in the prairies and cities of Alberta, Canada. She is of Japanese descent and is 4th generation, or Yonsei. She graduated from the MacEwan University and the Alberta College of Art & Design, studying both graphic design and illustration. Shortly after receiving her Bachelors of Design, Jenn moved to New York where she interned for illustrator and artist Mike Perry and for the fashion magazine Nylon.

Jenn’s body of work- illustration, gifs, painted murals and installations, engages in a dialogue of openness and curiosity. Her creative explorations are unbounded by medium specificity- they are instead inspired by playfulness, colour, and positivity. She pushes the boundaries between art and design, blurs the lines between tangible and intangible goods and inspires wonder.

Jenn has created work for clients ranging from Facebook to Arts & Crafts Records, and had the honour of creating the album artwork for Gord Downie’s record Introduce Yerself. She has previously assisted muralist Kirsten McCrea on a community engaged mural for Telus in Scarborough, painted for the city of Toronto with the StART Project, and last year for Bell Box Mural Projects. She has also painting for the arts market Market Collective in Calgary, leading a community based paint-by-number mural and in May 2019 she painted a large interactive mural.
properties.description: Exploring line, form, colour and scale to create an abstract painting in a vibrant and bold colour palette, evoking joy and positivity. The playful composition of the artwork deconstructs and reconstructs a summer walk through a dreamy landscape of overgrown flowers and greenery.

properties.artist_bio:
I received my MD in Fine Arts, specialty Textile in Academy of Fine Arts, Sofia, Bulgaria.
I participated in multiple street art projects including garage door and traffic signal box painting, skate parks, charity actions and also took part of the Tomorrowland bridge, Belgium.
I think of my mural art as of geometric fragments, including different native worldwide folklore patterns or anamorphic elements mixed with realistic human character shapes or real life actions.
My arrangements are schematic, inviting the viewer to move into a space of thinking, inspiring to question our making of the world through design and movement images.  I rely on our desire for beauty, poetic and seduction… also not being afraid of taking it to a critical view of social, political and cultural issues.
My work subject matter tends to be inspired by the history, shape, architectural structure, location and community spirit of the wall.
I use different techniques from hand cut stencil to paint printing techniques and free hand painting, spray paint and brush.

properties.artist_bio: My name is Katrina Canedo and I am a Toronto-based freelance visual artist and live painter. I typically work with acrylic paint and digital art. However, recently I've been getting more into creating murals for commercials spaces (with spray paint and house paint) and would really love to participate and learn more from StrART projects and how the organization beautifies the city. Generally, my work is influenced by how colours and how they shape a subject can express universal stories or emotions especially applying them on portraits to elaborate on the subject's nuanced story/mood. Since my work is essentially influenced by formless colours and emotions, my process basically involves trying to form or incorporate these colours/shapes into the subject I'm reinterpreting into my style. My overall goal for getting involved with StART is to essentially learn and challenge myself in new ways to express that colourful vision.

properties.artist_bio: I'm a Toronto-based fine artist, illustrator and mural artist. I'm very inspired by the things around me, and the people in my life. I utilize a lot of different mediums into my art practice such as oils, acrylics, watercolour, ink, graphite, spray paint and exterior latex paint. I have been involved in various community-led projects, private and commercial mural commissions. The most impactful projects that I've been apart of, have led me to mentor youth artists and that has been the most rewarding part of those projects. An extension of youth mentorship, I'm also the Artist-in-Residence at Waterfront Neighbourhood Centre. I instruct Room 13, an international Studio that guides a growing network of student-run arts studios in schools and community settings globally. In the past few years, I have been apart of numerous Bell Box Murals Project throughout the city as well as START Outside the Box in 2018.

Marley Allen-Ash is an illustrator and artist working in Toronto, Canada. She uses traditional printmaking and digital media to create illustrations and explore both historical and personal narratives.  In addition to illustration, she enjoys work on murals and self publishing comics with her collective, Grab Bag Club.  She studied at OCAD University, completing a bachelor of design and majoring in illustration. Her illustration work has been recognized by American Illustration, 3x3 Magazine and Creative Quarterly. Selected Clients include The Globe and Mail, CANADALAND, Cottage Life and Lenny Letter.

I have worked with StART before, through the Lakeshore Bike Lane Murals, Concrete Barrier Art Program, and Outside the Box. I'd love to be involved in more group and individual mural projects, such as laneway mural projects or painting underpasses. I'm really open to any type of opportunity, though in the past I've worked with exterior latex paint for murals, as well as creating digital files to be printed and used as vinyl wraps.

properties.artist_bio: Mike Parsons is a professional artist living in Toronto. I work exclusively with black and white images sing a combination of comic book illustration, graffiti street art and abstract images. Thematically my artworks explore the interrelationships between man, nature and technology primarily from an urban perspective. The goal of my work is express a positive optimistic warning towards progress and society. My work is playful yet insightful in order to appeal to audiences of all ages. I focus on live painting performances and street art because I believe public artworks have the most impact an offer the best opportunity to initiate dialogue. I worked as a fully licensed street artist from 2005-2009 where I created live murals at various locations across Toronto. Since that time I have become a full time muralist working across Canada and internationally. Notable clients include Hudson’s Bay Co., Scotiabank, Converse, Dr. Martens, Waterloo University, UofT, Thyssenkrupp Canada, A.G.O. StreetARTToronto.

properties.artist_bio: Mska is a self thought artist, working primarily with acrylics, encaustics, collages, spray paint, ceramics, screen & lino printing. She decided to take muralism more serious in 2010. Her background plays a lot in her style. Mska is originally from Peru, but has been in Canada for nearly 20 years and has been taking different artistic workshops at Central Tech and Peach Berserk printing studios, she has mastered a style of her own by mixing different ways of approaching her materials to get her ART to the next level. Mska was has been collaborating with StarToronto, helping with the beautification of neighborhoods in need of an artistic facelift by painting murals over vandalized public and private properties. She has been part of several events like Wallnoize, Wall Expressions, Womxn Paint and events such as Digital Dreams, Harvest Fest, etc.
properties.description: I was looking to add a little bit of nature into our busy city streets, this time I chose the Bull-headed Shrike (Lanius bucephalus), a passerine bird of eastern Asia, this bird has a harsh grating and chattering call and will also mimic other birds.

properties.artist_bio:
MONICA WICKELER
As a trained visual artist who has worked in the large scale painting industry in Toronto for many years, in outdoor advertising as a mural artist and in the film and television industry as a scenic artist, Monica Wickeler has found a love of community and public art. As well as painting community murals in playgrounds, on wading pools and in pedestrian laneways, she has recently enjoyed working with students to inspire them to approach large scale paintings in their own community and taking ownership and pride in who they are and in their neighborhoods.
ARTISTIC STATEMENT
I have always been inspired by the newest STREET/PUBLIC artist projects around the world. When I start a project my sketches will often be uploaded and worked on digitally to see how my ideas respond to the space it will be painted on I can digitally mock up and idea and can easily share it with the client. Once at the wall producing the work, that amazing feeling of working in the public eye kicks in and the getting feedback from pedestrians is always an inspiration. Recently I have been using a combination of brushwork and aerosol painting techniques and I am thrilled with the vibrancy of color and effects produced. Finding the connection between the visual landscape and the images the community connects with is my biggest goal during my design process.

properties.artist_bio:
In all that I do, I strive to bring people together with inspiration. I have a particular interest in supporting the art experience of families and children, and I carry my creativity and desire to connect through to my teaching practice. I have experience managing, curating, and instructing Art and Art History lessons at various schools and art studios in the GTA. I have taught art curriculums for school aged children, as well as individual workshops for all ages and groups, and I teach English as a foreign language.

My projects vary, but I am always thrilled by new possibilities, forever thinking of ways to apply myself. My illustrations are often concerned with the quality of a moment - perhaps the mystery of an unknown figure or the delight of a nostalgic object. Use of soft colours, gentle line art, and figurative subject matter has often been a characteristic of my work. The projects and materials I engage with may vary greatly, as I am always open to new inspirations and chances to grow.

I hope to always be conscious of the potential my work has to inspire, represent, and encourage — particularly with young viewers. Art has a profound impact on our every days lives — it builds character, opens minds, and forges relationships. My ardent desire to contribute to the street art scene is rooted in my conviction that art is for everyone. I am profoundly grateful to those artists who transform the city (and my experience of it) with their work. As a creator, I feel I must remain aware of how I can make artwork more accessible, in part by bringing my illustrations to the streets.

Programs like StART create a vital link between artists and communities. While I am motivated to make my artwork more accessible to the public, StART makes my goals as an artist more viable when too often I am inhibited by the financial barriers of creating and distributing art independently. I am deeply appreciative of this program and I am invigorated as an artist by the opportunities StART offers each year to learn and to share.
properties.description: The Toronto skyline is against a starry swath of night, while a figure has  plucked a star from the sky. Whatever wonders or pursuits that star may represent remains a tantalizing mystery for the viewer. The portal references a sense of belonging in the whole.

properties.artist_bio:
In the summer of 2019 I painted a traffic signal box for StART outside of the Toronto Western Hospital and the response from the community concerning my artwork was phenomenal. I want to keep working with StART  in order to continue fostering neighbourhood connections and uplifting local residents with my colourful artworks. The process, from designing the artwork to applying it over one week, was throughly enjoyable and rewarding.I feel there is more to learn from engaging with the diverse communities of our city and embracing the many layers of our culture.

I work primarily with acrylic paints and spray paint to create bright, family-friendly scenes of street characters and wildlife.

My goal is to find likeminded artists and project coordinators to achieve thought provoking work for the upcoming year. My work focuses on nature and the fragile state of the environment. I paint indoor and outdoor murals with themes such as local wildlife and climate change in effort to educate and celebrate the beauty and importance of local ecosystems. I believe communities are stronger when they have a connection to the natural world that exists amidst their neighbourhood. “Knowing your neighbour” is the first step to caring and protecting them. This stewardship brings communities together. I hope to work with stART to celebrate local communities of Toronto –including the people, plants and animals.

properties.artist_bio:
Vivian Rosas is a Toronto based Latinx illustrator and designer. Since graduating from OCADU, her primary work has been in editorial illustration, as well as in the animated video sphere. Her work is created in a variety of mediums including digital and screen-printing. She seeks to explore themes of feminism, empowerment, and diversity. Play and discovery are key to her practice, especially when she gets a chance to work on a mural.

As a Latinx illustrator, I like to focus on representation and cultural diversity in my work. I strive to create imagery that expresses a sense of inclusiveness and community. I'd love to work with StART so that I can continue creating fun, bold and vibrant pieces to brighten up the city of Toronto. I want to share my vision of a diverse and eclectic city and have people to feel represented in my work. I think my modern take and designs can bring new life to the city.

properties.artist_bio:
Yasaman Mehrsa is a visual artist, graphic designer and photographer living and working in Toronto. Born and raised in Tehran/Iran, Yasaman’s love of art began as a child and further Shaped by her studies at Brock University in Visual Arts, and Visual Communication and Graphic Design from Iran. Her unique art works are mainly influenced by nature.
Striving to create work that is distinctive, engaging and above all, memorable, she conveys a story or invokes a certain emotion in each of her works. She believes art is one of the purest forms of communication. In addition to painting and design she contributes to public and street art as well. Her goal is to be more engaged in beautifying city and involving in the community.
----------------------------------------------------------------
I’m passionate about creativity. When I start to create a piece of art, my mind and body become united and empowered in the process of making! Nature is my inspiration. Usually I spend some time in nature , taking some photos ( I do professional photography as well) and I try to incorporate what I see in my paintings but not in a realistic way. I get inspired by forms, colours or even sounds. I transfer my feeling and emotion into the painting surface; It’s my way of story telling.

I would like to be involved with StART because with my background in creativity and art, I see myself growing in public art and I want to put any effort to be engage in communities. I love to do art for people and see them enjoy their environments. In my opinion, Art is communication; it allows people from different cultures and different times to communicate with each other via images, sounds and stories. My responsibility as an artist is to be engage in my society and help people to get more connected with each other and their environment.
I want to do bigger projects and experience different platforms. I’m interested in both individual projects and team projects.

properties.artist_bio: Alesha Aquino is a Filipino-Canadian artist based in Toronto, Canada. Her practice is inspired by the role that mythology plays in our daily experiences, using syncretic narratives as a tool to explore the link between spirituality, identities to higher powers and the cathartic process of creativity.Aquino dabbles in multidisciplinary mediums such as weaving, painting, sculpture, jewelry design and tattoo adornment. She has exhibited her work locally (Toronto, Canada) as well as internationally in cities such as Florence (Italy) and Manila (Philippines).

properties.artist_bio:
Enlivened by his interest in spacial structures and interconnectivity, Andre Kan's paintings serve as excitable blueprints for a possible reality. Each work depicts the artists' signature imaginative building blocks that converge and begin to build upon each other and strengthening each other towards an ever transforming space. Kan's structures are substantial and complex but not yet anchored - they float suspended in his psychological space. In this way Kan's buildings remain a playful proposition for the viewer not yet tied to a specific place or function. With his dynamic formations, Kan propels us towards an ever optimistic future where new connections and constructions have yet to materialize.

His current work investigates the architectural interpretations that respond to our ever advancing society, and suggests what 'possibility' means through self discovery. Examining what mark making and its properties mean, as well as the significance in cause and effect, is important here. Kan's psychological structures depict change and evolution of space, while also questioning the fundamental nature of being and the world that encompasses it.

Andre Kan is a Toronto based painter. Since graduating from the Ontario College of Art & Design University in 2014, he continues his creative pursuits as an Artist, Muralist, Photographer, Curator, Producer, and Musician. His paintings have been showcased throughout Canada with permanent collections in the U.S and China. His murals can also be seen internationally including London, Spain, Portugal and Taiwan.



Email: andrekanart@gmail.com
Instagram: andrekan_
Twitter: @andrekanart

properties.artist_bio:
I am a visual artist currently based in Toronto, Canada via the UK (most recently Brighton). When I still resided in Brighton I took an illustration course and began running a small screen printing service from 2013 onwards. After moving to Toronto, I studied Fine Arts and Independent Studio Practice. More recently I have been getting into mural art, and have so far worked on an interactive community mural, had designs accepted for Outside the Box and Bell Boxes which will be completed in July 2019, and am taking the Career Development program with Mural Routes.

I am very keen on becoming more involved with StART and increasing my experience with murals and public art!

Bio: My artistic work is the result of my experiences living and working in various parts of Latin America. The rich and vibrant cultures of the places I’ve visited have been my main inspiration to create and share my artistic vision with others. As a Canadian-Colombian artist is empowering for me to paint around the themes of culture, nature, and identity enriching Canadian multiculturalism. Most of my murals are found in Canada and Colombia, my wish is to continue painting across Canada and the world.

properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Iran, I moved to Canada as a teenager. I studied at OCAD University, where I gained exposure to a variety of disciplines from Fine Arts to Graphic Design & Advertising. After obtaining my Bachelor’s degree, I began working as a Visual Communications Coordinator at a large corporation. After 7 years, I decided to pursue my own art and design practice. I have since been awarded and published a number of times, had a solo exhibition and have created a number of murals around Toronto. I create colourful and whimsical paintings, digital art and GIFs that focus on life as a woman, spirituality and everyday life. I’m a shameless coffee addict and frequent the local cafes. Dancing, yoga and biking are my preferred ways of recharging.
I started my street art work since 2018 at which point I painted on a utility box for StreetARToronto and since then I have painted multiple small scale murals around Toronto for StreetART, Bell Box Murals including garage doors and concrete walls. I would like to continue expanding my street art practice and beautify the city further.

properties.artist_bio:
Jieun June Kim is a Toronto based, Korean born painter and muralist.  She has exhibited her paintings around the world since 2010 at notable galleries and events, exploring the idea of “home” as an immigrant and creating safe space.
Jieun completed the Mural Art Career Development program offered by Mural Routes in 2017 and has since worked with various arts organizations, city of Toronto as well as corporate partners such as Samsung, Up Canada, and Collective Arts Brewery.
 She is the co-founder of KJ Bit Collective who creates murals and street art events, and a member of the Mural Routes advisory committee team. She is also the recipient of the Newcomer and Refugee Artist Mentorship grant from the Toronto Arts Council (2018).

properties.artist_bio:
I am a multidisciplinary artist and designer, forever exploring on my creative journey.  By day I work as an Art Director and Graphic Designer at a creative agency downtown. And by night, (and on weekends) I transform into a Hand Letterer, Muralist, and most recently a Calligrapher. Born, raised, and living in Toronto, I have always been passionate about visual arts. With a Bachelor of Design from OCAD University, I graduated in 2013 and entered into the design world with the majority of my work being digital. Due to a strong desire to create with my hands again in the last few years, I have returned to the traditional art of drawing and painting. Bringing this handmade feel and human touch back into my work makes it that much more memorable and unique.

Outdoor painting was a curiosity I first explored a few years ago when I decided to paint a vibrant mural on my porch as an end-of-summer activity and homage to my favourite artists and art movements. The larger canvas was something different and exciting for me to force me out of my comfort zone and challenge me to paint on an imperfect surface. Bringing colour and life to my neighbourhood was also something I thoroughly enjoyed, along with the unexpected interactions with people passing by for a smile, a chat or even a compliment. Engaging with a community through the creation of an art piece was such a magical experience for me that has me hooked on murals ever since! In the past year, I have created a few indoor murals for offices, whether it was painted or created digitally as a vinyl sticker to create a statement wall.

I have been following StART for about a year, admiring all the amazing projects in our city and would love to be a part of it. I am super excited to say that my first project with StART will be next week when I paint my first utility box! I would love to learn more about the Toronto mural world and how to get involved in more projects, learning from experienced artists and helping them out. Participating in StART initiatives and being part of a larger community of artists and art lovers that are making our city a better place to live, one street art piece at a time, would be a dream! At the end of the day, I just want to create art that engages and resonates with people and what better way to do this than to contribute to this organization. Since discovering StART, I have been so motivated by the beautiful mural art, it has encouraged me to reach out to artists, explore new neighbourhoods hunting for murals, and collaborate with like-minded artists. I believe that having a community of artists support each other and create together is so important and truly inspiring. I would love to give back to my home city of Toronto and create some magic with the help of StART.

At a time when the condominium market continues to thrive, the intention is to juxtapose the city's modern buildings with these timeless and unique historical homes, adding a little more charm to the urban.

properties.artist_bio:
Julii McMillan is a Toronto based illustrator striving to leave the world a little better than she found it. Julii graduated from OCADU with a BFA in Drawing & Painting and joined the Directors Guild of Canada, working on feature films, television series and music videos in Toronto and abroad.

Inspired by the public art works of the Mexican Muralists, Julii put up paste-ups, stencils works around Kensington Market during University. She recently painted her first outdoor murals in Spain, Haiti and Canada in 2018. This spring Julii attended Mural Routes' Beaches Mural Workshop and she is looking forward  to painting her first Outside the Box mural this summer at Yonge Street & Yonge Blvd.  Julii's current art series, The Joys, can be seen at the St.Lawrence Market June thru October hosted by Arts at the Market. Julii is seeking every opportunity to paint and share The Joys on a larger scale this summer!

properties.artist_bio: I was born and raised in Russia and completed my Masters education at the Savitskiy College of Fine Art.  Since then, I have worked in Russia, in the United Arab Emirates for over ten years, and for four years in North York, Toronto, where I now live.  As a figurative oil painter, I work with landscapes, portraits, still lifes, etc.  My art is influenced by older European classical tradition of my training, but also by impressionist technique and by the more playful colours and modern, expressive styles of painters like Marc Chagall, Franz Marc, Paul Gaugin, and others.  This openness and flexibility has been very important in my prolific second career as a children’s book illustrator in the very large Arab language publishing market and now in Canada where I continue to illustrate.

properties.artist_bio:
Natalie Very B. is an illustrator, muralist, and teacher of Polish-Canadian decent.
Having grown up in a country with a strong patriarchal regime and an obvious system of inequality, she finds solace in painting ethereal shapes of female figures and the stories that they tell. As an immigrant artist she often explores the concept of “home”, and the sense of wistful longing and nostalgia that it brings out in her work.
Her childhood experience became a strong incentive for her to make illustrations that depict women as beautiful, empowered, and strong. As a result, her current work is devoted to the investigation of whimsical shapes of feminism in today’s world.

I would like to work with StART as I have had wonderful experiences working with you in the past, and I would like to keep this collaboration growing. You allow me to express myself, educate people, and beautify Toronto with my skills and ideas.
properties.description: This colourful mural titled "Reach For The Stars" by Natalie Very B. is a tribute to female resilience, strength, and perseverance in mostly male-dominated professions. It carries a message of hope and encourages the viewer to pursue their dreams.

properties.artist_bio: Nicole D'Amario is an illustrator and mural artist, who dabbles in ceramics. Since 2016 she has been teaching children how to create public art though weekly classes. Nicole has collaborated with the Beaches International Jazz Festival to give children and the general public the opportunity to create public artwork (including murals) for their own spaces such as libraries, schools and hospitals. Much of Nicole's public mural work has been as a part of the Buck Teeth Girls Club, a female collective consisting of Melissa Luk, Caitlin Taguibao, Andrea Manica and herself. Clients include Good for Her, Mountain Equipment Coop, The City of Toronto and more.

By integrating unique and diverse natural, cultural and historical influences, she transforms blank walls into inclusive and stunning spaces. She designs each mural with visual aesthetics that are familiar to a particular community, inviting people to engage in an uplifting and meaningful experience.

properties.artist_bio: Rachel Wilmshurst is a Toronto-based multidisciplinary artist who has studied graphic design, painting & illustration with professional experience in a wide variety of art & design based roles. Skilled in fine art technique as well as digital processes, Rachel’s projects have included mural painting, public art installation and gallery exhibitions as well as illustration and graphic design for a growing list of local and international clients.Rachel's background in graphic design and fine art have collectively informed her style which is simultaneously geometric and organic. She uses a combination of brushed acrylic, aerosol and paint markers to achieve a tapestry of shape & colour, representing elements of the surrounding environment and what makes it special.

I hope to learn to use spray paint so that I can begin to create bigger and more detailed works faster in order to take my practice to the next level. I am also interested in the community aspect that stART has created. Through the various projects I have met and made connections with other artists who continue to support my practice outside of the StART realm. properties.artist_bio: Victor SY Wei is a chinese-born canadian immigrant that came to Canada with his parents and settled in toronto, Ontario at the age of 10. After studying business at Western Ontario in London, ON, and working in the accounting field for a number of years he reconnected with his true passion for Art. During his year long leave from Toronto, he travelled back to his home-town Wei Fang, China and a number of other countries such as Vietnam, Japan and Spain. On that journey he discovered amazing murals around the world. Inspired by all that he saw, Victor began leaving murals of his own at each city he travelled to. They told stories that relate to the history of the community. Some were simply figures filled with colour based on the folk tales he grew up with.
properties.description: Dragons have been an important icon in Chinese culture. They can represent a variety of things ranging from strength to having good fortune. The dragon is also the 5th zodiac out the of 12 based on the Chinese calendar. My hope is that the bright red dragon can bring some luck and prosperity to the neighborhood and it's locals!

properties.artist_bio:
I am a Toronto-based illustrator, muralist and comics artist working out of a studio space on Dupont that I share with other 3 artists. While a lot of my illustration work is done for editorial or corporate clients, I’ve also had the opportunity to work on some community-based and public artwork projects over the past 2 years that I’ve been especially excited about. Through involvement with StART, I would love to find out about more opportunities to create public mural art that lives in and complements the community it is a part of. I think art in the public realm is so interesting to me because of how impactful it can be on mundane life – a visual break in the expected city patterns of shopfront, garage door, lamppost, parking meter. Even an escape. Themes of the idiosyncratic in the ordinary, the dichotomy between real and imagined, are things that my own work is interested in exploring, along with a sense of whimsy and play.

During the past few summers, I’ve been able to work on the Outside the Box traffic signal mural project, Womxn Paint in Toronto and in Rexdale, and the Lightup Laneway project. The outdoor murals I’ve completed have used a combination of exterior latex paint and spray paint, and in the future I’d like to explore more of how these mediums can work together, as well as improve on my ability to use spray paint which I was introduced to through Womxn Paint. Through public hoarding projects with PATCH (Mississauga and Region of Peel Watermain hoarding near Celebration Square; Bay Adelaide hoarding) I also have experience producing digital images for large-scale digital printing.

This upcoming year, I hope to have more opportunities to learn about making public artwork that supports the community it is a part of. I also want to challenge myself to work on larger, more varied projects that offer the opportunity for diversity in imagery and representation. I want to try new painting techniques with elements such as gradients and textures, and involve spray painting more in my mural work. I’m also interested in obtaining heights certification so that I’m able to work on larger walls should the opportunity arise. And I’d like to think about how – in mural making as in other life practises – I can do so with greater attention to sustainable practises and to the impact of what I’m doing. In general, I’d love increased opportunities to help make the site I’m painting in both reflective of and interesting to the imaginations of those who live here.
properties.description: Homeward: Imaging a city as a space where creatures from all corners of the universe can come together and set down their homes side by side.

properties.artist_bio:
Working with StArt and seeing the positive impact it has on neighbourhoods, people and the development of artists is inspiring and makes me proud to be a part of.

Canadian graffiti artist Alexander Bacon began painting in the 90’s as a teenager.  He is best known for his colourful works lining the alleys and streets of Toronto and achieved international recognition.  Bacon describes the art form as being passed down from one generation to the next.
His work has evolved to deconstructing traditional graffiti spray paint techniques to create an abstract graffiti style while maintaining letter form.  His use of a mature colour pallet and mixing of realism with the stylized graffiti fonts gives his work a unique look with smooth transitions and texture.
Most recently Bacon has been doing large scale murals and Canvas work while maintaining the disciplines of graffiti.  His work can be seen all over Toronto.
properties.description: This mural highlights a collective vision of the area and its history shared by the local community and interpreted by Lead Artists Alexander Bacon and Quentin Rockford.
properties.title: Alex Bacon & Que Rockford

properties.artist_bio:
I’d love to work with StreetARToronto because I’m inspired by the artistic legacy they are building in the City of Toronto. StART’s vision to create beautiful and safer public spaces with a mandate to act inclusively, celebrate our strengths in diversity, to acknowledge and respect the cultures and lands of Indigenous persons, and mentor emerging talents, all reflect my own values in my professional and personal life.

I’ve been an artist for 20 years in the public realm, having exhibited in public art galleries, artist-run centres, art festivals, and having worked with public/private planning teams to create permanent public art with budgets up to $56,000.00 (Holland Bloorview Kids Rehabilitation Hospital). I work in several disciplines including sculpture (polyurethane resins, concrete, casting techniques), installation art (interactive works that light up, make noise, or move - typically destined for art festivals/events such as Nuit Blanche, Animating Our Waterfront, Hamilton Supercrawl), and painting murals.

My passion for community arts participation cemented over 15 years ago when I sat on the board of Carfac Ontario as Vice Chair, with Merlin Homer as Chair, a Mohawk Elder whom I consider as a mentor. We had an exceptional team of strong arts leaders and my experience at Carfac helped mould my understanding of fair remuneration, cultural/ethnic/language/gender challenges that artists’ face, and the importance of advocating for one another’s communities.  Profoundly affected by this experience, I’ve continued to work with communities and have co-founded three successful art collectives, Open Field Collective, KJ Bit, and Creativo Collective, whose mandates are to create artwork and murals in public spaces while being inclusive of surrounding communities. In 2017, the Open Field Collective was awarded the national ArtBridges award for “Innovation” in recognition of our dedication to community engagement and our “Street Projects” where we invented miniature art galleries to create and display artwork in public spaces such as residential front yards, King Street (Public Realm), and Guelph. We’ve partnered with Scouts Canada, Neilson Creative Centre (Etobicoke), King Edward PS, been sponsored by Waterfront Toronto, and supported by Neighbourhood Associations and private and corporate donors.

Last year, I was lead coordinator for one of StreetARToronto’s laneway mural/graffiti projects. It was a wonderful opportunity to mentor my KJ Bit collaborator, June Kim, as a facilitator in the project. This summer, we’ll be coordinating the second phase of this Euclid/Palmerston laneway with a roster of 40 artists and be presenting a WalkShop tour of this laneway for delegates of the National Association of City Transportation Officials. This September, we’ll be painting a mural in partnership with StreetARToronto and TTC at Finch Station. My goal is to continue painting more murals, participating in more laneway jams and creating new, innovative street art events. I’d love to continue working with StreetARToronto because I believe we have mutual respect for the experience and expertise that both sides bring to the table. Above all, I love learning new things, and StreetARToronto has given me a great opportunity to grow as an artist and a facilitator.
properties.description: Artist Nick Sweetman in partnership with the David Suzuki Foundation, Street Art Toronto, and 38 other artists transformed a tagged laneway into an outdoor gallery dedicated to drawing attention to the importance of our native pollinators like butterflies.
properties.title: Erika James

properties.artist_bio:
Graffiti and the various channels the practice exists in has allowed me find self, community and financial independence. To me, this world-culture is one of great value not only to individuals but also the larger community. I want to do all I can to participate in the production and instruction of this movement because of the freedom and joy that it can spread. My goals with StART would be to continue my Swirling of the city, help mentor young artists and create positive change in the community through the creation of large scale works/events, hopefully making our great city a hub for artistry in the light of this global movement.

BIO:
Flips is a Toronto based multi-media artist, life enthusiast and visual storyteller.
Inspired by the blending of cultural forces seen in Toronto and his homeland of Bulgaria, Flips’ focus is on promoting and celebrating world cultures and connectivity amongst people. His motto is that art has the power to unite people and aims to create works that inspire and instill this message.

Flips is best known in the streets of Toronto for his signature Swirl Style, which reflects the philosophy of unity through art in the swirling of color and line. Mirroring life, the Flips Swirl Clusters represent the state of flux that exists in life; a beautiful mess of movement and energy. At the heart of each swirl cluster exists a circle that represents the individual soul, linked to others through infinite ties. A grouping of swirls signifies a strong presence of community, creativity, and care.

properties.artist_bio: I am an emerging artist working in Toronto. I studied Theatre at the University of Ottawa before completing a Bachelor of Design in Illustration at OCAD University. I create images that exist on paper, walls, objects, spaces, and stages. I am interested in using imagery as an opportunity to explore the world, the environment and social issues. I want the public art that I make to be bright and colourful, something that might attract someone's attention as they walk by. I like to create dense images where flat colourful shapes fill the entire wall/object, which can deter graffiti but also can allow for the viewer to notice something new after repeated viewings. In recent projects “Night on the town” or “Canoe with wildlife” (attached below), I tried to connect the imagery to something interesting about the area: the former is a reference to jazz clubs that used to exist in the east side of toronto, and the latter is a tribute the canoe butterfly gardens that can be found in parks throughout the city. I draw people with a looseness in their form, joyously moving and interacting. I would love to be involved with START and create more community engaged art and collaborate with other artists. I am interested in creating images for different spaces and it is a goal of mine to create work in different cities in Canada and internationally.
properties.description: KJ Bit Collective partnered with StreetARToronto to transform this community laneway into a giant canvas of graffiti and mural art. KJ Bit organized 75 artists to paint garages in two live-paint jams. The initiatives were well supported by local residents who now enjoy their revitalized laneway. KJ Bit are Jieun June Kim and Erika James.
properties.title:
Erin
  McCluskey

properties.artist_bio:
Enlivened by his interest in spacial structures and interconnectivity, Andre Kan's paintings serve as excitable blueprints for a possible reality. Each work depicts the artists' signature imaginative building blocks that converge and begin to build upon each other and strengthening each other towards an ever transforming space. Kan's structures are substantial and complex but not yet anchored - they float suspended in his psychological space. In this way Kan's buildings remain a playful proposition for the viewer not yet tied to a specific place or function. With his dynamic formations, Kan propels us towards an ever optimistic future where new connections and constructions have yet to materialize.

His current work investigates the architectural interpretations that respond to our ever advancing society, and suggests what 'possibility' means through self discovery. Examining what mark making and its properties mean, as well as the significance in cause and effect, is important here. Kan's psychological structures depict change and evolution of space, while also questioning the fundamental nature of being and the world that encompasses it.

Andre Kan is a Toronto based painter. Since graduating from the Ontario College of Art & Design University in 2014, he continues his creative pursuits as an Artist, Muralist, Photographer, Curator, Producer, and Musician. His paintings have been showcased throughout Canada with permanent collections in the U.S and China. His murals can also be seen internationally including London, Spain, Portugal and Taiwan.



Email: andrekanart@gmail.com
Instagram: andrekan_
Twitter: @andrekanart
