properties.artist_bio: I started my own snowboard line called SPAZZ Snowboard Crap in 1992.I designed, manufactured and distributed a 28 piece line of clothing across Canada, parts of the US, France, Greenland and Japan.I opened the first snowboard/skate shop in downtown Toronto in 1993. I ran the shop and shipped to over 60 stores around the world until 2000. I moved to LA . I soon hooked up with the Jackass crew, Think Skateboards, Big Brother, Stance Magazine, Emperor Norton Records - producing music videos, skate graphics and illustrations for print.Omy, Gallery Boutique became a reality beside the Drake Hotel and we represented new street artists for four years producing over 60 successfull shows.I created the Plywood Collective who curated group shows at SPiN Toronto - worked with Microsoft, Live Nation, Arts & Crafts, Telus, Bell, Pabst, Astral Media, CNE Live Nation and many more.

properties.artist_bio:
Roshni Wijayasinha is a Toronto based visual artist who specializes in large abstract expressionist paintings that are inspired by nature and its energy. Using acrylic and mixed media, these paintings experiment with light, colours, textures and finishes, and many of her pieces can be transformed under a black light, or glow in the dark. Her work has been featured at several juried exhibits and galleries across North America, in product launches, at a food festival, in a permanent collection at a Hilton Hotel in Toronto, in publications, and can be found on the streets of Toronto on 6 traffic boxes.

My experience painting the START traffic box at Front & John Street was a wonderful collaboration with the public, inviting people of all ages and different nationalities (high tourist traffic) make a small mark on this piece. I'm interested in participating in more street art around Toronto, to help liven our streets, bring energy and positivity to our neighbourhoods and people. Engaging our community in the process, I would love the opportunity to be able to deliver happiness and surprise and delight passers by as I do with my vivid glow in the dark paintings. I welcome the opportunity to work with other more established street artists, to learn more about outdoor art and public engagement, share our skills and techniques and grow together. I would also love to share my love of colour and light with other emerging artists, teaching them about how different materials can be used to create different lighting effects.

properties.artist_bio: I am very grateful to be part of documenting Toronto’s Street Art scene officially and unofficially for the past  several years. I have also documented international street art in major cities and in remote villages globally. It is important for me learn and share the diverse narratives that marginalized folks have been communicating over the years. I look forward to the possibility of continuing to document these very important narratives.

properties.artist_bio: Pascal Paquette produces site- and context-specific works using painting, design, graffiti, street art and photography. His  work has been commissioned, published and exhibited internationally and locally, notably at the Museum of Contemporary Canadian Art (MOCCA), the Art Gallery of Ontario (AGO), Canadian Heritage as well as Art Basel (Switzerland), Art Basel Miami, FIAC (Paris, France), Art Chicago (USA), Art Cologne (Köln, Germany) and Scope (London, UK). The Ontario Arts Council, British Arts Council, European Cultural Fund, Open Society Foundation and Toronto Arts Council have all supported his projects. He currently lives in Toronto, Canada with his wife and three children.

properties.artist_bio:
Christina Mazzulla is a Toronto based multi-disciplinary artist who specializes in spray paint and mixed-media work. She is well known for her mural contributions throughout the city and paintings comprised of intricate cutouts and exploration of combined media. Her artwork is heavily informed by psychedelic imagery, incorporating wildlife, fantasy, landscapes, and electric colour gradients. Christina has been working as a professional artist and showcasing work having graduated from OCADU in 2012, with a Bachelor of Fine Arts. Her passion for street art combined with traditional fine art training has helped her form a unique style, and gain a large following throughout North America. Christina continues her creative pursuits within the gallery scene, while also remaining one of the few active female graffiti artists within Toronto. She has provided many commissioned murals for large businesses and non-profit organizations including American Express, Universal Music, Chevrolet Canada, PangeaSeed Foundation, and The David Suzuki Foundation. She has worked with City of Toronto BIA's and StArt Toronto, along with many privately funded mural projects, with hopes to continue working with other street art initiatives., I want to work with StART because the projects I have completed with Street Art Toronto's help have been not only the most enjoyable projects I have worked on in my career, but also the most lucrative for me, in terms of both payment and scale of exposure. I learn something new on every project we do together and working with StART staff has taught me virtually everything I know about what goes into publicly-funded street art projects, all the moving parts that need to be accounted for, communicating with the public, coordinating materials and other artists, publicity, etc. I want to keep building on this knowledge and skill set as we continue to spread colourful mural projects into new parts of the city/GTA.

Bio:
Nick Sweetman is a multidisciplinary artist from Toronto whose practice has explored painting and its intersection with photography, video, installation, mixed media, and urban intervention. He has exhibited in galleries around Toronto since 2011, completing his MFA in 2014 from OCAD University in the Interdisciplinary Art, Media & Design program. He received a certificate from the Mural Routes Leadership Training in Mural-Making program the same year and since then has been working in public space on mural projects, often in collaboration with other artists, and in partnership with various non-profit organizations (David Suzuki Foundation, The STEPS Initiative) as well as Street Art Toronto. He has successfully managed many large-scale projects both independently and as lead artist over a team of volunteers, from children up to adults. He has dedicated many projects to raising awareness about the importance of pollinators, bees and butterflies in particular, from painting giant bees towering over busy city streets to coordinating 30 or more artists to paint butterflies on garages in Toronto's laneways. Most recently, Nick has been working abroad, participating in the Eureka Street Art Festival in Humboldt County, California as well as contributing a mural to the Bondi Beach Sea Wall in Sydney, Australia.

properties.artist_bio:
(I previously accidentally submitted an application which was unfinished).
I’ve been doing graffiti and aerosol art since 16 years old. At 22 the desire to learn and evolve my skill set into a business has greatly expanded, motivating me to work with programs such as START. I have a great love for letters and graffiti, as well as a background in fine arts. I studied illustration for a few years at Sheridan college, during which my interest in realism grew. I hope as a young artist that collaborating with others will help me solidify my own "style", and sense of confidence. My goal would be to work on/ create pieces which allow me to expand upon graffiti and realism,and potentially combine the two.
(I move to the city in May and drive if location is an issue).

properties.artist_bio:
Blaze Wiradharma is an OCADU Graduate with a BDES in Illustration. After living in Singapore for the last two years,  he has returned to Toronto to continue freelancing as a Mural / Graffiti Artist, Illustrator and Graphic Designer. In his early beginnings, his interest in visual communication was sparked by graffiti and street art. These forms influenced him heavily, his style reflecting the vibrant and often bold nature of urban art. This also encouraged the development of letters, calligraphy & characters which are a large part of his work.

Blaze takes inspiration from all facets of his own life experiences, and strives to create imagery which reflects lessons that he has learned along with social commentary. He believes that large mural artwork in the public sphere has a responsibility to create questions in the viewers mind and encourage critical thinking. Blaze utilises spray paint and exterior latex to create his exterior and interior work. He strives to work with StART's amazing team to further develop his mural work, add to the already impressive visual landscape of Toronto, and also creating opportunities for emerging artists to grow and develop along side him.

properties.artist_bio:
Jacquie Comrie is a Toronto- base, multidisciplinary artist whose vibrant body of work intersects contemporary art and wellness at a global scale, using colour as a medium of social impact and mental health.

 Whether as murals on buildings, large scale structures, or canvases, her body of work is a dynamic exploration of the science of colour as the universal language of human emotion, producing works in Canada and internationally.  Colour has been proven to have a direct effect to human emotion, for which her palettes are consciously designed and orchestrated aiming to cater to mental wellbeing at large.

In such divisive times, and with mental health issues on the rise across the globe, her work aims to contribute to much needed spaces of mental elevation and reset,  to ultimately help improve quality of life of all individuals- one wall at a time.

properties.artist_bio:
Leyland Adams is mural artist with a love for graffiti, illustration and community building through art. Leyland completed his
Advanced Diploma in Visual Creative Arts at Sheridan College in 2014. Since then he has travelled across the country and the globe to create large scale murals and create art on shoes. He is a creative entrepreneur who lives to empower and inspire his community through innovative art and collaboration.

properties.artist_bio:
Impulsive expressionism. Moments of movement. Spray Paint.

The exploration of self-dialogue with material and atmosphere, grants moments of incidental and intentional aesthetics. Art continues to form an inner dialogue between viewer and content. The unconscious movement through painting produces a learning experience for audience and artist. Visual elements and aesthetics within one’s control, judged and defined. Allow oneself to interact with the uncontrollable, to embrace the sense of boundless energy.

I would love to share moments and experiences with a community audience to help influence creative growth and community connections using visual art.

properties.artist_bio: Darcy Obokata was born in London ON ,where he gravitated towards mark making from his early years.  His creativity was nurtured and guided through elementary and secondary school, where he completed the Beal vocational art program.  Upon the completion of his most thorough and structured art instruction, Darcy took the task of advancing his artist practice himself.  Refining his craft in non-conventional ways while working and collaborating with artists throughout Canada, the US, Southeast Asia, Australia and Brazil.  It is only through this community of colleagues and compatriots that his art is fully realized.

properties.artist_bio:
For the last three years, I've had the fortune to be part of various StART projects and it is truly inspiring for me as a street artist to see the support from the city towards this art form. I'd love to continue working with StART and be part of this art movement!
Bio: My artistic work is the result of my experiences living and working in various parts of Latin America. The rich and vibrant cultures of the places I’ve visited have been my main inspiration to create and share my artistic vision with others. As a Canadian-Colombian artist is empowering for me to paint around the themes of culture, nature, and identity enriching Canadian multiculturalism. Most of my murals are found in Canada and Colombia, my wish is to continue painting across Canada and the world.

properties.artist_bio:
I want to continue co-collaborating with StART to keep growing as an artist in my skill set, practice and portfolio. With StART’s support I want to be mentored in my mural career with any opportunities to connect with seasoned mural/street artists and get on a swing-stage, aerial lift, use a spray gun, while learning to comprehend XL large walls and huge quantities of paint among advanced techniques of execution and project production. I’ve currently reached the stage of painting garages in Toronto and am interested and ready to go larger.

Bio & Artist Statement
Anya Mielniczek is a Toronto based multidisciplinary artist who combines her fine art background with raw material grit in both private and public sectors creating mixed-media installations, mural work and facilitating community art activations.
The artists approach to mediums includes latex, aerosol and up-cycled waste, working with the mechanical application of spray and the energy of hand brushed strokes (infused with powerful female portraits and garbage bits if possible).
A Queen’s University graduate, Anya’s worked with various organizations, municipalities and businesses creating public art within communities around Toronto and internationally. Recent corporate projects include lead production on HideSeek, a 7000sq foot immersive art experience in Toronto and collaborations with BACARDI, QUO Makeup, Moroccanoil, DELL, RBC, 1800GOTJUNK and Chevrolet. Her commitment to her practice especially when aligned with public spaces is to create with purpose by giving nature a voice while defining a conversation with the viewer that may inspire and bring awareness for sustainable change., Mska is a self thought artist, working primarily with acrylics, encaustics, collages, spray paint, ceramics, screen & lino printing. She decided to take muralism more serious in 2010. Her background plays a lot in her style. Mska is originally from Peru, but has been in Canada for nearly 20 years and has been taking different artistic workshops at Central Tech and Peach Berserk printing studios, she has mastered a style of her own by mixing different ways of approaching her materials to get her ART to the next level. Mska was has been collaborating with StarToronto, helping with the beautification of neighborhoods in need of an artistic facelift by painting murals over vandalized public and private properties. She has been part of several events like Wallnoize, Wall Expressions, Womxn Paint and events such as Digital Dreams, Harvest Fest, etc.
properties.description: Artist Nick Sweetman in partnership with the David Suzuki Foundation, Street Art Toronto, and 38 other artists transformed a tagged laneway into an outdoor gallery dedicated to drawing attention to the importance of our native pollinators like butterflies.

properties.artist_bio:
BIO: My name is Andrea Rodriguez. I am an artist, creative graphic designer, illustrator, letterer, and art director from Toronto and Bogota. I hold a Bachelor of Design from OCAD U, a postgraduate in Typography and a Master in Art from Penninghen (Paris). In regards to my experience as a muralist, I have painted on various surfaces and I count on getting my Working at Heights certificate this summer. I aim to make Toronto a better place for everyone.

Artist Statement: My work originates from a mixture of Colombia and Canada. Loud and bold colours have been my signature for many years. My pieces call upon nature, reminiscent of my childhood years,  incorporating them in my life as a Canadian. Inspired by my years in France, I incorporate many techniques.

Every day, our city is being loaded with more concrete and I am actively trying to bring some colour into it. I illustrate plants and flowers because they bring happiness. Colour makes you forget about the imperfections of life, so I try to aim for colourful pieces.

When I started my master's degree, I was optimistic about the prospects of being an art director. However, the more classes advanced, the more I realized I was not meant to take on that role. My process to develop this style started in my first year of my master, when I was asked to re-imagined Boschs' Garden of Earthly Delights.  I started drawing plants and flowers from my native Colombia and mixing them with my Canadianness. The result had an interesting narrative, somewhat descriptive of my duality.

Now back in Canada, I have taken the time to draw from real plants. I go around to gardens and conservatories in Toronto, grabbing inspiration everywhere I visit.  I have produced a series of nature drawings, that symbolize my love for this city.  My approach is not looking only at the form of the plants, but transforming them into a  visual language.  In the end, I aim to bring colour, plants and happiness to wherever my art goes.

properties.artist_bio: I am an award winning illustrator and OCAD U graduate. Primarily I am a freelance designer and painter. My paintings have shown at galleries in Toronto and New York. I enjoy working in a variety of media and scale. My work has taken forms such as apparel, a kids book, signs and branding.My mural experience started in 2016 in Owen Sound with a mural commissioned by Koodo and designed by Emily May Rose. I would continue to create large scale works along side Emily for personal collections as well as clients such as Tridel. I have gone on my own participating in stART projects such as Light Up Laneway and the Mimico bike lane barriers this past year. Furthermore I have been commissioned for murals in local residences.

properties.artist_bio: Pam Lostracco is a Toronto mural artist and graphic designer. Her work forms connections with the local environment that create a sense of identity and belonging for those who live and work here. By integrating unique and diverse natural, cultural and historical influences, she transforms blank walls into inclusive and stunning spaces. She designs each mural with visual aesthetics that are familiar to a particular community, inviting people to engage in an uplifting and meaningful experience.

properties.artist_bio: I am a Russian-Canadian visual artist and muralist based in Toronto ON. I hold a BFA from Emily Carr University and Certificate in Mural Art from Mural Routes. Majority of my paintings revolve around relationship between figure and abstract space, as I tend to explore themes of personal identity, duality and shifting perceptions.In the past two years I have been working in public spaces painting murals. These projects have become meaningful and rewarding experiences for me as I got a chance to share my narrative with my community, alter spaces and engage public. I’ve participated in collaborative murals with Mural Routes and Artbarn School. I have also completed my own projects as a lead artist in a cafe, Art Fair and Public School. Last summer I was thrilled to participate in the StART OTB program and Bellbox Mural programs.

As an artist he mainly focuses on large-scale mural work, incorporating text, vivid colour, and urban imagery to challenge the monotony of urban spaces.

properties.artist_bio:
Yasaman Mehrsa is a visual artist, graphic designer and photographer living and working in Toronto. Born and raised in Tehran/Iran, Yasaman’s love of art began as a child and further Shaped by her studies at Brock University in Visual Arts, and Visual Communication and Graphic Design from Iran. Her unique art works are mainly influenced by nature.
Striving to create work that is distinctive, engaging and above all, memorable, she conveys a story or invokes a certain emotion in each of her works. She believes art is one of the purest forms of communication. In addition to painting and design she contributes to public and street art as well. Her goal is to be more engaged in beautifying city and involving in the community.
----------------------------------------------------------------
I’m passionate about creativity. When I start to create a piece of art, my mind and body become united and empowered in the process of making! Nature is my inspiration. Usually I spend some time in nature , taking some photos ( I do professional photography as well) and I try to incorporate what I see in my paintings but not in a realistic way. I get inspired by forms, colours or even sounds. I transfer my feeling and emotion into the painting surface; It’s my way of story telling.

I would like to be involved with StART because with my background in creativity and art, I see myself growing in public art and I want to put any effort to be engage in communities. I love to do art for people and see them enjoy their environments. In my opinion, Art is communication; it allows people from different cultures and different times to communicate with each other via images, sounds and stories. My responsibility as an artist is to be engage in my society and help people to get more connected with each other and their environment.
I want to do bigger projects and experience different platforms. I’m interested in both individual projects and team projects.

With a Bachelor of Design from the Ontario College of Art and Design University in Illustration, I enjoy creating playful works that embody contrasting textures and repeated patterns. I have experience working in the public realms as a public arts assistant with the STEPS Initiative, working alongside artists to create large scale murals.

properties.artist_bio:
Frannie Potts is a Toronto based artist whose vision is to uplift minds, bodies and spirits while providing access to the arts in underserved communities, one mural at a time. Frannie enjoys using bright colours and juxtaposing images as a tool to captivate the viewer in a thought-provoking manner; grounding them in the present moment with public art. She uses a variety of mediums throughout her work, such as spray paint, interior/exterior latex, acrylic, ink and digital media. Some of Frannie’s accomplishments include receiving a platinum level certificate in the Mural Art Career Development Course offered by Mural Routes, and completing a three month internship in California with international mural artist John Pugh. These achievements have allowed her to gain contacts in the industry and confidence as a professional mural artist. Frannie has worked on over 25 indoor and outdoor mural projects to date, which can be viewed throughout the city of Toronto.

Frannie Potts’ first experience working with StART was in partnership with Urban Arts in 2013. Frannie was hired as a youth artist for a mural project painted on MDO boards, which were later installed on a retaining wall by Weston Rd and Rogers Rd. Since then, she’s assisted many large-scale mural projects across the city with lead artists such as Jim Bravo, Emannuel Ciobonnica, Zeesy Powers, Rob Matejka, Ryan Dineen and Sean Martindale. Frannie has had the opportunity to paint independently on garage doors for Toronto’s Laneway Project and participated in painting a mural for Womxn Paint 2019. These experiences allowed her to gain the confidence and skills needed to mentor children and youth as a mural workshop series leader in partnership with VIBE Arts and Access Alliance.

The time Frannie spent as an assistant artist gave her the privilege to be mentored in a variety of technical, organizational and personable skills. The opportunity to mentor youth was one of Frannie’s favourite parts of assisting murals, and proved to be a rewarding and memorable experience. Each mural project Frannie has had the pleasure of working on in Toronto has given her the opportunity to grow and inspired her to set bigger goals as an artist. Frannie hopes that the next step for her in her artistic career is to lead a large-scale mural project with a team of youth and assistant artists. Frannie feels she has an obligation as an artist to amplify the voices of those in the community she’s working within through the lens of public art.

properties.artist_bio:
My name is Kayla Whitney and I work under my business name Koe Design. I maintain an active personal studio practic and work as an illustrator and a muralist full time. I have had the privilege of working on community projects over the past 2 years and the feeling has infected me. I always felt a sense of selfishness working within the confines of my studio and having had the opportunity to contribute my creative passion towards communities and neighbourhoods has motivated me to create in a way I have never felt before.
	I work primarily with brushes and house paint and have experience working on a variety of scales, heights and surfaces. I have lead teams of volunteers and also experienced artists. I have worked in artist teams and under the mentorship of an established artist on large scale projects.
	I would be honoured to be a part of StART programming and to work on a StART project because I myself align with so many of the goals of the organization. I have created art in and for communities and I have witnessed through how impactful public art is on a neighbourhood and a community. To be connected with a larger organization that has the ability to spread public art across the city of Toronto and bring it to the areas that need it the most would be wonderful as it would allow me the opportunity to further actualize my goals of using my art to create places and spaces that are memorable, safe, accessible and where community members take great pride of ownership.
	I have been so lucky as to work alongside Christiano D’Arujo on a StART project on Rogers Rd near Caledonia this past winter, and I got to witness its great impact on the community. It is a personal goal to be involved in more projects like that one and be given the opportunity to learn and grow as an artist from the challenges associated in executing projects of that size.

	I was working on a mural once and a woman came up to me to tell me how important she thinks public art is. She told me that she had survived an abusive relationship and was in the process of working with the police to convict her abuser. She told me that going to the police station was very difficult and each time she was done she would sit in front of this mural near the place station and look at its beauty and cry tears of joy and gratitude for where she was in her life. I cannot forget this woman or that story because the mural beside the police station is my work and her story is the reason I create work that exists in the world. My work is for people like her in moments like that, when all they need to see is a beautiful reminder of the humanity of all of us and the wonder of the world around us.

properties.artist_bio:
I am a multidisciplinary artist and designer, forever exploring on my creative journey.  By day I work as an Art Director and Graphic Designer at a creative agency downtown. And by night, (and on weekends) I transform into a Hand Letterer, Muralist, and most recently a Calligrapher. Born, raised, and living in Toronto, I have always been passionate about visual arts. With a Bachelor of Design from OCAD University, I graduated in 2013 and entered into the design world with the majority of my work being digital. Due to a strong desire to create with my hands again in the last few years, I have returned to the traditional art of drawing and painting. Bringing this handmade feel and human touch back into my work makes it that much more memorable and unique.

Outdoor painting was a curiosity I first explored a few years ago when I decided to paint a vibrant mural on my porch as an end-of-summer activity and homage to my favourite artists and art movements. The larger canvas was something different and exciting for me to force me out of my comfort zone and challenge me to paint on an imperfect surface. Bringing colour and life to my neighbourhood was also something I thoroughly enjoyed, along with the unexpected interactions with people passing by for a smile, a chat or even a compliment. Engaging with a community through the creation of an art piece was such a magical experience for me that has me hooked on murals ever since! In the past year, I have created a few indoor murals for offices, whether it was painted or created digitally as a vinyl sticker to create a statement wall.

I have been following StART for about a year, admiring all the amazing projects in our city and would love to be a part of it. I am super excited to say that my first project with StART will be next week when I paint my first utility box! I would love to learn more about the Toronto mural world and how to get involved in more projects, learning from experienced artists and helping them out. Participating in StART initiatives and being part of a larger community of artists and art lovers that are making our city a better place to live, one street art piece at a time, would be a dream! At the end of the day, I just want to create art that engages and resonates with people and what better way to do this than to contribute to this organization. Since discovering StART, I have been so motivated by the beautiful mural art, it has encouraged me to reach out to artists, explore new neighbourhoods hunting for murals, and collaborate with like-minded artists. I believe that having a community of artists support each other and create together is so important and truly inspiring. I would love to give back to my home city of Toronto and create some magic with the help of StART.

properties.artist_bio: I would love to continue my involvement for StART because I love creating work for my city! My work is happy and Toronto-centric, every piece I create is aimed to make the community smile, laugh, and think. After 5 years of doing street art and illustration full-time, I’ve been lucky enough to have the opportunity to travel and bring my Toronto raccoon murals around the world, but this will always be my favourite place to make art. I hope to up my scale this year and bring more colour into our already vibrant communities.

properties.artist_bio:
At the tender age of nine, Toronto-based illustrator Adrian Hayles discovered the expressive
nature of the visual arts. With his continued artistic development, illustration became his
deepest passion and talent. His desire to learn and absorb from his surroundings led him on a
personal creative journey. As a graduate of the Graphic Design program at Humber College
with over 10 years of working experience behind him, Adrian has established his place in
Toronto’s modern art community. His style is provocative and inspiring and defies
categorization. Blurring the lines between graffiti and ultra realism, Adrian’s voice and vision is
instantly identifiable. His works include countless portraits and illustrations for various
magazines and collaborations with the City of Toronto to develop murals for vacant community
spaces. In the past Adrian has painted complete buildings and city blocks, designed award
winning video games and animated television shows. He has also successfully developed and
filed a functioning patent for the Stud Horse Foldable Drawing Bench and is the Principal and
Founder of Behind the Front Visual Arts Studio.

Adrian
  Hayles

properties.title: Getso

properties.artist_bio:
I am a Toronto-based illustrator, muralist and comics artist working out of a studio space on Dupont that I share with other 3 artists. While a lot of my illustration work is done for editorial or corporate clients, I’ve also had the opportunity to work on some community-based and public artwork projects over the past 2 years that I’ve been especially excited about. Through involvement with StART, I would love to find out about more opportunities to create public mural art that lives in and complements the community it is a part of. I think art in the public realm is so interesting to me because of how impactful it can be on mundane life – a visual break in the expected city patterns of shopfront, garage door, lamppost, parking meter. Even an escape. Themes of the idiosyncratic in the ordinary, the dichotomy between real and imagined, are things that my own work is interested in exploring, along with a sense of whimsy and play.

During the past few summers, I’ve been able to work on the Outside the Box traffic signal mural project, Womxn Paint in Toronto and in Rexdale, and the Lightup Laneway project. The outdoor murals I’ve completed have used a combination of exterior latex paint and spray paint, and in the future I’d like to explore more of how these mediums can work together, as well as improve on my ability to use spray paint which I was introduced to through Womxn Paint. Through public hoarding projects with PATCH (Mississauga and Region of Peel Watermain hoarding near Celebration Square; Bay Adelaide hoarding) I also have experience producing digital images for large-scale digital printing.

This upcoming year, I hope to have more opportunities to learn about making public artwork that supports the community it is a part of. I also want to challenge myself to work on larger, more varied projects that offer the opportunity for diversity in imagery and representation. I want to try new painting techniques with elements such as gradients and textures, and involve spray painting more in my mural work. I’m also interested in obtaining heights certification so that I’m able to work on larger walls should the opportunity arise. And I’d like to think about how – in mural making as in other life practises – I can do so with greater attention to sustainable practises and to the impact of what I’m doing. In general, I’d love increased opportunities to help make the site I’m painting in both reflective of and interesting to the imaginations of those who live here.

properties.artist_bio: Mahjabeen Kabir (Mahja) (b. 1993, Abu Dhabi, UAE)  is an emerging visual mixed media artist living and studying in Toronto, ON. Previously having a background in Science, she is currently exploring her creative pursuit and hoping to have a career in Design. Her style uses vibrant colours, shapes and patterns to form dreamlike depictions of altered realities. She draws inspiration from nature and is always on the search of greater understanding. She delves into the emotions of memories to capture the essence of what once was, questions realities, explores curiosities within the self and surroundings and hopes to inspire people to explore themselves and question the world.

properties.artist_bio:
BIO: My name is Andrea Rodriguez. I am an artist, creative graphic designer, illustrator, letterer, and art director from Toronto and Bogota. I hold a Bachelor of Design from OCAD U, a postgraduate in Typography and a Master in Art from Penninghen (Paris). In regards to my experience as a muralist, I have painted on various surfaces and I count on getting my Working at Heights certificate this summer. I aim to make Toronto a better place for everyone.

Artist Statement: My work originates from a mixture of Colombia and Canada. Loud and bold colours have been my signature for many years. My pieces call upon nature, reminiscent of my childhood years,  incorporating them in my life as a Canadian. Inspired by my years in France, I incorporate many techniques.

Every day, our city is being loaded with more concrete and I am actively trying to bring some colour into it. I illustrate plants and flowers because they bring happiness. Colour makes you forget about the imperfections of life, so I try to aim for colourful pieces.

When I started my master's degree, I was optimistic about the prospects of being an art director. However, the more classes advanced, the more I realized I was not meant to take on that role. My process to develop this style started in my first year of my master, when I was asked to re-imagined Boschs' Garden of Earthly Delights.  I started drawing plants and flowers from my native Colombia and mixing them with my Canadianness. The result had an interesting narrative, somewhat descriptive of my duality.

Now back in Canada, I have taken the time to draw from real plants. I go around to gardens and conservatories in Toronto, grabbing inspiration everywhere I visit.  I have produced a series of nature drawings, that symbolize my love for this city.  My approach is not looking only at the form of the plants, but transforming them into a  visual language.  In the end, I aim to bring colour, plants and happiness to wherever my art goes.

KJ Bit organized 75 artists to paint garages in two live-paint jams. The initiatives were well supported by local residents who now enjoy their revitalized laneway. KJ Bit are Jieun June Kim and Erika James.

Andrea
  Rodriguez

properties.artist_bio:
My practice has always been quite interdisciplinary, from printmaking and photography, to drawing and sculpture, but as soon as street art entered my life I fell in love with it. I've been painting as an assistant to Kirsten McCrea (Hello Kirsten) since 2017 and have experienced the affect that street art has on communities firsthand. Painting projects like the underpass at Gerrard and Carlaw introduced me to wonderful people that stopped to thank us for brightening up a space that they encountered every day.  That's why I want to paint murals. That's why I love street art. It transforms the way that people engage with their city. It creates spaces that feel warm and inviting, that foster civic pride, and that make moving through the streets of Toronto more enjoyable.

Being considered for smaller StART projects would be a wonderful step forward in my career, but 'm also eager to paint with more established street artists as their assistants.  I have my WAH and swing stage certifications, and have assisted Kirsten on projects from start to finish over the past two years. Experiencing how different artists tackle the many challenges that come with each wall would be a huge opportunity.

  Chen

properties.artist_bio:
Born and raised in Iran, I moved to Canada as a teenager. I studied at OCAD University, where I gained exposure to a variety of disciplines from Fine Arts to Graphic Design & Advertising. After obtaining my Bachelor’s degree, I began working as a Visual Communications Coordinator at a large corporation. After 7 years, I decided to pursue my own art and design practice. I have since been awarded and published a number of times, had a solo exhibition and have created a number of murals around Toronto. I create colourful and whimsical paintings, digital art and GIFs that focus on life as a woman, spirituality and everyday life. I’m a shameless coffee addict and frequent the local cafes. Dancing, yoga and biking are my preferred ways of recharging.
I started my street art work since 2018 at which point I painted on a utility box for StreetARToronto and since then I have painted multiple small scale murals around Toronto for StreetART, Bell Box Murals including garage doors and concrete walls. I would like to continue expanding my street art practice and beautify the city further.

properties.artist_bio:
I want to continue co-collaborating with StART to keep growing as an artist in my skill set, practice and portfolio. With StART’s support I want to be mentored in my mural career with any opportunities to connect with seasoned mural/street artists and get on a swing-stage, aerial lift, use a spray gun, while learning to comprehend XL large walls and huge quantities of paint among advanced techniques of execution and project production. I’ve currently reached the stage of painting garages in Toronto and am interested and ready to go larger.

Bio & Artist Statement
Anya Mielniczek is a Toronto based multidisciplinary artist who combines her fine art background with raw material grit in both private and public sectors creating mixed-media installations, mural work and facilitating community art activations.
The artists approach to mediums includes latex, aerosol and up-cycled waste, working with the mechanical application of spray and the energy of hand brushed strokes (infused with powerful female portraits and garbage bits if possible).
A Queen’s University graduate, Anya’s worked with various organizations, municipalities and businesses creating public art within communities around Toronto and internationally. Recent corporate projects include lead production on HideSeek, a 7000sq foot immersive art experience in Toronto and collaborations with BACARDI, QUO Makeup, Moroccanoil, DELL, RBC, 1800GOTJUNK and Chevrolet. Her commitment to her practice especially when aligned with public spaces is to create with purpose by giving nature a voice while defining a conversation with the viewer that may inspire and bring awareness for sustainable change.
properties.description: KJ Bit Collective partnered with StreetARToronto to transform this community laneway into a giant canvas of graffiti and mural art. KJ Bit organized 75 artists to paint garages in two live-paint jams. The initiatives were well supported by local residents who now enjoy their revitalized laneway. KJ Bit are Jieun June Kim and Erika James.
properties.title: Anya Mielniczek & Oriah Scott

properties.artist_bio:
MONICA WICKELER
As a trained visual artist who has worked in the large scale painting industry in Toronto for many years, in outdoor advertising as a mural artist and in the film and television industry as a scenic artist, Monica Wickeler has found a love of community and public art. As well as painting community murals in playgrounds, on wading pools and in pedestrian laneways, she has recently enjoyed working with students to inspire them to approach large scale paintings in their own community and taking ownership and pride in who they are and in their neighborhoods.
ARTISTIC STATEMENT
I have always been inspired by the newest STREET/PUBLIC artist projects around the world. When I start a project my sketches will often be uploaded and worked on digitally to see how my ideas respond to the space it will be painted on I can digitally mock up and idea and can easily share it with the client. Once at the wall producing the work, that amazing feeling of working in the public eye kicks in and the getting feedback from pedestrians is always an inspiration. Recently I have been using a combination of brushwork and aerosol painting techniques and I am thrilled with the vibrancy of color and effects produced. Finding the connection between the visual landscape and the images the community connects with is my biggest goal during my design process.

Monica
  Wickler

properties.artist_bio:
I’d love to work with StreetARToronto because I’m inspired by the artistic legacy they are building in the City of Toronto. StART’s vision to create beautiful and safer public spaces with a mandate to act inclusively, celebrate our strengths in diversity, to acknowledge and respect the cultures and lands of Indigenous persons, and mentor emerging talents, all reflect my own values in my professional and personal life.

I’ve been an artist for 20 years in the public realm, having exhibited in public art galleries, artist-run centres, art festivals, and having worked with public/private planning teams to create permanent public art with budgets up to $56,000.00 (Holland Bloorview Kids Rehabilitation Hospital). I work in several disciplines including sculpture (polyurethane resins, concrete, casting techniques), installation art (interactive works that light up, make noise, or move - typically destined for art festivals/events such as Nuit Blanche, Animating Our Waterfront, Hamilton Supercrawl), and painting murals.

My passion for community arts participation cemented over 15 years ago when I sat on the board of Carfac Ontario as Vice Chair, with Merlin Homer as Chair, a Mohawk Elder whom I consider as a mentor. We had an exceptional team of strong arts leaders and my experience at Carfac helped mould my understanding of fair remuneration, cultural/ethnic/language/gender challenges that artists’ face, and the importance of advocating for one another’s communities.  Profoundly affected by this experience, I’ve continued to work with communities and have co-founded three successful art collectives, Open Field Collective, KJ Bit, and Creativo Collective, whose mandates are to create artwork and murals in public spaces while being inclusive of surrounding communities. In 2017, the Open Field Collective was awarded the national ArtBridges award for “Innovation” in recognition of our dedication to community engagement and our “Street Projects” where we invented miniature art galleries to create and display artwork in public spaces such as residential front yards, King Street (Public Realm), and Guelph. We’ve partnered with Scouts Canada, Neilson Creative Centre (Etobicoke), King Edward PS, been sponsored by Waterfront Toronto, and supported by Neighbourhood Associations and private and corporate donors.

Last year, I was lead coordinator for one of StreetARToronto’s laneway mural/graffiti projects. It was a wonderful opportunity to mentor my KJ Bit collaborator, June Kim, as a facilitator in the project. This summer, we’ll be coordinating the second phase of this Euclid/Palmerston laneway with a roster of 40 artists and be presenting a WalkShop tour of this laneway for delegates of the National Association of City Transportation Officials. This September, we’ll be painting a mural in partnership with StreetARToronto and TTC at Finch Station. My goal is to continue painting more murals, participating in more laneway jams and creating new, innovative street art events. I’d love to continue working with StreetARToronto because I believe we have mutual respect for the experience and expertise that both sides bring to the table. Above all, I love learning new things, and StreetARToronto has given me a great opportunity to grow as an artist and a facilitator., Jieun June Kim is a Toronto based, Korean born painter and muralist.  She has exhibited her paintings around the world since 2010 at notable galleries and events, exploring the idea of “home” as an immigrant and creating safe space.
Jieun completed the Mural Art Career Development program offered by Mural Routes in 2017 and has since worked with various arts organizations, city of Toronto as well as corporate partners such as Samsung, Up Canada, and Collective Arts Brewery.
 She is the co-founder of KJ Bit Collective who creates murals and street art events, and a member of the Mural Routes advisory committee team. She is also the recipient of the Newcomer and Refugee Artist Mentorship grant from the Toronto Arts Council (2018).

properties.artist_bio:
Enlivened by his interest in spacial structures and interconnectivity, Andre Kan's paintings serve as excitable blueprints for a possible reality. Each work depicts the artists' signature imaginative building blocks that converge and begin to build upon each other and strengthening each other towards an ever transforming space. Kan's structures are substantial and complex but not yet anchored - they float suspended in his psychological space. In this way Kan's buildings remain a playful proposition for the viewer not yet tied to a specific place or function. With his dynamic formations, Kan propels us towards an ever optimistic future where new connections and constructions have yet to materialize.

His current work investigates the architectural interpretations that respond to our ever advancing society, and suggests what 'possibility' means through self discovery. Examining what mark making and its properties mean, as well as the significance in cause and effect, is important here. Kan's psychological structures depict change and evolution of space, while also questioning the fundamental nature of being and the world that encompasses it.

Andre Kan is a Toronto based painter. Since graduating from the Ontario College of Art & Design University in 2014, he continues his creative pursuits as an Artist, Muralist, Photographer, Curator, Producer, and Musician. His paintings have been showcased throughout Canada with permanent collections in the U.S and China. His murals can also be seen internationally including London, Spain, Portugal and Taiwan.



Email: andrekanart@gmail.com
Instagram: andrekan_
Twitter: @andrekanart

properties.artist_bio: Curtia Wright is a multi-disciplinary fine artist and mural artist based in Toronto, Ontario.  Her current works delve into the spiritual and mental wellness of African peoples and the link to mythology and disseminating what‘fantasy’ is and who it belongs to. She's worked on many mural projects from independent to community based across the GTA. Her murals focus on mixing graphic and realistic works together to create vibrate collage paintings. In the past she's worked with Mural Routes, Art Starts, Street Art Toronto, Harbourfront Community Centre, Womxn Paint, Patch Project and other collaborations with mural artists in Toronto.

properties.artist_bio:
Avril, also known as, Av is a multidisciplinary designer specializing in graphic design and digital illustration. She started her career early in her life practicing traditional art. Her love for the arts and crafts developed from the early age of three. Since, then she has worked on a number of personal and professionally collaborative projects ranging from murals to logo and character design. After completing her first mural, she became obsessed with the process. The interactivity with the surrounding community and the large scale canvas are what stole her heart. She hopes to continue this act of bringing more walls to life!

Her work has been featured on BlogTO, Citytv News and has caught the eye of multiple social media influencers, such as Aimee Song (SongofStyle on Instagram).

Avril would love to become more involved in Toronto's art scene. She would love to use her art as a way of livening up the city and becoming more interactive with the people that make up Toronto.

properties.artist_bio:
Natalie Very B. is an illustrator, muralist, and teacher of Polish-Canadian decent.
Having grown up in a country with a strong patriarchal regime and an obvious system of inequality, she finds solace in painting ethereal shapes of female figures and the stories that they tell. As an immigrant artist she often explores the concept of “home”, and the sense of wistful longing and nostalgia that it brings out in her work.
Her childhood experience became a strong incentive for her to make illustrations that depict women as beautiful, empowered, and strong. As a result, her current work is devoted to the investigation of whimsical shapes of feminism in today’s world.

I would like to work with StART as I have had wonderful experiences working with you in the past, and I would like to keep this collaboration growing. You allow me to express myself, educate people, and beautify Toronto with my skills and ideas.
properties.description: This Paint Jam included participation of children, youth groups, and adults from Stonegate CHC programs and in the community to take part in the colorful painting of the path mural with lead artist Natalie Very B.
properties.title: Natalie Very B

A towering image of a deer is mixed with birdO’s signature surrealist style, playfully referencing the surrounding Deer Park neighbourhood.

I’ve currently reached the stage of painting garages in Toronto and am interested and ready to go larger.

Bio & Artist Statement
Anya Mielniczek is a Toronto based multidisciplinary artist who combines her fine art background with raw material grit in both private and public sectors creating mixed-media installations, mural work and facilitating community art activations.
The artists approach to mediums includes latex, aerosol and up-cycled waste, working with the mechanical application of spray and the energy of hand brushed strokes (infused with powerful female portraits and garbage bits if possible).
A Queen’s University graduate, Anya’s worked with various organizations, municipalities and businesses creating public art within communities around Toronto and internationally. Recent corporate projects include lead production on HideSeek, a 7000sq foot immersive art experience in Toronto and collaborations with BACARDI, QUO Makeup, Moroccanoil, DELL, RBC, 1800GOTJUNK and Chevrolet. Her commitment to her practice especially when aligned with public spaces is to create with purpose by giving nature a voice while defining a conversation with the viewer that may inspire and bring awareness for sustainable change., Early on, I perceived that my ambition was the act of painting itself, finding that the process coincided with the workings of my conscious and unconscious mind.Throughout my career I have also been fascinated by realism, specifically trompe l’oeil and it’s ability to affect the viewer. I have been creating trompe l’oeil murals in combination with my abstract works for over 20 years now. It has become for me a way to connect with the viewer on several different levels. I have discovered that painting illusions allows me to communicate with a larger audience, as people genuinely delighted when visually tricked. While both painting techniques claim to express reality truthfully, either suggests only a partial or incomplete view of a subject.
I am also extremely interested in the archival quality of work and how public art is produced, in an ethical and archival way. I have painted murals that are still on display over 20 years later. I feel that viewers of public work have an investment in the upkeep and archival quality of the work. Starting with the proper preparation, the production process should be considered when producing public art. When public art pieces become worn and decay after only a few seasons the public does not see the value in continuing to fund public art. Having worked for several years of trial and error I feel that I could offer proper preparation advice to many of the public art projects.
properties.description: These colorful pollinator themed murals help bring awareness to sustainability and the environment
properties.title: Anya  Mielniczek, Marg Cresswell & Brenda Coombs

properties.artist_bio: I am an artist and graphic designer born and raised in downtown Toronto. Themes that often emerge from my work include identity, nature and whimsy, and I express my ideas using a wide variety of mediums, including acrylic and oil painting, murals, paper cutting, printmaking and digital graphics.In the summer of 2019, I painted a large mural in Jean Sibelius Park, in partnership with StART. I’ve also painted a utility box with Outside the Box and completed two Bell Box murals. My mural painting experience also includes a mural at a community garden in Parkdale and assisting on large scale murals for William Lazos in Liberty Village and Phil Cote at Dundas and Jarvis.I hold a Master of Design degree from Carleton University and a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree from Queen’s University, and I have exhibited in galleries across Ontario.

properties.artist_bio: ‘Elicser’ Elliott explores narrative structures and new surfaces through the lens of more than a decade spent in the global graffiti community. A distinctive character-based practice, the work of Elicser is highly visible in cities throughout Canada, South America and South Africa. Known for his intuitive ability to capture the essence of a subject. Elicser Elliott leads the charge in the character-based movement in Toronto and was voted ‘Best Local Graffiti Artist’ by NOW Magazine for 2011 through 2014. His work was recently featured at the Institute for Contemporary Culture at the Royal Ontario Museum, the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, the Art Gallery of Ontario and at mural festivals in Hawaii and New York.
properties.description: Colourful depictions of members from the surrounding community.

The Tranzac Club and local community developed the project theme “You are Here, Annex” to guide the artists and showcase a local community’s memory of their neighbourhood before a large-scale development transformed the iconic Bloor-Bathurst intersection.

properties.artist_bio: Darcy Obokata was born in London ON ,where he gravitated towards mark making from his early years.  His creativity was nurtured and guided through elementary and secondary school, where he completed the Beal vocational art program.  Upon the completion of his most thorough and structured art instruction, Darcy took the task of advancing his artist practice himself.  Refining his craft in non-conventional ways while working and collaborating with artists throughout Canada, the US, Southeast Asia, Australia and Brazil.  It is only through this community of colleagues and compatriots that his art is fully realized.

properties.artist_bio:
Frannie Potts is a Toronto based artist whose vision is to uplift minds, bodies and spirits while providing access to the arts in underserved communities, one mural at a time. Frannie enjoys using bright colours and juxtaposing images as a tool to captivate the viewer in a thought-provoking manner; grounding them in the present moment with public art. She uses a variety of mediums throughout her work, such as spray paint, interior/exterior latex, acrylic, ink and digital media. Some of Frannie’s accomplishments include receiving a platinum level certificate in the Mural Art Career Development Course offered by Mural Routes, and completing a three month internship in California with international mural artist John Pugh. These achievements have allowed her to gain contacts in the industry and confidence as a professional mural artist. Frannie has worked on over 25 indoor and outdoor mural projects to date, which can be viewed throughout the city of Toronto.

Frannie Potts’ first experience working with StART was in partnership with Urban Arts in 2013. Frannie was hired as a youth artist for a mural project painted on MDO boards, which were later installed on a retaining wall by Weston Rd and Rogers Rd. Since then, she’s assisted many large-scale mural projects across the city with lead artists such as Jim Bravo, Emannuel Ciobonnica, Zeesy Powers, Rob Matejka, Ryan Dineen and Sean Martindale. Frannie has had the opportunity to paint independently on garage doors for Toronto’s Laneway Project and participated in painting a mural for Womxn Paint 2019. These experiences allowed her to gain the confidence and skills needed to mentor children and youth as a mural workshop series leader in partnership with VIBE Arts and Access Alliance.

The time Frannie spent as an assistant artist gave her the privilege to be mentored in a variety of technical, organizational and personable skills. The opportunity to mentor youth was one of Frannie’s favourite parts of assisting murals, and proved to be a rewarding and memorable experience. Each mural project Frannie has had the pleasure of working on in Toronto has given her the opportunity to grow and inspired her to set bigger goals as an artist. Frannie hopes that the next step for her in her artistic career is to lead a large-scale mural project with a team of youth and assistant artists. Frannie feels she has an obligation as an artist to amplify the voices of those in the community she’s working within through the lens of public art.

properties.artist_bio:
I have been involved with StART for a number of years now, and am grateful  for every opportunity to be involved in the ever changing Toronto landscape. The relationships I’ve built, and friends I’ve made as a direct result are invaluable. Moving forward into 2020, I would love to be even more involved, and painting as often as possible.

As an artist, I’m just looking to evolve with my own craft, always trying something new. Start has certainly provided an enormous amount of room to grow, with a lot of events having overlying themes, pushing me to think outside of the box on many occasions. Typefaces, fonts, and writing continue to be at the fore front of a majority of my work, however I’m also actively working on illustration and furthering techniques for background work as well.

As a carpenter/GC here in the city I handle so many of the materials going into, and out side of people’s homes. Some of which have wound up being garages in lane way projects! I’ve been drawn to some of these materials to use as elements in new work, recycling old doors and discarded pieces of stone and steel. Finding new forms for them to take at table size, but would ultimately like to scale up to a public installation size. Furniture designing and building has been a big focus in recent years and I believe could integrate so easily into sculpture/street installations.

Last year, with the help of Jodi Callan and the folks at start we received help with getting paint for the vanderhoof skatepark bowl. We have been repainting the bowl for a decade now, every year for a home grown skateboard contest called Hoedown at the Hoof. It was game changing to be able to invite more artists to fill out the entirety of the bowl and have everybody in matching colours. Especially as it was in time to commemorate the raptors win as well. We hope you guys would be happy to work with us again this year!

properties.artist_bio: Christina Mazzulla is a Toronto based multi-disciplinary artist who specializes in spray paint and mixed-media work. She is well known for her mural contributions throughout the city and paintings comprised of intricate cutouts and exploration of combined media. Her artwork is heavily informed by psychedelic imagery, incorporating wildlife, fantasy, landscapes, and electric colour gradients. Christina has been working as a professional artist and showcasing work having graduated from OCADU in 2012, with a Bachelor of Fine Arts. Her passion for street art combined with traditional fine art training has helped her form a unique style, and gain a large following throughout North America. Christina continues her creative pursuits within the gallery scene, while also remaining one of the few active female graffiti artists within Toronto. She has provided many commissioned murals for large businesses and non-profit organizations including American Express, Universal Music, Chevrolet Canada, PangeaSeed Foundation, and The David Suzuki Foundation. She has worked with City of Toronto BIA's and StArt Toronto, along with many privately funded mural projects, with hopes to continue working with other street art initiatives.

properties.artist_bio:
Ted Hamer is a multidisciplinary Artist and educator based in Toronto. His work explores the juxtaposition of nature with human constructs through explorations into challenging humanities anthropocentric views towards ourselves and our environment. He merges historical approaches to realist and modern art to explore the nature vs culture divide through figures that examine various overlapping themes of anthropocenterism using natural and man made elements and materials.
Ted's work has exhibited in the Art Gallery of Ontario, the Steamwhistle Gallery, the RMG, The Station Gallery, Nathan Phillips Square, Bluffs Gallery, the Super Wonder Gallery and his Sculptural Mural Installation is the centerpiece installation of the Aurora Cultural Centre in Aurora Ontario.

In paint I work with Aerosol and acrylic and Latex. In Sculpture I work in clays, fibreglass, resins, bronze and wood and am now experimenting with 3D printed pieces. I would like to work with StART to develop more street art that challenges the urban landscape with art based on nature and animals. My practice is moving more to the 3D side of things and I would like to work with StART to fabricate more street level sculptural pieces as I see the need for that in Toronto.
I have mentored many emerging artists but I feel I could use help in taking my own practice to the next level possibly through mentor ship or guidance from another artist.
I also coordinate creative projects and have worked previously with StART on the Outside the Box Program, with the Bell Box Murals Project and with the Aurora Cultural Centre facilitating workshops, designing and creating artwork and mentoring emerging artists.

properties.artist_bio: Mska is a self thought artist, working primarily with acrylics, encaustics, collages, spray paint, ceramics, screen & lino printing. She decided to take muralism more serious in 2010. Her background plays a lot in her style. Mska is originally from Peru, but has been in Canada for nearly 20 years and has been taking different artistic workshops at Central Tech and Peach Berserk printing studios, she has mastered a style of her own by mixing different ways of approaching her materials to get her ART to the next level. Mska was has been collaborating with StarToronto, helping with the beautification of neighborhoods in need of an artistic facelift by painting murals over vandalized public and private properties. She has been part of several events like Wallnoize, Wall Expressions, Womxn Paint and events such as Digital Dreams, Harvest Fest, etc.

properties.artist_bio:
Peru is an internationally recognized muralist and graphic artist whose practice is informed by digital and traditional art forms and his 20+ years of painting graffiti. Peru’s professional career started when he moved from Lima to Ottawa at 16; he won every Visual Arts Award in his high school, a Canadian Heritage grant to paint a mural in Vancouver for the International Earth Festival, and a 2 mural commission for the National Capital Commission. At age 20 he moved to Montreal where he continued winning prizes and awards from design contests at his local skateshop to the Millennium Excellence Scholarship.

His passion for art lead him to rise to the top of the local art scene working for brands and companies such as Bell, Cirque du Soleil and he painted a series of murals with the collective En Masse at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. With En Masse, Peru was part of dozens of collaborative murals throughout Canada, US, Mexico and China, and participated in mentorship programs with the Quebec English School Boards Association. He was also a central muralist for MU since its inception in 2007 and continues to work with them, most recently in 2020 where he will be painting the exterior of a high school.

When Peru moved to Toronto a decade later he worked for Urban Outfitters for 5 years as a Lead Display Artist. In this role he built and installed window and store displays participating in store openings across North America including the company’s largest store opening at Herald Square in New York City. Peru used these experiences to expand his skill set and work on art installations at the Osheaga Music Festival as well for American Express for their Live Life Experience Installations around the world; All the while establishing himself as a muralist by assisting, collaborating, and consulting for nearly every arts organization in Toronto, and mentoring individuals, peers and on several occasions’ at-risk youth from the Oasis Skateboard Factory. Peru’s corporate and big brand murals allowed him to balance his work with grass-roots organizations, non-for-profits and BIA’s which make up most of his portfolio. Some of Peru’s corporate clients include Facebook, Nike, Adidas, Corus, Maple Leaf Sports, and Marriott Hotels.
properties.description: Wall Expressions hosted by Team Spudbomb, brings the community together with street, mural and graffiti artists to showcase a diversity of art forms. In Allen Powell Lane, they worked with the Tranzac Club and local community to develop the project theme “You are Here, Annex” to guide artists and showcase the local community’s memory of their neighbourhood before a large-scale development transformed the iconic Bloor-Bathurst intersection.
properties.title: Peru 143

properties.artist_bio: I love the program and the initiatives that START is implementing in this city and can’t wait to see more beautiful projects come to life.  It would be amazing to be involved in curations and helping organize as well as to help bring community projects to life as an artist.  I’m interested mainly in aerosol projects but am more then willing to explore and learn more new techniques.

properties.address: 2265 Danforth Ave, Toronto, ON M4C 5K7, Canada
properties.description: The concept celebrates Front Line Heroes during the global COVID-19 pandemic. A rainbow colour gradient celebrates diversity and layered graffiti art lettering names Frontline and Essential Services across the four societal pillars: Health Care Services, Transport Services, City/Community Service Providers, & The Arts Community. The typography specifically is a combination of graffiti handstyles and calligraphy. An original style of font, developed and honed over 18 years as an aerosol artist - Calligraffiti. Graffiti is specifically used to pay homage to the art form that paved the way for public murals and street art globally. Graffiti is one of the foundational elements of hip hop, a resilient subculture that has positively impacted and changed lives in countless urban communities.
properties.title: Front Line Heroes

properties.address: 546 Richmond St W, Toronto, ON M5V 1Y4, Canada
properties.description: My mural showcases a 'thank you' to all the Frontline workers fighting against COVID-19 in graffiti style letters since the wall faces east in “Graffiti Alley”. I believe we all must do our part and I wanted to showcase how all of us our connected. I have included some of my Anishnawbe teachings about the 6 nations, the 4 directions and multiple layers of the medicine wheel to further showcase connection. This mural has four characters with the medicine wheel of the Anishnawbe people symbolized in each character. These symbols and characters represent all of humanity. It also includes the animal, plants, insects, humans, fish, and birds, and sacred geometry patterns within a variety of colours and shapes. My objective was to create both a tribute mural and a visual healing piece at the same time. This artwork is dedicated to all the Front line workers from an Anishnawbe artist perspective. I am deeply grateful to them, and have used this opportunity to say Thank you, 'Chi Miigwetch', with my own personal touch.
properties.title: Front Line Heroes
